"Is ther oght elles, Dorigen, but this?"	"Is there anything else, Dorigen, but this?"
"Nay, nay," quod she, "God helpe me so as wys!	"Nay, nay," she said, "So help me God!
This is to muche, and it were Goddes wille."	This is too much, even if it were God's will."
"Ye, wyf," quod he, "lat slepen that is stille.	"Yes, wife," he said, "let sleep that which is still.
It may be wel, paraventure, yet to day.	It may be well, perhaps, yet to day.
Ye shul youre trouthe holden, by my fay!	You shall keep your pledged word, by my faith!
For God so wisly have mercy upon me,	For as surely as God may have mercy upon me,
I hadde wel levere ystiked for to be	I had well rather be stabbed
For verray love which that I to yow have,	For sheer love which I to have for you,
But if ye sholde youre trouthe kepe and save.	Than you should (do anything but) keep and save your pledged word.
Trouthe is the hyeste thyng that man may kepe" --	One's pldged word is the highest thing that one may keep" --
But with that word he brast anon to wepe,	But with that word he immediately burst into tears,
And seyde, "I yow forbede, up peyne of deeth,	And said, "I you forbid, upon pain of death,
That nevere, whil thee lasteth lyf ne breeth,	That never, while thy life or breath lasts,
To no wight telle thou of this aventure --	Thou tell any person about this adventure --
As I may best, I wol my wo endure --	As I best can, I will my woe endure --
Ne make no contenance of hevynesse,	Nor make any outward appearance of sadness,
That folk of yow may demen harm or gesse."	That folk may believe or guess anything harmful concerning you."
And forth he cleped a squier and a mayde:	And forth he called a squire and a maid:
"Gooth forth anon with Dorigen," he sayde,	"Go forth right now with Dorigen," he said,
"And bryngeth hire to swich a place anon."	"And bring her to such a place quickly."
They take hir leve, and on hir wey they gon,	They take their leave, and on their way they go,
But they ne wiste why she thider wente.	But they knew not why she thither went.
He nolde no wight tellen his entente.	He would no person tell his intention.
Paraventure an heep of yow, ywis,	Perhaps a heap of you, indeed,
Wol holden hym a lewed man in this	Will consider him a foolish man in this
That he wol putte his wyf in jupartie.	That he will put his wife in jeopardy.
Herkneth the tale er ye upon hire crie.	Listen to the tale before you cry out about her.
She may have bettre fortune than yow semeth;	She may have better fortune than it seems to you;
And whan that ye han herd the tale, demeth.	And when you have heard the tale, judge.
This squier, which that highte Aurelius,	This squire, who was called Aurelius,
On Dorigen that was so amorus,	On Dorigen who was so amorous,
Of aventure happed hire to meete	By chance happened to meet her
Amydde the toun, right in the quykkest strete,	Amidst the town, right in the busiest street,
As she was bown to goon the wey forth right	As she was about to go the way directly
Toward the gardyn ther as she had hight.	Toward the garden where she had promised (to go).
And he was to the gardyn-ward also;	And he was going toward the garden also;
For wel he spyed whan she wolde go	For well he spied when she would go
Out of hir hous to any maner place.	Out of her house to any sort of place.
But thus they mette, of aventure or grace,	But thus they met, by chance or luck,
And he saleweth hire with glad entente,	And he salutes her cheerfully,
And asked of hire whiderward she wente;	And asked her where she went;
And she answerde, half as she were mad,	And she answered, as if she were half mad,
"Unto the gardyn, as myn housbonde bad,	"Unto the garden, as my husband commanded,
My trouthe for to holde -- allas, allas!"	My pledged word to keep -- alas, alas!"
Aurelius gan wondren on this cas,	Aurelius began to wonder about this case,
And in his herte hadde greet compassioun	And in his heart had great compassion
Of hire and of hire lamentacioun,	Of her and of her lamentation,
And of Arveragus, the worthy knyght,	And of Arveragus, the worthy knight,
That bad hire holden al that she had hight,	Who commanded her to keep all that she had promised,
So looth hym was his wyf sholde breke hir trouthe;	So hateful to him it was that his wife should break her word;
And in his herte he caughte of this greet routhe,	And in his heart he took great pity on this,
Considerynge the beste on every syde,	Considering what would be best in every respect,
That fro his lust yet were hym levere abyde	That he would rather yet refrain from his desire
Than doon so heigh a cherlyssh wrecchednesse	Than do so great a churlish despicable act
Agayns franchise and alle gentillesse;	Against generosity and all nobility of character;
For which in fewe wordes seyde he thus:	For which in few words he said thus:
"Madame, seyth to youre lord Arveragus	"Madam, say to your lord Arveragus
That sith I se his grete gentillesse	That since I see his great graciousness
To yow, and eek I se wel youre distresse,	To you, and also I see well your distress,
That him were levere han shame (and that were routhe)	That he would rather have shame (and that would be a pity)
Than ye to me sholde breke thus youre trouthe,	Than you should thus break your pledged word to me,
I have wel levere evere to suffre wo	I would well rather suffer woe always
Than I departe the love bitwix yow two.	Than I should break apart the love between you two.
I yow relesse, madame, into youre hond	I release you, madam, into your hand I return
Quyt every serement and every bond	Freely every pledge and every bond
That ye han maad to me as heerbiforn,	That you have made to me before now,
Sith thilke tyme which that ye were born.	Since that time when you were born.
My trouthe I plighte, I shal yow never repreve	I pledge my word, I shall never reprove you
Of no biheste, and heere I take my leve,	For any promise, and here I take my leave,
As of the treweste and the beste wyf	Of the truest and the best wife
That evere yet I knew in al my lyf.	That ever yet I knew in all my life.
But every wyf be war of hire biheeste!	But let every wife beware of her promise!
On Dorigen remembreth, atte leeste.	Remember Dorigen, at the least.
Thus kan a squier doon a gentil dede	Thus can a squire do a gentle deed
As wel as kan a knyght, withouten drede."	As well as can a knight, without doubt."
She thonketh hym upon hir knees al bare,	She thanks him upon her bare knees,
And hoom unto hir housbonde is she fare,	And home unto her husband she is gone,
And tolde hym al, as ye han herd me sayd;	And told him all, as you have heard me say;
And be ye siker, he was so weel apayd	And be you sure, he was so well pleased
That it were impossible me to wryte.	That it would be impossible for me to write.
What sholde I lenger of this cas endyte?	Why should I write longer about this matter?
Arveragus and Dorigen his wyf	Arveragus and Dorigen his wife
In sovereyn blisse leden forth hir lyf.	In perfect bliss lead forth their life.
Nevere eft ne was ther angre hem bitwene.	Never again was there any anger between them.
He cherisseth hire as though she were a queene,	He cherishes her as though she were a queen,
And she was to hym trewe for everemoore.	And she was to him true for evermore.
Of thise two folk ye gete of me namoore.	Of these two folk you get of me no more.
Aurelius, that his cost hath al forlorn,	Aurelius, that all his expenditure has forfeited,
Curseth the tyme that evere he was born:	Curses the time that ever he was born:
"Allas!" quod he. "Allas, that I bihighte	"Alas!" said he. "Alas, that I promised
Of pured gold a thousand pound of wighte	Of refined gold a thousand pounds of weight
Unto this philosophre! How shal I do?	Unto this scientist! What shall I do?
I se namoore but that I am fordo.	I see no more but that I am ruined.
Myn heritage moot I nedes selle,	My heritage I must of necessity sell,
And been a beggere; heere may I nat dwelle	And be a beggar; here I may not remain
And shamen al my kynrede in this place,	And shame all my kin in this place,
But I of hym may gete bettre grace.	Unless I can get a better grace (favor) from him.
But nathelees, I wole of hym assaye,	But nonetheless, I will try him, (offering)
At certeyn dayes, yeer by yeer, to paye,	At specific days, year by year, to pay,
And thanke hym of his grete curteisye.	And thank him for his great courtesy.
My trouthe wol I kepe, I wol nat lye."	My word I will keep, I will not lie."
With herte soor he gooth unto his cofre,	With a sore heart he goes unto his money box,
And broghte gold unto this philosophre,	And brought gold unto this scientist,
The value of fyve hundred pound, I gesse,	The value of five hundred pounds, I guess,
And hym bisecheth, of his gentillesse,	And him beseeches, of his nobleness,
To graunte hym dayes of the remenaunt;	To grant him days (on which to pay) the remnant;
And seyde, "Maister, I dar wel make avaunt,	And said, "Master, I dare well make boast,
I failled nevere of my trouthe as yit.	I failed never of my pledged word as yet.
For sikerly my dette shal be quyt	For surely my debt shall be repaid
Towardes yow, howevere that I fare	To you, even though I have
To goon a-begged in my kirtle bare.	To go a-begging in my bare tunic.
But wolde ye vouche sauf, upon seuretee,	But if you would agree, upon my promise,
Two yeer or thre for to respiten me,	To grant me a respite for two years or three,
Thanne were I wel; for elles moot I selle	Then I would be well; for otherwise I must sell
Myn heritage; ther is namoore to telle."	My heritage; there is no more to tell."
This philosophre sobrely answerde,	This scientist soberly answered,
And seyde thus, whan he thise wordes herde:	And said thus, when he heard these words:
"Have I nat holden covenant unto thee?"	"Have I not kept my agreement with thee?"
"Yes, certes, wel and trewely," quod he.	"Yes, certainly, well and truly," said he.
"Hastow nat had thy lady as thee liketh?"	"Hast thou not had thy lady as it pleases thee?"
"No, no," quod he, and sorwefully he siketh.	"No, no," said he, and sorrowfully he sighs.
"What was the cause? Tel me if thou kan."	"What was the cause? Tel me if thou know how."
Aurelius his tale anon bigan,	Aurelius his tale immediately began,
And tolde hym al, as ye han herd bifoore;	And told him all, as you have heard before;
It nedeth nat to yow reherce it moore.	There is no need to repeat it to you again.
He seide, "Arveragus, of gentillesse,	He said, "Arveragus, of his nobility,
Hadde levere dye in sorwe and in distresse	Had rather die in sorrow and in distress
Than that his wyf were of hir trouthe fals."	Than that his wife would be false of her pledged word."
The sorwe of Dorigen he tolde hym als;	The sorrow of Dorigen he told him also;
How looth hire was to been a wikked wyf,	How loathfull to her it was to be a wicked wife,
And that she levere had lost that day hir lyf,	And that she would rather have lost her life that day,
And that hir trouthe she swoor thurgh innocence,	And that her word she swore through ignorance,
She nevere erst hadde herde speke of apparence.	She never before had heard tell of illusion.
"That made me han of hire so greet pitee;	"That made me have for her such great pity;
And right as frely as he sente hire me,	And right as freely as he sent her to me,
As frely sente I hire to hym ageyn.	As freely I sent her to him again.
This al and som; ther is namoore to seyn."	This is the entire matter; there is no more to say."
This philosophre answerde, "Leeve brother,	This scientist answered, "Dear brother,
Everich of yow dide gentilly til oother.	Every one of you did nobly to the other.
Thou art a squier, and he is a knyght;	Thou art a squire, and he is a knight;
But God forbede, for his blisful myght,	But God forbid, for his blissful might,
But if a clerk koude doon a gentil dede	That a clerk could not do a gentle deed
As wel as any of yow, it is no drede!	As well as any of you, it is no doubt!
Sire, I releesse thee thy thousand pound,	Sir, I release thee from thy (debt of a) thousand pounds,
As thou right now were cropen out of the ground,	As if thou right now were crept out of the ground,
Ne nevere er now ne haddest knowen me.	Nor never before now had known me.
For, sire, I wol nat taken a peny of thee	For, sir, I will not take a penny from thee
For al my craft, ne noght for my travaille.	For all my craft, nor anything for my labor.
Thou hast ypayed wel for my vitaille.	Thou hast paid well for my living expenses.
It is ynogh, and farewel, have good day!"	It is enough, and farewell, have good day!"
And took his hors, and forth he goth his way.	And took his horse, and forth he goes his way.
Lordynges, this question, thanne, wol I aske now,	Gentlemen, this question, then, will I ask now,
Which was the mooste fre, as thynketh yow?	Which was the most free, as it seems to you?
Now telleth me, er that ye ferther wende.	Now tell me, before you farther go.
I kan namoore; my tale is at an ende.	I know no more; my tale is at an end.
The Prologe of the Cokes Tale	The Prologue of the Cook's Tale
The Cook of Londoun, whil the Reve spak,	The Cook of London, while the Reeve spoke,
For joye him thoughte he clawed him on the bak.	Was so happy he thought the Reeve scratched him on the back.
"Ha! ha!" quod he, "For Cristes passion,	"Ha! ha!" said he, "For Christ's passion,
This millere hadde a sharp conclusion	This miller had a sharp conclusion
Upon his argument of herbergage!	To his logical argument about lodging!
Wel seyde Salomon in his langage,	Well said Salomon in his language,
`Ne bryng nat every man into thyn hous,'	`Do not bring every man into thy house,'
For herberwynge by nyghte is perilous.	For providing lodging by night is perilous.
Wel oghte a man avysed for to be	Well ought a man to take heed
Whom that he broghte into his pryvetee.	Whom he brings into his private home.
I pray to God, so yeve me sorwe and care	I pray to God, give me sorrow and care
If evere, sitthe I highte Hogge of Ware,	If ever, since I was called Roger of Ware,
Herde I a millere bettre yset a-werk.	I heard a miller better set to work (tricked).
He hadde a jape of malice in the derk.	He had a malicious trick played on him in the dark.
But God forbede that we stynte heere;	But God forbid that we stop here;
And therfore, if ye vouche-sauf to heere	And therefore, if you agree to hear
A tale of me, that am a povre man,	A tale by me, who am a poor man,
I wol yow telle, as wel as evere I kan,	I will tell you, as well as ever I can,
A litel jape that fil in oure citee."	A little amusing affair that happened in our city."
Oure Hoost answerde and seide, "I graunte it thee.	Our Host answered and said, "I grant it to thee.
Now telle on, Roger; looke that it be good,	Now tell on, Roger; look that it be good,
For many a pastee hastow laten blood,	For of many a pastry hast thou drawn out the gravy,
And many a Jakke of Dovere hastow soold	And many a Jack of Dover (a kind of pie) hast thou sold
That hath been twies hoot and twies coold.	That has been twice hot and twice cold.
Of many a pilgrym hastow Cristes curs,	Of many a pilgrim hast thou Christ's curse,
For of thy percely yet they fare the wors,	For of thy parsley yet they fare the worse,
That they han eten with thy stubbel goos,	Which they have eaten with thy stubble-fed goose,
For in thy shoppe is many a flye loos.	For in thy shop is many a fly loose.
Now telle on, gentil Roger by thy name.	Now tell on, gentle Roger by thy name.
But yet I pray thee, be nat wroth for game;	But yet I pray thee, be not angry about a joke;
A man may seye ful sooth in game and pley."	A man may speak very truthfully in joking and play."
"Thou seist ful sooth," quod Roger, "by my fey!	"Thou sayest the truth," said Roger, "by my faith!
But `sooth pley, quaad pley,' as the Flemyng seith.	But `a true jest is a bad jest,' as the Fleming says.
And therfore, Herry Bailly, by thy feith,	And therefore, Harry Bailly, by thy faith,
Be thou nat wrooth, er we departen heer,	Be thou not angry, ere we depart here,
Though that my tale be of an hostileer.	Even though my tale is of an inn-keeper.
But nathelees I wol nat telle it yit;	But nonetheless I will not tell it yet;
But er we parte, ywis, thou shalt be quit."	But before we part, indeed, thou shalt be repaid."
And therwithal he lough and made cheere,	And with that he laughed and made good cheer,
And seyde his tale, as ye shul after heere.	And told his tale, as you shall next hear.
Heere bigynneth the Cookes Tale.	Here begins the Cook's Tale.
A prentys whilom dwelled in oure citee,	A apprentice once dwelt in our city,
And of a craft of vitailliers was hee.	And of a craft of food merchants was he.
Gaillard he was as goldfynch in the shawe,	Gaily dressed he was as is a goldfinch in the woods,
Broun as a berye, a propre short felawe,	Brown as a berry, a good-looking short fellow,
With lokkes blake, ykembd ful fetisly.	With locks black, combed full elegantly.
Dauncen he koude so wel and jolily	He could dance so well and jollily
That he was cleped Perkyn Revelour.	That he was called Perkin Reveler.
He was as ful of love and paramour	He was as full of love and womanizing
As is the hyve ful of hony sweete;	As is the hive full of honey sweet;
Wel was the wenche with hym myghte meete.	Happy was the wench who with him might meet.
At every bridale wolde he synge and hoppe;	At every wedding party he would sing and dance;
He loved bet the taverne than the shoppe.	He loved the tavern better than the shop.
For whan ther any ridyng was in Chepe,	For when there was any procession in Cheapside,
Out of the shoppe thider wolde he lepe --	Out of the shop thither would he leap --
Til that he hadde al the sighte yseyn,	Until that he had all the sight seen,
And daunced wel, he wolde nat come ayeyn --	And danced well, he would not come back--
And gadered hym a meynee of his sort	And gathered him a company of his sort
To hoppe and synge and maken swich disport;	To dance and sing and make such merriment;
And ther they setten stevene for to meete,	And there they agreed on a time to meet,
To pleyen at the dys in swich a streete.	To play at dice in such and such a street.
For in the toune nas ther no prentys	For in the town there was no apprentice
That fairer koude caste a paire of dys	That could better throw a pair of dice
Than Perkyn koude, and therto he was free	Than Perkin could, and thereto he was free
Of his dispense, in place of pryvetee.	In his spending, in a private place.
That fond his maister wel in his chaffare,	That found his master easily in his business accounts,
For often tyme he foond his box ful bare.	For many times he found his cash box completely bare.
For sikerly a prentys revelour	For surely (in the case of) an revelling apprentice
That haunteth dys, riot, or paramour,	Who makes a practice of dicing, debauchery, or womanizing,
His maister shal it in his shoppe abye,	His master shall pay for it in his shop,
Al have he no part of the mynstralcye.	Even though he has no share of the entertainment (for which he pays).
For thefte and riot, they been convertible,	For theft and debauchery, they are interchangeable.
Al konne he pleye on gyterne or ribible.	Even though he knows how to play on guitar or fiddle.
Revel and trouthe, as in a lowe degree,	Revelling and honesty, in one of low degree,
They been ful wrothe al day, as men may see.	Are always incompatible, as anyone can see.
This joly prentys with his maister bood,	This jolly apprentice with his master remained,
Til he were ny out of his prentishood,	Until he was nearly out of his apprenticeship,
Al were he snybbed bothe erly and late,	Although he was rebuked both early and late,
And somtyme lad with revel to Newegate.	And sometimes taken (as a prisoner) with music to Newgate prison.
But atte laste his maister hym bithoghte,	But at the last his master remembered,
Upon a day, whan he his papir soghte,	Upon a day, when Perkin sought his certificate of release,
Of a proverbe that seith this same word:	A proverb that says this same word:
"Wel bet is roten appul out of hoord	"Well better is a rotten apple out of the store
Than that it rotie al the remenaunt."	Than that it rot al the remnant."
So fareth it by a riotous servaunt;	So fares it with a debauched servant;
It is ful lasse harm to lete hym pace,	It is much less harm to let him go away,
Than he shende alle the servantz in the place.	Than that he should ruin all the servants in the place.
Therfore his maister yaf hym acquitance,	Therefore his master gave him his certificate,
And bad hym go, with sorwe and with meschance!	And ordered him to go, with sorrow and with bad luck!
And thus this joly prentys hadde his leve.	And thus this jolly apprentice had his leave.
Now lat hym riote al the nyght or leve.	Now let him revel all the night or leave off (do as he chooses).
And for ther is no theef withoute a lowke,	And because there is no thief without an accomplice,
That helpeth hym to wasten and to sowke	Who helps him to waste and to consume
Of that he brybe kan or borwe may,	That which he can steal or may borrow,
Anon he sente his bed and his array	Right away he sent his bed and his clothing
Unto a compeer of his owene sort,	Unto a companion of his own sort,
That lovede dys, and revel, and disport,	Who loved dicing, and revelling, and having fun,
And hadde a wyf that heeld for contenance	And had a wife that kept for the sake of appearances
A shoppe, and swyved for hir sustenance.	A shop, and screwed for her living.
Here folweth the Prologe of the Maunciples Tale.	Here follows the prologue of the Maniciple's Tale.
Woot ye nat where ther stant a litel toun	Know you not where there stands a little town
Which that ycleped is Bobbe-up-and-doun,	Which is called Bobbe-up-and-down,
Under the Blee, in Caunterbury Weye?	Under the Blee, in Canterbury Way?
Ther gan oure Hooste for to jape and pleye,	There began our Host to joke and play,
And seyde, "Sires, what! Dun is in the myre!	And said, "Sirs, what! Dun is in the mire!
Is ther no man, for preyere ne for hyre,	Is there no man, for prayer nor for hire,
That wole awake oure felawe al bihynde?	That will awake our fellow far behind us?
A theef myghte hym ful lightly robbe and bynde.	A thief might full easily rob and bind him.
See how he nappeth! See how, for cokkes bones,	See how he naps! See how, for cock's bones,
That he wol falle fro his hors atones!	That he will soon fall from his horse!
Is that a cook of Londoun, with meschaunce?	Is that a cook of London, with bad luck (to him)?
Do hym come forth, he knoweth his penaunce;	Make him come forth, he knows his penance;
For he shal telle a tale, by my fey,	For he shall tell a tale, by my faith,
Although it be nat worth a botel hey.	Although it be not worth a bundle of hay.
Awake, thou Cook," quod he, "God yeve thee sorwe!	Awake, thou Cook," said he, "God give thee sorrow!
What eyleth thee to slepe by the morwe?	What ails thee to sleep in the morning?
Hastow had fleen al nyght, or artow dronke?	Hast thou had fleas all night, or art thou drunk?
Or hastow with som quene al nyght yswonke,	Or hast thou with some prostitute all night labored,
So that thow mayst nat holden up thyn heed?"	So that thou can not hold up thy head?"
This Cook, that was ful pale and no thyng reed,	This Cook, who was full pale and not at all red,
Seyde to oure Hoost, "So God my soule blesse,	Said to our Host, "God bless my soul,
As ther is falle on me swich hevynesse,	There is fallen on me such heaviness,
Noot I nat why, that me were levere slepe	Know I not why, that I would rather sleep
Than the beste galon wyn in Chepe."	Than (have) the best gallon of wine in Cheapside."
"Wel," quod the Maunciple, "if it may doon ese	"Well," said the Manciple, "if it may give relief
To thee, sire Cook, and to no wight displese,	To thee, sir Cook, and be displeasing to no person,
Which that heere rideth in this compaignye,	Who rides here in this company,
And that oure Hoost wole, of his curteisye,	And (providing) that our Host would (agree), of his courtesy,
I wol as now excuse thee of thy tale.	I will for now excuse thee of thy tale.
For, in good feith, thy visage is ful pale,	For, in good faith, thy visage is full pale,
Thyne eyen daswen eek, as that me thynketh,	Thy eyes are dazed also, as it seems to me,
And, wel I woot, thy breeth ful soure stynketh:	And, well I know, thy breath full sourly stinks:
That sheweth wel thou art nat wel disposed.	That shows well thou art not in good health.
Of me, certeyn, thou shalt nat been yglosed.	By me, certainly, thou shalt not be deceived.
See how he ganeth, lo, this dronken wight,	See how he yawns, lo, this drunken fellow,
As though he wolde swolwe us anonright.	As though he would swallow us right away.
Hoold cloos thy mouth, man, by thy fader kyn!	Keep thy mouth closed, man, by thy father's kin!
The devel of helle sette his foot therin!	The devil of hell set his foot therein!
Thy cursed breeth infecte wole us alle.	Thy cursed breath would infect us all.
Fy, stynkyng swyn! Fy, foule moote thee falle!	Fie, stinking swine! Fie, may foul fortune thee befall!
A, taketh heede, sires, of this lusty man.	Ah, take heed, sirs, of this lusty man.
Now, sweete sire, wol ye justen atte fan?	Now, sweet sir, will you joust at the quintain?
Therto me thynketh ye been wel yshape!	It seems to me you are in good shape for that!
I trowe that ye dronken han wyn ape,	I believe that you have drunk until you act like an ape,
And that is whan men pleyen with a straw."	And that is when men play with a straw."
And with this speche the Cook wax wrooth and wraw,	And with this speech the Cook became angry and enraged,
And on the Manciple he gan nodde faste	And on the Manciple he began to shake his head fast
For lakke of speche, and doun the hors hym caste,	For lack of speech, and down the horse him threw,
Where as he lay, til that men hym up took.	Where he lay, until men lifted him up.
This was a fair chyvachee of a cook!	This was a fine feat of horsemanship by a cook!
Allas, he nadde holde hym by his ladel!	Alas, he had not kept himself by his ladle (i.e., stayed home)!
And er that he agayn were in his sadel,	And before he was again in his saddle,
Ther was greet showvyng bothe to and fro	There was great shoving both to and fro
To lifte hym up, and muchel care and wo,	To lift him up, and much care and woe,
So unweeldy was this sory palled goost.	So unwieldy was this sorry enfeebled soul.
And to the Manciple thanne spak oure Hoost:	And to the Manciple then spoke our Host:
"By cause drynke hath dominacioun	"Because drink has domination
Upon this man, by my savacioun,	Upon this man, by my salvation,
I trowe he lewedly wolde telle his tale.	I believe he would tell his tale badly.
For, were it wyn or oold or moysty ale	For, were it wine or old or new ale
That he hath dronke, he speketh in his nose,	That he has drunk, he speaks in his nose,
And fneseth faste, and eek he hath the pose.	And sneezes fast, and also he has a head cold.
"He hath also to do moore than ynough	"He has also more than enough to do
To kepen hym and his capul out of the slough;	To keep him and his horse out of the mud;
And if he falle from his capul eftsoone,	And if he fall from his horse again,
Thanne shal we alle have ynogh to doone	Then shall we all have enough to do
In liftyng up his hevy dronken cors.	In lifting up his heavy drunken body.
Telle on thy tale; of hym make I no fors.	Tell on thy tale; of him I take no account.
"But yet, Manciple, in feith thou art to nyce,	"But yet, Manciple, in faith thou art too foolish,
Thus openly repreve hym of his vice.	Thus openly to reprove him of his vice.
Another day he wole, peraventure,	Another day he would, perhaps,
Reclayme thee and brynge thee to lure;	Recall thee and bring thee to the lure (like a hawk);
I meene, he speke wole of smale thynges,	I mean, he would speak of small things,
As for to pynchen at thy rekenynges,	As for to find fault with thy accounts,
That were nat honest, if it cam to preef."	That may not be honest, if it comes to proof."
"No," quod the Manciple, "that were a greet mescheef!	"No," said the Manciple, "that would be a great mischief!
So myghte he lightly brynge me in the snare.	In that way he could easily bring me into the trap.
Yet hadde I levere payen for the mare	Yet I would rather pay for the mare
Which he rit on, than he sholde with me stryve.	That he rides on, than he should strive with me.
I wol nat wratthen hym, also moot I thryve!	I will not anger him, as I may thrive!
That that I spak, I seyde it in my bourde.	That which I spoke, I said it in my joking.
And wite ye what? I have heer in a gourde	And do you know what? I have here in a gourd
A draghte of wyn, ye, of a ripe grape,	A draught of wine, yes, of a ripe grape,
And right anon ye shul seen a good jape.	And right away you shall see a good joke.
This Cook shal drynke therof, if I may.	This Cook shall drink thereof, if I may.
Up peyne of deeth, he wol nat seye me nay."	Upon pain of death, he will not say me nay."
And certeynly, to tellen as it was,	And certainly, to tell it as it was,
Of this vessel the Cook drank faste, allas!	Of this vessel the Cook drank fast, alas!
What neded hym? He drank ynough biforn.	Why did he need that? He drank enough before.
And whan he hadde pouped in this horn,	And when he had blown in this horn,
To the Manciple he took the gourde agayn;	To the Manciple he gave the gourd again;
And of that drynke the Cook was wonder fayn,	And of that drink the Cook was wonderfully pleased,
And thanked hym in swich wise as he koude.	And thanked him in such a way as he could.
Thanne gan oure Hoost to laughen wonder loude,	Then began our Host to laugh wonderfully loud,
And seyde, "I se wel it is necessarie,	And said, "I see well it is necessary,
Where that we goon, good drynke with us carie;	Wherever we go, to carry good drink with us;
For that wol turne rancour and disese	For that will turn rancor and strife
T' acord and love, and many a wrong apese.	To accord and love, and appease many a wrong.
"O Bacus, yblessed be thy name,	"O Bacchus, blessed be thy name,
That so kanst turnen ernest into game!	Who so can turn earnest into game!
Worshipe and thank be to thy deitee!	Worship and thanks be to thy deity!
Of that mateere ye gete namoore of me.	Of that matter you get no more of me.
Telle on thy tale, Manciple, I thee preye."	Tell on thy tale, Manciple, I thee pray."
"Wel, sire," quod he, "now herkneth what I seye."	"Well, sir," said he, "now hearken what I say."
Heere bigynneth the Maunciples Tale of the Crowe.	Here begins the Manciple's Tale of the Crow.
Whan Phebus dwelled heere in this erthe adoun,	When Phoebus dwelled down here in this earth,
As olde bookes maken mencioun,	As old books make mention,
He was the mooste lusty bachiler	He was the most lusty bachelor
In al this world, and eek the beste archer.	In all this world, and also the best archer.
He slow Phitoun, the serpent, as he lay	He slew Phitoun, the serpent, as he lay
Slepynge agayn the sonne upon a day;	Sleeping in the sun upon a day;
And many another noble worthy dede	And many another noble worthy deed
He with his bowe wroghte, as men may rede.	He wrought with his bow, as men may read.
Pleyen he koude on every mynstralcie,	He could play on every minstrelsy,
And syngen that it was a melodie	And sing so that it was a pleasure
To heeren of his cleere voys the soun.	To hear of his clear voice the sound.
Certes the kyng of Thebes, Amphioun,	Certainly the king of Thebes, Amphioun,
That with his syngyng walled that citee,	Who with his singing walled that city,
Koude nevere syngen half so wel as hee.	Could never sing half so well as he.
Therto he was the semelieste man	Thereto he was the best looking man
That is or was sith that the world bigan.	That is or was since the world began.
What nedeth it his fetures to discryve?	What needs it his features to describe?
For in this world was noon so faire on-lyve.	For in this world was no one so handsome alive.
He was therwith fulfild of gentillesse,	He was therewith filled full of nobility,
Of honour, and of parfit worthynesse.	Of honor, and of perfect worthiness.
This Phebus, that was flour of bachilrie,	This Phoebus, which was the flower of knighthood,
As wel in fredom as in chivalrie,	As well in generosity as in chivalry,
For his desport, in signe eek of victorie	For his amusement, in sign also of victory
Of Phitoun, so as telleth us the storie,	Over Phitoun, as tells us the story,
Was wont to beren in his hand a bowe.	Was accustomed to bear in his hand a bow.
Now hadde this Phebus in his hous a crowe	Now had this Phoebus in his house a crow
Which in a cage he fostred many a day,	Which in a cage he fostered many a day,
And taughte it speken, as men teche a jay.	And taught it to speak, as men teach a jay.
Whit was this crowe as is a snow-whit swan,	White was this crow as is a snow-white swan,
And countrefete the speche of every man	And imitate the speech of every man
He koude, whan he sholde telle a tale.	He could, when he should tell a tale.
Therwith in al this world no nyghtyngale	Therewith in all this world no nightingale
Ne koude, by an hondred thousand deel,	Could not, by a hundred thousand times,
Syngen so wonder myrily and weel.	Sing so wonderfully merrily and well.
Now hadde this Phebus in his hous a wyf	Now had this Phoebus in his house a woman
Which that he lovede moore than his lyf,	Whom he loved more than his life,
And nyght and day dide evere his diligence	And night and day did ever his efforts
Hir for to plese and doon hire reverence,	To please her and do her reverence,
Save oonly, if the sothe that I shal sayn,	Save only, if I shall say the truth,
Jalous he was, and wolde have kept hire fayn.	Jealous he was, and would eagerly have kept her.
For hym were looth byjaped for to be,	For he was loath to be tricked,
And so is every wight in swich degree;	And so is every person in such a situation;
But al in ydel, for it availleth noght.	But all in vain, for it does not help.
A good wyf, that is clene of werk and thoght,	A good wife, who is clean of deed and thought,
Sholde nat been kept in noon awayt, certayn;	Should not be constantly watched, certainly;
And trewely the labour is in vayn	And truly the labor is in vain
To kepe a shrewe, for it wol nat bee.	To keep a shrew, for it will not be.
This holde I for a verray nycetee,	This hold I for a real act of folly,
To spille labour for to kepe wyves:	To waste labor guarding wives:
Thus writen olde clerkes in hir lyves.	Thus wrote old clerks in their time.
But now to purpos, as I first bigan:	But now to purpose, as I first began:
This worthy Phebus dooth al that he kan	This worthy Phoebus does all that he can
To plesen hire, wenynge for swich plesaunce,	To please her, supposing for such pleasing actions,
And for his manhede and his governaunce,	And for his manly qualities and his behavior,
That no man sholde han put hym from hir grace.	That no man should have put him out of her grace.
But God it woot, ther may no man embrace	But God knows it, there can no man embrace
As to destreyne a thyng which that nature	And restrain a thing which nature
Hath natureelly set in a creature.	Has naturally set in a creature.
Taak any bryd, and put it in a cage,	Take any bird, and put it in a cage,
And do al thyn entente and thy corage	And give all thy attention and take thy pains
To fostre it tendrely with mete and drynke	To foster it tenderly with food and drink
Of alle deyntees that thou kanst bithynke,	Of all dainties that thou can imagine,
And keep it al so clenly as thou may,	And keep it as cleanly as thou can,
Although his cage of gold be never so gay,	Although his cage of gold be never so gay,
Yet hath this brid, by twenty thousand foold,	Yet would this bird, by twenty thousand times,
Levere in a forest that is rude and coold	Rather in a forest that is rude and cold
Goon ete wormes and swich wrecchednesse.	Go eat worms and such wretched food.
For evere this brid wol doon his bisynesse	For ever this bird will work diligently
To escape out of his cage, yif he may.	To escape out of his cage, if he can.
His libertee this brid desireth ay.	His liberty this bird desires always.
Lat take a cat, and fostre hym wel with milk	Let's take a cat, and foster him well with milk
And tendre flessh, and make his couche of silk,	And tender meat, and make his couch of silk,
And lat hym seen a mous go by the wal,	And let him see a mouse go by the wall,
Anon he weyveth milk and flessh and al,	Right then he refuses milk and meat and all,
And every deyntee that is in that hous,	And every dainty that is in that house,
Swich appetit hath he to ete a mous.	Such appetite has he to eat a mouse.
Lo, heere hath lust his dominacioun,	Lo, here has lust his domination,
And appetit fleemeth discrecioun.	And appetite drives away discretion.
A she-wolf hath also a vileyns kynde.	A she-wolf has also an evil nature.
The lewedeste wolf that she may fynde,	The most crude wolf that she can find,
Or leest of reputacioun, wol she take,	Or least of reputation, will she take,
In tyme whan hir lust to han a make.	In time when she lusts to have a mate.
Alle thise ensamples speke I by thise men	All these examples I about speak these men
That been untrewe, and nothyng by wommen.	That are untrue, and nothing about women.
For men han evere a likerous appetit	For men have ever a lecherous appetite
On lower thyng to parfourne hire delit	On lower things to perform their delight
Than on hire wyves, be they never so faire,	Than on their wives, be they never so fair,
Ne never so trewe, ne so debonaire.	Nor never so true, nor so gracious.
Flessh is so newefangel, with meschaunce,	Flesh is so fond of novelty, curses on it,
That we ne konne in nothyng han plesaunce	That we can not take pleasure in anything
That sowneth into vertu any while.	That is consonant with virtue for any length of time.
This Phebus, which that thoghte upon no gile,	This Phoebus, who thought upon no guile,
Deceyved was, for al his jolitee.	Deceived was, despite all his attractive qualities.
For under hym another hadde shee,	For under him another had she,
A man of litel reputacioun,	A man of little reputation,
Nat worth to Phebus in comparisoun.	Worth nothing in comparison to Phoebus.
The moore harm is, it happeth ofte so,	The more harm is, it happens often so,
Of which ther cometh muchel harm and wo.	Of which there comes much harm and woe.
And so bifel, whan Phebus was absent,	And so befell, when Phoebus was absent,
His wyf anon hath for hir lemman sent.	His wife immediately has for her sweetheart sent.
Hir lemman? Certes, this is a knavyssh speche!	Her sweetheart? Certes, this is a knavish speech!
Foryeveth it me, and that I yow biseche.	Forgive it me, and that I you beseech.
The wise Plato seith, as ye may rede,	The wise Plato says, as you may read,
The word moot nede accorde with the dede.	The word must by necessity accord with the deed.
If men shal telle proprely a thyng,	If men shall tell a thing properly,
The word moot cosyn be to the werkyng.	The word must be cousin to the deed.
I am a boystous man, right thus seye I:	I am an unlearned man, right thus say I:
Ther nys no difference, trewely,	There is no difference, truly,
Bitwixe a wyf that is of heigh degree,	Between a wife that is of high degree,
If of hir body dishonest she bee,	If of her body dishonest she bee,
And a povre wenche, oother than this --	And a poor wench, other than this --
If it so be they werke bothe amys --	If it so be they work both amiss --
But that the gentile, in estaat above,	Except that the gentle, higher in rank,
She shal be cleped his lady, as in love;	She shall be called his lady, as in love;
And for that oother is a povre womman,	And because that other is a poor woman,
She shal be cleped his wenche or his lemman.	She shall be called his wench or his sweetie.
And, God it woot, myn owene deere brother,	And, God it knows, my own dear brother,
Men leyn that oon as lowe as lith that oother.	Men lay that one as low as lies that other.
Right so bitwixe a titlelees tiraunt	Right so between an usurping tyrant
And an outlawe or a theef erraunt,	And an outlaw or an arrant thief,
The same I seye: ther is no difference.	The same I say: there is no difference.
To Alisaundre was toold this sentence,	To Alexander was told this sentence,
That, for the tirant is of gretter myght	That, because the tyrant is of greater might
By force of meynee for to sleen dounright,	By the size of his army to slay downright,
And brennen hous and hoom, and make al playn,	And burn house and home, and level everything,
Lo, therfore is he cleped a capitayn;	Lo, therefore is he called a captain;
And for the outlawe hath but smal meynee,	And because the outlaw has but a small group of followers,
And may nat doon so greet an harm as he,	And can not do as much harm as he,
Ne brynge a contree to so greet mescheef,	Nor bring a country to such great mischief,
Men clepen hym an outlawe or a theef.	Men call him an outlaw or a thief.
But for I am a man noght textueel,	But because I am not a learned man,
I wol noght telle of textes never a deel;	I will tell nothing of texts, never a bit;
I wol go to my tale, as I bigan.	I will go to my tale, as I began.
Whan Phebus wyf had sent for hir lemman,	When Phoebus wife had sent for her leman,
Anon they wroghten al hire lust volage.	Right away they satisfied all their reckless lust.
The white crowe, that heeng ay in the cage,	The white crow, that hanged always in the cage,
Biheeld hire werk, and seyde never a word.	Beheld their work, and said never a word.
And whan that hoom was come Phebus, the lord,	And when home was come Phoebus, the lord,
This crowe sang "Cokkow! Cokkow! Cokkow!"	This crow sang "Cuckoo! Cuckoo! Cuckoo!"
"What, bryd?" quod Phebus. "What song syngestow?	"What, bird?" said Phoebus. "What song singest thou?
Ne were thow wont so myrily to synge	Were thou not accustomed so merrily to sing
That to myn herte it was a rejoysynge	That to my heart it was a rejoicing
To heere thy voys? Allas, what song is this?"	To hear thy voice? Alas, what song is this?"
"By God," quod he, "I synge nat amys.	"By God," said he, "I sing not amiss.
Phebus," quod he, "for al thy worthynesse,	Phoebus," said he, "for all thy worthiness,
For al thy beautee and thy gentilesse,	For all thy beauty and thy nobility,
For al thy song and al thy mynstralcye,	For all thy song and all thy music,
For al thy waityng, blered is thyn ye	For all thy watching, thou hast been tricked
With oon of litel reputacioun,	By one of little reputation,
Noght worth to thee, as in comparisoun,	Not worth, compared to thee,
The montance of a gnat, so moote I thryve!	The value of a gnat, as I may thrive!
For on thy bed thy wyf I saugh hym swyve."	For on thy bed I saw him copulate with thy wife."
What wol ye moore? The crowe anon hym tolde,	What more do you want? The crow immediately him told,
By sadde tokenes and by wordes bolde,	By clear evidence and by bold words,
How that his wyf had doon hire lecherye,	How his wife had done her lechery,
Hym to greet shame and to greet vileynye,	To his great shame and to his great dishonor,
And tolde hym ofte he saugh it with his yen.	And told him repeatedly he saw it with his eyes.
This Phebus gan aweyward for to wryen,	This Phoebus began to turn away,
And thoughte his sorweful herte brast atwo.	And thought his sorrowful heart would break in two.
His bowe he bente, and sette therinne a flo,	His bow he bent, and set therein an arrow,
And in his ire his wyf thanne hath he slayn.	And in his ire his wife then has he slain.
This is th' effect; ther is namoore to sayn;	This is the substance of it; there is no more to say;
For sorwe of which he brak his mynstralcie,	For sorrow of which he broke his musical instruments,
Bothe harpe, and lute, and gyterne, and sautrie;	Both harp, and lute, and cither, and psaltery;
And eek he brak his arwes and his bowe,	And also he broke his arrows and his bow,
And after that thus spak he to the crowe:	And after that thus spoke he to the crow:
"Traitour," quod he, "with tonge of scorpioun,	"Traitor," said he, "with tongue of scorpion,
Thou hast me broght to my confusioun;	Thou hast me brought to my ruin;
Allas, that I was wroght! Why nere I deed?	Alas, that I was wrought! Why was I not dead?
O deere wyf! O gemme of lustiheed!	O dear wife! O gem of delight!
That were to me so sad and eek so trewe,	Who were to me so stable and also so true,
Now listow deed, with face pale of hewe,	Now liest thou dead, with face pale of hue,
Ful giltelees, that dorste I swere, ywys!	Full guiltless, that dare I swear, indeed!
O rakel hand, to doon so foule amys!	O rash hand, to do so foul a crime!
O trouble wit, O ire recchelees,	O troubled wit, O reckless anger,
That unavysed smyteth gilteles!	That recklessly smites the guiltless!
O wantrust, ful of fals suspecion,	O mistrust, full of false suspicion,
Where was thy wit and thy discrecion?	Where was thy wit and thy discretion?
O every man, be war of rakelnesse!	O every man, beware of rashness!
Ne trowe no thyng withouten strong witnesse.	Do not believe any thing without strong evidence.
Smyt nat to soone, er that ye witen why,	Smite not too soon, before you know why,
And beeth avysed wel and sobrely	And be advised well and soberly
Er ye doon any execucion	Before you act in any way
Upon youre ire for suspecion.	Upon your anger caused by suspicion.
Allas, a thousand folk hath rakel ire	Alas, a thousand folk has rash anger
Fully fordoon, and broght hem in the mire.	Completely undone, and brought them in the mire.
Allas! For sorwe I wol myselven slee!"	Alas! For sorrow I will myself slay!"
And to the crowe, "O false theef!" seyde he,	And to the crow, "O false thief!" said he,
"I wol thee quite anon thy false tale.	"I will pay thee back immediately (for) thy false tale.
Thou songe whilom lyk a nyghtyngale;	Thou once sang like a nightingale;
Now shaltow, false theef, thy song forgon,	Now shalt thou, false thief, give up thy song,
And eek thy white fetheres everichon,	And also thy white feathers every one,
Ne nevere in al thy lif ne shaltou speke.	Nor never in all thy life shalt thou speak.
Thus shal men on a traytour been awreke;	Thus shall men on a traitor be avenged;
Thou and thyn ofspryng evere shul be blake,	Thou and thy offspring ever shall be black,
Ne nevere sweete noyse shul ye make,	Nor never sweet noise shall you make,
But evere crie agayn tempest and rayn,	But ever cry in anticipation of tempest and rain,
In tokenynge that thurgh thee my wyf is slayn."	As a sign that through thee my wife is slain."
And to the crowe he stirte, and that anon,	And to the crow he rushed, and that right away,
And pulled his white fetheres everychon,	And pulled out his white feathers every one,
And made hym blak, and refte hym al his song,	And made him black, and took away all his song,
And eek his speche, and out at dore hym slong	And also his speech, and out the door slung him
Unto the devel, which I hym bitake;	Unto the devil, to whom I commit him;
And for this caas been alle crowes blake.	And because of this case all crows are black.
Lordynges, by this ensample I yow preye,	Gentlemen, by this example I you pray,
Beth war, and taketh kep what that ye seye:	Beware, and take care what you say:
Ne telleth nevere no man in youre lyf	And tell never any man in your life
How that another man hath dight his wyf;	How another man has copulated with his wife;
He wol yow haten mortally, certeyn.	He will hate you mortally, certainly.
Daun Salomon, as wise clerkes seyn,	Dan Salomon, as wise clerks say,
Techeth a man to kepen his tonge weel.	Teaches a man to guard his tongue well.
But, as I seyde, I am noght textueel.	But, as I said, I am not learned.
But nathelees, thus taughte me my dame:	But nonetheless, thus taught me my mother:
"My sone, thenk on the crowe, a Goddes name!	"My son, think on the crow, in God's name!
My sone, keep wel thy tonge, and keep thy freend.	My son, hold well thy tongue, and keep thy friend.
A wikked tonge is worse than a feend;	A wicked tongue is worse than a fiend;
My sone, from a feend men may hem blesse.	My son, from a fiend men can bless themselves.
My sone, God of his endelees goodnesse	My son, God of his endless goodness
Walled a tonge with teeth and lippes eke,	Walled a tongue with teeth and lips also,
For man sholde hym avyse what he speeke.	So that man should think about what he may speak.
My sone, ful ofte, for to muche speche	My son, very often, for too much speech
Hath many a man been spilt, as clerkes teche,	Has many a man been ruined, as clerks teach,
But for litel speche avysely	But for little speech well considered
Is no man shent, to speke generally.	Is no man harmed, to speak generally.
My sone, thy tonge sholdestow restreyne	My son, thy tongue thou should restrain
At alle tymes, but whan thou doost thy peyne	At all times, but when thou make an effort
To speke of God, in honour and preyere.	To speak of God, in honor and prayer.
The firste vertu, sone, if thou wolt leere,	The first virtue, son, if thou will learn,
Is to restreyne and kepe wel thy tonge;	Is to restrain and guard well thy tongue;
Thus lerne children whan that they been yonge.	Thus learn children when they are young.
My sone, of muchel spekyng yvele avysed,	My son, of much ill-considered speaking,
Ther lasse spekyng hadde ynough suffised,	Where less speaking had well enough sufficed,
Comth muchel harm; thus was me toold and taught.	Comes much harm; thus was me told and taught.
In muchel speche synne wanteth naught.	In much speech sin is not lacking.
Wostow wherof a rakel tonge serveth?	Knowest thou what a rash tongue serves for?
Right as a swerd forkutteth and forkerveth	Right as a sword cuts and carves
An arm a-two, my deere sone, right so	An arm in two, my dear son, just so
A tonge kutteth freendshipe al a-two.	A tongue cuts friendship all in two.
A jangler is to God abhomynable.	A tale-teller is to God abominable.
Reed Salomon, so wys and honurable;	Read Salomon, so wise and honorable;
Reed David in his psalmes; reed Senekke.	Read David in his psalms; read Seneca.
My sone, spek nat, but with thyn heed thou bekke.	My son, speak not, but with thy head thou nod.
Dissimule as thou were deef, if that thou heere	Act as if thou were deaf, if thou hear
A janglere speke of perilous mateere.	A tale-teller speak of perilous matter.
The Flemyng seith, and lerne it if thee leste,	The Fleming says, and learn it if thou please,
That litel janglyng causeth muchel reste.	That little tale-telling causes much rest.
My sone, if thou no wikked word hast seyd,	My son, if thou no wicked word hast said,
Thee thar nat drede for to be biwreyd;	Thou need not dread to be betrayed;
But he that hath mysseyd, I dar wel sayn,	But he who has spoken evil, I dare well say,
He may by no wey clepe his word agayn.	He can by no way call his word back.
Thyng that is seyd is seyd, and forth it gooth,	Thing that is said is said, and forth it goes,
Though hym repente, or be hym nevere so looth.	Though he repent, or be ever so unwilling (it be known).
He is his thral to whom that he hath sayd	He is his slave to whom he has said
A tale of which he is now yvele apayd.	A tale of which he is now very sorry.
My sone, be war, and be noon auctour newe	My son, beware, and be no author new
Of tidynges, wheither they been false or trewe.	Of tidings, whether they be false or true.
Whereso thou come, amonges hye or lowe,	Wherever thou come, amongst high or low,
Kepe wel thy tonge and thenk upon the crowe."	Hold well thy tongue and think upon the crow."
The wordes of the Hoost to the compaignye.	The words of the host to the company.
Oure Hooste saugh wel that the brighte sonne	Our Host saw well that the bright sun
The ark of his artificial day hath ronne	The arc of his twelve-hour day has run
The ferthe part, and half an houre and moore,	One fourth, and half an hour and more,
And though he were not depe ystert in loore,	And though he was not far advanced in learning,
He wiste it was the eightetethe day	He knew it was the eighteenth day
Of Aprill, that is messager to May;	Of April, that is messenger to May;
And saugh wel that the shadwe of every tree	And saw well that the shadow of every tree
Was in lengthe the same quantitee	Was in length the same quantity
That was the body erect that caused it.	As was the erect body that caused it.
And therefore by the shadwe he took his wit	And therefore by the shadow he judged
That Phebus, which that shoon so clere and brighte,	That Phoebus, which shone so clear and bright,
Degrees was fyve and fourty clombe on highte,	Five and forty degrees had climbed on height,
And for that day, as in that latitude,	And for that day, in that latitude,
It was ten of the clokke, he gan conclude,	It was ten o'clock, he did conclude,
And sodeynly he plighte his horse aboute.	And suddenly he pulled his horse about.
"Lordynges," quod he, "I warne yow, al this route,	"Gentlemen," said he, "I warn you, all this company,
The fourthe party of this day is gon.	One fourth of this day is gone.
Now for the love of God and of Seint John,	Now for the love of God and of Saint John,
Leseth no tyme, as ferforth as ye may.	Lose no time, insofar as you can.
Lordynges, the tyme wasteth nyght and day,	Gentlemen, the time wastes away night and day,
And steleth from us, what pryvely slepynge,	And steals from us, in part imperceptibly when sleeping,
And what thurgh necligence in oure wakynge,	And in part through negligence when we are awake,
As dooth the streem that turneth nevere agayn,	As does the stream that never turns back,
Descendynge from the mountaigne into playn.	Descending from the mountain into the plain.
Wel kan Senec and many a philosophre	Well can Seneca and many a philosopher
Biwaillen tyme moore than gold in cofre;	Bewail time more than gold in coffer;
For `Los of catel may recovered be,	For `Loss of property may be recovered,
But los of tyme shendeth us,' quod he.	But loss of time ruins us,' said he.
It wol nat come agayn, withouten drede,	It will not come again, without doubt,
Nomoore than wole Malkynes maydenhede,	No more than will Malkin's maidenhead,
Whan she hath lost it in hir wantownesse.	When she has lost it in her wantonness.
Lat us nat mowlen thus in ydelnesse.	Let us not grow moldy thus in idleness.
"Sire Man of Lawe," quod he, "so have ye blis,	"Sir Man of Law," said he, "as you may have bliss,
Telle us a tale anon, as forward is.	Tell us a tale now, as was agreed.
Ye been submytted, thurgh youre free assent,	You have submitted, through your free assent,
To stonden in this cas at my juggement.	To stand in this case at my judgment.
Acquiteth yow now of youre biheeste;	Now fulfill your promise;
Thanne have ye do youre devoir atte leeste."	Then have you done your duty at the least."
"Hooste," quod he, "depardieux, ich assente;	"Host," said he, "in God's name, I assent;
To breke forward is nat myn entente.	To break our agreement is not my intent.
Biheste is dette, and I wole holde fayn	Promise is debt, and I will eagerly keep
Al my biheste, I kan no bettre sayn.	All my promise, I can say no better.
For swich lawe as a man yeveth another wight,	For such law as a man gives another person,
He sholde hymselven usen it, by right;	He should himself use it, by right;
Thus wole oure text. But nathelees, certeyn,	Thus our text will have it. But nonetheless, certainly,
I kan right now no thrifty tale seyn	Right now I can tell no suitable tale
That Chaucer, thogh he kan but lewedly	That Chaucer, though he is ignorant
On metres and on rymyng craftily,	Of meters and of riming craftily,
Hath seyd hem in swich Englissh as he kan	Has (not already) said them in such English as he knows
Of olde tyme, as knoweth many a man;	Long ago, as knows many a man;
And if he have noght seyd hem, leve brother,	And if he has not said them, dear brother,
In o book, he hath seyd hem in another.	In one book, he has said them in another.
For he hath toold of loveris up and doun	For he has told of lovers up and down
Mo than Ovide made of mencioun	More than Ovid made mention of
In his Episteles, that been ful olde.	In his Epistles, that are very old.
What sholde I tellen hem, syn they been tolde?	Why should I tell them, since they have been told?
"In youthe he made of Ceys and Alcione,	"In youth he wrote about Ceyx and Alcion,
And sitthen hath he spoken of everichone,	And since has he spoken of each one,
Thise noble wyves and thise loveris eke.	These noble wives and these lovers also.
Whoso that wole his large volume seke,	Whoever will seek his large volume,
Cleped the Seintes Legende of Cupide,	Called the Saints' Legend of Cupid,
Ther may he seen the large woundes wyde	There may he see the large wounds wide
Of Lucresse, and of Babilan Tesbee;	Of Lucretia, and Thisbe of Babylon;
The swerd of Dido for the false Enee;	The sword of Dido (used) because of the false Aeneas;
The tree of Phillis for hire Demophon;	The tree of Phyllis for her Demophon;
The pleinte of Dianire and of Hermyon,	The complaint of Deianire and of Hermione,
Of Adriane, and of Isiphilee --	Of Ariadne, and of Hypsipyle --
The bareyne yle stondynge in the see --	The barren isle standing in the sea --
The dreynte Leandre for his Erro;	The drowned Leander for his Hero;
The teeris of Eleyne, and eek the wo	The tears of Helen, and also the woe
Of Brixseyde, and of the, Ladomya;	Of Briseis, and of thee, Laodamia;
The crueltee of the, queene Medea,	The cruelty of thee, queen Medea,
Thy litel children hangynge by the hals,	Thy little children hanging by the neck,
For thy Jason, that was of love so fals!	Because of thy Jason, that was in love so false!
O Ypermystra, Penelopee, Alceste,	O Hypermnestra, Penelope, Alcestis,
Youre wifhod he comendeth with the beste!	Your wifehood he commends with the best!
"But certeinly no word ne writeth he	"But certainly no word writes he
Of thilke wikke ensample of Canacee,	Of that wicked example of Canace,
That loved hir owene brother synfully --	Who loved her own brother sinfully --
Of swiche cursed stories I sey fy! --	Of such cursed stories I say fie! --
Or ellis of Tyro Appollonius,	Or else of Apollonius of Tyre,
How that the cursed kyng Antiochus	How that the cursed king Antiochus
Birafte his doghter of hir maydenhede,	Deprived his daughter of her maidenhead,
That is so horrible a tale for to rede,	That is so horrible a tale to read,
Whan he hir threw upon the pavement.	When he threw her upon the pavement.
And therfore he, of ful avysement,	And therefore he, after careful consideration
Nolde nevere write in none of his sermons	Would never write in any of his compositions
Of swiche unkynde abhomynacions,	Of such unnatural abominations,
Ne I wol noon reherce, if that I may.	Nor will I tell any such, if that I may.
"But of my tale how shal I doon this day?	"But of my tale what shall I do this day?
Me were looth be likned, doutelees,	I would hate to be likened, doubtless,
To Muses that men clepe Pierides --	To the Muses that men call Pierides --
Methamorphosios woot what I mene;	Metamorphoses shows what I mean;
But nathelees, I recche noght a bene	But nonetheless, I reckon it not worth a bean
Though I come after hym with hawebake.	Though I come after him with a humble dish.
I speke in prose, and lat him rymes make."	I speak in prose, and let him make rhymes."
And with that word he, with a sobre cheere,	And with that word he, with a solemn demeanor,
Bigan his tale, as ye shal after heere.	Began his tale, as you shall after hear.
The Prologe of the Mannes Tale of Law	The Prologue of the Man's Tale of Law
O hateful harm, condicion of poverte!	O hateful harm, condition of poverty!
With thurst, with coold, with hunger so confoundid!	By thirst, by cold, by hunger so distressed!
To asken help thee shameth in thyn herte;	To ask help thou art ashamed in thy heart;
If thou noon aske, with nede artow so woundid	If thou ask for none, thou art so wounded by need
That verray nede unwrappeth al thy wounde hid!	That true need reveals all thy hidden wound!
Maugree thyn heed, thou most for indigence	Despite all you can do, thou must for indigence
Or stele, or begge, or borwe thy despence!	Either steal, or beg, or borrow thy living expenses!
Thow blamest Crist and seist ful bitterly	Thou blamest Christ and sayest full bitterly
He mysdeparteth richesse temporal;	He wrongly allots temporal riches;
Thy neighebor thou wytest synfully,	Thy neighbor thou blamest sinfully,
And seist thou hast to lite and he hath al.	And sayest thou hast too little and he has all.
"Parfay," seistow, "somtyme he rekene shal,	"By my faith," sayest thou, "sometimes he shall pay for it,
Whan that his tayl shal brennen in the gleede,	When his tail shall burn in the live coals,
For he noght helpeth needfulle in hir neede."	For he helps not the needy in their need."
Herkne what is the sentence of the wise:	Listen to what is the opinion of the wise:
"Bet is to dyen than have indigence";	"Better it is to die than to have poverty";
"Thy selve neighebor wol thee despise."	"Thy very neighbor will despise thee."
If thou be povre, farwel thy reverence!	If thou be poor, farewell thy reverence!
Yet of the wise man take this sentence:	Yet of the wise man take this advice:
"Alle the dayes of povre men been wikke."	"All the days of poor men are painful."
Be war, therfore, er thou come to that prikke!	Beware, therefore, before thou come to that point!
If thou be povre, thy brother hateth thee,	If thou be poor, thy brother hates thee,
And alle thy freendes fleen from thee, allas!	And all thy friends flee from thee, alas!
O riche marchauntz, ful of wele been yee,	O rich merchants, full of prosperity are you,
O noble, o prudent folk, as in this cas!	O noble, o prudent folk, in such a case as this!
Youre bagges been nat fild with ambes as,	Your bags are not filled with double aces (a losing throw in dice),
But with sys cynk, that renneth for youre chaunce;	But with six five, that is your winning number;
At Cristemasse myrie may ye daunce!	At Christmas merrily may you dance!
Ye seken lond and see for yowre wynnynges;	You seek land and sea for your winnings;
As wise folk ye knowen al th' estaat	As wise folk you know all the condition
Of regnes; ye been fadres of tidynges	Of (foreign) lands; you are fathers of tidings
And tales, bothe of pees and of debaat.	And tales, both of peace and of war.
I were right now of tales desolaat,	I would right now be without any tales,
Nere that a marchant, goon is many a yeere,	Were it not that a merchant, gone by is many a year,
Me taughte a tale, which that ye shal heere.	Taught me a tale, which you shall hear.
Heere begynneth the Man of Lawe his tale.	Here begins the tale of the Man of Law.
In Surrye whilom dwelte a compaignye	In Syria once dwelt a company
Of chapmen riche, and therto sadde and trewe,	Of rich merchants, and moreover trustworthy and true,
That wyde-where senten hir spicerye,	That wherever they sent their oriental goods,
Clothes of gold, and satyns riche of hewe.	Cloth of gold, and satins rich in color.
Hir chaffare was so thrifty and so newe	Their merchandise was so serviceable and so novel
That every wight hath deyntee to chaffare	That every person has desire to trade
With hem, and eek to sellen hem hire ware.	With them, and also to sell them their goods.
Now fil it that the maistres of that sort	Now it happened that the masters of that company
Han shapen hem to Rome for to wende;	Have prepared themselves to travel to Rome;
Were it for chapmanhod or for disport,	Were it for business or for pleasure,
Noon oother message wolde they thider sende,	No other messenger would they thither send,
But comen hemself to Rome; this is the ende.	But came themselves to Rome; this is the sum of it.
And in swich place as thoughte hem avantage	And in such a place as they thought advantageous
For hire entente, they take hir herbergage.	For their purposes, they take their lodging.
Sojourned han thise merchantz in that toun	These merchants have sojourned in that town
A certein tyme, as fil to hire plesance.	A certain length of time, as accorded with their desires.
And so bifel that th' excellent renoun	And it so happened that the excellent renown
Of the Emperoures doghter, dame Custance,	Of the Emperor's daughter, Lady Custance,
Reported was, with every circumstance,	Was reported, in full detail,
Unto thise Surryen marchantz in swich wyse,	Unto these Syrian merchants in such a manner,
Fro day to day, as I shal yow devyse.	From day to day, as I shall tell you.
This was the commune voys of every man:	This was the common opinion of every man:
"Oure Emperour of Rome -- God hym see! --	"Our Emperor of Rome -- may God look after him! --
A doghter hath that, syn the world bigan,	A daughter has that, since the world began,
To rekene as wel hir goodnesse as beautee,	To consider as well her goodness as beauty,
Nas nevere swich another as is shee.	There was never such another as is she.
I prey to God in honour hire susteene,	I pray to God to sustain her in honor,
And wolde she were of al Europe the queene.	And would she were of all Europe the queen.
"In hire is heigh beautee, withoute pride,	"In her is great beauty, without pride,
Yowthe, withoute grenehede or folye;	Youth, without immaturity or folly;
To alle hire werkes vertu is hir gyde;	In all her deeds virtue is her guide;
Humblesse hath slayn in hire al tirannye.	Humility has slain in her all tyranny.
She is mirour of alle curteisye;	She is mirror of all courtesy;
Hir herte is verray chambre of hoolynesse,	Her heart is a true chamber of holiness,
Hir hand, ministre of fredam for almesse."	Her hand, minister of generosity in giving alms."
And al this voys was sooth, as God is trewe.	And all this opinion was true, as God is true.
But now to purpos lat us turne agayn.	But now to the point let us turn again.
Thise marchantz han doon fraught hir shippes newe,	These merchants have had their ships newly loaded,
And whan they han this blisful mayden sayn,	And when they have this blissful maiden seen,
Hoom to Surrye been they went ful fayn,	Home to Syria they have gone very happily,
And doon hir nedes as they han doon yoore,	And they conduct their business as they have done for years,
And lyven in wele; I kan sey yow namoore.	And live in prosperity; I can tell you no more.
Now fil it that thise marchantz stode in grace	Now it happened that these merchants stood in the good graces
Of hym that was the Sowdan of Surrye;	Of him that was the Sultan of Syria;
For whan they cam from any strange place,	For when they came from any foreign place,
He wolde, of his benigne curteisye,	He would, of his gracious courtesy,
Make hem good chiere, and bisily espye	Entertain them well, and busily seek out
Tidynges of sondry regnes, for to leere	News from various countries, to learn
The wondres that they myghte seen or heere.	The wonders that they could have seen or heard.
Amonges othere thynges, specially,	Amongst other things, specially,
Thise marchantz han hym toold of dame Custance	These merchants have told him of Lady Custance
So greet noblesse in ernest, ceriously,	Such great noble qualities in earnest, in detail,
That this Sowdan hath caught so greet plesance	That this Sultan has caught such great desire
To han hir figure in his remembrance,	To have her figure in his remembrance,
That al his lust and al his bisy cure	That all his desire and all his intense concern
Was for to love hire while his lyf may dure.	Was to love her while his life may endure.
Paraventure in thilke large book	Perhaps in that large book
Which that men clepe the hevene ywriten was	Which men call the heaven was written
With sterres, whan that he his birthe took,	In stars, when he was born,
That he for love sholde han his deeth, allas!	That he because of love should have his death, alas!
For in the sterres, clerer than is glas,	For in the stars, clearer than is glass,
Is writen, God woot, whoso koude it rede,	Is written, God knows, whoever could read it,
The deeth of every man, withouten drede.	The death of every man, without doubt.
In sterres, many a wynter therbiforn,	In stars, many a winter before then,
Was writen the deeth of Ector, Achilles,	Was written the death of Hector, Achilles,
Of Pompei, Julius, er they were born;	Of Pompey, Julius, before they were born;
The strif of Thebes; and of Ercules,	The strife of Thebes; and of Hercules,
Of Sampson, Turnus, and of Socrates	Of Sampson, Turnus, and of Socrates
The deeth; but mennes wittes ben so dulle	The death; but men's wits are so dull
That no wight kan wel rede it atte fulle.	That no person can well interpret it fully.
This Sowdan for his privee conseil sente,	This Sultan for his privy council sent,
And, shortly of this matiere for to pace,	And, to pass briefly over this matter,
He hath to hem declared his entente,	He has to them declared his intent,
And seyde hem, certein, but he myghte have grace	And said to them, certainly, unless he could have the good fortune
To han Custance withinne a litel space,	To have Custance within a little time,
He nas but deed; and charged hem in hye	He was as good as dead; and ordered them hastily
To shapen for his lyf som remedye.	To arrange some remedy to save his life .
Diverse men diverse thynges seyden;	Different men said different things;
They argumenten, casten up and doun;	They argue, consider alternatives;
Many a subtil resoun forth they leyden;	Many a subtle argument they laid forth;
They speken of magyk and abusioun.	They speak of magic and deception.
But finally, as in conclusioun,	But finally, in conclusion,
They kan nat seen in that noon avantage,	They can not see any advantage in that,
Ne in noon oother wey, save mariage.	Nor in any other way, save for marriage.
Thanne sawe they therinne swich difficultee	Then saw they in that such difficulty
By wey of reson, for to speke al playn,	By way of reason, to speak all plainly,
By cause that ther was swich diversitee	Because there was such difference
Bitwene hir bothe lawes, that they sayn	Between their two religions, that they say
They trowe that no "Cristen prince wolde fayn	They suppose that no "Christian prince would be willing
Wedden his child under oure lawe sweete	To wed his child under our sweet religion
That us was taught by Mahoun, oure prophete."	That was taught us by Mohammed, our prophet."
And he answerde, "Rather than I lese	And he answered, "Rather than I lose
Custance, I wol be cristned, doutelees.	Custance, I will be christened, doubtless.
I moot been hires; I may noon oother chese.	I must be hers; I can choose no other.
I prey yow hoold youre argumentz in pees;	I pray you to keep your arguments silent;
Saveth my lyf, and beth noght recchelees	Save my life, and be not negligent
To geten hire that hath my lyf in cure,	To get her who has my life in her keeping,
For in this wo I may nat longe endure."	For in this woe I can not long endure."
What nedeth gretter dilatacioun?	What needs greater increase of words?
I seye, by tretys and embassadrie,	I say, by treaty and negotiation,
And by the popes mediacioun,	And by the pope's mediation,
And al the chirche, and al the chivalrie,	And all the church, and all the knights,
That in destruccioun of mawmettrie,	That for the destruction of idolatry,
And in encrees of Cristes lawe deere,	And for the increase of Christ's dear law,
They been acorded, so as ye shal heere:	They are agreed, as you shall hear:
How that the Sowdan and his baronage	That the Sultan and his baronage
And alle his liges sholde ycristned be,	And all his vassals should christened be,
And he shal han Custance in mariage,	And he shall have Custance in marriage,
And certein gold, I noot what quantitee;	And a certain amount of gold, I do not know how much;
And heer-to founden sufficient suretee.	And for this provided sufficient pledges.
This same accord was sworn on eyther syde;	This same agreement was sworn on either side;
Now, faire Custance, almyghty God thee gyde!	Now, fair Custance, almighty God thee guide!
Now wolde som men waiten, as I gesse,	Now would some men expect, as I guess,
That I sholde tellen al the purveiance	That I should tell all the preparations
That th' Emperour, of his grete noblesse,	That the Emperor, of his great nobility,
Hath shapen for his doghter, dame Custance.	Has arranged for his daughter, Lady Custance.
Wel may men knowen that so greet ordinance	Well may men know that such great preparation
May no man tellen in a litel clause	No man can tell in a brief statement
As was arrayed for so heigh a cause.	As was provided for so important an occasion.
Bisshopes been shapen with hire for to wende,	Bishops are appointed to go with her,
Lordes, ladies, knyghtes of renoun,	Lords, ladies, knights of renown,
And oother folk ynowe; this is th' ende;	And other folk enough; this is the sum of it;
And notified is thurghout the toun	And it is made known throughout the town
That every wight, with greet devocioun,	That every person, with great devotion,
Sholde preyen Crist that he this mariage	Should pray Christ that He this marriage
Receyve in gree and spede this viage.	Receive favorably and lend success to this voyage.
The day is comen of hir departynge;	The day is come of her departure;
I seye, the woful day fatal is come,	I say, the woeful fatal day is come,
That ther may be no lenger tariynge,	That there may be no longer tarrying,
But forthward they hem dressen, alle and some.	But to go forth they prepare themselves, one and all.
Custance, that was with sorwe al overcome,	Custance, that was with sorrow all overcome,
Ful pale arist, and dresseth hire to wende;	Full pale arises, and prepares herself to go;
For wel she seeth ther is noon oother ende.	For well she sees there is no other possible conclusion.
Allas, what wonder is it thogh she wepte,	Alas, what wonder is it though she wept,
That shal be sent to strange nacioun	She who shall be sent to a foreign nation
Fro freendes that so tendrely hire kepte,	From friends who so tenderly cared for her,
And to be bounden under subjeccioun	And to be bound under subjection
Of oon, she knoweth nat his condicioun?	By one, (of whom) she knows not his character?
Housbondes been alle goode, and han ben yoore;	Husbands are all good, and have been for years;
That knowen wyves; I dar sey yow na moore.	Wives know that; I dare say you no more.
"Fader," she seyde, "thy wrecched child Custance,	"Father," she said, "thy wretched child Custance,
Thy yonge doghter fostred up so softe,	Thy young daughter fostered up so tenderly,
And ye, my mooder, my soverayn plesance	And you, my mother, my greatest joy
Over alle thyng, out-taken Crist on-lofte,	Over all things, except Christ above,
Custance youre child hire recomandeth ofte	Custance your child commends herself often
Unto youre grace, for I shal to Surrye,	Unto your grace, for I must go to Syria,
Ne shal I nevere seen yow moore with ye.	Nor shall I never see you again with my eyes.
"Allas, unto the Barbre nacioun	"Alas, unto the pagan world
I moste anoon, syn that it is youre wille;	I must go right now, since it is your will;
But Crist, that starf for our redempcioun	But Christ, that died for our redemption
So yeve me grace his heestes to fulfille!	Give me grace his commands to fulfill!
I, wrecche womman, no fors though I spille!	I, wretched woman, no matter though I die!
Wommen are born to thraldom and penance,	Women are born to servitude and suffering,
And to been under mannes governance."	And to be under man's governance."
I trowe at Troye, whan Pirrus brak the wal	I believe at Troy, when Pirrus broke the wall
Or Ilion brende, at Thebes the citee,	Before Ilion burned, at Thebes the city,
N' at Rome, for the harm thurgh Hanybal	Nor at Rome, for the harm wrought by Hannibal
That Romayns hath venquysshed tymes thre,	Who has vanquished Romans three times,
Nas herd swich tendre wepyng for pitee	Was not heard such tender weeping for pity
As in the chambre was for hire departynge;	As in the chamber was for her departing;
But forth she moot, wher-so she wepe or synge.	But forth she must go, whether she weeps or sings.
O firste moevyng! Crueel firmament,	O first moving! Cruel firmament,
With thy diurnal sweigh that crowdest ay	With thy daily motion that pushes ever
And hurlest al from est til occident	And hurls all from east to west

Infortunat ascendent tortuous,	Unfortunate ascending oblique house, [see n.]

Imprudent Emperour of Rome, allas!	Imprudent Emperor of Rome, alas!

Is no tyme bet than oother in swich cas?	Is no time better than another in such a case?

To shippe is brought this woful faire mayde	To ship is brought this woeful fair maid

The mooder of the Sowdan, welle of vices,	The mother of the Sultan, well of vices,

How he wol lete his olde sacrifices;	How he will leave his old sacrifices;

Yeven by Goddes message Makomete.	Given by God's messenger Mohammed.
But oon avow to grete God I heete,	But one vow to great God I promise,

O Sowdanesse, roote of iniquitee!	O Sultaness, root of iniquity!

Noght trowe I the triumphe of Julius,	I do not believe the triumph of Julius,

But this scorpioun, this wikked goost,	But this scorpion, this wicked spirit,

This olde Sowdanesse, cursed krone,	This old Sultaness, cursed crone,

O my Custance, ful of benignytee,	O my Custance, full of goodness,

Yeres and dayes fleet this creature	Years and days floated this creature

And I answere to that demande agayn,	And I answer to that question in reply,
Who saved Danyel in the horrible cave	Who saved Daniel in the horrible cave

No wight but God that he bar in his herte.	No one but God Whom he bore in his heart.

Crist, which that is to every harm triacle,	Christ, Who is a medicine for every harm,

She dryveth forth into oure occian	She drives forth into our ocean

Sathan, that evere us waiteth to bigile,	Satan, that ever waits (for a chance) to trick us,

Almyghty God, that saveth al mankynde,	Almighty God, that saves all mankind,
Have on Custance and on hir child som mynde,	Have for Custance and for her child some thought,
That fallen is in hethen hand eft soone,	Who fallen is in heathen hand once more,
In point to spille, as I shal telle yow soone.	On the point of dying, as I shall tell you soon.
Doun fro the castel comth ther many a wight	Down from the castle comes there many a person

But shortly, from the castel, on a nyght,	But shortly, from the castle, on a night,
The lordes styward -- God yeve hym meschance! --	The lord's steward -- God give him bad luck! --
A theef, that hadde reneyed oure creance,	A thief, that had renounced our religion,
Cam into ship allone, and seyde he sholde	Came into ship alone, and said he should
Hir lemman be, wher-so she wolde or nolde.	Her lover be, whether she would or would not.
Wo was this wrecched womman tho bigon;	Woebegone then was this wretched woman;
Hir child cride, and she cride pitously.	Her child cried, and she cried pitifully.
But blisful Marie heelp hire right anon;	But blissful Mary helped her right then;

And in the see he dreynte for vengeance;	And in the sea he drowned as a punishment;
And thus hath Crist unwemmed kept Custance.	And thus has Christ kept Custance undefiled.
O foule lust of luxurie, lo, thyn ende!	O foul lust of lechery, lo, thy end!
Nat oonly that thou feyntest mannes mynde,	Not only that thou make man's mind grow faint,
But verraily thou wolt his body shende.	But truly thou wilt his body destroy.
Th' ende of thy werk, or of thy lustes blynde,	The end of thy work, or of thy blind desires,
Is compleynyng. Hou many oon may men fynde	Is lamentation. How many a one may men find
That noght for werk somtyme, but for th' entente	That not for the deed sometimes, but for the intention
To doon this synne, been outher slayn or shente!	To do this sin, are either slain or destroyed!
How may this wayke womman han this strengthe	How may this weak woman have this strength
