O Golias, unmesurable of lengthe,	O Goliath, immeasurable of height,
Hou myghte David make thee so maat,	How could David make thee so defeated,
So yong and of armure so desolaat?	So young and so lacking in arms and armor?
Hou dorste he looke upon thy dredful face?	How dared he look upon thy dreadful face?
Wel may men seen, it nas but Goddes grace.	Well may men see, it was nothing but God's grace.
Who yaf Judith corage or hardynesse	Who gave Judith courage or hardiness

And to deliveren out of wrecchednesse	And to deliver out of wretchedness

That right as God spirit of vigour sente	That just as God the spirit of vigor sent

So sente he myght and vigour to Custance.	So sent he might and vigor to Custance.
Forth gooth hir ship thurghout the narwe mouth	Forth goes her ship throughout the narrow mouth
Of Jubaltare and Septe, dryvynge ay	Of Gibraltar and Morocco, driving ever
Somtyme west, and somtyme north and south,	Sometimes west, and sometimes north and south,

Now lat us stynte of Custance but a throwe,	Now let us stint of Custance but a short while,
And speke we of the Romayn Emperour,	And speak we of the Roman Emperor,

Thus kan Oure Lady bryngen out of wo	Thus can Our Lady bring out of woe

And longe tyme dwelled she in that place,	And long time dwelled she in that place,

The senatoures wyf hir aunte was,	The senator's wife was her aunt,

I wol no lenger tarien in this cas,	I will no longer tarry in this case,

Upon a day fil in swich repentance	Upon a day fell in such repentance

For he hadde riden moore than trot or paas;	For he had ridden at more than a trot or a walk;
He hadde ay priked lik as he were wood.	He had always spurred as if he were crazy.
A clote-leef he hadde under his hood	A burdock-leaf he had under his hood
For swoot and for to keep his heed from heete.	For sweat and to keep his head from heat.
But it was joye for to seen hym swete!	But what a joy it was to see him sweat!
His forheed dropped as a stillatorie	His forehead dripped like a still
Were ful of plantayne and of paritorie.	Full of the herbs plantain and pellitory.
And whan that he was come, he gan to crye,	And when he was come to us, he began to cry out,
"God save," quod he, "this joly compaignye!	"God save," said he, "this jolly company!
Faste have I priked," quod he, "for youre sake,	Fast have I spurred," said he, "for your sake,
By cause that I wolde yow atake,	Because I wanted to overtake you,
To riden in this myrie compaignye."	To ride in this merry company."
His yeman eek was ful of curteisye,	His yeoman also was full of courtesy,
And seyde, "Sires, now in the morwe-tyde	And said, "Sirs, just now in the morning time
I saugh yow ryde out of youre hostelrie,	I saw you ride out of your hostelry,
And warned heer my lord and my soverayn,	And told my lord here and my sovereign,
Which that to ryden with yow is ful fayn	Who is very eager to ride with you
For his desport; he loveth daliaunce."	For his pleasure; he loves sociability."
"Freend, for thy warnyng God yeve thee good chaunce,"	"Friend, for thy telling him God give thee good luck,"
Thanne seyde oure Hoost, "for certein it wolde seme	Then said our Host, "for certainly it would seem
Thy lord were wys, and so I may wel deme.	Thy lord is wise, and as I can well judge.
He is ful jocunde also, dar I leye!	He is very cheerful also, I dare wager!
Can he oght telle a myrie tale or tweye,	Can he in any way tell a merry tale or two,
With which he glade may this compaignye?"	With which he may gladden this company?"
"Who, sire? My lord? Ye, ye, withouten lye,	"Who, sir? My lord? Yes, yes, without lie,
He kan of murthe and eek of jolitee	He knows about mirth and also about jollity
Nat but ynough; also, sire, trusteth me,	More than enough; also, sir, trust me,
And ye hym knewe as wel as do I,	If you knew him as well as do I,
Ye wolde wondre how wel and craftily	You would wonder how well and craftily
He koude werke, and that in sondry wise.	He knows how to work, and that in a variety of ways.
He hath take on hym many a greet emprise,	He has taken on him many a great enterprise,
Which were ful hard for any that is heere	Which would be very hard for any one who is here
To brynge aboute, but they of hym it leere.	To bring about, unless they learn it from him.
As hoomly as he rit amonges yow,	Despite how modestly he rides amongst you,
If ye hym knewe, it wolde be for youre prow.	If you knew him, it would be to your advantage.
Ye wolde nat forgoon his aqueyntaunce	You would not forgo his acquaintance
For muchel good, I dar leye in balaunce	For great riches, I dare wager on that
Al that I have in my possessioun.	All that I have in my possession.
He is a man of heigh discrecioun;	He is a man of great discretion;
I warne yow wel, he is a passyng man."	I tell you indeed, he is a remarkable man."
"Wel," quod oure Hoost, "I pray thee, tel me than,	"Well," said our Host, "I pray thee, tell me then,
Is he a clerk, or noon? Telle what he is."	Is he a clerk, or not? Tell what he is."
"Nay, he is gretter than a clerk, ywis,"	"Nay, he is greater than a clerk, indeed,"
Seyde this Yeman, "and in wordes fewe,	Said this Yeoman, "and in few words,
Hoost, of his craft somwhat I wol yow shewe.	Host, I will show you something of his craft.
"I seye, my lord kan swich subtilitee --	"I say, my lord knows such esoteric science --
But al his craft ye may nat wite at me,	But all his craft you can not know from me,
And somwhat helpe I yet to his wirkyng --	And yet somewhat I help in his work --
That al this ground on which we been ridyng,	That all this ground on which we are riding,
Til that we come to Caunterbury toun,	Until we come to Canterbury town,
He koude al clene turnen up-so-doun,	He could turn all completely upside down,
And pave it al of silver and of gold."	And pave it all with silver and with gold."
And whan this Yeman hadde this tale ytold	And when this Yeoman had this tale told
Unto oure Hoost, he seyde, "Benedicitee!	Unto our Host, he said, "Bless you!
This thyng is wonder merveillous to me,	This thing is wonderfully marvelous to me,
Syn that thy lord is of so heigh prudence,	Since thy lord is of such great prudence,
By cause of which men sholde hym reverence,	Because of which men should reverence him,
That of his worshipe rekketh he so lite.	That he cares so little for his own self-respect.
His overslope nys nat worth a myte,	His outer garment is not worth a fraction of a penny,
As in effect, to hym, so moot I go,	Because in fact, to him, as I may go (I swear),
It is al baudy and totore also.	It is all dirty and tattered also.
Why is thy lord so sluttissh, I the preye,	Why is thy lord so slovenly, I pray thee,
And is of power bettre clooth to beye,	And has the power to buy better cloth,
If that his dede accorde with thy speche?	If his deeds accord with thy speech?
Telle me that, and that I thee biseche."	Tell me that, and of that I beseech thee."
"Why?" quod this Yeman, "wherto axe ye me?	"Why?" said this Yeoman, "why do you ask me?
God help me so, for he shal nevere thee!	So help me God, for he shall never prosper!
(But I wol nat avowe that I seye,	(But I will not publicly acknowledge what I say,
And therfore keepe it secree, I yow preye.)	And therefore keep it secret, I pray you.)
He is to wys, in feith, as I bileeve.	He is too wise, in faith, as I believe.
That that is overdoon, it wol nat preeve	That which is done too much, it will not turn out
Aright, as clerkes seyn; it is a vice.	Right, as clerks say; it is a vice.
Wherfore in that I holde hym lewed and nyce.	Therefore in that I hold him ignorant and foolish.
For whan a man hath over-greet a wit,	For when a man has too great a wit,
Ful oft hym happeth to mysusen it.	Very often he happens to misuse it.
So dooth my lord, and that me greveth soore;	So does my lord, and that sorely grieves me;
God it amende! I kan sey yow namoore."	God amend it! I can tell you no more."
"Ther-of no fors, good Yeman," quod oure Hoost;	"That does not matter, good Yeoman," said our Host;
"Syn of the konnyng of thy lord thow woost,	"Since thou knowest of the cunning of thy lord,
Telle how he dooth, I pray thee hertely,	Tell how he does, I pray thee heartily,
Syn that he is so crafty and so sly.	Since he is so crafty and so sly.
Where dwelle ye, if it to telle be?"	Where do you dwell, if it can be told?"
"In the suburbes of a toun," quod he,	"In the outskirts of a town," said he,
"Lurkynge in hernes and in lanes blynde,	"Lurking in hiding places and in dead-end alleys,
Whereas thise robbours and thise theves by kynde	Where these robbers and these thieves by nature
Holden hir pryvee fereful residence,	Hold their private fearful residence,
As they that dar nat shewen hir presence;	Like those who dare not show their presence;
So faren we, if I shal seye the sothe."	So fare we, if I shall say the truth."
"Now," quod oure Hoost, "yit lat me talke to the.	"Now," said our Host, "yet let me talk to thee.
Why artow so discoloured of thy face?"	Why art thou so discolored in thy face?"
"Peter!" quod he, "God yeve it harde grace,	"Peter!" said he, "God give it bad luck,
I am so used in the fyr to blowe	I am so used to blow in the fire
That it hath chaunged my colour, I trowe.	That it has changed my color, I believe.
I am nat wont in no mirour to prie,	I am not accustomed to peer in any mirror,
But swynke soore and lerne multiplie.	But to work hard and to learn to transmute metals.
We blondren evere and pouren in the fir,	We blunder ever and stare in the fire,
And for al that we faille of oure desir,	And despite all that, we fail to achieve our desire,
For evere we lakken oure conclusioun.	For ever we lack our desired conclusion.
To muchel folk we doon illusioun,	To many folk we do delusion,
And borwe gold, be it a pound or two,	And borrow gold, be it a pound or two,
Or ten, or twelve, or manye sommes mo,	Or ten, or twelve, or many greater sums,
And make hem wenen, at the leeste weye,	And make them believe, at the very least,
That of a pound we koude make tweye.	That of one pound we could make two.
Yet is it fals, but ay we han good hope	Yet is it false, but always we have good hope
It for to doon, and after it we grope.	To do it, and after it we grope.
But that science is so fer us biforn,	But that knowledge is so far ahead of us,
We mowen nat, although we hadden it sworn,	We can not, although we had sworn it,
It overtake, it slit awey so faste.	Overtake it, it slides away so fast.
It wole us maken beggers atte laste."	It will make us beggars at the last."
Whil this Yeman was thus in his talkyng,	While this Yeoman was thus in his talking,
This Chanoun drough hym neer and herde al thyng	This Canon drew himself nearer and heard every thing
Which this Yeman spak, for suspecioun	Which this Yeoman spoke, for suspicion
Of mennes speche evere hadde this Chanoun.	Of men's speech ever had this Canon.
For Catoun seith that he that gilty is	For Cato says that he who is guilty
Demeth alle thyng be spoke of hym, ywis.	Believes every thing is spoken about him, indeed.
That was the cause he gan so ny hym drawe	That was the cause he did draw himself so near
To his Yeman, to herknen al his sawe.	To his Yeoman, to hear all his speech.
And thus he seyde unto his Yeman tho:	And thus he said unto his Yeoman then:
"Hoold thou thy pees and spek no wordes mo,	"Hold thou thy peace and speak no more words,
For if thou do, thou shalt it deere abye.	For if thou do, thou shalt dearly pay for it.
Thou sclaundrest me heere in this compaignye,	Thou slanderest me here in this company,
And eek discoverest that thou sholdest hyde."	And also revealest what thou shouldest hide."
"Ye," quod oure Hoost, "telle on, what so bityde.	"Yes," said our Host, "tell on, whataever may happen.
Of al his thretyng rekke nat a myte!"	Reckon all his threatening not worth a fraction of a penny!"
"In feith," quod he, "namoore I do but lyte."	"In faith," said he, "I do (reckon him) but little any more."
And whan this Chanon saugh it wolde nat bee,	And when this Canon saw it would not be,
But his Yeman wolde telle his pryvetee,	But that his Yeoman would tell his secrets,
He fledde awey for verray sorwe and shame.	He fled away for true sorrow and shame.
"A!" quod the Yeman, "heere shal arise game;	"Ah!" said the Yeoman, "here shall arise some amusement;
Al that I kan anon now wol I telle.	Right now I will tell all that I know.
Syn he is goon, the foule feend hym quelle!	Since he is gone, may the foul fiend kill him!
For nevere heerafter wol I with hym meete	For never hereafter will I meet with him
For peny ne for pound, I yow biheete.	For penny nor for pound, I promise you.
He that me broghte first unto that game,	He who brought me first unto that game,
Er that he dye, sorwe have he and shame!	Before he dies, may he have sorrow and shame!
For it is ernest to me, by my feith;	For it is serious (not game) to me, by my faith;
That feele I wel, what so any man seith.	That feel I well, whatever any man says.
And yet, for al my smert and al my grief,	And yet, for all my pain and all my grief,
For al my sorwe, labour, and meschief,	For all my sorrow, labor, and mischief,
I koude nevere leve it in no wise.	I could never leave it in any way.
Now wolde God my wit myghte suffise	Now I wish to God my wit might suffice
To tellen al that longeth to that art!	To tell all that belongs to that art!
But nathelees yow wol I tellen part.	But nonetheless you desire that I tell part.
Syn that my lord is goon, I wol nat spare;	Since my lord is gone, I will not spare;
Swich thyng as that I knowe, I wol declare.	Such things as what I know, I will declare.
Heere endeth the Prologe of the Chanouns Yemannes Tale .	Here ends the Prologue of the Canon's Yeoman's Tale.
Heere bigynneth the Chanouns Yeman his Tale.	Here begins the Canon's Yeoman's Tale.
Prima Pars	Prima Pars
With this Chanoun I dwelt have seven yeer,	With this Canon I have dwelt seven years,
And of his science am I never the neer.	And as to his science I am never the nearer (to success).
Al that I hadde I have lost therby,	All that I had I have lost thereby,
And, God woot, so hath many mo than I.	And, God knows, so have many more than I.
Ther I was wont to be right fressh and gay	Where I was accustomed to be right fresh and gay
Of clothyng and of oother good array,	Of clothing and of other splendid furnishings,
Now may I were an hose upon myn heed;	Now may I wear a hose upon my head;
And wher my colour was bothe fressh and reed,	And whereas my color was both fresh and red,
Now is it wan and of a leden hewe --	Now is it pale and of a leaden hue --
Whoso it useth, soore shal he rewe! --	Whoever uses it (that art), sorely shall he rue! --
And of my swynk yet blered is myn ye.	And by my work yet my eye is bleared.
Lo, which avantage is to multiplie!	Lo, how profitable it is to transute metals!
That slidynge science hath me maad so bare	That slippery science has made me so bare
That I have no good, wher that evere I fare;	That I have no possessions, wherever I fare;
And yet I am endetted so therby	And yet by this I am so indebted
Of gold that I have borwed, trewely,	For gold that I have borrowed, truly,
That whil I lyve I shal it quite nevere.	That while I live I shall never repay it.
Lat every man be war by me for evere!	Let every man be warned by me forever!
What maner man that casteth hym therto,	Whatever sort of man that applies himself to that,
If he continue, I holde his thrift ydo.	If he continue, I consider his prosperity done for.
For so helpe me God, therby shal he nat wynne,	For so help me God, he shall not profit thereby,
But empte his purs and make his wittes thynne.	But empty his purse and make his wits thin.
And whan he thurgh his madnesse and folye	And when he through his madness and folly
Hath lost his owene good thurgh jupartye,	Has lost his own possessions in this dangerous business,
Thanne he exciteth oother folk therto,	Then he incites other folk to that,
To lesen hir good as he hymself hath do.	To lose their possessions as he himself has done.
For unto shrewes joye it is and ese	For unto scoundrels it is joy and ease
To have hir felawes in peyne and disese.	To have their fellows in pain and hardship.
Thus was I ones lerned of a clerk.	Thus was I once taught by a clerk.
Of that no charge; I wol speke of oure werk.	No matter about that; I will speak of our work.
Whan we been there as we shul exercise	When we are where we shall exercise
Oure elvysshe craft, we semen wonder wise,	Our mysterious craft, we seem wonderfully wise,
Oure termes been so clergial and so queynte.	Our terms are so scholarly and so strange.
I blowe the fir til that myn herte feynte.	I blow the fire until my heart faints.
What sholde I tellen ech proporcion	Why should I tell each proportion
Of thynges whiche that we werche upon --	Of the things that we work upon --
As on fyve or sixe ounces, may wel be,	As on five or six ounces, it may well be,
Of silver, or som oother quantitee --	Of silver, or some other quantity --
And bisye me to telle yow the names	And busy myself to tell you the names
Of orpyment, brent bones, iren squames,	Of orpiment (arsenic trisulfide), burned bones, iron flakes,
That into poudre grounden been ful smal;	That are ground into very fine powder;
And in an erthen pot how put is al,	And how all is put in an earthen pot,
And salt yput in, and also papeer,	And salt put in, and also pepper,
Biforn thise poudres that I speke of heer;	Before these powders that I speak of here;
And wel ycovered with a lampe of glas;	And well covered with a lamp-shaped vessel of glass;
And of muche oother thyng which that ther was;	And of many other things which were there;
And of the pot and glasses enlutyng	And sealing of the pot and glasses
That of the eyr myghte passe out nothyng;	So that not a bit of the air could pass out;
And of the esy fir, and smart also,	And of the slow fir, and fast also,
Which that was maad, and of the care and wo	Which was made, and of the care and woe
That we hadde in oure matires sublymyng,	That we had in purifying our materials,
And in amalgamyng and calcenyng	And in blending and reducing to powder
Of quyksilver, yclept mercurie crude?	Of quicksilver, called raw mercury?
For alle oure sleightes we kan nat conclude.	Despite all our tricks we can not succeed.
Oure orpyment and sublymed mercurie,	Our orpiment (arsenic trisulfide), and purified mercury,
Oure grounden litarge eek on the porfurie,	Our litharge (lead monoxide) ground also on the porphyry mortar,
Of ech of thise of ounces a certeyn --	A certain number of ounces of each of these --
Noght helpeth us; oure labour is in veyn.	Nothing helps us; our labor is in vain.
Ne eek oure spirites ascencioun,	Also neither our spirit's vaporization,
Ne oure materes that lyen al fix adoun,	Nor our materials that remain fixed in the pot,
Mowe in oure werkyng no thyng us availle,	Can in any way help us in our working,
For lost is al oure labour and travaille;	For all our labor and travail is lost;
And al the cost, a twenty devel waye,	And all the expenditure, in the name of twenty devils,
Is lost also, which we upon it laye.	Which we spent upon it, is lost also.
Ther is also ful many another thyng	There is also very many another thing
That is unto oure craft apertenyng.	That pertains unto our craft.
Though I by ordre hem nat reherce kan,	Though I can not list them in their proper order,
By cause that I am a lewed man,	Because I am an unlearned man,
Yet wol I telle hem as they come to mynde,	Yet will I tell them as they come to mind,
Thogh I ne kan nat sette hem in hir kynde:	Though I can not set them in their proper categories:
As boole armonyak, verdegrees, boras,	Such as armenian bol (red clay), verdigris (copper acetate), borax,
And sondry vessels maad of erthe and glas,	And various vessels made of clay and glass,
Oure urynales and oure descensories,	Our urinals and our retorts,
Violes, crosletz, and sublymatories,	Vials, crucibles, and sublimation vessels,
Cucurbites and alambikes eek,	Vessels for distilling and alembics also,
And othere swiche, deere ynough a leek --	And other such things, very expensive at the price of a leek --
Nat nedeth it for to reherce hem alle --	There ia no need to list them all --
Watres rubifiyng, and boles galle,	Liquids that cause reddening, and bull's gall,
Arsenyk, sal armonyak, and brymstoon;	Arsenic, sal ammoniac, and brimstone;
And herbes koude I telle eek many oon,	And herbs could I tell also many a one,
As egremoyne, valerian, and lunarie,	Such as agrimony, valerian, and moonwort,
And othere swiche, if that me liste tarie;	And other such things, if I wanted to tarry;
Oure lampes brennyng bothe nyght and day,	Our lamps burning both night and day,
To brynge aboute oure purpos, if we may;	To bring about our purpose, if we can;
Oure fourneys eek of calcinacioun,	Also our furnace for reducing substances to powder,
And of watres albificacioun;	And of whitening by liquids;
Unslekked lym, chalk, and gleyre of an ey,	Unslaked lime, chalk, and white of an egg,
Poudres diverse, asshes, donge, pisse, and cley,	Various powders, ashes, dung, piss, and clay,
Cered pokkets, sal peter, vitriole,	Waxed (waterproofed) packets, saltpeter, sulphuric acid,
And diverse fires maad of wode and cole;	And various sorts of fires made of wood and coal;
Sal tartre, alkaly, and sal preparat,	Potassium nitrate, alkali, and purified salt,
And combust materes and coagulat;	And burned materials and solidified;
Cley maad with hors or mannes heer, and oille	Clay made with horse or man's hair, and oil
Of tartre, alum glas, berme, wort, and argoille,	Of tartar, crystallized alum, yeast, unfermented malt, and argol,
Resalgar, and oure materes enbibyng,	Arsenic, and soaking our materials,
And eek of oure materes encorporyng,	And also of forming a compound of our materials,
And of oure silver citrinacioun,	And of turning our silver to a yellow color,
Oure cementyng and fermentacioun,	Our fusion by heat and fermentation,
Oure yngottes, testes, and many mo.	Our casting molds, crucibles for testing, and many more.
I wol yow telle, as was me taught also,	I will tell you, as it was taught also to me,
The foure spirites and the bodies sevene,	The four spirits and the seven metals
By ordre, as ofte I herde my lord hem nevene.	By order, as often I heard my lord name them.
The firste spirit quyksilver called is,	The first spirit is called quicksilver,
The seconde orpyment, the thridde, ywis,	The second orpiment (arsenic trisulfide), the third, indeed,
Sal armonyak, and the ferthe brymstoon.	Sal ammoniac, and the fourth brimstone.
The bodyes sevene eek, lo, hem heere anoon:	The seven metals also, lo, hear them now:
Sol gold is, and Luna silver we insist,	Sun is gold, and Moon silver we say,
Mars iren, Mercurie quyksilver we clepe,	Mars iron, Mercury we call quicksilver,
Saturnus leed, and Juppiter is tyn,	Saturn lead, and Jupiter is tin,
And Venus coper, by my fader kyn!	And Venus copper, by my father's kin!
This cursed craft whoso wole excercise,	Whoever will exercise this cursed craft,
He shal no good han that hym may suffise,	He shall have no wealth that can be enough for him,
For al the good he spendeth theraboute	For all the wealth he spends on this
He lese shal; therof have I no doute.	He shall lose; of that have I no doubt.
Whoso that listeth outen his folie,	Whoever desires to make public his folly,
Lat hym come forth and lerne multiplie;	Let him come forth and learn to transmute base metals;
And every man that oght hath in his cofre,	And every man that has anything in his strong-box,
Lat hym appiere and wexe a philosophre.	Let him appear and become an alchemist.
Ascaunce that craft is so light to leere?	Is that craft were so easy to learn?
Nay, nay, God woot, al be he monk or frere,	Nay, nay, God knows, be he monk or friar,
Preest or chanoun, or any oother wyght,	Priest or canon, or any other creature,
Though he sitte at his book bothe day and nyght	Though he sit at his book both day and night
In lernyng of this elvysshe nyce loore,	In learning of this mysterious foolish lore,
Al is in veyn, and parde, muchel moore.	All is in vain, and by God, much more.
To lerne a lewed man this subtiltee --	To teach an ignorant man this ingenious skill --
Fy! Spek nat therof, for it wol nat bee.	Fie! Speak not about that, for it will not be.
And konne he letterure or konne he noon,	And know he book learning or know he none,
As in effect, he shal fynde it al oon.	In fact, he shall find it all the same.
For bothe two, by my savacioun,	For both of the two, by my salvation,
Concluden in multiplicacioun	Conclude in transmutation
Ylike wel, whan they han al ydo;	Equally well, when they are all done;
This is to seyn, they faillen bothe two.	This is to say, they fail, both of the two.
Yet forgat I to maken rehersaille	Yet I forgot to make enumeration
Of watres corosif, and of lymaille,	Of acidic waters, and of metal filings,
And of bodies mollificacioun,	And of the softening of materials,
And also of hire induracioun;	And also of their hardening;
Oilles, ablucions, and metal fusible --	Oils, cleansings, and fusible metal --
To tellen al wolde passen any bible	To tell all would be longer than any large book
That owher is; wherfore, as for the beste,	That is anywhere; therefore, as for the best,
Of alle thise names now wol I me reste,	Of all these names now I will rest myself,
For, as I trowe, I have yow toold ynowe	For, as I believe, I have told you enough
To reyse a feend, al looke he never so rowe.	To raise a fiend, though he look never so rough.
A! Nay! Lat be; the philosophres stoon,	Ah! Nay! Let be; the philosophers' stone,
Elixer clept, we sechen faste echoon;	Called Elixir, we seek earnestly each one of us;
For hadde we hym, thanne were we siker ynow.	For if we had it, then we would be very well off.
But unto God of hevene I make avow,	But unto God of heaven I make avow,
For al oure craft, whan we han al ydo,	Despite all our craft, when we have all done,
And al oure sleighte, he wol nat come us to.	And all our skill, he will not come us to.
He hath ymaad us spenden muchel good,	He has made us spend much money,
For sorwe of which almoost we wexen wood,	For sorrow of which we almost go mad,
But that good hope crepeth in oure herte,	Except that good hope creeps into our heart,
Supposynge evere, though we sore smerte,	Supposing ever, though we sorely suffer,
To be releeved by hym afterward.	To be relieved by him afterward.
Swich supposyng and hope is sharp and hard;	Such supposing and hope is sharp and hard;
I warne yow wel, it is to seken evere.	I warn you well, it is to keep seeking forever.
That futur temps hath maad men to dissevere,	That future tense has made men to be separated,
In trust therof, from al that evere they hadde.	In trust on that, from all that ever they had.
Yet of that art they kan nat wexen sadde,	Yet of that art they can not be satisfied,
For unto hem it is a bitter sweete --	For unto them it is a bitter sweet --
So semeth it -- for nadde they but a sheete	So it seems -- for had they nothing but a sheet
Which that they myghte wrappe hem inne a-nyght,	Which they might wrap themselves in at night,
And a brat to walken inne by daylyght,	And a rough cloak to walk in by daylight,
They wolde hem selle and spenden on this craft.	They would sell them and spend it on this craft.
They kan nat stynte til no thyng be laft.	They can not stop until nothing is left.
And everemoore, where that evere they goon,	And evermore, wherever they go,
Men may hem knowe by smel of brymstoon.	Men can know them by the smell of brimstone.
For al the world they stynken as a goot;	For all the world they stink like a goat;
Hir savour is so rammyssh and so hoot	Their odor is so like a goat and so intense
That though a man from hem a mile be,	That though a man be a mile from them,
The savour wole infecte hym, trusteth me.	The odor will infect him, trust me.
Lo, thus by smellyng and threedbare array,	Lo, thus by smelling and threadbare array,
If that men liste, this folk they knowe may.	If men so desire, this folk they can know.
And if a man wole aske hem pryvely	And if a man will ask them privily
Why they been clothed so unthriftily,	Why they are clothed so poorly,
They right anon wol rownen in his ere,	They right away will whisper in his ear,
And seyn that if that they espied were,	And say that if they were recognized,
Men wolde hem slee by cause of hir science.	Men would slay them because of their knowledge.
Lo, thus this folk bitrayen innocence!	Lo, thus these folk betray innocence!
Passe over this; I go my tale unto.	Pass over this; I go unto my tale.
Er that the pot be on the fir ydo,	Before the pot on the fire is done,
Of metals with a certeyn quantitee,	With a specific quantity of metals,
My lord hem tempreth, and no man but he --	My lord tempers them, and no man but he --
Now he is goon, I dar seyn boldely --	Now he is gone, I dare say boldly --
For, as men seyn, he kan doon craftily.	For, as men say, he can work craftily.
Algate I woot wel he hath swich a name;	Although I know well he has such a reputation;
And yet ful ofte he renneth in a blame.	And yet very often he gets in trouble.
And wite ye how? Ful ofte it happeth so	And do you know how? Full often it so happens
The pot tobreketh, and farewel, al is go!	The pot shatters, and farewell, all is gone!
Thise metals been of so greet violence	These metals are of such great violence
Oure walles mowe nat make hem resistence,	The sides of our vessels can not make resistance to them,
But if they weren wroght of lym and stoon;	Unless they were made of lime and stone;
They percen so, and thurgh the wal they goon.	They pierce so, and through the wall they go.
And somme of hem synken into the ground --	And some of them sink into the ground --
Thus han we lost by tymes many a pound --	Thus have we quickly lost many a pound --
And somme are scatered al the floor aboute;	And some are scattered all over the floor;
Somme lepe into the roof. Withouten doute,	Some leap into the roof. Without doubt,
Though that the feend noght in oure sighte hym shewe,	Though the fiend does not show himself to our sight,
I trowe he with us be, that ilke shrewe!	I believe he is with us, that same scoundrel!
In helle, where that he is lord and sire,	In hell, where he is lord and sire,
Nis ther moore wo, ne moore rancour ne ire.	There is no greater woe, nor greater rancor nor ire.
Whan that oure pot is broke, as I have sayd,	When our pot is broken, as I have said,
Every man chit and halt hym yvele apayd.	Every man chides and considers himsef ill used.
Somme seyde it was long on the fir makyng;	Some said it was due to the making of the fire;
Somme seyde nay, it was on the blowyng --	Some said nay, it was due to the blowing --
Thanne was I fered, for that was myn office.	Then was I afraid, for that was my job.
"Straw!" quod the thridde, "ye been lewed and nyce.	"Rubbish!" said the third, "you are ignorant and foolish.
It was nat tempred as it oghte be."	It was not tempered as it ought to be."
"Nay," quod the fourthe, "stynt and herkne me.	"Nay," said the fourth, "be quiet and listen to me.
By cause oure fir ne was nat maad of beech,	Because our fire was not made of beech,
That is the cause and oother noon, so thee'ch!"	That is the cause and none other, as I may prosper!"
I kan nat telle wheron it was long,	I can not tell what it was due to,
But wel I woot greet strif is us among.	But well I know great strife is among us.

Of thise perils I wol be war eftsoone.	Of these perils I will be wary next time.
I am right siker that the pot was crased.	I am very sure that the pot was cracked.

Us moste putte oure good in aventure.	We must put our possessions at risk.

Ther was defaute in somwhat, wel I woot."	There was something wrong, I well know."
Another seyde the fir was over-hoot --	Another said the fire was too hot --
But, be it hoot or coold, I dar seye this,	But, be it hot or cold, I dare say this,
That we concluden everemoore amys.	That we conclude always with something gone wrong.
We faille of that which that we wolden have,	We fail to get that which we want to have,
And in oure madnesse everemoore we rave.	And in our madness always we rave.
And whan we been togidres everichoon,	And when we are all together every one,
Every man semeth a Salomon.	Every man seems a Solomon.
But al thyng which that shineth as the gold	But every thing thah shines like gold

Ne every appul that is fair at eye	Nor every apple that is fair to the eye
Ne is nat good, what so men clappe or crye.	Is not good, whatever men may chatter or cry.
Right so, lo, fareth it amonges us:	Right so, lo, it fares among us:
He that semeth the wiseste, by Jhesus,	He who seems the wisest, by Jesus,

And he that semeth trewest is a theef.	And he that seems truest is a thief.
That shul ye knowe, er that I fro yow wende,	That shall you know, before I from you wend,

Explicit prima pars	Ther is a chanoun of religioun
There is a canon regular	Amonges us, wolde infecte al a toun,
Amongst us, who would infect a whole town,	Thogh it as greet were as was Nynyvee,
Though it were as big as was Nineveh,	Rome, Alisaundre, Troye, and othere three.
Rome, Alexandria, Troy, and any three others.	His sleightes and his infinite falsnesse
His tricks and his infinite falseness	Ther koude no man writen, as I gesse,
No man could write, as I guess,	Though that he myghte lyve a thousand yeer.
Though he might live a thousand years.	In al this world of falshede nis his peer,
In all this world is not his equal in falsehood,	For in his termes he wol hym so wynde,
For in his technical terms he will so wrap himself,	And speke his wordes in so sly a kynde,

I will tell it here in your presence.	But worshipful chanons religious,
But worshipful religious canons,	Ne demeth nat that I sclaundre youre hous,

Although my tale be about a canon.	Of every ordre som shrewe is, pardee,

But in this case listen to what I shall say.	In Londoun was a preest, an annueleer,

Who therein had dwelled many a year,	Which was so plesaunt and so servysable
Who was so pleasant and so attentive	Unto the wyf, where as he was at table,

That she would not allow him to pay anything	For bord ne clothyng, wente he never so gaye,
For board nor clothing, went he never so gay,	And spendyng silver hadde he right ynow.
And he had plenty of spending money.	Therof no fors; I wol procede as now,
That does not not matter; I will now proceed,	And tell forth my tale of the canon
That broghte this preest to confusioun.	Who brought this priest to ruin.
This false chanon cam upon a day	This false canon came upon one day
Unto this preestes chambre, wher he lay,	Unto this priest's chamber, where he stayed,
Bisechynge hym to lene hym a certeyn	Beseeching him to lend him a certain amount
Of gold, and he wolde quite it hym ageyn.	Of gold, and he would pay it back to him again.

And if so be that thow me fynde fals,	And if it so be that thou find me false,

This preest hym took a marc, and that as swithe,	This priest gave him a mark, and that very quickly,
And this chanoun hym thanked ofte sithe,	And this canon thanked him many times,

Wherof this preest was wonder glad and fayn.	For which this priest was wonderfully glad and happy.

To swich a man I kan never seye nay."	To such a man I can never say no."

Considereth, sires, how that, in ech estaat,	Consider, sirs, how, in each social rank,
Bitwixe men and gold ther is debaat	Betwixt men and gold there is conflict
So ferforth that unnethes is ther noon.	So widespread that there is hardly any gold left.
This multiplying blent so many oon	This transmutation blinds so many a one

Philosophres speken so mystily	Philosophers speak so mystically

The philosophres sworn were everychoon	The alchemists were sworn every single one

"Ye ryde as coy and stille as dooth a mayde	"You ride as demure and quiet as does a maid
Were newe spoused, sittynge at the bord;	Who is just married, sitting at the banquet table;
This day ne herde I of youre tonge a word.	This day I heard not one word from your tongue.
I trowe ye studie aboute som sophyme;	I suppose you are thinking about some logical problem;
But Salomon seith `every thyng hath tyme.'	But Solomon says `every thing has its time.'
"For Goddes sake, as beth of bettre cheere!	"For God's sake, cheer up!
It is no tyme for to studien heere.	It is no time to study here.
Telle us som myrie tale, by youre fey!	Tell us some merry tale, by your faith!
For what man that is entred in a pley,	For whatever man is entered in a game,
He nedes moot unto the pley assente.	He of necessity must assent unto the rules.
But precheth nat, as freres doon in Lente,	But preach not, as friars do in Lent,
To make us for oure olde synnes wepe,	To make us weep for our old sins,
Ne that thy tale make us nat to slepe.	And let not thy tale put us to sleep.
"Telle us som murie thyng of aventures.	"Tell us some merry thing of adventures.
Youre termes, youre colours, and youre figures,	Your technical terms, your figures of speech, and your rhetorical devices,
Keepe hem in stoor til so be ye endite	Keep them in reserve until it so be that you compose
Heigh style, as whan that men to kynges write.	High style, as when men write to kings.
Speketh so pleyn at this tyme, we yow preye,	Speak so plainly at this time, we pray of you,
That we may understonde what ye seye."	That we can understand what you say."
This worthy clerk benignely answerde:	This worthy clerk graciously answered:
"Hooste," quod he, "I am under youre yerde;	"Host," said he, "I am under your authority;
Ye han of us as now the governance,	You have the governance of us now,
And therfore wol I do yow obeisance,	And therefore will I obey you,
As fer as resoun axeth, hardily.	So far as reason demands, indeed.
I wol yow telle a tale which that I	I will tell you a tale which I
Lerned at Padowe of a worthy clerk,	Learned at Padua from a worthy clerk,
As preved by his wordes and his werk.	As was proven by his words and his work.
He is now deed and nayled in his cheste;	He is now dead and nailed in his coffin;
I prey to God so yeve his soule reste!	I pray to God to give his soul rest.
"Fraunceys Petrak, the lauriat poete,	"Francis Petrarch, the laureate poet,
Highte this clerk, whos rethorike sweete	Was called this clerk, whose sweet rhetoric
Enlumyned al Ytaille of poetrie,	Illuminated all Italy with poetry,
As Lynyan dide of philosophie,	As Lynyan did with philosophy,
Or lawe, or oother art particuler;	Or law, or other specialized field of study;
But Deeth, that wol nat suffre us dwellen heer,	But Death, that will not allow us to remain here,
But as it were a twynklyng of an ye,	But as if it were a twinkling of an eye,
Hem bothe hath slayn, and alle shul we dye.	Has slain them both, and we all shall die.
"But forth to tellen of this worthy man	"But forth to tell of this worthy man
That taughte me this tale, as I bigan,	That taught me this tale, as I began,
I seye that first with heigh stile he enditeth,	I say that first with high style he composes,
Er he the body of his tale writeth,	Before he writes the body of his tale,
A prohemye, in the which discryveth he	A proem, in which he describes
Pemond and of Saluces the contree,	Piedmont and the country of Saluces,
And speketh of Apennyn, the hilles hye,	And speaks of the Apennines, the high hills,
That been the boundes of West Lumbardye,	That are the boundaries of West Lombardy,
And of Mount Vesulus in special,	And of Mount Vesulus in particular,
Where as the Poo out of a welle smal	Where the Po out of a small well
Taketh his firste spryngyng and his sours,	Takes its first springing and its source,
That estward ay encresseth in his cours	That eastward ever increases in its course
To Emele-ward, to Ferrare, and Venyse,	Toward Emelia, to Ferrara, and Venice,
The which a long thyng were to devyse.	Which would be a long thing to relate.
And trewely, as to my juggement,	And truly, as to my judgment,
Me thynketh it a thyng impertinent,	It seems to me a thing irrelevant,
Save that he wole conveyen his mateere;	Save that he wishes to introduce his subject matter;
But this his tale, which that ye may heere."	But this is his tale, which you may hear."
A markys whilom lord was of that lond,	A marquis once was lord of that land,
As were his worthy eldres hym bifore;	As were his worthy elders before him;
And obeisant, ay redy to his hond,	And obedient, ever ready to his hand (to do his commands),
Were alle his liges, bothe lasse and moore.	Were all his subjects, both lesser ranks and nobles.
Thus in delit he lyveth, and hath doon yoore,	Thus in delight he lives, and has done since long before,
Biloved and drad, thurgh favour of Fortune,	Beloved and feared, through favor of Fortune,
Bothe of his lordes and of his commune.	Both by his lords and by his citizenry.
Therwith he was, to speke as of lynage,	Moreover he was, to speak of lineage,
The gentilleste yborn of Lumbardye,	The most noble born in Lombardy,
A fair persone, and strong, and yong of age,	A handsome person, and strong, and young of age,
And ful of honour and of curteisye;	And full of honor and of courtesy;
Discreet ynogh his contree for to gye,	Discreet enough to govern his country,
Save in somme thynges that he was to blame;	Except in some things he was to blame;
And Walter was this yonge lordes name.	And Walter was this young lord's name.
I blame hym thus: that he considered noght	I blame him thus: that he considered not
In tyme comynge what myghte hym bityde,	In time coming what might happen to him,
But on his lust present was al his thoght,	But on his immediate pleasure was all his thought,
As for to hauke and hunte on every syde.	Such as to hawk and hunt on every side.
Wel ny alle othere cures leet he slyde,	Well nigh all other cares he let slip away,
And eek he nolde -- and that was worst of alle --	And also he would not -- and that was worst of all --
Wedde no wyf, for noght that may bifalle.	Wed any woman, for anything that may befall.
Oonly that point his peple bar so soore	Only that point his people took so badly
That flokmeele on a day they to hym wente,	That in groups on one day they went to him,
And oon of hem, that wisest was of loore --	And one of them, that wisest was in learning --
Or elles that the lord best wolde assente	Or else the one that the lord most readily would consent
That he sholde telle hym what his peple mente,	That he should tell him what his people meant,
Or elles koude he shewe wel swich mateere --	Or else he knew well how to present such a matter --
He to the markys seyde as ye shul heere:	He to the marquis said as you shall hear:
"O noble markys, youre humanitee	"O noble marquis, your graciousness
Asseureth us and yeveth us hardinesse,	Makes us confident and gives us boldness,
As ofte as tyme is of necessitee,	As often as it is time (to do so) by necessity,
That we to yow mowe telle oure hevynesse.	That we to you may tell our sorrow.
Accepteth, lord, now of youre gentillesse	Grant, lord, now of your nobility
That we with pitous herte unto yow pleyne,	That we with pitiful heart may unto you complain,
And lat youre eres nat my voys desdeyne.	And let your ears not disdain (to hear) my voice.
"Al have I noght to doone in this mateere	"Although I have nothing to do in this matter
Moore than another man hath in this place,	More than another man has in this place,
Yet for as muche as ye, my lord so deere,	Yet for as much as you, my lord so dear,
Han alwey shewed me favour and grace	Have always shown me favor and grace
I dar the bettre aske of yow a space	I dare the more confidently to ask of you a time
Of audience to shewen oure requeste,	Of hearing to present our request,
And ye, my lord, to doon right as yow leste.	And you, my lord, to do right as it may please you.
"For certes, lord, so wel us liketh yow	"For certainly, lord, so well you please us
And al youre werk, and evere han doon, that we	And all your actions, and ever have done so, that we
Ne koude nat us self devysen how	Could not ourselves imagine how
We myghte lyven in moore felicitee,	We might live in more happiness,
Save o thyng, lord, if it youre wille be,	Save one thing, lord, if it be your will,
That for to been a wedded man yow leste;	That you would desire to be a wedded man;
Thanne were youre peple in sovereyn hertes reste.	Then your people would be in complete peace of mind.
"Boweth youre nekke under that blisful yok	"Bow your neck under that blissful yoke
Of soveraynetee, noght of servyse,	Of sovereignty, not of servitude,
Which that men clepe spousaille or wedlok;	Which men call marriage or wedlock;
And thenketh, lord, among youre thoghtes wyse	And think, lord, among your wise thoughts
How that oure dayes passe in sondry wyse,	How our days pass in various ways,
For thogh we slepe, or wake, or rome, or ryde,	For though we sleep, or wake, or roam, or ride,
Ay fleeth the tyme; it nyl no man abyde.	Ever flees the time; it will wait for no man.
"And thogh youre grene youthe floure as yit,	"And though your green youth flowers as yet,
In crepeth age alwey, as stille as stoon,	In creeps age always, as still as stone,
And deeth manaceth every age, and smyt	And death menaces every age, and smites
In ech estaat, for ther escapeth noon;	In each rank, for there escapes no one;
And al so certein as we knowe echoon	And just as certainly as we know, each one of us,
That we shul deye, as uncerteyn we alle	That we shall die, as uncertain we all
Been of that day whan deeth shal on us falle.	Are of that day when death shall on us fall.
"Accepteth thanne of us the trewe entente,	"Accept then the true intent of us,
That nevere yet refuseden youre heeste,	Who never yet refused your command,
And we wol, lord, if that ye wole assente,	And we will, lord, if you will assent,
Chese yow a wyf, in short tyme atte leeste,	Chose a wife for you, in short time at the least,
Born of the gentilleste and of the meeste	Born of the most noble and of the greatest (in rank)
Of al this land, so that it oghte seme	Of all this land, so that it must seem
Honour to God and yow, as we kan deeme.	Honor to God and you, so far as we can judge.
"Delivere us out of al this bisy drede,	"Deliver us out of all this constant fear,
And taak a wyf, for hye Goddes sake!	And take a wife, for high God's sake!
For if it so bifelle, as God forbede,	For if it so happen, may God forbid,
That thurgh youre deeth youre lyne sholde slake,	That through your death your line should die out,
And that a straunge successour sholde take	And that a foreign successor should take
Youre heritage, O wo were us alyve!	Your heritage, O woe would it be to us in our lifetime!
Wherfore we pray you hastily to wyve."	Wherefore we pray you hastily to take a wife."
Hir meeke preyere and hir pitous cheere	Their meek prayer and their pitiful manner
Made the markys herte han pitee.	Made the marquis's heart have pity.
"Ye wol," quod he, "myn owene peple deere,	"You want," said he, "my own people dear,
To that I nevere erst thoughte streyne me.	That which I never before thought to compel myself.
I me rejoysed of my liberte,	I rejoiced in my liberty,
That seelde tyme is founde in mariage;	That seldom is found in marriage;
Ther I was free, I moot been in servage.	Where I was free, I must be in servitude.
"But nathelees I se youre trewe entente,	"But nevertheless I see your true intent,
And truste upon youre wit, and have doon ay;	And trust upon your intelligence, and always have done so;
Wherfore of my free wyl I wole assente	Therefore of my free will I will assent
To wedde me, as soone as evere I may.	To wed, as soon as ever I can.
But ther as ye han profred me to-day	But insofar as you have offered me to-day
To chese me a wyf, I yow relesse	To choose me a wife, I release you
That choys and prey yow of that profre cesse.	(From making) that choice and pray you to cease (making) that offer.
"For God it woot, that children ofte been	"For God knows it, that children often are
Unlyk hir worthy eldres hem bifore;	Unlike their worthy elders (who came) before them;
Bountee comth al of God, nat of the streen	All goodness comes from God, not from the lineage
Of which they been engendred and ybore.	By which they are conceived and born.
I truste in Goddes bountee, and therfore	I trust in God's goodness, and therefore
My mariage and myn estaat and reste	My marriage and my estate and peace of mind
I hym bitake; he may doon as hym leste.	I entrust to him; he may do as he pleases.
"Lat me allone in chesynge of my wyf --	"Let me alone in the choosing of my wife --
That charge upon my bak I wole endure.	That responsibility upon my back I will endure.
But I yow preye, and charge upon youre lyf,	But I you pray, and order you upon your life,
What wyf that I take, ye me assure	Whatever wife I take, you me assure
To worshipe hire, whil that hir lyf may dure,	To honor her, while her life may endure,
In word and werk, bothe heere and everywheere,	In word and deed, both here and everywhere,
As she an emperoures doghter weere.	As if she were an emperor's daughter.
"And forthermoore, this shal ye swere: that ye	"And furthermore, this shall you swear: that you
Agayn my choys shul neither grucche ne stryve;	Against my choice shall neither grouch nor strive;
For sith I shal forgoon my libertee	For since I must forgo my liberty
At youre requeste, as evere moot I thryve,	At your request, as ever I may thrive,
Ther as myn herte is set, ther wol I wyve;	Where my heart is set, there will I take a wife;
And but ye wole assente in swich manere,	And unless you will assent in such a manner,
I prey yow, speketh namoore of this matere."	I pray you, speak no more of this matter."
With hertely wyl they sworen and assenten	With heartfelt will they swore and assent
To al this thyng -- ther seyde no wight nay --	To all this thing -- there said no person nay --
Bisekynge hym of grace, er that they wenten,	Beseeching him of grace, before they went,
That he wolde graunten hem a certein day	That he would grant them a fixed day
Of his spousaille, as soone as evere he may;	Of his wedding, as soon as ever he can;
For yet alwey the peple somwhat dredde,	For yet always the people somewhat dreaded,
Lest that the markys no wyf wolde wedde.	Lest the marquis no wife would wed.
He graunted hem a day, swich as hym leste,	He granted them a day, such as he pleased,
On which he wolde be wedded sikerly,	On which he would be wedded surely,
And seyde he dide al this at hir requeste.	And said he did all this at their request.
And they, with humble entente, buxomly,	And they, with humble good will, obediently,
Knelynge upon hir knees ful reverently,	Kneeling upon their knees full reverently,
Hym thonken alle; and thus they han an ende	All thanked him; and thus they have a conclusion
Of hire entente, and hoom agayn they wende.	In accord with their wishes, and home again they go.
And heerupon he to his officeres	And thereupon he to his officers
Comaundeth for the feste to purveye,	Commands the feast to prepare,
And to his privee knyghtes and squieres	And to his household knights and squires
Swich charge yaf as hym liste on hem leye;	Gave such orders as he desired to lay on them;
And they to his comandement obeye,	And they to his commandment obey,
And ech of hem dooth al his diligence	And each of them does all his efforts
To doon unto the feeste reverence.	To lend honor unto the feast.
Noght fer fro thilke paleys honurable,	Not far from that same noble palace,
Wher as this markys shoop his mariage,	Where this marquis planned his marriage,
There stood a throop, of site delitable,	There stood a small village, in a delightful location,
In which that povre folk of that village	In which poor folk of that village
Hadden hir beestes and hir herbergage,	Had their beasts and their dwellings
And of hire labour tooke hir sustenance,	And of their labor took their sustenance,
After that the erthe yaf hem habundance.	According to what produce the earth gave them.
Amonges thise povre folk ther dwelte a man	Among these poor folk there dwelt a man
Which that was holden povrest of hem alle;	Who was considered poorest of them all;
But hye God somtyme senden kan	But high God sometimes can send
His grace into a litel oxes stalle;	His grace into a little ox's stall;
Janicula men of that throop hym calle.	Janicula men of that village call him.
A doghter hadde he, fair ynogh to sighte,	A daughter had he, fair enough in appearance,
And Grisildis this yonge mayden highte.	And Griselda this young maiden was called.
But for to speke of vertuous beautee,	But to speak of virtuous beauty,
Thanne was she oon the faireste under sonne;	Then was she the fairest of all under sun;
For povreliche yfostred up was she,	Because she was raised in poverty,
No likerous lust was thurgh hire herte yronne.	No sensual desire had run through her heart.
Wel ofter of the welle than of the tonne	Much more often of the well than of the wine barrel
She drank, and for she wolde vertu plese,	She drank, and because she would satisfy the demands of virtue
She knew wel labour but noon ydel ese.	She knew well labor but no idle ease.
But thogh this mayde tendre were of age,	But though this maid was tender of age,
Yet in the brest of hire virginitee	Yet in the breast of her virginity
Ther was enclosed rype and sad corage;	There was enclosed a mature and steadfast spirit;
And in greet reverence and charitee	And in great reverence and charity
Hir olde povre fader fostred shee.	Her old poor father she cared for.
A fewe sheep, spynnynge, on feeld she kepte;	A few sheep, while spinning, on field she kept;
She wolde noght been ydel til she slepte.	She would not be idle until she slept.
And whan she homward cam, she wolde brynge	And when she homeward came, she would bring
Wortes or othere herbes tymes ofte,	Cabbages or other greens very often,
The whiche she shredde and seeth for hir lyvynge,	Which she shredded and boiled for their sustenance
And made hir bed ful hard and nothyng softe;	And made her bed full hard and not at all soft;
And ay she kepte hir fadres lyf on-lofte	And ever she sustained her father's life
With everich obeisaunce and diligence	With every obedience and diligence
That child may doon to fadres reverence.	That child may do to father's reverence.
Upon Grisilde, this povre creature,	Upon Griselda, this poor creature,
Ful ofte sithe this markys sette his ye	Very many times this marquis set his eye
As he on huntyng rood paraventure;	By chance, as he on hunting rode;
And whan it fil that he myghte hire espye,	And when it happened that he might see her,
He noght with wantown lookyng of folye	He not with lecherous looking of folly
His eyen caste on hire, but in sad wyse	His eyes cast on hire, but in serious manner
Upon hir chiere he wolde hym ofte avyse,	Upon her demeanor he would often think,
Commendynge in his herte hir wommanhede,	Commending in his heart her womanly qualities,
And eek hir vertu, passynge any wight	And also her virtue, passing any person
Of so yong age, as wel in chiere as dede.	Of so young age, as well in manner as deed.
For thogh the peple have no greet insight	For though the people have no great insight
In vertu, he considered ful right	In virtue, he considered very carefully
Hir bountee, and disposed that he wolde	Her goodness, and decided that he would
Wedde hire oonly, if evere he wedde sholde.	Wed her only, if ever he should wed.
The day of weddyng cam, but no wight kan	The day of wedding came, but no person can
Telle what womman that it sholde be;	Tell what woman it should be;
For which merveille wondred many a man,	For which marvel wondered many a man,
And seyden, whan they were in privetee,	And said, when they were in private,
"Wol nat oure lord yet leve his vanytee?	"Will not our lord yet leave his vanity?
Wol he nat wedde? Allas! Allas, the while!	Will he not wed? Alas! Alas, the times!
Why wole he thus hymself and us bigile?"	Why will he thus himself and us deceive?"
But nathelees this markys hath doon make	But nevertheless this marquis has made
Of gemmes, set in gold and in asure,	Of gems, set in gold and in azure,
Brooches and rynges, for Grisildis sake;	Brooches and rings, for Griselda's sake;
And of hir clothyng took he the mesure	And of her clothing he took the measure
By a mayde lyk to hire stature,	By a maid like her (in) stature,
And eek of othere aornementes alle	And also of all other ornaments
That unto swich a weddyng sholde falle.	That unto such a wedding should be appropriate.
The time of undren of the same day	The time of mid-morning of the same day
Approcheth, that this weddyng sholde be,	Approaches, when this wedding should be,
And al the paleys put was in array,	And all the palace was put in proper order,
Bothe halle and chambres, ech in his degree;	Both hall and chambers, each in its turn;
Houses of office stuffed with plentee	Storage buildings stuffed with plenty,
Ther maystow seen, of deyntevous vitaille	There canst thou see, of delicious foods
That may be founde as fer as last Ytaille.	What can be found from as far as farthest Italy.
This roial markys, richely arrayed,	This royal marquis, richly arrayed,
Lordes and ladyes in his compaignye,	Lords and ladies in his company,
The whiche that to the feeste weren yprayed,	Who were invited to the feast,
And of his retenue the bachelrye,	And of his retinue the knights,
With many a soun of sondry melodye,	With many a sound of varied melody,
Unto the village of the which I tolde	Unto the village of which I told
In this array the righte wey han holde.	In this splendid array the direct route have held.
Grisilde of this, God woot, ful innocent,	Griselda of this, God knows, full ignorant,
That for hire shapen was al this array,	That for her was all this splendour prepared,
To fecchen water at a welle is went,	Has gone to fetch water at a well,
And cometh hoom as soone as ever she may;	And comes home as soon as ever she can;
For wel she hadde herd seyd that thilke day	For well she had heard said that same day
The markys sholde wedde, and if she myghte,	The marquis should wed, and if she could,
She wolde fayn han seyn som of that sighte.	She would be happy to have seen some of that sight.
She thoghte, "I wole with othere maydens stonde,	She thought, "I will stand with other maidens,
That been my felawes, in oure dore and se	Who are my fellows, in our door and see
The markysesse, and therfore wol I fonde	The marchioness, and therefore will I try
To doon at hoom, as soone as it may be,	To do at home, as soon as it can be,
The labour which that longeth unto me,	The chores that I must do,
And thanne I may at leyser hire biholde,	And then I may at leisure her behold,
If she this wey unto the castel holde."	If she takes this way to the castle."
And as she wolde over hir threshold gon,	And as she would over her threshold go,
The markys cam and gan hire for to calle;	The marquis came and called her;
And she set doun hir water pot anon,	And she set down her water pot quickly,
Biside the thresshfold, in an oxes stalle,	Beside the threshold, in an ox's stall,
And doun upon hir knes she gan to falle,	And down upon her knees she fell,
And with sad contenance kneleth stille,	And with sober countenance kneels without speaking,
Til she had herd what was the lordes wille.	Until she had heard what was the lord's will.
This thoghtful markys spak unto this mayde	This pensive marquis spoke unto this maid
Ful sobrely, and seyde in this manere:	Full soberly, and said in this manner:
"Where is youre fader, O Grisildis?" he sayde.	"Where is your father, O Griselda?" he said.
And she with reverence, in humble cheere,	And she with reverence, in humble manner,
Answerde, "Lord, he is al redy heere."	Answered, "Lord, he is right here."
And in she gooth withouten lenger lette,	And in she goes without longer delay,
And to the markys she hir fader fette.	And to the marquis she fetched her father.
He by the hand thanne took this olde man,	He by the hand then took this old man,
And seyde thus, whan he hym hadde asyde:	And said thus, when he had him aside:
"Janicula, I neither may ne kan	"Janicula, I neither may nor can
Lenger the plesance of myn herte hyde.	Longer hide the desire of my heart.
If that thou vouche sauf, what so bityde,	If thou agree, whatsoever may happen,
Thy doghter wol I take, er that I wende,	Thy daughter will I take, before I depart,
As for my wyf, unto hir lyves ende.	For my wife, until her life's end.
"Thou lovest me, I woot it wel certeyn,	"Thou lovest me, I know it well for certain,
And art my feithful lige man ybore,	And art my faithful liege man born,
And al that liketh me, I dar wel seyn	And all that pleases me, I dare well say
It liketh thee, and specially therfore	It pleases thee, and specially therefore
Tel me that poynt that I have seyd bifore,	Tell me of that question that I have stated previously,
If that thou wolt unto that purpos drawe,	If thou will agree with that proposal,
To take me as for thy sone-in-lawe."	To take me for thy son-in-law."
This sodeyn cas this man astonyed so	This sudden occurrence this man so astounded
That reed he wax; abayst and al quakynge	That he grew red; abashed and all trembling
He stood; unnethes seyde he wordes mo,	He stood; hardly said he any more words,
But oonly thus: "Lord," quod he, "my willynge	But only thus: "Lord," said he, "my desire
Is as ye wole, ne ayeynes youre likynge	Is as you wish, and against your pleasure
I wol no thyng, ye be my lord so deere;	I will do nothing, you are my lord so dear;
Right as yow lust, governeth this mateere."	Right as you please, govern this matter."
"Yet wol I," quod this markys softely,	"Yet I want," said this marquis softly,
"That in thy chambre I and thou and she	"That in thy chamber I and thou and she
Have a collacioun, and wostow why?	Have a discussion, and knowest thou why?
For I wol axe if it hire wille be	For I will ask if it be her will
To be my wyf and reule hire after me.	To be my wife and conduct herself as I decide.
And al this shal be doon in thy presence;	And all this shall be done in thy presence;
I wol noght speke out of thyn audience."	I will say nothing out of thy hearing."
And in the chambre, whil they were aboute	And in the chamber, while they were engaged in
Hir tretys, which as ye shal after heere,	Their negotiation, which you shall after hear,
The peple cam unto the hous withoute,	The people came unto outside the house,
And wondred hem in how honest manere	And wondered in what a virtuous manner
And tentifly she kepte hir fader deere.	And how attentively she cared for her dear father.
But outrely Grisildis wondre myghte,	But certainly Griselda might wonder,
For nevere erst ne saugh she swich a sighte.	For never before saw she such a sight.
No wonder is thogh that she were astoned	Though it is no wonder that she was astonished
To seen so greet a gest come in that place;	To see so great a guest come in that place;
She nevere was to swiche gestes woned,	She never was accustomed to such guests,
For which she looked with ful pale face.	For which she looked full pale in her face.
But shortly forth this matere for to chace,	But shortly forth this matter to pursue,
Thise arn the wordes that the markys sayde	These are the words that the marquis said
To this benigne, verray, feithful mayde:	To this benign, true, faithful maid:
"Grisilde," he seyde, "ye shal wel understonde	"Griselda," he said, "you shall well understand
It liketh to youre fader and to me	It is pleasing to your father and to me
That I yow wedde, and eek it may so stonde,	That I you wed, and also it may so stand,
As I suppose, ye wol that it so be.	As I suppose, that you desire that it so be.
But thise demandes axe I first," quod he,	But these questions ask I first," said he,
"That, sith it shal be doon in hastif wyse,	"That, since it shall be done in a hasty manner,
Wol ye assente, or elles yow avyse?	Will you assent, or else think it over?
"I seye this: be ye redy with good herte	"I say this: are you ready (to submit) with good heart
To al my lust, and that I frely may,	To all my desires, and that I freely may,
As me best thynketh, do yow laughe or smerte,	As seems best to me, make you laugh or feel pain,
And nevere ye to grucche it, nyght ne day?	And you never to grouch about it, at any time?
And eek whan I sey `ye,' ne sey nat `nay,'	And also when I say `yes,' say not `nay,'
Neither by word ne frownyng contenance?	Neither by word nor frowning countenance?
Swere this, and heere I swere oure alliance."	Swear this, and here I swear our alliance."
Wondrynge upon this word, quakynge for drede,	Wondering upon these words, trembling for fear,
She seyde, "Lord, undigne and unworthy	She said, "Lord, unsuitable and unworthy
Am I to thilke honour that ye me beede,	Am I of that same honor that you offer me,
But as ye wole youreself, right so wol I.	But as you desire yourself, right so desire I.
And heere I swere that nevere willyngly,	And here I swear that never willingly,
In werk ne thoght, I nyl yow disobeye,	In deed nor thought, will I disobey you,
For to be deed, though me were looth to deye."	Even to be dead, though I would hate to die."
"This is ynogh, Grisilde myn," quod he.	"This is enough, Griselda mine," said he.
And forth he gooth with a ful sobre cheere	And forth he goes with a full sober manner
Out at the dore, and after that cam she,	Out of the door, and after that came she,
And to the peple he seyde in this manere:	And to the people he said in this manner:
"This is my wyf," quod he, "that standeth heere.	"This is my wife," said he, "that stands here.
Honoureth hire and loveth hire, I preye,	Honor her and love her, I pray,
Whoso me loveth; ther is namoore to seye."	Whoever loves me; there is no more to say."
And for that no thyng of hir olde geere	And so that nothing of her old belongings
She sholde brynge into his hous, he bad	She should bring into his house, he ordered
That wommen sholde dispoillen hire right theere;	That women should undress her right there;
Of which thise ladyes were nat right glad	Of which these ladies were not very happy
To handle hir clothes, wherinne she was clad.	To handle her clothes, in which she was clad.
But nathelees, this mayde bright of hewe	But nevertheless, this maid bright of hue
Fro foot to heed they clothed han al newe.	From foot to head they have clothed all new.
Hir heris han they kembd, that lay untressed	Her hair have they combed, that lay unkempt
Ful rudely, and with hir fyngres smale	Very crudely, and with their elegant fingers
A corone on hire heed they han ydressed,	A crown on her head they have placed,
And sette hire ful of nowches grete and smale.	And set her garments full of jeweled ornaments of every sort.
Of hire array what sholde I make a tale?	Of her appearance why should I make a long tale?
Unnethe the peple hir knew for hire fairnesse	The hardly people knew her for her beauty
Whan she translated was in swich richesse.	When she was translated into such riches.
This markys hath hire spoused with a ryng	This marquis has espoused her with a ring
Broght for the same cause, and thanne hire sette	Brought for the same purpose, and then set her
Upon an hors, snow-whit and wel amblyng,	Upon a horse, snow-white and with a gentle pace,
And to his paleys, er he lenger lette,	And to his palace, before he longer delayed,
With joyful peple that hire ladde and mette,	With joyful people that led and met her,
Conveyed hire; and thus the day they spende	Conducted her; and thus the day they spend
In revel, til the sonne gan descende.	In revel, until the sun descended.
And shortly forth this tale for to chace,	And shortly forth this tale to pursue,
I seye that to this newe markysesse	I say that to this new marchioness
God hath swich favour sent hire of his grace	God has such favor sent her of his grace
That it ne semed nat by liklynesse	That it seemed not likely
That she was born and fed in rudenesse,	That she was born and fed in humble circumstances,
As in a cote or in an oxe-stalle,	In a peasant's hut or in an ox-stall,
But norissed in an emperoures halle.	But nurtured in an emperor's hall.
To every wight she woxen is so deere	To every person she is grown so dear
And worshipful that folk ther she was bore,	And worshipful that folk where she was born,
And from hire birthe knewe hire yeer by yeere,	And from her birth knew her year by year,
Unnethe trowed they -- but dorste han swore --	They hardly believed -- but dared have sworn --
That to Janicle, of which I spak bifore,	That to Janicle, of whom I spoke before,
She doghter were, for, as by conjecture,	She was daughter, for, by conjecture,
Hem thoughte she was another creature.	They thought she was another creature.
For though that evere vertuous was she,	For though that she was always virtuous,
She was encressed in swich excellence	She was increased in such excellence
Of thewes goode, yset in heigh bountee,	Of good characteristics, set in high goodness,
And so discreet and fair of eloquence,	And so discreet and fair of eloquence,
So benigne and so digne of reverence,	So benign and so worthy of reverence,
And koude so the peples herte embrace,	And could so the people's heart embrace,
That ech hire lovede that looked on hir face.	That each who looked on her face loved her.
Noght oonly of Saluces in the toun	Not only in the town of Saluces
Publiced was the bountee of hir name,	Was made known the praise of her name,
But eek biside in many a regioun,	But also moreover in many a region,
If oon seide wel, another seyde the same;	If one said well, another said the same;
So spradde of hire heighe bountee the fame	So spread the fame of her high goodness
That men and wommen, as wel yonge as olde,	That men and women, as well young as old,
Goon to Saluce upon hire to biholde.	Go to Saluce to look upon her.
Thus Walter lowely -- nay, but roially --	Thus Walter lowly -- nay, but royally --
Wedded with fortunat honestetee,	Wedded with beneficial virtue,
In Goddes pees lyveth ful esily	In God's peace lives full easily
At hoom, and outward grace ynogh had he;	At home, and to all appearances he had sufficient happiness;
And for he saugh that under low degree	And because he saw that under low social rank
Was ofte vertu hid, the peple hym heelde	Was often virtue hid, the people considered him
A prudent man, and that is seyn ful seelde.	A prudent man, and that is seen full seldom.
Nat oonly this Grisildis thurgh hir wit	Not only this Griselda through her wit
Koude al the feet of wyfly hoomlinesse,	Knew all the skills of a housewife's duties,
But eek, whan that the cas required it,	But also, when the situation required it,
The commune profit koude she redresse.	The public good could she promote.
Ther nas discord, rancour, ne hevynesse	There was no discord, rancor, nor sadness
In al that land that she ne koude apese,	In all that land that she could not alleviate,
And wisely brynge hem alle in reste and ese.	And wisely bring them all in rest and ease.
Though that hire housbonde absent were anon,	Though her husband was absent at the time,
If gentil men or othere of hire contree	If noble men or others of her country
Were wrothe, she wolde bryngen hem aton;	Were wroth, she would bring them to agreement;
So wise and rype wordes hadde she,	Such wise and well considered words had she,
And juggementz of so greet equitee,	And judgments of such great justice,
That she from hevene sent was, as men wende,	That she was sent from heaven, as men supposed,
Peple to save and every wrong t'amende.	People to save and every wrong to amend.
Nat longe tyme after that this Grisild	Not long time after this Griselda
Was wedded, she a doghter hath ybore,	Was married, she has borne a daughter,
Al had hire levere have born a knave child;	Although she would rather have given birth to a male child;
Glad was this markys and the folk therfore,	Glad was this marquis and the folk for this,
For though a mayde child coome al bifore,	For though a maid child came all before,
She may unto a knave child atteyne	She may unto a male child attain
By liklihede, syn she nys nat bareyne.	By likelihood, since she is not barren.
Ther fil, as it bifalleth tymes mo,	There happened, as it befalls many times,
Whan that this child had souked but a throwe,	When this child had suckled but a short time,
This markys in his herte longeth so	This marquis in his heart longs so
To tempte his wyf, hir sadnesse for to knowe,	To test his wife, her constancy to know,
That he ne myghte out of his herte throwe	That he could not out of his heart throw
This merveillous desir his wyf t'assaye;	This strange desire to test his wife;
Nedelees, God woot, he thoghte hire for t'affraye.	Needless, God knows, he intended to frighten her.
He hadde assayed hire ynogh bifore,	He had tested her enough before,
And foond hire evere good; what neded it	And found her always good; why was it needed
Hire for to tempte, and alwey moore and moore,	To test her, and always more and more,
Though som men preise it for a subtil wit?	Though some men praise its ingenuity?
But as for me, I seye that yvele it sit	But as for me, I say that it ill befits one
To assaye a wyf whan that it is no nede,	To test a wife when there is no need,
And putten hire in angwyssh and in drede.	And put her in anguish and in dread.
For which this markys wroghte in this manere:	For which this marquis worked in this manner:
He cam allone a-nyght, ther as she lay,	He came alone at night, where she lay,
With stierne face and with ful trouble cheere,	With stern face and with a very troubled manner,
And seyde thus: "Grisilde," quod he, "that day	And said thus: "Griselda," said he, "that day
That I yow took out of youre povere array,	That I took you out of your impoverished situation,
And putte yow in estaat of heigh noblesse --	And put you in the condition of high nobility --
Ye have nat that forgeten, as I gesse?	You have not forgotten that, as I suppose?
"I seye, Grisilde, this present dignitee,	"I say, Griselda, this present high social position,
In which that I have put yow, as I trowe,	In which I have put you, as I believe,
Maketh yow nat foryetful for to be	Requires that you be not forgetful
That I yow took in povre estaat ful lowe,	That I took you in a poor, very humble condition,
For any wele ye moot youreselven knowe.	Despite any present prosperity you must know it yourself.
Taak heede of every word that y yow seye;	Take heed of every word that I say to you;
Ther is no wight that hereth it but we tweye.	There is no person that hears it but we two.
"Ye woot youreself wel how that ye cam heere	"You know well yourself how you came here
Into this hous, it is nat longe ago;	Into this house, it is not long ago;
And though to me that ye be lief and deere,	And though to me you are beloved and dear,
Unto my gentils ye be no thyng so.	Unto my nobles you are not at all so.
They seyn, to hem it is greet shame and wo	They say, to them it is great shame and woe
For to be subgetz and been in servage	To be subjects and be in servitude
To thee, that born art of a smal village.	To thee, that art born in a humble village.
"And namely sith thy doghter was ybore	"And especially since thy daughter was born
Thise wordes han they spoken, doutelees.	These words have they spoken, doubtless.
But I desire, as I have doon bifore,	But I desire, as I have done before,
To lyve my lyf with hem in reste and pees.	To live my life with them in rest and peace.
I may nat in this caas be recchelees;	I can not be imprudent in this case;
I moot doon with thy doghter for the beste,	I must do with thy daughter for the best,
Nat as I wolde, but as my peple leste.	Not as I would want, but as my people desire.
"And yet, God woot, this is ful looth to me;	"And yet, God knows, this is full hateful to me;
But nathelees withoute youre wityng	But nevertheless without your knowledge
I wol nat doon; but this wol I," quod he,	I will not do anything; but this I desire," said he,
"That ye to me assente as in this thyng.	"That you assent to me in this matter.
Shewe now youre pacience in youre werkyng,	Show now in your actions your patience,
That ye me highte and swore in youre village	That you promised me and swore in your village
