Whan she had herd al this, she noght ameved	When she had heard all this, she changed not
Neither in word, or chiere, or contenaunce,	Neither in word, nor manner, nor countenance,
For, as it semed, she was nat agreved.	For, as it seemed, she was not aggrieved.
She seyde, "Lord, al lyth in youre plesaunce.	She said, "Lord, all is subject to your pleasure.
My child and I, with hertely obeisaunce,	My child and I, with heart-felt obedience,
Been youres al, and ye mowe save or spille	Are entirely yours, and you may save or kill
Youre owene thyng; werketh after youre wille.	Your own thing; do as you will.
"Ther may no thyng, God so my soule save,	"There can nothing, as God my soul may save,
Liken to yow that may displese me;	Please you that may displease me;
Ne I desire no thyng for to have,	Nor do I desire to have anything,
Ne drede for to leese, save oonly yee.	Nor dread to lose, save only you.
This wyl is in myn herte, and ay shal be;	This will is in my heart, and ever shall be;
No lengthe of tyme or deeth may this deface,	No length of time or death can obliterate this,
Ne chaunge my corage to another place."	Nor change my heart to another place."
Glad was this markys of hire answeryng,	Glad was this marquis of her answer,
But yet he feyned as he were nat so;	But yet he feigned as if he were not so;
Al drery was his cheere and his lookyng,	All sorrowful was his manner and his look,
Whan that he sholde out of the chambre go.	When he had to go out of the chamber.
Soone after this, a furlong wey or two,	Soon after this, in a few minutes,
He prively hath toold al his entente	He privately has told all his plan
Unto a man, and to his wyf hym sente.	Unto a man, and sent him to his wife.
A maner sergeant was this privee man,	A sort of sergeant (policeman) was this confidential servant,
The which that feithful ofte he founden hadde	Whom he had often found faithful
In thynges grete, and eek swich folk wel kan	In important matters, and also such folk well can
Doon execucioun in thynges badde.	Carry out their orders in evil matters.
The lord knew wel that he hym loved and dradde;	The lord knew well that he loved and dreaded him;
And whan this sergeant wiste his lordes wille,	And when this sergeant knew his lord's will,
Into the chambre he stalked hym ful stille.	Into the chamber he stalked very quietly.
"Madame," he seyde, "ye moote foryeve it me,	"Madame," he said, "you must forgive it me,
Though I do thyng to which I am constreyned.	Though I do a thing to which I am constrained.
Ye been so wys that ful wel knowe ye	You are so wise that full well you know
That lordes heestes mowe nat been yfeyned;	That lords' commands may not be evaded (by feigning);
They mowe wel been biwailled or compleyned,	They may well be bewailed or complained of,
But men moote nede unto hire lust obeye,	But men must by necessity unto their desires obey,
And so wol I; ther is namoore to seye.	And so will I; there is no more to say.
"This child I am comanded for to take" --	"This child I am commanded to take" --
And spak namoore, but out the child he hente	And spoke no more, but out the child he seized
Despitously, and gan a cheere make	Mercilessly, and made a face
As though he wolde han slayn it er he wente.	As if he would have slain it before he went.
Grisildis moot al suffre and al consente,	Griselda must suffer all and consent to all,
And as a lamb she sitteth meke and stille,	And as a lamb she sits meek and still,
And leet this crueel sergeant doon his wille.	And let this cruel sergeant do his will.
Suspecious was the diffame of this man,	Suspicious was the bad reputation of this man,
Suspect his face, suspect his word also;	Suspect his face, suspect his word also;
Suspect the tyme in which he this bigan.	Suspect the time in which he this began.
Allas! Hir doghter that she loved so,	Alas! Her daughter that she loved so,
She wende he wolde han slawen it right tho.	She thought he would have slain it right then.
But nathelees she neither weep ne syked,	But nevertheless she neither wept nor sighed,
Conformynge hire to that the markys lyked.	Conforming herself to what the marquis pleased.
But atte laste to speken she bigan,	But at the last she began to speak,
And mekely she to the sergeant preyde,	And meekly she to the sergeant prayed,
So as he was a worthy gentil man,	As he was a worthy gentle man,
That she moste kisse hire child er that it deyde.	That she might kiss her child before it died.
And in hir barm this litel child she leyde	And in her lap this little child she laid

And lulled it, and after gan it kisse.	And lulled it, and afterward kissed it.
And thus she seyde in hire benigne voys,	And thus she said in her benign voice,
"Fareweel my child! I shal thee nevere see.	"Farewell my child! I shall thee never see.
But sith I thee have marked with the croys	But since I have marked thee with the cross

That for us deyde upon a croys of tree,	That for us died upon a cross of wood,
Thy soule, litel child, I hym bitake,	Thy soul, little child, I entrust to him,
For this nyght shaltow dyen for my sake."	For this night shalt thou die for my sake."
I trowe that to a norice in this cas	I believe that to a nurse in this case
It had been hard this reuthe for to se;	It would have been hard this pitiful situation to see;
Wel myghte a mooder thanne han cryd "allas!"	Well might a mother then have cried "alas!"
But nathelees so sad stidefast was she	But nevertheless so firmly steadfast was she
That she endured al adversitee,	That she endured all adversity,
And to the sergeant mekely she sayde,	And to the sergeant meekly she said,
"Have heer agayn youre litel yonge mayde.	"Have here again your little young maid.
"Gooth now," quod she, "and dooth my lordes heeste;	"Go now," said she, "and do my lord's command;

Burieth this litel body in som place	Bury this little body in some place
That beestes ne no briddes it torace."	That no beasts nor birds tear it to pieces."
But he no word wol to that purpos seye,	But he no word will say to that proposal,
But took the child and wente upon his weye.	But took the child and went upon his way.
This sergeant cam unto his lord ageyn,	This sergeant came unto his lord again,
And of Grisildis wordes and hire cheere	And of Griselda's words and her manner
He tolde hym point for point, in short and pleyn,	He told him in detail, in short and plain (words),
And hym presenteth with his doghter deere.	And presents him with his daughter dear.
Somwhat this lord hadde routhe in his manere,	Somewhat this lord had pity in his manner,
But nathelees his purpos heeld he stille,	But nevertheless his purpose held he still,
As lordes doon, whan they wol han hir wille;	As lords do, when they will have their will;
And bad this sergeant that he pryvely	And commanded this sergeant that he secretly
Sholde this child softe wynde and wrappe,	Should this child softly wind and wrap (in a blanket),
With alle circumstances tendrely,	With every care tenderly,
And carie it in a cofre or in a lappe;	And carry it in a box or in a folded cloth;
But, upon peyne his heed of for to swappe,	But, upon pain of having his head cut off,

Ne whenne he cam, ne whider that he wente;	Nor whence he came, nor whither he went;
But at Boloigne to his suster deere,	But at Bologna to his sister dear,

He sholde it take and shewe hire this mateere,	He should take it and explain to her this matter,
Bisekynge hire to doon hire bisynesse	Beseeching her to do her best

The sergeant gooth, and hath fulfild this thyng;	The sergeant goes, and has fulfilled this order;
But to this markys now retourne we.	But to this marquis we now return.
For now gooth he ful faste ymaginyng	For now he goes very intently considering
If by his wyves cheere he myghte se,	If by his wife's appearance he might see,
Or by hire word aperceyve, that she	Or by her word perceive, if she

As glad, as humble, as bisy in servyse,	As glad, as humble, as diligent in service,
And eek in love, as she was wont to be,	And also in love, as she was accustomed to be,
Was she to hym in every maner wyse;	Was she to him in every sort of way;
Ne of hir doghter noght a word spak she.	Nor of her daughter not a word spoke she.
Noon accident, for noon adversitee,	No external sign, for any adversity,
Was seyn in hire, ne nevere hir doghter name	Was seen in her, and never her daughter's name
Ne nempned she, in ernest nor in game.	Mentioned she, in earnest nor in jest (in any way).
In this estaat ther passed been foure yeer	In this condition there are passed four years
Er she with childe was, but, as God wolde,	Before she was with child, but, as God would,
A knave child she bar by this Walter,	A male child she bore by this Walter,
Ful gracious and fair for to biholde.	Very gracious and beautiful in appearance.
And whan that folk it to his fader tolde,	And when folk told it to his father,
Nat oonly he but al his contree merye	Not only he but all his country merry
Was for this child, and God they thanke and herye.	Was for this child, and God they thank and praise.
Whan it was two yeer old, and fro the brest	When it was two years old, and from the breast
Departed of his norice, on a day	Of his nurse weaned, on one day
This markys caughte yet another lest	This marquis caught yet another desire
To tempte his wyf yet ofter, if he may.	To test his wife yet again, if he can.
O nedelees was she tempted in assay!	O needless was she put to the test!
But wedded men ne knowe no mesure,	But wedded men know no moderation,
Whan that they fynde a pacient creature.	When they find a patient creature.
"Wyf," quod this markys, "ye han herd er this	"Wife," said this marquis, "you have heard before this

And namely sith my sone yboren is,	And especially since my son is born,
Now is it worse than evere in al oure age.	Now is it worse than ever in all our lives.
The murmur sleeth myn herte and my corage,	The grumbling slays my heart and my feelings,
For to myne eres comth the voys so smerte	For to my ears comes the voice so sharply
That it wel ny destroyed hath myn herte.	That it well nigh has destroyed my heart.

Thanne shal the blood of Janicle succede	Then shall the blood of Janicle succeed

For though thyn housbonde armed be in maille,	For though thy husband be armed in mail,
The arwes of thy crabbed eloquence	The arrows of thy spiteful eloquence
Shal perce his brest and eek his aventaille.	Shall pierce his breast and also his neck-guard.
In jalousie I rede eek thou hym bynde,	In jealousy I advise also that thou bind him,
And thou shalt make hym couche as doth a quaille.	And thou shalt make him cower as does a quail.
If thou be fair, ther folk been in presence,	If thou be fair, where folk are present,
Shewe thou thy visage and thyn apparaille;	Show thou thy visage and thy apparel;
If thou be foul, be fre of thy dispence;	If thou be ugly, be lavish in thy expenditures;
To gete thee freendes ay do thy travaille;	To get thee friends always work hard;
Be ay of chiere as light as leef on lynde,	Be ever in behavior as light as a leaf on a linden tree,
And lat hym care, and wepe, and wrynge, and waille!	And let him grieve, and weep, and wring his hands, and wail!
Bihoold the murye words of the Host	Behold, the merry words of the Host.
This worthy Clerk, whan ended was his tale,	When ended was the tale of this worthy Clerk,
Oure Hooste seyde, and swoor, "By Goddes bones,	Our Host said, and swore, "By God's bones,
Me were levere than a barel ale	I would rather than have a barrel of ale
My wyf at hoom had herd this legende ones!	My wife at home had heard this legend once!
This is a gentil tale for the nones,	This is a fine tale for this occasion,
As to my purpos, wiste ye my wille;	For my purposes, if you knew my will;
But thyng that wol nat be, lat it be stille."	But thing that will not be, let it be still."
The Prologue of the Nonnes Preestes Tale.	The Prologue of the Nuns and Priests Tale.
"Hoo!" quod the Knyght, "good sire, namoore of this!	"Whoa!" said the Knight, "good sire, no more of this!
That ye han seyd is right ynough, ywis,	What you have said is quite enough, indeed,
And muchel moore; for litel hevynesse	And much more; for a little sadness
Is right ynough to muche folk, I gesse.	Is quite enough for many people, I guess.
I seye for me, it is a greet disese,	I say for myself, it is a great distress,
Whereas men han been in greet welthe and ese,	When men have been in great wealth and ease,
To heeren of hire sodeyn fal, allas!	To hear of their sudden fall, alas!
And the contrarie is joye and greet solas,	And the contrary is joy and great comfort,
As whan a man hath been in povre estaat,	As when a man has been in a poor condition,
And clymbeth up and wexeth fortunat,	And climbs up and becomes fortunate,
And there abideth in prosperitee.	And there remains in prosperity.
Swich thyng is gladsom, as it thynketh me,	Such a thing is pleasing, as it seems to me,
And of swich thyng were goodly for to telle."	And of such a thing it would be good to tell."
"Ye," quod oure Hooste, "by Seint Poules belle!	"Yea," said our Host, "by Saint Paul's bell!
Ye seye right sooth; this Monk he clappeth lowde.	You say the very truth; this Monk he chatters noisily.
He spak how Fortune covered with a clowde	He spoke of how Fortune covered with a cloud
I noot nevere what; and als of a tragedie	I know not what; and also of a tragedy
Right now ye herde, and pardee, no remedie	Just now you heard, and by God, no remedy
It is for to biwaille ne compleyne	Is it to bewail or lament
That that is doon, and als it is a peyne,	That which is done, and also it is a pain,
As ye han seyd, to heere of hevynesse.	As you have said, to hear of sadness.
"Sire Monk, namoore of this, so God yow blesse!	"Sir Monk, no more of this, as God may you bless!
Youre tale anoyeth al this compaignye.	Your tale annoys all this company.
Swich talkyng is nat worth a boterflye,	Such talking is not worth a butterfly,
For therinne is ther no desport ne game.	For in it there is no pleasure nor amusement.
Wherfore, sire Monk, daun Piers by youre name,	Therefore, Sir Monk, dan Piers by your name,
I pray yow hertely telle us somwhat elles;	I pray yow earnestly tell us something else;
For sikerly, nere clynkyng of youre belles	For truly, were it not for the clinking of your bells
That on youre bridel hange on every syde,	That on your bridle hang on every side,
By hevene kyng that for us alle dyde,	By heaven's King who for us all died,
I sholde er this han fallen doun for sleep,	I should before this have fallen down because of sleepiness,
Althogh the slough had never been so deep;	Although the mud had never been so deep;
Thanne hadde your tale al be toold in veyn.	Then had your tale been told all in vain.
For certeinly, as that thise clerkes seyn,	For certainly, as these clerks say,
Whereas a man may have noon audience,	Where a man may have no hearers,
Noght helpeth it to tellen his sentence.	It is no use to tell his opinion.
"And wel I woot the substance is in me,	"And well I know the capacity of appreciation is in me,
If any thyng shal wel reported be.	If any thing shall be well told.
Sir, sey somwhat of huntyng, I yow preye."	Sir, say something about hunting, I you pray."
"Nay," quod this Monk, "I have no lust to pleye.	"Nay," said this Monk, "I have no desire to play.
Now lat another telle, as I have toold."	Now let another tell, as I have told."
Thanne spak oure Hoost with rude speche and boold,	Then spoke oure Host with rude speech and bold,
And seyde unto the Nonnes Preest anon,	And said unto the Nun's Priest straightway,
"Com neer, thou preest, com hyder, thou sir John!	"Come near, thou priest, come hither, thou sir John!
Telle us swich thyng as may oure hertes glade.	Tell us such thing as may our hearts gladden.
Be blithe, though thou ryde upon a jade.	Be happy, though thou ride upon a nag.
What thogh thyn hors be bothe foul and lene?	What if thy horse be both poor and lean?
If he wol serve thee, rekke nat a bene.	If he will serve thee, care not a bean.
Looke that thyn herte be murie everemo."	See that thy heart be merry evermore."
"Yis, sir," quod he, "yis, Hoost, so moot I go,	"Yes indeed, sir," said he, "yes indeed, Host, as I may I prosper,
But I be myrie, ywis I wol be blamed."	Unless I be merry, indeed I will be blamed."
And right anon his tale he hath attamed,	And right away his tale he has begun,
And thus he seyde unto us everichon,	And thus he said unto us every one,
This sweete preest, this goodly man sir John.	This sweet priest, this goodly man sir John.
A povre wydwe, somdeel stape in age,	A poor widow, somewhat advanced in age,
Was whilom dwellyng in a narwe cotage,	Was once dwelling in a small cottage,
Biside a grove, stondynge in a dale.	Beside a grove, standing in a dale.
This wydwe, of which I telle yow my tale,	This widow, of whom I tell you my tale,
Syn thilke day that she was last a wyf	Since that same day that she was last a wife
In pacience ladde a ful symple lyf,	In patience led a very simple life,
For litel was hir catel and hir rente.	For little was her possessions and her income.
By housbondrie of swich as God hire sente	By husbandry of such as God sent her
She foond hirself and eek hir doghtren two.	She provided for herself and also her two daughters.
Thre large sowes hadde she, and namo,	She had three large sows, and no more,
Three keen, and eek a sheep that highte Malle.	Three cows, and also a sheep that is called Malle.
Ful sooty was hire bour and eek hir halle,	Full sooty was her bedchamber and also her hall,
In which she eet ful many a sklendre meel.	In which she ate very many a scanty meal.
Of poynaunt sauce hir neded never a deel.	She needed not a bit of spicy sauce.
No deyntee morsel passed thurgh hir throte;	No dainty morsel passed through her throat;
Hir diete was accordant to hir cote.	Her diet was such as her farm produced.
Repleccioun ne made hire nevere sik;	Overeating never made her sick;
Attempree diete was al hir phisik,	Moderate diet was all her medical treatment,
And exercise, and hertes suffisaunce.	And exercise, and a contented heart.
The goute lette hire nothyng for to daunce,	The gout not at all prevented her from dancing,
N' apoplexie shente nat hir heed.	And apoplexy harmed not her head.
No wyn ne drank she, neither whit ne reed;	No wine she drank, neither white nor red;
Hir bord was served moost with whit and blak --	Her board was provided mostly with white and black --
Milk and broun breed, in which she foond no lak,	Milk and dark bread, in which she found no lack,
Seynd bacoun, and somtyme an ey or tweye,	Broiled bacon, and sometimes an egg or two,
For she was, as it were, a maner deye.	For she was, as it were, a sort of dairywoman.
A yeerd she hadde, enclosed al aboute	She had a yard, enclosed all around
With stikkes, and a drye dych withoute,	With sticks, and a dry ditch outside it,
In which she hadde a cok, hight Chauntecleer.	In which she had a cock, called Chauntecleer.
In al the land, of crowyng nas his peer.	In all the land, there was not his peer in crowing.
His voys was murier than the murie orgon	His voice was merrier than the merry organ
On messe-dayes that in the chirche gon.	That goes in the church on mass-days.
Wel sikerer was his crowyng in his logge	Well more accurate was his crowing in his lodge
Than is a clokke or an abbey orlogge.	Than is a clock or an abbey timepiece.
By nature he knew ech ascencioun	By nature he knew (the hour of) each ascension
Of the equynoxial in thilke toun;	Of the celestial equator in that same town;
For whan degrees fiftene weren ascended,	For when degrees fifteen were ascended,
Thanne crew he that it myghte nat been amended.	Then he crowed so that it could not be improved.
His coomb was redder than the fyn coral,	His comb was redder than the fine coral,
And batailled as it were a castel wal;	And notched with battlements as if it were a castle wall;
His byle was blak, and as the jeet it shoon;	His bill was black, and it shone like the jet stone;
Lyk asure were his legges and his toon;	Like azure were his legs and his toes;
His nayles whitter than the lylye flour,	His nails whiter than the lily flour,
And lyk the burned gold was his colour.	And like the burnished gold was his color.
This gentil cok hadde in his governaunce	This gentle cock had in his governance
Sevene hennes for to doon al his plesaunce,	Seven hens to do all his pleasure,
Whiche were his sustres and his paramours,	Which were his sisters and his concubines,
And wonder lyk to hym, as of colours;	And wonderfully like him, in their colors;
Of whiche the faireste hewed on hir throte	Of which the fairest colored on her throat
Was cleped faire damoysele Pertelote.	Was called fair demoiselle Pertelote.
Curteys she was, discreet, and debonaire,	Courteous she was, discreet, and gracious,
And compaignable, and bar hyrself so faire	And companionable, and bore herself so fair
Syn thilke day that she was seven nyght oold	Since that same day that she was seven nights old
That trewely she hath the herte in hoold	That truly she has in possession the heart
Of Chauntecleer, loken in every lith;	Of Chauntecleer, locked in every limb (completely);
He loved hire so that wel was hym therwith.	He loved her so that well was him because of that.
But swich a joye was it to here hem synge,	But such a joy it was to hear them sing,
Whan that the brighte sonne gan to sprynge,	When the bright sun began to spring,
In sweete accord, "My lief is faren in londe!" --	In sweet accord, "My love has gone to the country!" --
For thilke tyme, as I have understonde,	For in that same time, as I have understood,
Beestes and briddes koude speke and synge.	Beasts and birds could speak and sing.
And so bifel that in a dawenynge,	And so befell that in a dawning,
As Chauntecleer among his wyves alle	As Chauntecleer among all his wives
Sat on his perche, that was in the halle,	Sat on his perch, that was in the hall,
And next hym sat this faire Pertelote,	And next to him sat this faire Pertelote,
This Chauntecleer gan gronen in his throte,	This Chauntecleer began to groan in his throat,
As man that in his dreem is drecched soore.	As one that in his dream is deeply troubled.
And whan that Pertelote thus herde hym roore,	And when Pertelote thus heard him roar,
She was agast and seyde, "Herte deere,	She was aghast and said, "Dear heart,
What eyleth yow, to grone in this manere?	What ails you, to groan in this manner?
Ye been a verray sleper; fy, for shame!"	You are a true (sound) sleeper; fie, for shame!"
And he answerde, and seyde thus: "Madame,	And he answered, and said thus: "Madame,
I pray yow that ye take it nat agrief.	I pray you that you take it not amiss.
By God, me mette I was in swich meschief	By God, I dreamed I was in such mischief
Right now that yet myn herte is soore afright.	Right now that yet my heart is grievously frightened.
Now God," quod he, "my swevene recche aright,	Now God," said he, "interpret my dream correctly,
And kepe my body out of foul prisoun!	And keep my body out of foul prison!
Me mette how that I romed up and doun	I dreamed how I roamed up and down
Withinne our yeerd, wheer as I saugh a beest	Within our yard, where I saw a beast
Was lyk an hound, and wolde han maad areest	Was like a hound, and would have seized
Upon my body, and wolde han had me deed.	Upon my body, and would have had me dead.
His colour was bitwixe yelow and reed,	His color was between yellow and red,
And tipped was his tayl and bothe his eeris	And tipped was his tail and both his ears
With blak, unlyk the remenant of his heeris;	With black, unlike the rest of his hair;
His snowte smal, with glowynge eyen tweye.	His snout small, with two glowing eyes.
Yet of his look for feere almoost I deye;	Yet for fear of his look I almost die;
This caused me my gronyng, doutelees."	This caused my groaning, doubtless."
"Avoy!" quod she, "fy on yow, hertelees!	"Shame!" said she, "fie on you, coward!
Allas," quod she, "for, by that God above,	Alas," said she, "for, by that God above,
Now han ye lost myn herte and al my love!	Now have you lost my heart and all my love!
I kan nat love a coward, by my feith!	I can not love a coward, by my faith!
For certes, what so any womman seith,	For certainly, whatever any woman says,
We alle desiren, if it myghte bee,	We all desire, if it might be,
To han housbondes hardy, wise, and free,	To have husbands hardy, wise, and generous,
And secree -- and no nygard, ne no fool,	And secret -- and no miser, nor no fool,
Ne hym that is agast of every tool,	Nor him who is afraid of every weapon,
Ne noon avauntour, by that God above!	Nor any boaster, by that God above!
How dorste ye seyn, for shame, unto youre love	How dare you say, for shame, unto your love
That any thyng myghte make yow aferd?	That any thing might make you afraid?
Have ye no mannes herte, and han a berd?	Have you no man's heart, and have a beard?
Allas! And konne ye been agast of swevenys?	Alas! And can you be frightened of dreams?
Nothyng, God woot, but vanitee in sweven is.	Nothing, God knows, but foolishness is in dreams.
Swevenes engendren of replecciouns,	Dreams are produced by overeating,
And ofte of fume and of complecciouns,	And often by stomach vapors and by the mixture of bodily humors,
Whan humours been to habundant in a wight.	When humors are too abundant in a person.
Certes this dreem, which ye han met to-nyght,	Certainly this dream, which you have dreamed to-night,
Cometh of the greete superfluytee	Comes of the great superfluity
Of youre rede colera, pardee,	Of your red choleric humor, indeed,
Which causeth folk to dreden in hir dremes	Which causes folk in their dreams to be afraid
Of arwes, and of fyr with rede lemes,	Of arrows, and of fire with red flames,
Of rede beestes, that they wol hem byte,	Of red beasts, (fearing) that they will bite them,
Of contek, and of whelpes, grete and lyte;	Of strife, and of dogs, big and little;
Right as the humour of malencolie	Right as the humor of melancholy
Causeth ful many a man in sleep to crie	Causes very many a man in sleep to cry
For feere of blake beres, or boles blake,	For fear of black bears, or black bulls,
Or elles blake develes wole hem take.	Or else black devils will take them.
Of othere humours koude I telle also	Of other humors could I tell also
That werken many a man sleep ful wo;	That cause many a man much woe (in) sleep;
But I wol passe as lightly as I kan.	But I will pass over as lightly as I can.
"Lo Catoun, which that was so wys a man,	"Lo Cato, who was so wise a man,
Seyde he nat thus, `Ne do no fors of dremes'?	Said he not thus, `Attach no importance to dreams'?
"Now sire," quod she, "whan we flee fro the bemes,	"Now sir," said she, "when we fly from the beams,
For Goddes love, as taak som laxatyf.	For God's love, take some laxative.
Up peril of my soule and of my lyf,	Upon peril of my soul and of my life,
I conseille yow the beste -- I wol nat lye --	I counsel you the best -- I will not lie --
That bothe of colere and of malencolye	That both of choler and of melancholy
Ye purge yow; and for ye shal nat tarie,	You purge yourself; and so that you shall not delay,
Though in this toun is noon apothecarie,	Though in this town is no apothecary,
I shal myself to herbes techen yow	I shall myself guide you to herbs
That shul been for youre hele and for youre prow;	That shall be for your health and for your benefit;
And in oure yeerd tho herbes shal I fynde	And in our yard I shall find those herbs
The whiche han of hire propretee by kynde	The which by nature have the power
To purge yow bynethe and eek above.	To purge you beneath and also above.
Foryet nat this, for Goddes owene love!	Forget not this, for God's own love!
Ye been ful coleryk of compleccioun;	You are dominated by the choleric humor;
Ware the sonne in his ascencioun	Beware the sun when it is high in the sky
Ne fynde yow nat repleet of humours hoote.	And do not find yourself with an excess of hot humors.
And if it do, I dar wel leye a grote,	And if there be an excess, I dare well bet four pence,
That ye shul have a fevere terciane,	That you shall have a fever recurring every three days,
Or an agu that may be youre bane.	Or an ague that may be your death.
A day or two ye shul have digestyves	A day or two you shall have digestives
Of wormes, er ye take youre laxatyves	Of worms, before you take your laxatives
Of lawriol, centaure, and fumetere,	Of spurge laurel, centaury, and fumitory,
Or elles of ellebor, that groweth there,	Or else of hellebore, that grows there,
Of katapuce, or of gaitrys beryis,	Of caper-spurge, or of rhamus,
Of herbe yve, growyng in oure yeerd, ther mery is;	Of ground ivy, growing in our yard, where it is pleasant;
Pekke hem up right as they growe and ete hem yn.	Peck them up right as they grow and eat them in.
Be myrie, housbonde, for youre fader kyn!	Be merry, husband, for your father's kin!
Dredeth no dreem; I kan sey yow namoore."	Dread no dream; I can say you no more."
"Madame," quod he, "graunt mercy of youre loore.	"Madame," said he, "great thanks for your learning.
But nathelees, as touchyng daun Catoun,	But nonetheless, as touching dan Cato,
That hath of wysdom swich a greet renoun,	That has of wisdom such a great renown,
Though that he bad no dremes for to drede,	Though he commanded (us) to dread no dreams,
By God, men may in olde bookes rede	By God, men may in old books read
Of many a man moore of auctorite	Of many a man of more authority
Than evere Caton was, so moot I thee,	Than Cato ever was, as I may prosper,
That al the revers seyn of this sentence,	Who say all the reverse of this sentence,
And han wel founden by experience	And have well found by experience
That dremes been significaciouns	That dreams are significations
As wel of joye as of tribulaciouns	As well of joy as of tribulations
That folk enduren in this lif present.	That folk endure in this present life.
Ther nedeth make of this noon argument;	There need be no argument about this;
The verray preeve sheweth it in dede.	The proof itself shows it in the deed.
"Oon of the gretteste auctour that men rede	"One of the greatest author that men read
Seith thus: that whilom two felawes wente	Says thus: that once two fellows went
On pilgrimage, in a ful good entente,	On pilgrimage, with a very good intention,
And happed so, they coomen in a toun	And it so happened, they came in a town
Wher as ther was swich congregacioun	Where there was such a gathering
Of peple, and eek so streit of herbergage,	Of people, and also such a scantiness of lodging,
That they ne founde as muche as o cotage	That they found not so much as one cottage
In which they bothe myghte ylogged bee.	In which they both might be lodged.
Wherfore they mosten of necessitee,	Therefore they must of necessity,
As for that nyght, departen compaignye;	For that night, part company;
And ech of hem gooth to his hostelrye,	And each of them goes to his hostelry,
And took his loggyng as it wolde falle.	And took his lodging as it would befall.
That oon of hem was logged in a stalle,	The one of them was lodged in a stall,
Fer in a yeerd, with oxen of the plough;	Far in a yard, with oxen of the plough;
That oother man was logged wel ynough,	That other man was lodged well enough,
As was his aventure or his fortune,	As was his adventure or his fortune,
That us governeth alle as in commune.	Which us governs all in common.
"And so bifel that, longe er it were day,	"And it so befell that, long before it was day,
This man mette in his bed, ther as he lay,	This man dreamed in his bed, where he lay,
How that his felawe gan upon hym calle,	How his fellow began to call upon him,
And seyde, `Allas, for in an oxes stalle	And said, `Alas, for in an oxen's stall
This nyght I shal be mordred ther I lye!	This night I shall be murdered where I lie!
Now help me, deere brother, or I dye.	Now help me, dear brother, or I die.
In alle haste com to me!' he sayde.	In all haste come to me!' he said.
This man out of his sleep for feere abrayde;	This man out of his sleep for fear awakened suddenly;
But whan that he was wakened of his sleep,	But when he was wakened of his sleep,
He turned hym and took of this no keep.	He turned himself and took no heed of this.
Hym thoughte his dreem nas but a vanitee.	He thought his dream was nothing but a fantasy.
Thus twies in his slepyng dremed hee;	Thus twice in his sleeping he dreamed;
And atte thridde tyme yet his felawe	And at third time yet his fellow
Cam, as hym thoughte, and seide, `I am now slawe.	Came, as it seemed to him, and said, `I am now slain.
Bihoold my bloody woundes depe and wyde!	Behold my bloody wounds deep and wide!
Arys up erly in the morwe tyde,	Arise up early in the morning time,
And at the west gate of the toun,' quod he,	And at the west gate of the town,' he said,
`A carte ful of dong ther shaltow se,	`A cart full of dung there shalt thou see,
In which my body is hid ful prively;	In which my body is hid very secretly;
Do thilke carte arresten boldely.	Have that same cart immediately seized.
My gold caused my mordre, sooth to sayn,'	My gold caused my murder, to say the truth,'
And tolde hym every point how he was slayn,	And told him in full detail how he was slain,
With a ful pitous face, pale of hewe.	With a very piteous face, pale of hue.
And truste wel, his dreem he foond ful trewe,	And trust well, his dream he found very true,
For on the morwe, as soone as it was day,	For on the morrow, as soon as it was day,
To his felawes in he took the way;	To his fellow's inn he took the way;
And whan that he cam to this oxes stalle,	And when he came to this oxen's stall,
After his felawe he bigan to calle.	After his fellow he began to call.
"The hostiler answerede hym anon,	"The innkeeper answered him straightway,
And seyde, `Sire, your felawe is agon.	And said, `Sir, your fellow is gone.
As soone as day he wente out of the toun.'	As soon as it was day he went out of the town.'
"This man gan fallen in suspecioun,	"This man began to fall in suspicion,
Remembrynge on his dremes that he mette,	Remembering his dreams that he dreamed,
And forth he gooth -- no lenger wolde he lette --	And forth he goes -- no longer would he delay --
Unto the west gate of the toun, and fond	Unto the west gate of the town, and found
A dong-carte, wente as it were to donge lond,	A dung-cart, which went as if it were to dung land,
That was arrayed in that same wise	That was drawn up in that same manner
As ye han herd the dede man devyse.	As you have heard the dead man tell.
And with an hardy herte he gan to crye	And with a hardy heart he began to cry for
Vengeance and justice of this felonye:	Vengeance and justice of this felony:
`My felawe mordred is this same nyght,	`My fellow is murdered this same night,
And in this carte he lith gapyng upright.	And in this cart he lies gaping upright.
I crye out on the ministres,' quod he,	I cry out on the officials,' said he,
`That sholden kepe and reulen this citee.	`Who should guard and rule this city.
Harrow! Allas! Heere lith my felawe slayn!'	Help! Alas! Here lies my fellow slain!'
What sholde I moore unto this tale sayn?	What should I more unto this tale say?
The peple out sterte and caste the cart to grounde,	The people rushed out and cast the cart to ground,
And in the myddel of the dong they founde	And in the middle of the dung they found
The dede man, that mordred was al newe.	The dead man, who was just recently murdered.
"O blisful God, that art so just and trewe,	"O blissful God, that art so just and true,
Lo, how that thou biwreyest mordre alway!	Lo, how thou always reveal murder!
Mordre wol out; that se we day by day.	Murder will out; we see that day by day.
Mordre is so wlatsom and abhomynable	Murder is so disgusting and abominable
To God, that is so just and resonable,	To God, who is so just and reasonable,
That he ne wol nat suffre it heled be,	That He will not suffer it to be hidden,
Though it abyde a yeer, or two, or thre.	Though it may wait a year, or two, or three.
Mordre wol out, this my conclusioun.	Murder will out, this is my conclusion.
And right anon, ministres of that toun	And immediately, officials of that town
Han hent the carter and so soore hym pyned,	Have seized the carter and so painfully tortured him,
And eek the hostiler so soore engyned,	And also the hosteller so grievously tortured,

And were anhanged by the nekke-bon.	And were hanged by the neck-bone.
"Heere may men seen that dremes been to drede.	"Here men may seen that dreams are to be feared.
And certes in the same book I rede,	And certainly in the same book I read,
Right in the nexte chapitre after this --	Right in the next chapter after this --
I gabbe nat, so have I joye or blis --	I do not lie, as I may have joy or bliss --
Two men that wolde han passed over see,	Two men that would have passed over see,
For certeyn cause, into a fer contree,	For a certain reason, into a far country,
If that the wynd ne hadde been contrarie,	If that the wind had not been contrary,
That made hem in a citee for to tarie	That made them to tarry in a city

But on a day, agayn the even-tyde,	But on a day, toward the evening time,
The wynd gan chaunge, and blew right as hem leste.	The wind began to change, and blew exactly as they desired.
Jolif and glad they wente unto hir reste,	Jolly and glad they went unto their rest,

But herkneth! To that o man fil a greet mervaille:	But listen! To that one man befell a great marvel:
That oon of hem, in slepyng as he lay,	The one of them, in sleeping as he lay,
Hym mette a wonder dreem agayn the day.	He dreamed a wondrous dream before the day.
Hym thoughte a man stood by his beddes syde,	He thought a man stood by his bed's side,
And hym comanded that he sholde abyde,	And commanded him that he should stay,
And seyde hym thus: `If thou tomorwe wende,	And said to him thus: `If thou travel tomorrow,
Thow shalt be dreynt; my tale is at an ende.'	Thou shalt be drowned; my tale is at an end.'
He wook, and tolde his felawe what he mette,	He woke, and told his fellow what he dreamed,
And preyde hym his viage for to lette;	And prayed him to delay his voyage;
As for that day, he preyde hym to byde.	For that day, he prayed him to wait.
His felawe, that lay by his beddes syde,	His fellow, that lay by his bed's side,
Gan for to laughe, and scorned him ful faste.	Began to laugh, and vigorously scorned him.
`No dreem,' quod he, `may so myn herte agaste	`No dream,' said he, `may so frighten my heart
That I wol lette for to do my thynges.	That I will desist from doing my tasks.
I sette nat a straw by thy dremynges,	I set not a straw by (put no value on) thy dreams,
For swevenes been but vanytees and japes.	For dreams are but fantasies and foolishness.
Men dreme alday of owles and of apes,	Men dream all the time of owls and of apes,
And of many a maze therwithal;	And of many a source of amazement indeed;
Men dreme of thyng that nevere was ne shal.	Men dream of a thing that never was nor shall be.
But sith I see that thou wolt heere abyde,	But since I see that thou will remain here,
And thus forslewthen wilfully thy tyde,	And thus willfully waste thy tide,
God woot, it reweth me; and have good day!'	God knows, it makes me sorry; and have good day!'
And thus he took his leve, and wente his way.	And thus he took his leave, and went his way.
But er that he hadde half his cours yseyled,	But before he had sailed half his course,
Noot I nat why, ne what myschaunce it eyled,	I know not why, nor what mischance harmed it,
But casuelly the shippes botme rente,	But by chance the ship's bottom broke open,
And ship and man under the water wente	And ship and man went under the water
In sighte of othere shippes it bisyde,	In sight of other ships beside it,
That with hem seyled at the same tyde.	That with them sailed on the same tide.
And therfore, faire Pertelote so deere,	And therefore, faire Pertelote so dear,
By swiche ensamples olde maistow leere	By such old examples thou may learn
That no man sholde been to recchelees	That no man should be too heedless

That many a dreem ful soore is for to drede.	That many a dream is very greatly to be feared.

That was Kenulphus sone, the noble kyng	That was son of Kenulphus, the noble king
Of Mercenrike, how Kenelm mette a thyng.	Of Mercia, how Kenelm dreamed a thing.
A lite er he was mordred, on a day,	A little before he was murdered, on a day,
His mordre in his avysioun he say.	He saw his murder in his vision.
His norice hym expowned every deel	His nurse completely explained to him

And therfore litel tale hath he toold	And therefore he put little store
Of any dreem, so hooly was his herte.	In any dream, so holy was his heart.
By God! I hadde levere than my sherte	By God! I had rather than my shirt (give my shirt)
That ye hadde rad his legende, as have I.	That you had read his legend, as have I.
"Dame Pertelote, I sey yow trewely,	"Dame Pertelote, I say you truly,
Macrobeus, that writ the avisioun	Macrobius, that wrote the vision
In Affrike of the worthy Cipioun,	In Africa of the worthy Scipio,
Affermeth dremes, and seith that they been	Affirms (the value of) dreams, and says that they are
Warnynge of thynges that men after seen.	Warnings of things that men later see (come to pass)
And forthermoore, I pray yow, looketh wel	And furthermore, I pray you, look well

If he heeld dremes any vanitee.	If he held dreams (to be) any foolishness.
Reed eek of Joseph, and ther shul ye see	Read also of Joseph, and there shall you see

Warnynge of thynges that shul after falle.	Warnings of things that shall afterward befall.
Looke of Egipte the kyng, daun Pharao,	Consider the king of Egypt, dan Pharaoh,
His bakere and his butiller also,	His baker and his butler also,
Wher they ne felte noon effect in dremes.	Whether or not they felt any effect in dreams.
Whoso wol seken actes of sondry remes	Whoever will seek out the histories of various nations
May rede of dremes many a wonder thyng.	May read many a wonderful thing about dreams.
Lo Cresus, which that was of Lyde kyng,	Lo Croesus, who was king of Lydia,
Mette he nat that he sat upon a tree,	Dreamed he not that he sat upon a tree,
Which signified he sholde anhanged bee?	Which signified he should be hanged?
Lo heere Andromacha, Ectores wyf,	Lo here Andromacha, Hector's wife,
That day that Ector sholde lese his lyf,	That day that Hector should lose his life,
She dremed on the same nyght biforn	She dreamed on the same night before
How that the lyf of Ector sholde be lorn,	How the life of Hector should be lost,
If thilke day he wente into bataille.	If that same day he went into battle.
She warned hym, but it myghte nat availle;	She warned him, but it might not avail;
He wente for to fighte natheles,	He went to fight nonetheless,
But he was slayn anon of Achilles.	But he was slain straightway by Achilles.
But thilke tale is al to longe to telle,	But that same tale is all too long to tell,
And eek it is ny day; I may nat dwelle.	And also it is nigh day; I may not delay.
Shortly I seye, as for conclusioun,	Shortly I say, as for conclusion,
That I shal han of this avisioun	That I shall have of this vision
Adversitee; and I seye forthermoor	Adversity; and I say furthermore

For they been venymes, I woot it weel;	For they are poisonous, I know it well;
I hem diffye, I love hem never a deel!	I renounce them, I love them not at all!
"Now let us speke of myrthe, and stynte al this.	"Now let us speak of mirth, and stop all this.
Madame Pertelote, so have I blis,	Madame Pertelote, as I may have bliss,
Of o thyng God hath sent me large grace;	Of one thing God has sent me a great favor;
For whan I se the beautee of youre face,	For when I see the beauty of your face,
Ye been so scarlet reed aboute youre yen,	You are so scarlet red about your eyes,
It maketh al my drede for to dyen;	It makes all my dread die;
For al so siker as In principio,	For as surely as `In the beginning,
Mulier est hominis confusio --	`Woman is the ruin of man --'
Madame, the sentence of this Latyn is,	Madame, the meaning of this Latin is,
`Womman is mannes joye and al his blis.'	`Woman is man's joy and all his bliss.'
For whan I feele a-nyght your softe syde --	For when I feel at night your soft side --
Al be it that I may nat on yow ryde,	Although I can not on you ride,
For that oure perche is maad so narwe, allas --	Because our perch is made so narrow, alas --
I am so ful of joye and of solas,	I am so full of joy and of pleasure,
That I diffye bothe sweven and dreem."	That I renounce both vision and dream."
And with that word he fley doun fro the beem,	And with that word he flew down from the beam,
For it was day, and eke his hennes alle,	For it was day, and also all his hens,
And with a chuk he gan hem for to calle,	And with a cluck he began to call them,
For he hadde founde a corn, lay in the yerd.	Because he had found a seed, which lay in the yard.
Real he was, he was namoore aferd.	Royal he was, he was no longer afraid.
He fethered Pertelote twenty tyme,	He embraced Pertelote twenty times,
And trad hire eke as ofte, er it was pryme.	And copulated with her also as often, before it was  a.m..
He looketh as it were a grym leoun,	He looks as if he were a grim lion,
And on his toos he rometh up and doun;	And on his toes he roams up and down;
Hym deigned nat to sette his foot to grounde.	He deigned not to set his foot to ground.
He chukketh whan he hath a corn yfounde,	He clucks when he has found a seed,
And to hym rennen thanne his wyves alle.	And then his wives all run to him.
Thus roial, as a prince is in his halle,	Thus royal, as a prince is in his hall,
Leve I this Chauntecleer in his pasture,	Leave I this Chauntecleer in his feeding place,
And after wol I telle his aventure.	And after I will tell his adventure.
Whan that the month in which the world bigan,	When the month in which the world began,
That highte March, whan God first maked man,	Which is called March, when God first made man,
Was compleet, and passed were also,	Was complete, and passed were also,

Madame Pertelote, my worldes blis,	Madame Pertelote, my world's bliss,

For evere the latter ende of joye is wo.	For ever the latter end of joy is woe.
God woot that worldly joye is soone ago;	God knows that worldly joy is soon gone;
And if a rethor koude faire endite,	And if a rhetorician could fairly compose,
He in a cronycle saufly myghte it write	He in a chronicle confidently could write it

Now every wys man, lat him herkne me;	Now every wise man, let him listen to me;
This storie is also trewe, I undertake,	This story is as true, I declare,

That wommen holde in ful greet reverence.	Which women hold in very great reverence.
Now wol I torne agayn to my sentence.	Now will I turn again to my subject matter.
A col-fox, ful of sly iniquitee,	A fox, full of sly iniquity,
That in the grove hadde woned yeres three,	That in the grove had dwelled three years,
By heigh ymaginacioun forncast,	By exalted imagination predestined,

As gladly doon thise homycides alle	As habitually do all these homicides
That in await liggen to mordre men.	That in ambush lie to murder men.
O false mordrour, lurkynge in thy den!	O false murderer, lurking in thy den!
O newe Scariot, newe Genylon,	O new Judas Iscariot, new Genylon,
False dissymulour, o Greek Synon,	False deceiver, O Greek Synon,

Thou were ful wel ywarned by thy dremes	Thou were very well warned by thy dreams
That thilke day was perilous to thee;	That that same day was perilous to thee;
But what that God forwoot moot nedes bee,	But what God knows beforehand must by necessity be,
After the opinioun of certein clerkis.	According to the opinion of certain scholars.
Witnesse on hym that any parfit clerk is,	Take witness of him that is a thoroughly competent scholar,
That in scole is greet altercacioun	That in the university is great disagreement
In this mateere, and greet disputisoun,	In this matter, and great disputation,
And hath been of an hundred thousand men.	And has been (disputed) by a hundred thousand men.

As kan the hooly doctour Augustyn,	As can the holy doctor Augustine,
Or Boece, or the Bisshop Bradwardyn,	Or Boethius, or the Bishop Bradwardyn,
Wheither that Goddes worthy forwityng	Whether God's worthy foreknowledge

"Nedely" clepe I symple necessitee --	"Need" I call simple necessity --
Or elles, if free choys be graunted me	Or else, if free choice be granted to me

I wol nat han to do of swich mateere;	I will not have to do with such matter;
My tale is of a cok, as ye may heere,	My tale is of a cock, as you may hear,

To walken in the yerd upon that morwe	To walk in the yard upon that morning

Thise been the cokkes wordes, and nat myne;	These are the cock's words, and not mine;
