But nathelees it was so fair a sighte	But nonetheless it was so fair a sight
That it made alle hire hertes for to lighte,	That it made all their hearts to lighten,
What for the seson and the morwenynge,	What for the season and the dawning,
And for the foweles that she herde synge.	And for the fowls that she heard sing.
For right anon she wiste what they mente	For right away she knew what they meant
Right by hir song, and knew al hire entente.	Exactly by their song, and knew all their meaning.
The knotte why that every tale is toold,	The main point for which every tale is told,
If it be taried til that lust be coold	If it is delayed until the desire (to hear it) is cold
Of hem that han it after herkned yoore,	Of those who have listened to it for a long time,
The savour passeth ever lenger the moore,	The taste (for it) passes away more and more,
For fulsomnesse of his prolixitee;	Because of the overabundance of its prolixity;
And by the same resoun, thynketh me,	And by the same reason, it seems to me,
I sholde to the knotte condescende,	I should proceed to the main point,
And maken of hir walkyng soone an ende.	And quickly put an end to her walking.
Amydde a tree, for drye as whit as chalk,	In a tree, for dryness as white as chalk,
As Canacee was pleyyng in hir walk,	As Canacee was amusing herself in her walk,
Ther sat a faucon over hire heed ful hye,	There sat a falcon over her head full high,
That with a pitous voys so gan to crye	That with a pitiful voice so did cry
That all the wode resouned of hire cry.	That all the wood resounded with her cry.
Ybeten hadde she hirself so pitously	She had beaten herself so pitifully
With bothe hir wynges til the rede blood	With both her wings until the red blood
Ran endelong the tree ther-as she stood.	Ran down the length of the tree in which she stood.
And evere in oon she cryde alwey and shrighte,	And continually she cried always and shrieked,
And with hir beek hirselven so she prighte	And with her beak herself she so stabbed
That ther nys tygre, ne noon so crueel beest	That there is no tiger, nor any beast so cruel
That dwelleth outher in wode or in forest,	That dwells either in wood or in forest,
That nolde han wept, if that he wepe koude,	That would not have wept, if he could weep,
For sorwe of hire, she shrighte alwey so loude.	For sorrow of her, she shrieked always so loud.
For ther nas nevere yet no man on lyve,	For there was never yet no man alive,
If that I koude a faucon wel discryve,	If I could well describe a falcon,
That herde of swich another of fairnesse,	That heard of its equal in beauty,
As wel of plumage as of gentillesse	As well in plumage as in nobility
Of shap, of al that myghte yrekened be.	In shape, in all that might reckoned be.
A faucon peregryn thanne semed she	A peregrine falcon then seemed she
Of fremde land; and everemoore, as she stood,	From foreign land; and repeatedly, as she stood,
She swowneth now and now for lak of blood,	She swoons every now and then for lack of blood,
Til wel neigh is she fallen fro the tree.	Until well nigh is she fallen from the tree.
This faire kynges doghter, Canacee,	This fair king's daughter, Canacee,
That on hir fynger baar the queynte ryng,	That on her finger bore the strange ring,
Thurgh which she understood wel every thyng	Through which she well understood every thing
That any fowel may in his leden seyn,	That any fowl may in his language say,
And koude answeren hym in his ledene ageyn,	And could answer him in his language in return,
Hath understonde what this faucon seyde,	Has understood what this falcon said,
And wel neigh for the routhe almoost she deyde.	And well nigh for the pity she almost died.
And to the tree she gooth ful hastily,	And to the tree she goes full hastily,
And on this faukon looketh pitously,	And on this falcon looks compassionately,
And heeld hir lappe abrood, for wel she wiste	And spread wide her skirt, for well she knew
The faukon moste fallen fro the twiste,	The falcon must fall from the branch,
Whan that it swowned next, for lak of blood.	When it swooned next, for lack of blood.
A longe whil to wayten hire she stood	A long while to await her she stood
Til atte laste she spak in this manere	Until at the last she spoke in this manner
Unto the hauk, as ye shal after heere:	Unto the hawk, as you shall after hear:
"What is the cause, if it be for to telle,	"What is the cause, if it may be told,
That ye be in this furial pyne of helle?"	That you be in this pain such as the Furies suffer in hell?"
Quod Canacee unto this hauk above.	Said Canacee unto this hawk above.
"Is this for sorwe of deeth or los of love?	"Is this for sorrow of death or loss of love?
For, as I trowe, thise been causes two	For, as I believe, these are the two causes
That causen moost a gentil herte wo;	That most cause woe to a gentle heart;
Of oother harm it nedeth nat to speke.	Of other harm there is no need to speak.
For ye youreself upon yourself yow wreke,	For you avenge yourself upon yourself,
Which proveth wel that outher ire or drede	Which proves well that either anger or fear
Moot been enchesoun of youre cruel dede,	Must be the reason for your cruel deed,
Syn that I see noon oother wight yow chace.	Since I see no other creature hunt you.
For love of God, as dooth youreselven grace,	For love of God, spare yourself,
Or what may been youre help? For west nor est	Or what can be your help? For west nor east
Ne saugh I nevere er now no bryd ne beest	I saw never ere now no bird nor beast
That ferde with hymself so pitously.	That treated himself so piteously.
Ye sle me with youre sorwe verraily,	You slay me with your sorrow truly,
I have of yow so greet compassioun.	I have of you such great compassion.
For Goddes love, com fro the tree adoun;	For God's love, come down from the tree;
And as I am a kynges doghter trewe,	And as I am a king's daughter true,
If that I verraily the cause knewe	If that I truly knew the cause
Of youre disese, if it lay in my myght,	Of your malady, if it lay in my power,
I wolde amenden it er that it were nyght,	I would amend it ere it were night,
As wisly helpe me grete God of kynde!	So help me great God of nature!
And herbes shal I right ynowe yfynde	And herbs shall I in abundance find
To heel with youre hurtes hastily."	With which to heal your hurts quickly."
Tho shrighte this faucon yet moore pitously	Then shrieked this falcon yet more pitifully
Than ever she dide, and fil to grounde anon,	Than ever she did, and fell to ground straightway,
And lith aswowne, deed and lyk a stoon,	And lies in a swoon, dead and like a stone,
Til Canacee hath in hire lappe hire take	Until Canacee has in her lap her taken
Unto the tyme she gan of swough awake.	Until the time she awoke from the swoon.
And after that she of hir swough gan breyde,	And after she started up from her swoon,
Right in hir haukes ledene thus she seyde:	Right in her hawk's language thus she said:
"That pitee renneth soone in gentil herte,	"That pity runs soon in a gentle heart,
Feelynge his similitude in peynes smerte,	Feeling its counterpart in sharp pains,
Is preved alday, as men may it see,	Is proven every day, as men may it see,
As wel by werk as by auctoritee;	As well by deeds as by written authority;
For gentil herte kitheth gentillesse.	For a gentle heart makes known its noble character.
I se wel that ye han of my distresse	I see well that you have of my distress
Compassion, my faire Canacee,	Compassion, my faire Canacee,
Of verray wommanly benignytee	Out of true womanly goodness
That Nature in youre principles hath set.	That Nature in your natural disposition has set.
But for noon hope for to fare the bet,	But for no hope to fare the better,
But for to obeye unto youre herte free,	But to obey unto your heart noble,
And for to maken othere be war by me,	And to make others be warned by my example,
As by the whelp chasted is the leon,	As by the whelp chastised is the lion,
Right for that cause and that conclusion,	Right for that cause and to that conclusion,
Whil that I have a leyser and a space,	While that I have the time and the opportunity,
Myn harm I wol confessen er I pace."	My harm I will reveal ere I go away."
And evere, whil that oon hir sorwe tolde,	And ever, while that one her sorrow told,
That oother weep as she to water wolde	That other wept as she would turn to water
Til that the faucon bad hire to be stille,	Until the falcon prayed her to be still,
And, with a syk, right thus she seyde hir wille:	And, with a sigh, right thus she spoke her mind:
"Ther I was bred -- allas, that ilke day! --	"Where I was bred -- alas, that same day! --
And fostred in a roche of marbul gray	And fostered on a cliff of marble gray
So tendrely that no thyng eyled me,	So tenderly that no thing ailed me,
I nyste nat what was adversitee	I knew not what was adversity
Til I koude flee ful hye under the sky.	Until I could fly full high under the sky.
Tho dwelte a tercelet me faste by,	Then dwelt a male falcon very near me,
That semed welle of alle gentillesse;	That seemed an exemplar of all nobility;
Al were he ful of treson and falsnesse,	Although he was full of treason and falseness,
It was so wrapped under humble cheere,	It was so concealed under humble bearing,
And under hewe of trouthe in swich manere,	And under the appearance of truth in such a manner,
Under plesance, and under bisy peyne,	Under pleasantness, and under careful attentiveness,
That no wight koude han wend he koude feyne,	That no creature could have supposed he could feign,
So depe in greyn he dyed his coloures.	So deeply in a fast dye he dyed his true colors.
Right as a serpent hit hym under floures	Just as a serpent hides himself under flowers
Til he may seen his tyme for to byte,	Until he can see his time to bite,
Right so this god of loves ypocryte	Just so this god of love's hypocrite
Dooth so his cerymonyes and obeisaunces,	So does his ceremonies and obeisances,
And kepeth in semblaunt alle his observaunces	And keeps in outward appearance all his observances
That sownen into gentillesse of love.	That are in accord with nobility in love.
As in a toumbe is al the faire above,	As in a tomb all the beauty is above,
And under is the corps, swich as ye woot,	And under is the corpse, as you know,
Swich was this ypocrite, bothe coold and hoot.	Such was this hypocrite, in every circumstance.
And in this wise he served his entente	And in this manner he served his own purpose
That, save the feend, noon wiste what he mente,	So that, except for the fiend, no one knew what he meant,
Til he so longe hadde wopen and compleyned,	Until he so long had wept and complained,
And many a yeer his service to me feyned,	And many a year his service to me feigned,
Til that myn herte, to pitous and to nyce,	Until my heart, too compassionate and too naive,
Al innocent of his crouned malice,	Entirely ignorant of his consummate malice,
Forfered of his deeth, as thoughte me,	Very frightened that he might die, as it seemed to me,
Upon his othes and his seuretee,	Upon receiving his oaths and his pledges,
Graunted hym love, upon this condicioun,	Granted him love, upon this condition,
That everemoore myn honour and renoun	That evermore my honor and renown
Were saved, bothe privee and apert;	Were safe, both in private and in public (in all ways);
This is to seyn, that after his desert,	This is to say, that according to his deserts,
I yaf hym al myn herte and al my thoght --	I gave him all my heart and all my thought --
God woot and he, that ootherwise noght --	God knows and he, I would not have agreed on any other terms --
And took his herte in chaunge of myn for ay.	And took his heart in exchange for mine for ever.
But sooth is seyd, goon sithen many a day,	But truly it is said, since many a day gone by,
`A trewe wight and a theef thenken nat oon.'	`An honest creature and a thief think not alike.'
And whan he saugh the thyng so fer ygoon	And when he saw the business so far advanced
That I hadde graunted hym fully my love	That I had granted him fully my love
In swich a gyse as I have seyd above,	In such a manner as I have said above,
And yeven hym my trewe herte as free	And gave him my true heart as freely
As he swoor he yaf his herte to me,	As he swore he gave his heart to me,
Anon this tigre, ful of doublenesse,	Immediately this tiger, full of treachery,
Fil on his knees with so devout humblesse,	Fell on his knees with such devout humility,
With so heigh reverence, and, as by his cheere,	With such high reverence, and, as seemed by his appearance,
So lyk a gentil lovere of manere,	So like a gentle lover in his manners,
So ravysshed, as it semed, for the joye	So ravished, as it seemed, for the joy
That nevere Jason ne Parys of Troye --	That never Jason nor Paris of Troy --
Jason? certes, ne noon oother man	Jason? certainly, nor any other man
Syn Lameth was, that alderfirst bigan	Since Lameth was, he who first of all began
To loven two, as writen folk biforn --	To love two, as folk wrote long ago --
Ne nevere, syn the firste man was born,	Nor ever, since the first man was born,
Ne koude man, by twenty thousand part,	Could (any) man, by (so much as) one twenty thousandth,
Countrefete the sophymes of his art,	Reproduce the deceptive sophisms of his art,
Ne were worthy unbokelen his galoche,	Nor were worthy to unbuckle his galosh,
Ther doublenesse or feynyng sholde approche,	Where duplicity or feigning were concerned,
Ne so koude thonke a wight as he dide me!	Nor so could thank a creature as he did to me!
His manere was an hevene for to see	His manner was a heaven to see
Til any womman, were she never so wys,	For any woman, were she never so wise,
So peynted he and kembde at point-devys	So painted he and made himself elegant in every way,
As wel his wordes as his contenaunce.	Both his words and his countenance.
And I so loved hym for his obeisaunce,	And I so loved him for his obeisance,
And for the trouthe I demed in his herte,	And for the truth I believed was in his heart,
That if so were that any thyng hym smerte,	That if it so were that any thing pained him,
Al were it never so lite, and I it wiste,	Although it were never so little, and I knew of it,
Me thoughte I felte deeth myn herte twiste.	It seemed to me I felt death twist my heart.
And shortly, so ferforth this thyng is went	And shortly, this business had gone forth so far
That my wyl was his willes instrument;	That my will was his will's instrument;
This is to seyn, my wyl obeyed his wyl	This is to say, my will obeyed his will
In alle thyng, as fer as reson fil,	In all things, so far as was consonant with reason,
Kepynge the boundes of my worshipe evere.	Keeping ever the limits set by my honor.
Ne nevere hadde I thyng so lief, ne levere,	Nor never loved anyone more, or even as much
As hym, God woot, ne nevere shal namo.	As him, God knows, nor never shall again.
"This laste lenger than a yeer or two,	"This lasted longer than a year or two,
That I supposed of hym noght but good.	That I supposed of him nothing but good.
But finally, thus atte laste it stood,	But finally, thus at the last it stood,
That Fortune wolde that he moste twynne	That Fortune would have it that he must depart
Out of that place which that I was inne.	Out of that place where I was.
Wher me was wo, that is no questioun;	Whether I was woeful, there is no question;
I kan nat make of it discripsioun.	I can not make a description of it.
For o thyng dar I tellen boldely:	For one thing I dare tell boldly:
I knowe what is the peyne of deeth therby;	By this experience I know what is the pain of death;
Swich harm I felte for he ne myghte bileve.	Such harm I felt because he could not remain.
So on a day of me he took his leve,	So one day he took his leave of me,
So sorwefully eek that I wende verraily	So sorrowfully also that I believed truly
That he had felt as muche harm as I,	That he had felt as much harm as I,
Whan that I herde hym speke and saugh his hewe.	When I heard him speak and saw his appearance.
But nathelees, I thoughte he was so trewe,	But nevertheless, I thought he was so true,
And eek that he repaire sholde ageyn	And also that he should return again
Withinne a litel while, sooth to seyn;	Within a little while, to say the truth;
And resoun wolde eek that he moste go	And it was reasonable also that he must go
For his honour, as ofte it happeth so,	For his honor, as often it happens so,
That I made vertu of necessitee,	So that I made virtue of necessity,
And took it wel, syn that it moste be.	And took it well, since it had to be.
As I best myghte, I hidde fro hym my sorwe,	As I best could, I hid from him my sorrow,
And took hym by the hond, Seint John to borwe,	And took him by the hand, with Saint John as my guarantor,
And seyde hym thus: `Lo, I am youres al;	And said to him thus: `Lo, I am all yours;
Beth swich as I to yow have been and shal.'	Be to me such as I to you have been and shall be.'
What he answerde, it nedeth noght reherce;	What he answered, it needs not be repeated;
Who kan sey bet than he, who kan do werse?	Who can speak better than he, who can act worse?
Whan he hath al wel seyd, thanne hath he doon.	When he has said everything well, then he has done (all he will do).
`Therfore bihoveth hire a ful long spoon	`Therefore she must have a very long spoon
That shal ete with a feend,' thus herde I seye.	Who shall eat with a fiend,' thus I have heard said.
So atte laste he moste forth his weye,	So at the last he had to go forth on his way,
And forth he fleeth til he cam ther hym leste.	And forth he speeds until he came where he pleased.
Whan it cam hym to purpos for to reste,	When he decided to rest,
I trowe he hadde thilke text in mynde,	I believe he had that text in mind,
That `alle thyng, repeirynge to his kynde,	That `every thing, by returning to its natural state,
Gladeth hymself;' thus seyn men, as I gesse.	Makes himself happy;' thus say men, as I suppose.
Men loven of propre kynde newefangelnesse,	Men, because of their nature, love novelty,
As briddes doon that men in cages fede.	As do birds that men feed in cages.
For though thou nyght and day take of hem hede,	For though thou take care of them night and day,
And strawe hir cage faire and softe as silk,	And strew their cages with straw fair and soft as silk,
And yeve hem sugre, hony, breed and milk,	And give them sugar, honey, bread and milk,
Yet right anon as that his dore is uppe	Yet just as soon as his door is left open
He with his feet wol spurne adoun his cuppe,	He with his feet will kick down his cup,
And to the wode he wole and wormes ete;	And to the wood he will go and eat worms;
So newefangel been they of hire mete,	They are so fond of novelty in their food,
And loven novelries of propre kynde,	And love novelties because of their nature,
No gentillesse of blood ne may hem bynde.	No nobility of blood can restrain them.
"So ferde this tercelet, allas the day!	"So fared this falcon, alas the day!
Though he were gentil born, and fressh and gay,	Though he was of noble birth, and fresh and gay,
And goodlich for to seen, and humble and free,	And goodly to look upon and humble and generous,
He saugh upon a tyme a kyte flee,	He saw upon a time a kite (scavenger bird) fly by,
And sodeynly he loved this kyte so	And suddenly he so loved this kite
That al his love is clene fro me ago,	That all his love is completely gone from me,
And hath his trouthe falsed in this wyse.	And has turned his truth false in this manner.
Thus hath the kyte my love in hire servyse,	Thus has the kite my lover in her service,
And I am lorn withouten remedie!"	And I am lost, without remedy!"
And with that word this faucon gan to crie	And with that word this falcon did cry out
And swowned eft in Canacees barm.	And swooned again in Canacee's lap.
Greet was the sorwe for the haukes harm	Great was the sorrow for the hawk's harm
That Canacee and alle hir wommen made;	That Canacee and all her women made;
They nyste hou they myghte the faucon glade.	They knew not how they might cheer up the falcon.
But Canacee hom bereth hire in hir lappe,	But Canacee carries her home enfolded in her gown,
And softely in plastres gan hire wrappe,	And softly did wrap her in bandages,
Ther as she with hire beek hadde hurt hirselve.	Where she with her beak had hurt herself.
Now kan nat Canacee but herbes delve	Now Canacee can do nothing but dig herbs
Out of the ground, and make salves newe	Out of the ground, and make new salves
Of herbes preciouse and fyne of hewe	Of herbs, precious and delicate in color,
To heelen with this hauk. Fro day to nyght	With which to heal this hawk. From dawn to nighttime
She dooth hire bisynesse and al hire myght,	She devotes her efforts and all her power,
And by hire beddes heed she made a mewe	And by her bed's head she made a pen
And covered it with veluettes blewe,	And covered it with velvet cloths, blue
In signe of trouthe that is in wommen sene.	As a sign of truth that is in women seen.
And al withoute, the mewe is peynted grene,	And on all the outside, the pen is painted green,
In which were peynted alle thise false fowles,	In which were painted all these false fowls,
As ben thise tidyves, tercelettes, and owles;	Such as are these small birds, falcons, and owls;
Right for despit were peynted hem bisyde,	For sheer scorn were painted beside them,
Pyes, on hem for to crie and chyde.	Magpies, to cry out against them and chide them.
Thus lete I Canacee hir hauk kepyng;	Thus I leave Canacee keeping her hawk;
I wol namoore as now speke of hir ryng	I will for now speak no more of her ring
Til it come eft to purpos for to seyn	Until it becomes again appropriate to tell
How that this faucon gat hire love ageyn	How this falcon got back her love,
Repentant, as the storie telleth us,	Repentant, as the story tells us,
By mediacion of Cambalus,	By the mediation of Cambalus,
The kynges sone, of which I yow tolde.	The king's son, of whom I told you.
But hennesforth I wol my proces holde	But henceforth I will keep to my narrative
To speken of aventures and of batailles	To speak of adventures and of battles
That nevere yet was herd so grete mervailles.	That never yet were heard such great marvels.
First wol I telle yow of Cambyuskan,	First will I tell you of Cambyuskan,
That in his tyme many a citee wan;	That in his time many a city won;
And after wol I speke of Algarsif,	And after I will speak of Algarsif,
How that he wan Theodora to his wif,	How he won Theodora to his wife,
For whom ful ofte in greet peril he was,	For whom full often in great peril he was,
Ne hadde he ben holpen by the steede of bras;	Had he not been helped by the steed of brass;
And after wol I speke of Cambalo,	And next I will speak of Cambalo,
That faught in lystes with the bretheren two	That fought in lists with the brethren two
For Canacee er that he myghte hire wynne.	For Canacee ere he could win her.
And ther I lefte I wol ayeyn bigynne.	And where I left off I will again begin.
Appollo whirleth up his chaar so hye	Appollo whirls up his chariot so high
Til that the god Mercurius hous, the slye --	To that house of the god Mercury, the sly --
"In feith, Squier, thow hast thee wel yquit	"In faith, Squire, thou hast well acquitted thyself.
And gentilly. I preise wel thy wit,"	And nobly. I praise well thy intelligence,"
Quod the Frankeleyn, "considerynge thy yowthe,	Said the Franklin, "considering thy youth,
So feelyngly thou spekest, sire, I allow the!	With such feeling thou speakest, sir, I praise thee!
As to my doom, ther is noon that is heere	In my opinion, there is no one that is here
Of eloquence that shal be thy peere,	That shall be thy equal in eloquence,
If that thou lyve; God yeve thee good chaunce,	If thou live; God give thee good luck,
And in vertu sende thee continuaunce,	And in virtue send thee perseverance,
For of thy speche I have greet deyntee.	For I take great pleasure in thy speech.
I have a sone, and by the Trinitee,	I have a son, and by the Trinity,
I hadde levere than twenty pound worth lond,	I had rather than have twenty pound's worth of land,
Though it right now were fallen in myn hond,	Though it right now were fallen in my hand,
He were a man of swich discrecioun	That he were a man of such discretion
As that ye been! Fy on possessioun,	As you are! Fie on possessions,
But if a man be vertuous withal!	Unless a man is virtuous as well!
I have my sone snybbed, and yet shal,	I have rebuked my son, and shall again,
For he to vertu listeth nat entende;	Because he has no desire to devote himself to virtue;
But for to pleye at dees, and to despende	But to play at dice, and to spend
And lese al that he hath is his usage.	And lose all that he has is his usage.
And he hath levere talken with a page	And he would rather talk with a serving boy
Than to comune with any gentil wight	Than converse with any noble person
Where he myghte lerne gentillesse aright."	From whom he might learn true nobility."
"Straw for youre gentillesse!" quod oure Hoost.	"Straw for your nobility!" said our Host.
"What, Frankeleyn! Pardee, sire, wel thou woost	"What, Franklin! By God, sir, well thou knowest
That ech of yow moot tellen atte leste	That each of you must tell at the least
A tale or two, or breken his biheste."	A tale or two, or break his promise."
"That knowe I wel, sire," quod the Frankeleyn.	"That know I well, sir," said the Franklin.
"I prey yow, haveth me nat in desdeyn,	"I pray you, hold me not in disdain,
Though to this man I speke a word or two."	Though to this man I speak a word or two."
"Telle on thy tale withouten wordes mo."	"Tell on thy tale without more words."
"Gladly, sire Hoost," quod he, "I wole obeye	"Gladly, sir Host," said he, "I will obey
Unto your wyl; now herkneth what I seye.	Unto your will; now hearken what I say.
I wol yow nat contrarien in no wyse	I will not offend you in any way
As fer as that my wittes wol suffyse.	So far as my mental abilities will suffice.
I prey to God that it may plesen yow;	I pray to God that it may please you;
Thanne woot I wel that it is good ynow."	Then I will know well that it is good enough."
Whilom, as olde stories tellen us,	Once, as old histories tell us,
Ther was a duc that highte Theseus;	There was a duke who was called Theseus;
Of Atthenes he was lord and governour,	He was lord and governor of Athens,
And in his tyme swich a conquerour	And in his time such a conqueror
That gretter was ther noon under the sonne.	That there was no one greater under the sun.
Ful many a riche contree hadde he wonne;	Very many a powerful country had he won;
What with his wysdom and his chivalrie,	What with his wisdom and his chivalry,
He conquered al the regne of Femenye,	He conquered all the land of the Amazons,
That whilom was ycleped Scithia,	That once was called Scithia,
And weddede the queene Ypolita,	And wedded the queen Ypolita,
And broghte hire hoom with hym in his contree	And brought her home with him into his country
With muchel glorie and greet solempnytee,	With much glory and great ceremony,
And eek hir yonge suster Emelye.	And also her young sister Emelye.
And thus with victorie and with melodye	And thus with victory and with festivity
Lete I this noble duc to Atthenes ryde,	I leave this noble duke riding to Athens,
And al his hoost in armes hym bisyde.	And all his host in arms beside him.
And certes, if it nere to long to heere,	And certainly, if it were not too long to hear,
I wolde have toold yow fully the manere	I would have told you fully the manner
How wonnen was the regne of Femenye	How the reign of Femenye was won
By Theseus and by his chivalrye;	By Theseus and by his chivalry;
And of the grete bataille for the nones	And of the great battle at that time
Bitwixen Atthenes and Amazones;	Between Athenians and Amazons;
And how asseged was Ypolita,	And how Ypolita was besieged,
The faire, hardy queene of Scithia;	The fair, bold queen of Scithia;
And of the feste that was at hir weddynge,	And of the festivity that was at their wedding,
And of the tempest at hir hoom-comynge;	And of the storm at her home-coming;
But al that thyng I moot as now forbere.	But all that matter I must now forgo.
I have, God woot, a large feeld to ere,	I have, God knows, a large field to till,
And wayke been the oxen in my plough.	And the oxen in my plow are weak.
The remenant of the tale is long ynough.	The remnant of the tale is long enough.
I wol nat letten eek noon of this route;	Also I will not hinder any one of this company;
Lat every felawe telle his tale aboute,	Let every fellow tell his tale in turn,
And lat se now who shal the soper wynne;	And let's see now who shall win the supper;
And ther I lefte, I wol ayeyn bigynne.	And where I left off, I will again begin.
This duc, of whom I make mencioun,	This duke, of whom I make mention,
Whan he was come almoost unto the toun,	When he was come almost unto the town,
In al his wele and in his mooste pride,	In all his prosperity and in his most pride,
He was war, as he caste his eye aside,	He was aware, as he cast his eye aside,
Where that ther kneled in the heighe weye	Where there kneeled in the high way
A compaignye of ladyes, tweye and tweye,	A company of ladies, two by two,
Ech after oother clad in clothes blake;	Each after another, clad in black clothes;
But swich a cry and swich a wo they make	But such a cry and such a woeful (lament) they make
That in this world nys creature lyvynge	That in this world is no living creature
That herde swich another waymentynge;	That (ever) heard lamentation such as this;
And of this cry they nolde nevere stenten	And of this cry they would not ever stop
Til they the reynes of his brydel henten.	Until they seized the reins of his bridle.
"What folk been ye, that at myn hom-comynge	"What folk are you, who at my homecoming
Perturben so my feste with criynge?"	So disturb my festival with crying?"
Quod Theseus. "Have ye so greet envye	Said Theseus. "Have you such great envy
Of myn honour, that thus compleyne and crye?	Of my honor, (you) who thus lament and cry?
Or who hath yow mysboden or offended?	Or who has injured or offended you?
And telleth me if it may been amended,	And tell me if it may be remedied,
And why that ye been clothed thus in blak."	And why you are clothed thus in black."
The eldeste lady of them alle spak,	The eldest lady of them all spoke,
Whan she hadde swowned with a deedly cheere,	After she had swooned with (so) deadly a countenance,
That it was routhe for to seen and heere;	That it was pitiful to see and hear;
She seyde, "Lord, to whom Fortune hath yiven	She said, "Lord, to whom Fortune has given
Victorie, and as a conqueror to lyven,	Victory, and (allowed) to live as a conqueror,
Nat greveth us youre glorie and youre honour,	Your glory and your honor does not grieve us,
But we biseken mercy and socour.	But we beseech (you for) mercy and succor.
Have mercy on oure wo and oure distresse!	Have mercy on our woe and our distress!
Som drope of pitee, thurgh thy gentillesse,	Some drop of pity, because of thy nobility,
Upon us wrecched wommen lat thou falle,	Let thou fall upon us wretched women,
For, certes, lord, ther is noon of us alle	For, certainly, lord, there is not one of us all
That she ne hath been a duchesse or a queene.	Who has not been a duchesse or a queen.
Now be we caytyves, as it is wel seene,	Now we are miserable wretches, as it is easily seen,
Thanked be Fortune and hire false wheel,	Thanks be to Fortune and her false wheel,
That noon estaat assureth to be weel.	Who assures no estate (will continue) to be well.
And certes, lord, to abyden youre presence,	And certainly, lord, to await your presence,
Heere in this temple of the goddesse Clemence	Here in this temple of the goddess Clemency
We han ben waitynge al this fourtenyght.	We have been waiting all this fortnight.
Now help us, lord, sith it is in thy myght.	Now help us, lord, since it is in thy power.
"I, wrecche, which that wepe and wayle thus,	"I, wretch, who weep and wail thus,
Was whilom wyf to kyng Cappaneus,	Was once wife to king Cappaneus,
That starf at Thebes -- cursed be that day! --	Who died at Thebes -- cursed be that day! --
And alle we that been in this array	And all of us who are in this condition
And maken al this lamentacioun,	And make all this lamentation,
We losten alle oure housbondes at that toun,	We lost all our husbands at that town,
Whil that the seege theraboute lay.	While the siege lay around it.
And yet now the olde Creon -- weylaway! --	And yet now the old Creon -- woe oh woe! --
That lord is now of Thebes the citee,	Who is now lord of the city of Thebes,
Fulfild of ire and of iniquitee,	Filled with anger and with iniquity,
He, for despit and for his tirannye,	He, for spite and for his tyranny,
To do the dede bodyes vileynye	To do dishonor to the dead bodies
Of alle oure lordes whiche that been yslawe,	Of all our lords who are slain,
Hath alle the bodyes on an heep ydrawe,	Has dragged all the bodies in a heap,
And wol nat suffren hem, by noon assent,	And will not allow them, not at all,
Neither to been yburyed nor ybrent,	Neither to be buried nor burned,
But maketh houndes ete them in despit."	But makes hounds eat them as an insult."
And with that word, withouten moore respit,	And with that word, without more delay,
They fillen gruf and criden pitously,	They fell face down and cried piteously,
"Have on us wrecched wommen som mercy,	"Have some mercy on us wretched women,
And lat oure sorwe synken in thyn herte."	And let our sorrow sink in thy heart."
This gentil duc doun from his courser sterte	This gentle duke leaped down from his war horse
With herte pitous, whan he herde them speke.	With compassionate heart, when he heard them speak.
Hym thoughte that his herte wolde breke,	It seemed to him that his heart would break,
Whan he saugh hem so pitous and so maat,	When he saw them so pitiful and so dejected,
That whilom weren of so greet estaat;	That once were of such high rank;
And in his armes he hem alle up hente,	And in his arms he caught up them all,
And hem conforteth in ful good entente,	And comforts them with very good will,
And swoor his ooth, as he was trewe knyght,	And swore his oath, as he was true knight,
He wolde doon so ferforthly his myght	(That) he would do his might so completely
Upon the tiraunt Creon hem to wreke	To avenge them upon the tyrant Creon
That al the peple of Grece sholde speke	That all the people of Greece should speak (about)
How Creon was of Theseus yserved	How Creon was treated by Theseus
As he that hadde his deeth ful wel deserved.	As one who had very well deserved his death.
And right anoon, withouten moore abood,	And right away, without more delay,
His baner he desplayeth, and forth rood	He displays his banner, and rode forth
To Thebes-ward, and al his hoost biside.	Toward Thebes, and all his army beside (him).
No neer Atthenes wolde he go ne ride,	He would not walk nor ride any nearer to Athens,
Ne take his ese fully half a day,	Nor take his ease fully half a day,
But onward on his wey that nyght he lay,	But that night he lay (camped) on his way,
And sente anon Ypolita the queene,	And sent straightway Ypolita the queen,
And Emelye, hir yonge suster sheene,	And Emelye, her beautiful young sister,
Unto the toun of Atthenes to dwelle,	Unto the town of Athens to dwell,
And forth he rit; ther is namoore to telle.	And forth he rides; there is no more to tell.
The rede statue of Mars, with spere and targe,	The red statue of Mars, with spear and shield,
So shyneth in his white baner large	So shines in his large white banner
That alle the feeldes glyteren up and doun;	That all the fields glitter all around;
And by his baner born is his penoun	And by his banner is carried his pennon

The Mynotaur, which that he wan in Crete.	The Minotaur, which he defeated in Crete.
Thus rit this duc, thus rit this conquerour,	Thus rides this duke, thus rides this conqueror,
And in his hoost of chivalrie the flour,	And in his army the flower of chivalry,
Til that he cam to Thebes and alighte	Until he came to Thebes and dismounted

But shortly for to speken of this thyng,	But briefly to speak of this thing,
With Creon, which that was of Thebes kyng,	With Creon, who was king of Thebes,
He faught, and slough hym manly as a knyght	He fought, and slew him boldly as a knight

And by assaut he wan the citee after,	And by assault he won the city afterwards,

And to the ladyes he restored agayn	And he gave back to the ladies

To doon obsequies, as was tho the gyse.	To do obsequies, as was then the custom.
But it were al to longe for to devyse	But it would be all too long to describe

That the ladyes made at the brennynge	That the ladies made at the burning

That Theseus, the noble conquerour,	That Theseus, the noble conqueror,
Dooth to the ladyes, whan they from hym wente;	Does to the ladies, when they went from him;
But shortly for to telle is myn entente.	But briefly to tell is my intent.
Whan that this worthy duc, this Theseus,	When this worthy duke, this Theseus,
Hath Creon slayn and wonne Thebes thus,	Has slain Creon and thus won Thebes,
Stille in that feeld he took al nyght his reste,	Still in that field he took all night his rest,
And dide with al the contree as hym leste.	And did with all the country as he pleased.
To ransake in the taas of bodyes dede,	To search in the heap of dead bodies,
Hem for to strepe of harneys and of wede,	To strip them of armor and of clothing,
The pilours diden bisynesse and cure	The scavengers took great pains and worked hard
After the bataille and disconfiture.	After the battle and defeat.
And so bifel that in the taas they founde,	And (it) so befell that in the heap they found,
Thurgh-girt with many a grevous blody wounde,	Pierced through with many a grievous bloody wound,
Two yonge knyghtes liggynge by and by,	Two young knights lying side by side,
Bothe in oon armes, wroght ful richely,	Both with the same coat of arms, very richly wrought,
Of whiche two Arcita highte that oon,	Of which two one was called Arcite,
And that oother knyght highte Palamon.	And that other knight was called Palamon.
Nat fully quyke, ne fully dede they were,	They were not fully alive, nor fully dead,
But by hir cote-armures and by hir gere	But by their coats of arms and by their equipment
The heraudes knewe hem best in special	The heralds best knew them in particular
As they that weren of the blood roial	As they that were of the royal blood
Of Thebes, and of sustren two yborn.	Of Thebes, and born of two sisters.
Out of the taas the pilours han hem torn,	The scavengers have pulled them out of the heap,
And han hem caried softe unto the tente	And have carried them softy unto the tent
Of Theseus; and he ful soone hem sente	Of Theseus; and he very soon sent them
To Atthenes, to dwellen in prisoun	To Athens, to dwell in prison
Perpetuelly -- he nolde no raunsoun.	Perpetually -- he would not (accept) any ransom.
And whan this worthy duc hath thus ydon,	And when this worthy duke has thus done,
He took his hoost, and hoom he rit anon	He took his army, and home he rides straightway
With laurer crowned as a conquerour;	As a conqueror crowned with laurel;
And ther he lyveth in joye and in honour	And there he lives in joy and in honor
Terme of his lyf; what nedeth wordes mo?	For the duration of his life; what more words are needed?
And in a tour, in angwissh and in wo,	And in a tower, in anguish and in woe,
This Palamon and his felawe Arcite	This Palamon and his fellow Arcite
For everemoore; ther may no gold hem quite.	For evermore (remain); no gold can ransom them.
This passeth yeer by yeer and day by day,	This passes year by year and day by day,
Till it fil ones, in a morwe of May,	Until it befell once, in a morning of May,
That Emelye, that fairer was to sene	That Emelye, who was fairer to be seen
Than is the lylie upon his stalke grene,	Than is the lily upon its green stalk,
And fressher than the May with floures newe --	And fresher than the May with new flowers --
For with the rose colour stroof hire hewe,	For her hue vied with color of the rose,
I noot which was the fyner of hem two --	I do not know which was the finer of them two --
Er it were day, as was hir wone to do,	Before it was day, as was her custom to do,
She was arisen and al redy dight,	She was arisen and all ready prepared,
For May wole have no slogardie anyght.	For May will have no laziness at night.
The sesoun priketh every gentil herte,	The season urges on every gentle heart,
And maketh it out of his slep to sterte,	And makes it out of its sleep to awake suddenly,
And seith "Arys, and do thyn observaunce."	And says "Arise, and do thy observance."
This maked Emelye have remembraunce	This made Emelye remember
To doon honour to May, and for to ryse.	To do honor to May, and to rise.
Yclothed was she fressh, for to devyse:	She was gaily clothed, so to say:
Hir yelow heer was broyded in a tresse	Her yellow hair was braided in a tress
Bihynde hir bak, a yerde long, I gesse.	Behind her back, a yard long, I guess.
And in the gardyn, at the sonne upriste,	And in the garden, at the rising of the sun,
She walketh up and doun, and as hire liste	She walks up and down, and as she pleases
She gadereth floures, party white and rede,	She gathers flowers, mixed white and red,
To make a subtil gerland for hire hede;	To make an intricate garland for her head;
And as an aungel hevenysshly she soong.	And she sang (as) heavenly as an angel.
The grete tour, that was so thikke and stroong,	The great tower, that was so thick and strong,
Which of the castel was the chief dongeoun	Which was the main fortification of the castle
(Ther as the knyghtes weren in prisoun	(Where the knights were in prison
Of which I tolde yow and tellen shal),	Of which I told yow and shall tell),
Was evene joynant to the gardyn wal	Was just next to the garden wall
Ther as this Emelye hadde hir pleyynge.	Where this Emelye took her pleasure.
Bright was the sonne and cleer that morwenynge,	The sun was bright and clear that morning,
And Palamoun, this woful prisoner,	And Palamon, this woeful prisoner,
As was his wone, by leve of his gayler,	As was his custom, by permission of his jailer,
Was risen and romed in a chambre an heigh,	Had risen and roamed in a chamber on high,
In which he al the noble citee seigh,	In which he saw all the noble city,
And eek the gardyn, ful of braunches grene,	And also the garden, full of green branches,
Ther as this fresshe Emelye the shene	Where this fresh Emelye the bright
Was in hire walk, and romed up and doun.	Was in her walk, and roamed up and down.
This sorweful prisoner, this Palamoun,	This sorrowful prisoner, this Palamon,
Goth in the chambre romynge to and fro	Goes in the chamber roaming to and fro
And to hymself compleynynge of his wo.	And to himself lamenting his woe.
That he was born, ful ofte he seyde, "allas!"	That he was born, full often he said, "alas!"
And so bifel, by aventure or cas,	And so it happened, by chance or accident,
That thurgh a wyndow, thikke of many a barre	That through a window, thickly set with many a bar
Of iren greet and square as any sparre,	Of iron, great and square as any beam,
He cast his eye upon Emelya,	He cast his eye upon Emelye,
And therwithal he bleynte and cride, "A!"	And with that he turned pale and cried, "A!"
As though he stongen were unto the herte.	As though he were stabbed unto the heart.
And with that cry Arcite anon up sterte	And with that cry Arcite immediately leaped up
And seyde, "Cosyn myn, what eyleth thee,	And said, "My cousin, what ails thee,
That art so pale and deedly on to see?	Who art so pale and deadly to look upon?
Why cridestow? Who hath thee doon offence?	Why didst thou cry out? Who has done thee offence?
For Goddes love, taak al in pacience	For the love of God, take all in patience
Oure prisoun, for it may noon oother be.	Our imprisonment, for it may not be otherwise.
Fortune hath yeven us this adversitee.	Fortune has given us this adversity.
Som wikke aspect or disposicioun	Some wicked aspect or disposition
Of Saturne, by som constellacioun,	Of Saturn, by some arrangement of the heavenly bodies,
Hath yeven us this, although we hadde it sworn;	Has given us this, although we had sworn it would not be;
So stood the hevene whan that we were born.	So stood the heavens when we were born.
We moste endure it; this is the short and playn."	We must endure it; this is the short and plain."
This Palamon answerde and seyde agayn,	This Palamon answered and said in reply,
"Cosyn, for sothe, of this opinioun	"Cousin, truly, concerning this opinion
Thow hast a veyn ymaginacioun.	Thou hast a foolish conception.
This prison caused me nat for to crye,	This prison did not cause me to cry out,
But I was hurt right now thurghout myn ye	But I was hurt right now through my eye

I noot wher she be womman or goddesse,	I know not whether she is woman or goddess,
But Venus is it soothly, as I gesse."	But truly it is Venus, as I suppose."

Out of this prisoun help that we may scapen.	Help that we may escape out of this prison.
And if so be my destynee be shapen	And if it be so that my destiny is shaped

And with that word Arcite gan espye	And with that word Arcite did see
Wher as this lady romed to and fro,	Where this lady roamed to and fro,

Arcite is hurt as muche as he, or moore.	Arcite is hurt as much as he, or more.
And with a sigh he seyde pitously,	And with a sigh he said piteously,

And but I have hir mercy and hir grace,	And unless I have her mercy and her grace,
That I may seen hire atte leeste weye,	So that I can at least see her,
I nam but deed; ther nis namoore to seye."	I am as good as dead; there is no more to say."
This Palamon, whan he tho wordes herde,	This Palamon, when he heard those words,
Dispitously he looked and answerde,	Angrily he looked and answered,
"Wheither seistow this in ernest or in pley?"	"Sayest thou this in earnest or in play?"
"Nay," quod Arcite, "in ernest, by my fey!	"Nay," said Arcite, "in earnest, by my faith!
God helpe me so, me list ful yvele pleye."	So help me God, I have no desire to play."
This Palamon gan knytte his browes tweye.	This Palamon did knit his two brows.
"It nere," quod he, "to thee no greet honour	"It would not be," said he, "any great honor to thee
For to be fals, ne for to be traitour	To be false, nor to be traitor
To me, that am thy cosyn and thy brother	To me, who am thy cousin and thy brother
Ysworn ful depe, and ech of us til oother,	Sworn very sincerely, and each of us to the other,
That nevere, for to dyen in the peyne,	That never, though we had to die by torture,
Til that the deeth departe shal us tweyne,	Until death shall part us two,

But that thou sholdest trewely forthren me	But rather thou shouldest truly help me

I woot right wel, thou darst it nat withseyn.	I know right well, thou darest not deny it.
Thus artow of my conseil, out of doute,	Thus thou art my trusted confidant, without doubt,

To love my lady, whom I love and serve,	To love my lady, whom I love and serve,
And evere shal til that myn herte sterve.	And ever shall until my heart dies.
Nay, certes, false Arcite, thow shalt nat so.	Nay, certainly, false Arcite, thou shalt not (do) so.
I loved hire first, and tolde thee my wo	I loved hire first, and told thee my woe

To forthre me, as I have toold biforn.	To further me, as I have told before.
For which thou art ybounden as a knyght	For which thou art bound as a knight
To helpen me, if it lay in thy myght,	To help me, if it lay in thy power,
Or elles artow fals, I dar wel seyn."	Or else thou art false, I dare well say."
This Arcite ful proudly spak ageyn:	This Arcite full proudly spoke in return:
"Thow shalt," quod he, "be rather fals than I;	"Thou shalt," said he, "be rather false than I;
And thou art fals, I telle thee outrely,	And thou art false, I tell thee flatly,
For paramour I loved hire first er thow.	As a mistress I loved her first before thou.
What wiltow seyen? Thou woost nat yet now	What wilt thou say? Thou knowest not yet now
Wheither she be a womman or goddesse!	Whether she is a woman or goddess!
Thyn is affeccioun of hoolynesse,	Thine is a feeling of holiness,
And myn is love as to a creature;	And mine is love as to a creature;
For which I tolde thee myn aventure	For which I told thee my circumstance
As to my cosyn and my brother sworn.	As to my cousin and my sworn brother.
I pose that thow lovedest hire biforn;	I posit (this assumption): that thou lovedest her first;
Wostow nat wel the olde clerkes sawe,	Knowest thou not well the old clerks' saying,
That `who shal yeve a lovere any lawe?'	That `who shall give a lover any law?'
Love is a gretter lawe, by my pan,	Love is a greater law, by my skull,
Than may be yeve to any erthely man;	Than may be given to any earthly man;
And therfore positif lawe and swich decree	And therefore positive (man-made) law and such decree
Is broken al day for love in ech degree.	Is broken every day for love in every way.
A man moot nedes love, maugree his heed;	A man must of necessity love, in spite of all he can do;
He may nat fleen it, thogh he sholde be deed,	He can not flee (from) it, though he should be dead,
Al be she mayde, or wydwe, or elles wyf.	Whether she be maid, or widow, or else wife.
And eek it is nat likly al thy lyf	And also it is not likely all thy life
To stonden in hir grace; namoore shal I;	To stand in her good graces; no more shall I;
For wel thou woost thyselven, verraily,	For well thou thyself knowest, truly,
That thou and I be dampned to prisoun	That thou and I are condemned to prison
Perpetuelly; us gayneth no raunsoun.	Perpetually; no ransom can help us.
We stryve as dide the houndes for the boon;	We strive as the hounds did for the bone;
They foughte al day, and yet hir part was noon.	They fought all day, and yet their share was nothing.
Ther cam a kyte, whil that they were so wrothe,	There came a kite, while they were so angry,
And baar awey the boon bitwixe hem bothe.	And carried away the bone between them both.
And therfore, at the kynges court, my brother,	And therefore, at the king's court, my brother,
Ech man for hymself, ther is noon oother.	Each man for himself, there is no other (way).
Love, if thee list, for I love and ay shal;	Love, if it please thee, for I love and always shall;
And soothly, leeve brother, this is al.	And truly, dear brother, this is all.
Heere in this prisoun moote we endure,	Here in this prison we must endure,
And everich of us take his aventure."	And each one of us take his chance."
Greet was the strif and long bitwix hem tweye,	Great and long was the strife between them two,
If that I hadde leyser for to seye;	If I had leisure to tell (it);
But to th'effect. It happed on a day,	But to the point. It happened on a day,
To telle it yow as shortly as I may,	To tell it to you as briefly as I can,
A worthy duc that highte Perotheus,	A worthy duke that was called Perotheus,
That felawe was unto duc Theseus	Who was a friend to duke Theseus
Syn thilke day that they were children lite,	Since that same time that they were little children,
Was come to Atthenes his felawe to visite,	Had come to Athens to visit his friend,
And for to pleye as he was wont to do;	And to amuse himself as he was accustomed to do;
For in this world he loved no man so,	For in this world he loved no man so (much),
And he loved hym als tendrely agayn.	And he (Theseus) loved him as tenderly in turn.
So wel they lovede, as olde bookes sayn,	So well they loved, as old books say,
That whan that oon was deed, soothly to telle,	That when one was dead, truly to tell,
His felawe wente and soughte hym doun in helle --	His friend went and sought him down in hell --
But of that storie list me nat to write.	But of that story I do not desire to write.
Duc Perotheus loved wel Arcite,	Duke Perotheus loved well Arcite,
And hadde hym knowe at Thebes yeer by yere,	And had known him at Thebes year after year,
And finally at requeste and preyere	And finally at request and prayer
Of Perotheus, withouten any raunsoun,	Of Perotheus, without any ransom,
Duc Theseus hym leet out of prisoun	Duke Theseus let him out of prison
Frely to goon wher that hym liste over al,	Freely to go all over, wherever he wishes,
In swich a gyse as I you tellen shal.	In such a manner as shall I tell you.
This was the forward, pleynly for t'endite,	This was the agreement, plainly to write,
Bitwixen Theseus and hym Arcite:	Between Theseus and this Arcite:
That if so were that Arcite were yfounde	That if it so were that Arcite were found
Evere in his lif, by day or nyght, oo stounde	Ever in his life, by day or night, at any moment
In any contree of this Theseus,	In any country of this Theseus,
And he were caught, it was acorded thus,	And if he were caught, it was agreed thus,
That with a swerd he sholde lese his heed.	That with a sword he should lose his head.
Ther nas noon oother remedie ne reed;	There was no other remedy nor course of action;
But taketh his leve, and homward he him spedde.	But (he) takes his leave, and homeward he sped.
Lat hym be war! His nekke lith to wedde.	Let him be ware! His neck lies as a pledge.
How greet a sorwe suffreth now Arcite!	How great a sorrow now suffers Arcite!
The deeth he feeleth thurgh his herte smyte;	He feels the death smite through his heart;
He wepeth, wayleth, crieth pitously;	He weeps, wails, cries piteously;
To sleen hymself he waiteth prively.	To slay himself he secretly awaits (an opportunity).
He seyde, "Allas that day that I was born!	He said, "Alas that day that I was born!
Now is my prisoun worse than biforn;	Now my prison is worse than before;
Now is me shape eternally to dwelle	Now I am destined eternally to dwell
Noght in purgatorie, but in helle.	Not in purgatory, but in hell.
Allas, that evere knew I Perotheus!	Alas, that ever I knew Perotheus!
For elles hadde I dwelled with Theseus,	For else I would have remained with Theseus,
Yfetered in his prisoun everemo.	Fettered in his prison evermore.
Thanne hadde I been in blisse and nat in wo.	Then would I have been in bliss and not in woe.
Oonly the sighte of hire whom that I serve,	Only the sight of her whom I serve,
Though that I nevere hir grace may deserve,	Though I never can deserve her grace,
Wolde han suffised right ynough for me.	Would have sufficed right enough for me.
O deere cosyn Palamon," quod he,	O dear cousin Palamon," said he,
"Thyn is the victorie of this aventure.	"The victory of this adventure is thine.
Ful blisfully in prison maistow dure --	Very blissfully in prison thou can remain --
In prison? Certes nay, but in paradys!	In prison? Certainly not, but in paradise!
Wel hath Fortune yturned thee the dys,	Well has Fortune turned the dice for thee,
That hast the sighte of hire, and I th'absence.	That hast the sight of her, and I the absence.
For possible is, syn thou hast hire presence,	For it is possible, since thou hast her presence,
And art a knyght, a worthy and an able,	And art a knight, a worthy and an able (one),
That by som cas, syn Fortune is chaungeable,	That by some chance, since Fortune is changeable,
Thow maist to thy desir somtyme atteyne.	Thou mayest sometime attain thy desire.
But I, that am exiled and bareyne	But I, who am exiled and barren
Of alle grace, and in so greet dispeir	Of all grace, and in so great despair
That ther nys erthe, water, fir, ne eir,	That there is not earth, water, fire, nor air,
Ne creature that of hem maked is,	Nor creature that is made of them,
That may me helpe or doon confort in this,	That can help me or do comfort (to me) in this,
Wel oughte I sterve in wanhope and distresse.	Well ought I to die in despair and distress.
Farwel my lif, my lust, and my gladnesse!	Farwell my life, my desire, and my gladness!
"Allas, why pleynen folk so in commune	"Alas, why do folk so commonly complain
On purveiaunce of God, or of Fortune,	About the providence of God, or of Fortune,
That yeveth hem ful ofte in many a gyse	That gives them full often in many a manner
Wel bettre than they kan hemself devyse?	Much better than they can themselves imagine?
Som man desireth for to han richesse,	One man desires to have riches,
That cause is of his mordre or greet siknesse;	Which is the cause of his murder or great sickness;
And som man wolde out of his prisoun fayn,	And one man would happily (go) out of his prison,
That in his hous is of his meynee slayn.	Who is slain in his house by members of his household.
Infinite harmes been in this mateere.	Infinite harms are in this matter.
We witen nat what thing we preyen heere;	We know not what thing we pray for here;
We faren as he that dronke is as a mous.	We act like one who is drunk as a mouse.
A dronke man woot wel he hath an hous,	A drunk man knows well he has a house,
But he noot which the righte wey is thider,	But he does not know which is the right way to it,
And to a dronke man the wey is slider.	And to a drunk man the way is slippery.
And certes, in this world so faren we;	And certainly, so we fare in this world;
We seken faste after felicitee,	We seek eagerly after felicity,
But we goon wrong ful often, trewely.	But we go wrong very often, truly.
Thus may we seyen alle, and namely I,	Thus can we all say, and especially I,
That wende and hadde a greet opinioun	Who supposed and had a firm belief
That if I myghte escapen from prisoun,	That if I might escape from prison,
Thanne hadde I been in joye and parfit heele,	Then I would have been in joy and perfect well-being,
Ther now I am exiled fro my wele.	Whereas now I am exiled from my source of happiness.
Syn that I may nat seen you, Emelye,	Since I can not see you, Emelye,
I nam but deed; ther nys no remedye."	I am as good as dead; there is not any remedy."
Upon that oother syde Palamon,	Upon that other side Palamon,
Whan that he wiste Arcite was agon,	When he knew Arcite was gone,
Swich sorwe he maketh that the grete tour	He makes such sorrow that the great tour
Resouneth of his youlyng and clamour.	Resounds with his yowling and clamor.
The pure fettres on his shynes grete	The great fetters themselves on his shins
Weren of his bittre, salte teeres wete.	Were wet from his bitter, salt tears.
"Allas," quod he, "Arcita, cosyn myn,	"Alas," said he, "Arcite, cousin mine,
Of al oure strif, God woot, the fruyt is thyn.	Of all our strife, God knows, the profit is thine.
Thow walkest now in Thebes at thy large,	Thou walkest freely now in Thebes,
And of my wo thow yevest litel charge.	And thou care little about my woe.
Thou mayst, syn thou hast wisdom and manhede,	Thou mayest, since thou hast wisdom and manhood,
Assemblen alle the folk of oure kynrede,	Assemble all the folk of our family,
And make a werre so sharp on this citee	And make a war so sharp on this city
That by som aventure or some tretee	That by some chance or some treaty
Thow mayst have hire to lady and to wyf	Thou mayest have her as lady and as wife
For whom that I moste nedes lese my lyf.	For whom I must of necessity lose my life.
For, as by wey of possibilitee,	For, as by way of possibility,
Sith thou art at thy large, of prisoun free,	Since thou art at thy liberty, free of prison,
And art a lord, greet is thyn avauntage	And art a lord, thy advantage is great,
Moore than is myn, that sterve here in a cage.	More than is mine, who die here in a cage.
For I moot wepe and wayle, whil I lyve,	For I must weep and wail, while I live,
With al the wo that prison may me yive,	With all the woe that prison may give me,
And eek with peyne that love me yeveth also,	And also with pain that love gives me also,
That doubleth al my torment and my wo."	That doubles all my torment and my woe."
Therwith the fyr of jalousie up sterte	With that the fire of jealousy started up
Withinne his brest, and hente him by the herte	Within his breast, and seized him by the heart
So woodly that he lyk was to biholde	So madly that he was to look upon like
The boxtree or the asshen dede and colde.	The box tree or the ash dead and cold.
Thanne seyde he, "O crueel goddes that governe	Then said he, "O cruel gods that govern
This world with byndyng of youre word eterne,	This world with binding of your eternal word,
And writen in the table of atthamaunt	And write in the table of adamant (hardest of stones)
Youre parlement and youre eterne graunt,	Your decision and your eternal decree,
What is mankynde moore unto you holde	Why is mankind more obligated unto you
Than is the sheep that rouketh in the folde?	Than is the sheep that cowers in the sheepfold?
For slayn is man right as another beest,	For man is slain exactly like another beast,
And dwelleth eek in prison and arreest,	And dwells also in prison and detention,
And hath siknesse and greet adversitee,	And has sickness and great adversity,
And ofte tymes giltelees, pardee.	And often times guiltless, indeed.
"What governance is in this prescience,	"What (sort of) governance is in this foreknowledge,
That giltelees tormenteth innocence?	That torments guiltless innocence?
And yet encresseth this al my penaunce,	And yet this increases all my suffering,
That man is bounden to his observaunce,	That man is bound to his duty,
For Goddes sake, to letten of his wille,	For God's sake, to refrain from his desire,
Ther as a beest may al his lust fulfille.	Whereas a beast may fulfill all his desire.
And whan a beest is deed he hath no peyne;	And when a beast is dead he has no pain;
But man after his deeth moot wepe and pleyne,	But man after his death must weep and lament,
Though in this world he have care and wo.	Though in this world he may have (had) care and woe.
Withouten doute it may stonden so.	Without doubt such is the case.
The answere of this lete I to dyvynys,	The answer to this I leave to theologians,
But wel I woot that in this world greet pyne ys.	But well I know that great pain is in this world.
Allas, I se a serpent or a theef,	Alas, I see a serpent or a thief,
That many a trewe man hath doon mescheef,	That has done mischief to many a true man,
Goon at his large, and where hym list may turne.	Go at his liberty, and can go where he pleases.
But I moot been in prisoun thurgh Saturne,	But I must be in prison because of Saturn,
And eek thurgh Juno, jalous and eek wood,	And also because of Juno, jealous and also mad,
That hath destroyed wel ny al the blood	Who has destroyed well nigh all the blood
Of Thebes with his waste walles wyde;	Of Thebes with its wide devastated walls;
And Venus sleeth me on that oother syde	And Venus slays me on that other side
For jalousie and fere of hym Arcite."	For jealousy and fear of this Arcite."
Now wol I stynte of Palamon a lite,	Now will I cease (speaking of) of Palamon for a little while,
And lete hym in his prisoun stille dwelle,	And leave him to dwell in his prison still,
And of Arcita forth I wol yow telle.	And of Arcite forth I will tell you.
The somer passeth, and the nyghtes longe	The summer passes, and the long nights
Encressen double wise the peynes stronge	Increase doubly the strong pains
Bothe of the lovere and the prisoner.	Both of the lover and the prisoner.
I noot which hath the wofuller mester.	I know not which has the more woeful task.
For, shortly for to seyn, this Palamoun	For, briefly to say (it), this Palamon
Perpetuelly is dampned to prisoun,	Is damned perpetually to prison,
In cheynes and in fettres to been deed;	In chains and in fetters to be dead;
And Arcite is exiled upon his heed	And Arcite is exiled on threat of losing his head
For everemo, as out of that contree,	For evermore, out of that country,
Ne nevere mo ne shal his lady see.	Nor nevermore shall see his lady.
Yow loveres axe I now this questioun:	Yow lovers now I ask this question:
Who hath the worse, Arcite or Palamoun?	Who has the worse, Arcite or Palamon?
That oon may seen his lady day by day,	That one may see his lady every day,
But in prison he moot dwelle alway;	But in prison he must always dwell;
That oother wher hym list may ride or go,	That other where he pleases may ride or walk,
But seen his lady shal he nevere mo.	But he shall see his lady nevermore.
Now demeth as yow liste, ye that kan,	Now judge as it pleases you, you who know (of such things),
For I wol telle forth as I bigan.	For I will tell forth as I began.
Whan that Arcite to Thebes comen was,	When Arcite was come to Thebes,
Ful ofte a day he swelte and seyde "Allas!"	Very often each day he grew faint and said "Alas!"
For seen his lady shal he nevere mo.	For he shall never more see his lady.
And shortly to concluden al his wo,	And shortly to conclude (telling) all his woe,
So muche sorwe hadde nevere creature	So much sorrow never had creature
That is, or shal, whil that the world may dure.	That is, or shall (be), while the world may endure.
His slep, his mete, his drynke, is hym biraft,	He is bereft of his sleep, his food, his drink
That lene he wex and drye as is a shaft;	So that he became lean and dry as is a stick;
His eyen holwe and grisly to biholde,	His eyes sunken and grisly to behold,
His hewe falow and pale as asshen colde,	His hue sickly yellow and pale as cold ashes,
And solitarie he was and evere allone,	And he was solitary and ever alone,
And waillynge al the nyght, makynge his mone;	And wailing all the night, making his moan;
And if he herde song or instrument,	And if he heard song or instrument,
Thanne wolde he wepe, he myghte nat be stent.	Then would he weep, he could not be stopped.
So feble eek were his spiritz, and so lowe,	So feeble also were his spirits, and so low,
And chaunged so, that no man koude knowe	And changed so, that no man could know
His speche nor his voys, though men it herde.	His speech nor his voice, though men heard it.
And in his geere for al the world he ferde	And in his behavior for all the world he fared
Nat oonly lik the loveris maladye	Not only like the lover's malady
Of Hereos, but rather lyk manye,	Of Hereos, but rather like mania,
Engendred of humour malencolik	Engendered by the melancholic humor
Biforen, in his celle fantastik.	In the front lobe, in his imagination.
And shortly, turned was al up so doun	And shortly, all was turned topsy-turvy
Bothe habit and eek disposicioun	Both the physical condition and also the mental disposition
Of hym, this woful lovere daun Arcite.	Of him, this woeful lover dan Arcite.
What sholde I al day of his wo endite?	Why should I all daylong write of his woe?
Whan he endured hadde a yeer or two	When he had endured a year or two
This crueel torment and this peyne and wo,	This cruel torment and this pain and woe,
At Thebes, in his contree, as I seyde,	At Thebes, in his country, as I said,
Upon a nyght in sleep as he hym leyde,	Upon one night as he laid himself in sleep,
Hym thoughte how that the wynged god Mercurie	It seemed to him that the winged god Mercury
Biforn hym stood and bad hym to be murie.	Stood before him and commanded him to be merry.
His slepy yerde in hond he bar uprighte;	His sleep-inducing staff he carried upright in his hand;
An hat he werede upon his heris brighte.	He wore a hat upon his bright hair.
Arrayed was this god, as he took keep,	This god was dressed, as he (Arcite) noticed,
As he was whan that Argus took his sleep;	As he was when he put Argus to sleep;
And seyde hym thus: "To Atthenes shaltou wende,	And said to him thus: "To Athens shalt thou go,
Ther is thee shapen of thy wo an ende."	Where an end of thy woe is destined for thee."
And with that word Arcite wook and sterte.	And with that word Arcite awoke and leaped up.
"Now trewely, hou soore that me smerte,"	"Now truly, however sorely it may pain me,"
Quod he, "to Atthenes right now wol I fare,	Said he, "I will go to Athens right now,
Ne for the drede of deeth shal I nat spare	Nor shall I refrain for the dread of death
To se my lady, that I love and serve.	From seeing my lady, whom I love and serve.
In hire presence I recche nat to sterve."	In her presence I care not if I die."
And with that word he caughte a greet mirour,	And with that word he picked up a large mirror,
And saugh that chaunged was al his colour,	And saw that all his color was changed,
And saugh his visage al in another kynde.	And saw his visage all (changed) to another sort.
And right anon it ran hym in his mynde,	And right away it ran to him in his mind,
That, sith his face was so disfigured	That, since his face was so disfigured
Of maladye the which he hadde endured,	By the malady which he had endured,
He myghte wel, if that he bar hym lowe,	He might well, if he conducted himself humbly,
Lyve in Atthenes everemoore unknowe,	Live in Athens evermore unknown,
And seen his lady wel ny day by day.	And see his lady almost every day.
And right anon he chaunged his array,	And right away he changed his clothing,
And cladde hym as a povre laborer,	And clad himself as a poor laborer,
And al allone, save oonly a squier	And all alone, except only a squire
That knew his privetee and al his cas,	Who knew his private affairs and all his situation,
Which was disgised povrely as he was,	Who was disguised as poorly as he was,
To Atthenes is he goon the nexte way.	To Athens he is gone the nearest way.
And to the court he wente upon a day,	And to the court he went upon a day,
And at the gate he profreth his servyse	And at the gate he offers his service
To drugge and drawe, what so men wol devyse.	To drudge and draw water, whatever men will command.
And shortly of this matere for to seyn,	And shortly to speak of this matter,
He fil in office with a chamberleyn	He was given employment by a household attendant
The which that dwellynge was with Emelye,	Who was dwelling with Emelye,
For he was wys and koude soone espye,	For he was wise and could soon take the measure
Of every servaunt, which that serveth here.	Of every servant, who serves here.
Wel koude he hewen wode, and water bere,	He could well hew wood, and carry water,
For he was yong and myghty for the nones,	For he was young and mighty indeed,
And therto he was long and big of bones	And moreover he was tall and strong of bones
To doon that any wight kan hym devyse.	To do what any one can command him.
A yeer or two he was in this servyse,	A year or two he was in this service,
Page of the chambre of Emelye the brighte,	Page of the chamber of Emelye the bright,
And Philostrate he seyde that he highte.	And he said that he was called Philostrate.
But half so wel biloved a man as he	But half so well beloved a man as he
Ne was ther nevere in court of his degree;	Was never in court (anyone) of his rank;
He was so gentil of condicioun	He was so noble in manner
That thurghout al the court was his renoun.	That his fame was (spread) throughout all the court .
They seyden that it were a charitee	They said that it would be a act of charity
That Theseus wolde enhauncen his degree,	If Theseus would advance his rank,
And putten hym in worshipful servyse,	And put him in noble employment,
Ther as he myghte his vertu excercise.	Where he could exercise his abilities.
And thus withinne a while his name is spronge,	And thus within a short time his fame is sprung,
Bothe of his dedes and his goode tonge,	Both for his deeds and his good speech,
That Theseus hath taken hym so neer	That Theseus has taken him so near
That of his chambre he made hym a squier,	That he has made him a squire of his chamber,
And gaf hym gold to mayntene his degree.	And gave him gold to maintain (a life style suitable to) his rank.
And eek men broghte hym out of his contree,	And also men brought him out of his country,
From yeer to yeer, ful pryvely his rente;	From year to year, very secretly, his income;
But honestly and slyly he it spente,	But properly and slyly he spent it,
That no man wondred how that he it hadde.	So that no man wondered how he acquired it.
And thre yeer in this wise his lif he ladde,	And three years in this manner he led his life,
And bar hym so, in pees and eek in werre,	And conducted himself so that, in peace and also in war,
Ther was no man that Theseus hath derre.	There was no man whom Theseus holds dearer.
And in this blisse lete I now Arcite,	And in this bliss I now leave Arcite,
And speke I wole of Palamon a lite.	And I will speak of Palamon a little.
In derknesse and horrible and strong prisoun	In darkness and horrible and strong imprisonment
Thise seven yeer hath seten Palamoun	These seven years Palamon has sat
Forpyned, what for wo and for distresse.	Wasted by suffering, what for woe and for distress.
Who feeleth double soor and hevynesse	Who feels double pain and sadness
But Palamon, that love destreyneth so	But Palamon, whom love so afflicts
That wood out of his wit he goth for wo?	That he goes mad, out of his wits because of woe?
And eek therto he is a prisoner	And also moreover he is a prisoner
Perpetuelly, noght oonly for a yer.	Perpetually, not just for a year.
Who koude ryme in Englyssh proprely	Who could rime in English properly
His martirdom? For sothe it am nat I;	His martyrdom? In truth it is not I;
Therfore I passe as lightly as I may.	Therefore I pass on as quickly as I can.
It fel that in the seventhe yer, of May	It happened that in the seventh year, of May
The thridde nyght (as olde bookes seyn,	The third night (as old books say,
That al this storie tellen moore pleyn),	That tell all this story more fully),
Were it by aventure or destynee --	Whether it was by chance or fate --
As, whan a thyng is shapen, it shal be --	As, when a thing is pre-ordained, it must be --
That soone after the mydnyght Palamoun,	That soon after midnight Palamon,
By helpyng of a freend, brak his prisoun	With the help of a friend, broke out of his prison
And fleeth the citee faste as he may go.	And flees the city as fast as he can go.
For he hadde yeve his gayler drynke so	For he had so given his jailer drink
Of a clarree maad of a certeyn wyn,	Of a spiced and sweetened drink made of a certain wine,
With nercotikes and opie of Thebes fyn,	With narcotics and pure opium of Thebes,
That al that nyght, thogh that men wolde him shake,	That all that night, though men would shake him,
The gayler sleep; he myghte nat awake.	The jailer slept; he could not awake.
And thus he fleeth as faste as evere he may.	And thus he flees as fast as ever he can.
The nyght was short and faste by the day	The night was short and very close to the day
That nedes cost he moot hymselven hyde,	So that by necessity he must hide himself,
And til a grove faste ther bisyde	And to a grove close by
With dredeful foot thanne stalketh Palamon.	With fearful foot then stalks Palamon.
For, shortly, this was his opinion:	For, shortly, this was his idea:
That in that grove he wolde hym hyde al day,	That in that grove he would hide himself all day,
And in the nyght thanne wolde he take his way	And in the night then he would take his way
To Thebes-ward, his freendes for to preye	Toward Thebes, to pray his friends

And shortly, outher he wolde lese his lif	And shortly, he would either lose his life
Or wynnen Emelye unto his wyf.	Or win Emelye to be his wife.
This is th'effect and his entente pleyn.	This is the purpose and his full intent.
Now wol I turne to Arcite ageyn,	Now I will turn again to Arcite,
That litel wiste how ny that was his care,	That little knew how near his trouble was,
Til that Fortune had broght him in the snare.	To which Fortune had brought him in the snare.
The bisy larke, messager of day,	The busy lark, messenger of day,
Salueth in hir song the morwe gray,	Salutes the morning gray in her song,
And firy Phebus riseth up so bright	And fiery Phoebus rises up so bright

And in a path he rometh up and doun,	And in a path he roams up and down,
Ther as by aventure this Palamoun	Where by chance this Palamon

For soore afered of his deeth was he.	For he was sorely afraid of his death.

It is ful fair a man to bere hym evene,	It is very good for a man to act calmly,

Ful litel woot Arcite of his felawe,	Arcite knows full little of his fellow,
That was so ny to herknen al his sawe,	Who was near enough to hear all his speech,
For in the bussh he sitteth now ful stille.	For in the thicket he sits now very still.

Of Cadmus, which that was the firste man	Of Cadmus, who was the first man

So that I koude doon aught to youre plesaunce."	Provided that I could do anything to please you."

And I wol love hire maugree al thy myght!	And I will love her in spite of all thy might!

This Palamon answerde, "I graunte it thee."	This Palamon answered, "I agree."
And thus they been departed til amorwe,	And thus they are departed until morning,
Whan ech of hem had leyd his feith to borwe.	When each of them had laid his faith as a pledge.
O Cupide, out of alle charitee!	O Cupid, devoid of all kindness to others!
O regne, that wolt no felawe have with thee!	O reign, that will have no partner with thee!
Ful sooth is seyd that love ne lordshipe	Full truly it is said that love nor lordship

Wel fynden that Arcite and Palamoun.	Arcite and Palamon well find that (to be true).
Arcite is riden anon unto the toun,	Arcite has ridden immediately into the town,

And in the grove, at tyme and place yset,	And in the grove, at time and place set,
This Arcite and this Palamon ben met.	This Arcite and this Palamon are met.
To chaungen gan the colour in hir face;	The color in their faces began to change;

That stondeth at the gappe with a spere,	He who stands at the gap in the forrest with a spear,
Whan hunted is the leon or the bere,	When the lion or the bear is hunted,

As fer as everich of hem oother knewe.	When each of them knew the other.

Thou myghtest wene that this Palamon	Thou mightest suppose that this Palamon

And forth I wole of Theseus yow telle.	And forth I will tell you of Theseus.
The destinee, ministre general,	The destiny, general minister,
That executeth in the world over al	That executes in the world everywhere
The purveiaunce that God hath seyn biforn,	The providence that God has foreseen,
So strong it is that, though the world had sworn	So strong it is that, though the world had sworn
The contrarie of a thyng by ye or nay,	The contrary of a thing by yes or no,
Yet somtyme it shal fallen on a day	Yet sometimes it shall happen on one day
That falleth nat eft withinne a thousand yeer.	That happens not again in a thousand years.
For certeinly, oure appetites heer,	For certainly, our desires here,

This mene I now by myghty Theseus,	I mean this now in regard to mighty Theseus,
That for to hunten is so desirus,	Who is so desirous to hunt,

Cleer was the day, as I have toold er this,	The day was clear, as I have told before this,
