Now looketh, is nat that an heigh folye?	Now look, is that not a great folly?
Who may been a fool but if he love?	Who can be a fool unless he is in love?
Bihoold, for Goddes sake that sit above,	Behold, for the sake of God who sits above,
Se how they blede! Be they noght wel arrayed?	See how they bleed! Are they not in fine condition?
Thus hath hir lord, the god of love, ypayed	Thus has their lord, the god of love, paid
Hir wages and hir fees for hir servyse!	Their wages and their fees for their service!
And yet they wenen for to been ful wyse	And yet they consider themselves very wise,
That serven love, for aught that may bifalle.	Those who serve love, whatever may happen.
But this is yet the beste game of alle,	But this is yet the best joke of all,
That she for whom they han this jolitee	That she for whom they have this sport
Kan hem therfore as muche thank as me.	Owes them as much gratitude for this as she owes me.
She woot namoore of al this hoote fare,	She knows no more of all this passionate business,
By God, than woot a cokkow or an hare!	By God, than knows a cuckoo or a hare!
But all moot ben assayed, hoot and coold;	But all must be tried, hot or cold;
A man moot ben a fool, or yong or oold --	A man must be a fool, either young or old --
I woot it by myself ful yore agon,	I know it by my own experience very long ago,
For in my tyme a servant was I oon.	For in my time I was a servant (of love).
And therfore, syn I knowe of loves peyne	And therefore, since I know of love's pain
And woot hou soore it kan a man distreyne,	And know how sorely it can afflict a man,
As he that hath ben caught ofte in his laas,	As one who has been often caught in its snare,
I yow foryeve al hoolly this trespaas,	I wholly forgive you this trespass,
At requeste of the queene, that kneleth heere,	At the request of the queen, who kneels here,
And eek of Emelye, my suster deere.	And also of Emelye, my dear sister.
And ye shul bothe anon unto me swere	And you must both immediately swear unto me
That nevere mo ye shal my contree dere,	That you shall never more harm my country,
Ne make werre upon me nyght ne day,	Nor make war upon me at any time,
But been my freendes in all that ye may.	But be my friends in all that you can.
I yow foryeve this trespas every deel."	I forgive you this trespass completely."
And they hym sworen his axyng faire and weel,	And they fairly and well swore to him (to do) his request,
And hym of lordshipe and of mercy preyde,	And prayed him to be their lord and to have mercy ,
And he hem graunteth grace, and thus he seyde:	And he grants them his favor, and thus he said:
"To speke of roial lynage and richesse,	"To speak of royal lineage and riches,
Though that she were a queene or a princesse,	Though she were a queen or a princess,
Ech of you bothe is worthy, doutelees,	Each of you both is worthy, doubtless,
To wedden whan tyme is; but nathelees --	To wed when it is time; but none the less --
I speke as for my suster Emelye,	I speak for my sister Emelye,
For whom ye have this strif and jalousye --	For whom you have this strife and jealousy --
Ye woot yourself she may nat wedden two	You know yourself she can not wed two
Atones, though ye fighten everemo,	At once, though you were to fight for evermore,
That oon of you, al be hym looth or lief,	That one of you, whether he likes it or not,
He moot go pipen in an yvy leef;	He must go whistle in an ivy leaf;
This is to seyn, she may nat now han bothe,	This is to say, she can not now have both,
Al be ye never so jalouse ne so wrothe.	Although you be never so jealous nor so angry.
And forthy I yow putte in this degree,	And therefore I put you in this situation,
That ech of yow shal have his destynee	That each of you shall have his destiny
As hym is shape, and herkneth in what wyse;	As is ordained for him, and listen in what way;
Lo, heere youre ende of that I shal devyse.	Lo, hear what I shall arrange for your fate.
My wyl is this, for plat conclusioun,	My will is this, for flat conclusion,
Withouten any repplicacioun --	Without any arguing --
If that you liketh, take it for the beste:	If this pleases you, take it for the best:
That everich of you shal goon where hym leste	That each one of you shall go where he pleases
Frely, withouten raunson or daunger,	Freely, without ransom or resistance,
And this day fifty wykes, fer ne ner,	And fifty weeks from this day, more or less,
Everich of you shal brynge an hundred knyghtes	Each one of you shall bring a hundred knights
Armed for lystes up at alle rightes,	Armed up for the lists in all respects,
Al redy to darreyne hire by bataille.	All ready to decide the right to her by battle.
And this bihote I yow withouten faille,	And this I promise you without fail,
Upon my trouthe, and as I am a knyght,	Upon my word, and as I am a knight,
That wheither of yow bothe that hath myght --	That whichever of you both who has the power --
This is to seyn, that wheither he or thow	This is to say, that whether he or thou
May with his hundred, as I spak of now,	Can with his hundred, as I spoke of now,
Sleen his contrarie, or out of lystes dryve,	Slay his opponent, or drive him out of the lists ,
Thanne shal I yeve Emelya to wyve	Then I shall give Emelye as wife
To whom that Fortune yeveth so fair a grace.	To whom Fortune gives so good a gift (to win the battle).
The lystes shal I maken in this place,	I shall make the lists in this place,
And God so wisly on my soule rewe	And as God may surely have pity on my soul
As I shal evene juge been and trewe.	I shall be an impartial and true judge.
Ye shul noon oother ende with me maken,	You shall make no other agreement with me,
That oon of yow ne shal be deed or taken.	(Save this:) that one of you must be dead or taken.
And if yow thynketh this is weel ysayd,	And if it seems to you that this is well said,
Seyeth youre avys, and holdeth you apayd.	Say your opinion, and consider yourself satisfied.
This is youre ende and youre conclusioun."	This is your (destined) end and your conclusion."
Who looketh lightly now but Palamoun?	Who but Palamon looks happy now?
Who spryngeth up for joye but Arcite?	Who springs up for joy but Arcite?
Who kouthe telle, or who kouthe it endite,	Who could tell, or who could describe in writing,
The joye that is maked in the place	The joy that is made in the place
Whan Theseus hath doon so fair a grace?	When Theseus has behaved so graciously?
But doun on knees wente every maner wight,	But down on knees went every sort of person,
And thonked hym with al hir herte and myght,	And thanked him with all their heart and might,
And namely the Thebans often sithe.	And especially the Thebans many times.
And thus with good hope and with herte blithe	And thus with good hope and with happy heart
They taken hir leve, and homward gonne they ride	They take their leave, and homeward did they ride
To Thebes with his olde walles wyde.	To Thebes with his old wide walls.
I trowe men wolde deme it necligence	I suppose men would consider it negligence
If I foryete to tellen the dispence	If I forget to tell the expenditure
Of Theseus, that gooth so bisily	Of Theseus, who goes (about) so busily
To maken up the lystes roially,	To build the lists royally,
That swich a noble theatre as it was	That such a noble theatre as it was
I dar wel seyen in this world ther nas.	I dare well say there was not (another such) in this world.
The circuit a myle was aboute,	The circumference was a mile around,
Walled of stoon, and dyched al withoute.	Walled with stone, and surrounded by a ditch.
Round was the shap, in manere of compas,	Round was the shape, in the manner of a circle,
Ful of degrees, the heighte of sixty pas,	Full of tiers of seats, the height of sixty paces,
That whan a man was set on o degree,	That when a man was set on one tier of seats,
He letted nat his felawe for to see.	He did not hinder his fellow from seeing.
Estward ther stood a gate of marbul whit,	Eastward there stood a gate of white marble,
Westward right swich another in the opposit.	Westward just such another on the opposite (side).
And shortly to concluden, swich a place	And shortly to conclude, such a place
Was noon in erthe, as in so litel space;	Was none in earth, (constructed) in so little time;
For in the lond ther was no crafty man	For in the land there was no skilled man
That geometrie or ars-metrike kan,	Who knows geometry or arithmetic,
Ne portreyour, ne kervere of ymages,	Nor painter, nor carver of images,
That Theseus ne yaf him mete and wages	That Theseus did not give him food and wages
The theatre for to maken and devyse.	To make and devise the theatre.
And for to doon his ryte and sacrifise,	And to do his rite and sacrifice,
He estward hath, upon the gate above,	He has eastward, upon the gate above,
In worshipe of Venus, goddesse of love,	In worship of Venus, goddess of love,
Doon make an auter and an oratorie;	Had made an altar and a chapel;
And on the gate westward, in memorie	And on the westward gate, in memory

That coste largely of gold a fother.	That cost fully a cartload of gold.
And northward, in a touret on the wal,	And northward, in a turret on the wall,
Of alabastre whit and reed coral,	Of white alabaster and red coral,
An oratorie, riche for to see,	A chapel, rich to look upon,
In worshipe of Dyane of chastitee,	In worship of Diana of chastity,
Hath Theseus doon wroght in noble wyse.	Has Theseus had made in noble style.
But yet hadde I foryeten to devyse	But yet had I forgotten to describe
The noble kervyng and the portreitures,	The noble sculpture and the portraits,
The shap, the contenaunce, and the figures	The shape, the appearance, and the figures
That weren in thise oratories thre.	That were in these three chapels.
First in the temple of Venus maystow se	First in the temple of Venus canst thou see

The broken slepes, and the sikes colde,	The broken sleeps, and the cold sighs,

The firy strokes of the desirynge	The fiery strokes of the desiring
That loves servantz in this lyf enduren;	That love's servants endure in this life;
The othes that hir covenantz assuren;	The oaths that assure their covenants;
Pleasance and Hope, Desir, Foolhardynesse,	Pleasure and Hope, Desire, Foolhardiness,
Beautee and Youthe, Bauderie, Richesse,	Beauty and Youth, Mirth, Riches,

For soothly al the mount of Citheroun,	For truly all the mount of Cithaeron,
Ther Venus hath hir principal dwellynge,	Where Venus has her principal dwelling,

Nat was foryeten the porter, Ydelnesse,	The porter, Idleness, was not forgotten

Ne yet the folye of kyng Salomon,	Nor yet the folly of king Solomon,
Ne yet the grete strengthe of Ercules --	Nor yet the great strength of Hercules --
Th'enchauntementz of Medea and Circes --	The enchantments of Medea and Circes --
Ne of Turnus, with the hardy fiers corage,	Nor of Turnus, with the hardy fierce courage,

Thus may ye seen that wysdom ne richesse,	Thus can you see that wisdom nor riches,
Beautee ne sleighte, strengthe ne hardynesse,	Beauty nor trickery, strength nor bravery,
Ne may with Venus holde champartie,	Can not share power with Venus,
For as hir list the world than may she gye.	For she may rule the world as she pleases.
Lo, alle thise folk so caught were in hir las,	Lo, all these folk were so caught in her snare,

Suffiseth heere ensamples oon or two,	One or two examples here suffice,
And though I koude rekene a thousand mo.	Even though I could recount a thousand more.
The statue of Venus, glorious for to se,	The statue of Venus, glorious to look upon,
Was naked, fletynge in the large see,	Was naked, floating in the large sea,
And fro the navele doun al covered was	And from the navel down all was covered

A citole in hir right hand hadde she,	She had a citole (zither-like instrument) in her right hand,

A bowe he bar and arwes brighte and kene.	He carried a bow and arrows bright and keen.
Why sholde I noght as wel eek telle yow al	Why should I not as well also tell you all

Al peynted was the wal, in lengthe and brede,	All painted was the wall, in length and breadth,
Lyk to the estres of the grisly place	Like to the interior of the grisly place

In thilke colde, frosty regioun	In that same cold, frosty region

First on the wal was peynted a forest,	First a forest was painted on the wall,
In which ther dwelleth neither man ne best,	In which there dwells neither man nor beast,
With knotty, knarry, bareyne trees olde,	With knotty, gnarled, barren old trees,
Of stubbes sharpe and hidouse to biholde,	Of stumps sharp and hideous to behold,
In which ther ran a rumbel in a swough,	Through which there ran a rumbling in a moaning of wind,

And therout came a rage and swich a veze	And out of there came a rush of wind and such a blast

The northren lyght in at the dores shoon,	The northern light shone in at the doors,

Thurgh which men myghten any light discerne.	Through which men might discern any light.
The dore was al of adamant eterne,	The door was all of eternal adamant (hardest of stones),
Yclenched overthwart and endelong	Bound crosswise and lengthwise
With iren tough; and for to make it strong,	With tough iron; and to make it strong,
Every pyler, the temple to sustene,	Every pillar, to support the temple,
Was tonne-greet, of iren bright and shene.	Was big as a large barrel, (made) of iron bright and shining.
Ther saugh I first the derke ymaginyng	There I saw first the malicious plotting
Of Felonye, and al the compassyng;	Of Felony, and all the scheming;
The crueel Ire, reed as any gleede;	The cruel Anger, red as any glowing coal;
The pykepurs, and eek the pale Drede;	The pick-purse, and also the pale Fear;
The smylere with the knyf under the cloke;	The smiler with the knife under the cloak;

Al ful of chirkyng was that sory place.	All full of creaking was that sorry place.
The sleere of hymself yet saugh I ther --	There yet I saw slayer of himself there --
His herte-blood hath bathed al his heer --	His heart-blood has bathed all his hair --

Amyddes of the temple sat Meschaunce,	Amidst the temple sat Misfortune,

Yet saugh I Woodnesse, laughynge in his rage,	Yet I saw Madness, laughing in his rage,

The cartere overryden with his carte --	The wagon driver run over by his wagon --

Ther were also, of Martes divisioun,	There were also, of those influenced by Mars,

Wel koude he peynten lifly that it wroghte;	He who made it well knew how to paint in a life-like manner;

And sikerly ther trowed many a man	And surely many a man there believed

For every wight that lovede chivalrye	For every person that loved chivalry
And wolde, his thankes, han a passant name,	And would, willingly, have an outstanding reputation
Hath preyed that he myghte been of that game;	Has prayed that he might participate in that game;
And wel was hym that therto chosen was,	And well it was for him who was chosen to be there,
For if ther fille tomorwe swich a cas,	For if there fell tomorrow such a situation,
Ye knowen wel that every lusty knyght	You know well that every vigorous knight
That loveth paramours and hath his myght,	Who loves passionately and has his might,
Were it in Engelond or elleswhere,	Were it in England or elsewhere,
They wolde, hir thankes, wilnen to be there --	They would, willingly, desire to be there --
To fighte for a lady, benedicitee!	To fight for a lady, bless me!
It were a lusty sighte for to see.	It would be a pleasing sight to see.
And right so ferden they with Palamon.	And right so fared those with Palamon.
With hym ther wenten knyghtes many on;	With him there went knights many a one;
Som wol ben armed in an haubergeoun,	One of them will be armed in a coat of mail,
And in a brestplate and a light gypoun;	And in a breastplate and a light tunic;
And som wol have a paire plates large;	And one of them will have a set of plate armor;
And som wol have a Pruce sheeld or a targe;	And one of them will have a Prussian shield or a buckler;
Som wol ben armed on his legges weel,	One of them will be well armed on his legs,
And have an ax, and som a mace of steel --	And have an axe, and one a mace of steel --
Ther is no newe gyse that it nas old.	There is no new fashion that has not been old.
Armed were they, as I have yow told,	They were armed, as I have told you,
Everych after his opinioun.	Every one according to his preference.
Ther maistow seen, comynge with Palamoun,	There mayst thou seen, coming with Palamon,
Lygurge hymself, the grete kyng of Trace.	Lycurgus himself, the great king of Thrace.
Blak was his berd, and manly was his face;	Black was his beard, and manly was his face;
The cercles of his eyen in his heed,	The circles of his eyes in his head,
They gloweden bitwixen yelow and reed,	They glowed between yellow and red,
And lik a grifphon looked he aboute,	And he looked about like a griffin (with an eagle's head),
With kempe heeris on his browes stoute;	With shaggy hairs on his stout brows;
His lymes grete, his brawnes harde and stronge,	His limbs large, his muscles hard and strong,
His shuldres brode, his armes rounde and longe;	His shoulders broad, his arms round and long;
And as the gyse was in his contree,	And as was the fashion in his country,
Ful hye upon a chaar of gold stood he,	He stood full high upon a chariot of gold,
With foure white boles in the trays.	With four white bulls in the traces.
In stede of cote-armure over his harnays,	Instead of a tunic with his coat of arms over his armor,
With nayles yelewe and brighte as any gold,	With claws yellow and bright as any gold,
He hadde a beres skyn, col-blak for old.	He had a bear's skin, coal-black because of age.
His longe heer was kembd bihynde his bak;	His long hair was combed behind his back;
As any ravenes fethere it shoon for blak;	Like any raven's feather it shone because of its blackness;
A wrethe of gold, arm-greet, of huge wighte,	A wreath of gold, thick as an arm, of huge weight,
Upon his heed, set ful of stones brighte,	Upon his head, set full of bright stones,
Of fyne rubyes and of dyamauntz.	Of fine rubies and of diamonds.
Aboute his chaar ther wenten white alauntz,	About his chariot there went white wolfhounds,
Twenty and mo, as grete as any steer,	Twenty and more, as big as any steer,
To hunten at the leoun or the deer,	To hunt for the lion or the deer,
And folwed hym with mosel faste ybounde,	And followed him with muzzles securely bound,
Colered of gold, and tourettes fyled rounde.	Wearing collars of gold, and rings for leashes filed round.
An hundred lordes hadde he in his route,	He had a hundred lords in his company,
Armed ful wel, with hertes stierne and stoute.	Very well armed, with stern and stout hearts.
With Arcita, in stories as men fynde,	With Arcite, as people find in histories,
The grete Emetreus, the kyng of Inde,	The great Emetreus, the king of India,
Upon a steede bay trapped in steel,	Upon a reddish-brown steed with trappings of steel,
Covered in clooth of gold, dyapred weel,	Covered in cloth of gold, well decorated (with geometric patterns),
Cam ridynge lyk the god of armes, Mars.	Came riding like the god of arms, Mars.
His cote-armure was of clooth of Tars	His tunic with his coat of arms was of cloth of Tarsia (in Turkestan)
Couched with perles white and rounde and grete;	Adorned with pearls white and round and big;
His sadel was of brend gold newe ybete;	His saddle was newly adorned with pure gold;
A mantelet upon his shulder hangynge,	A short cloak hanging upon his shoulder,
Bret-ful of rubyes rede as fyr sparklynge;	Brimful of rubies red as sparkling fire;
His crispe heer lyk rynges was yronne,	His curly hair like rings was run (fashioned),
And that was yelow, and glytered as the sonne.	And that was yellow, and glittered like the sun.
His nose was heigh, his eyen bright citryn,	His nose was high, his eyes bright lemon yellow,
His lippes rounde, his colour was sangwyn;	His lips round, his color was ruddy;
A fewe frakenes in his face yspreynd,	A few freckles were sprinkled in his face,
Bitwixen yelow and somdel blak ymeynd;	Between yellow and somewhat mingled with black;
And as a leon he his lookyng caste.	And as a lion he cast about his look.
Of fyve and twenty yeer his age I caste.	I reckon his age at five and twenty years.
His berd was wel bigonne for to sprynge;	His beard had well begun to spring;
His voys was as a trompe thonderynge.	His voice was like a trumpet thundering.
Upon his heed he wered of laurer grene	Upon his head he wore of green laurel
A gerland, fressh and lusty for to sene.	A garland, fresh and pleasing to look upon.
Upon his hand he bar for his deduyt	Upon his hand he carried for his delight
An egle tame, as any lilye whyt.	A tame eagle, white as any lily.
An hundred lordes hadde he with hym there,	He had a hundred lords with him there,
Al armed, save hir heddes, in al hir gere,	All armed, except for their heads, in all their equipment,
Ful richely in alle maner thynges.	Very richly in every detail.
For trusteth wel that dukes, erles, kynges	For trust well that dukes, earls, kings
Were gadered in this noble compaignye,	Were gathered in this noble company,
For love and for encrees of chivalrye.	For love and for the benefit of chivalry.
Aboute this kyng ther ran on every part	About this king there ran on all sides
Ful many a tame leon and leopart.	Full many a tame lion and leopard.
And in this wise thise lordes, alle and some,	And in this manner these lords, one and all,
Been on the Sonday to the citee come	Are come to the city on the Sunday
Aboute pryme, and in the toun alight.	About nine a.m., and in the town dismounted.
This Theseus, this duc, this worthy knyght,	This Theseus, this duke, this worthy knight,
Whan he had broght hem into his citee,	When he had brought them into his city,
And inned hem, everich at his degree,	And provided them lodging, each one according to his rank,
He festeth hem, and dooth so greet labour	He feasts them, and does such great labor
To esen hem and doon hem al honour	To entertain them and do them all honor
That yet men wenen that no mannes wit	That people still believe that the wit of no man
Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it.	Of any rank could do better.
The mynstralcye, the service at the feeste,	The music, the service at the feast,
The grete yiftes to the meeste and leeste,	The great gifts to every one,
The riche array of Theseus paleys,	The rich adornment of Theseus' palace,
Ne who sat first ne last upon the deys,	Nor who sat first nor last upon the dais,
What ladyes fairest been or best daunsynge,	What ladies are fairest or best in dancing,
Or which of hem kan dauncen best and synge,	Or which of them can dance best and sing,
Ne who moost felyngly speketh of love;	Nor who speaks most feelingly of love;
What haukes sitten on the perche above,	What hawks sit on the perch above,
What houndes liggen on the floor adoun --	What hounds lie down on the floor --
Of al this make I now no mencioun,	I now make no mention of all this,
But al th' effect; that thynketh me the beste.	But (speak only) of the substance; that seems to me the best.
Now cometh the point, and herkneth if yow leste.	Now comes the point, and listen if you please.
The Sonday nyght, er day bigan to sprynge,	The Sunday night, before day began to spring,
Whan Palamon the larke herde synge	When Palamon heard the lark sing
(Although it nere nat day by houres two,	(Although it was not day by two hours,
Yet the larke sang) and Palamon right then	Yet sang the lark) and Palamon right then
With hooly herte and with an heigh corage,	With pious heart and with a noble disposition,
He roos to wenden on his pilgrymage	He rose to go on his pilgrimage
Unto the blissful Citherea benign --	To the blessed gracious Citherea --
I mene Venus, honurable and digne.	I mean Venus, honorable and worshipful.
And in hir houre he walketh forth a pas	And in her (planetary) hour he walks forth slowly
Unto the lystes ther hire temple was,	Unto the lists where her temple was,
And doun he kneleth, and with humble cheere	And down he kneels, and with humble expression
And herte soor he seyde as ye shal heere:	And painful heart he said as you shall hear:
"Faireste of faire, O lady myn, Venus,	"Fairest of the fair, O lady mine, Venus,
Doughter to Jove and spouse of Vulcanus,	Daughter to Jove and spouse of Vulcan,
Thow gladere of the mount of Citheron,	Thou maker of joy of the mount of Citheron,
For thilke love thow haddest to Adoon,	For that same love thou haddest to Adonis,
Have pitee of my bittre teeris smerte,	Have pity on my bitter, smarting tears,
And taak myn humble preyere at thyn herte.	And take my humble prayer to thy heart.
Allas! I ne have no langage to telle	Alas! I do not have any language to tell
Th'effectes ne the tormentz of myn helle;	The effects nor the torments of my hell;
Myn herte may myne harmes nat biwreye;	My heart can not reveal my harms;
I am so confus that I kan noght seye	I am so befuddled that I can not say (anything)
But `Mercy, lady bright, that knowest weele	But `Mercy, lady bright, who knowest well
My thought and seest what harmes that I feele!'	My thought and seest what harms I feel!'
Considere al this and rewe upon my soore,	Consider all this and have pity upon my pain,
As wisly as I shal for everemoore,	As surely as I shall for evermore,
Emforth my myght, thy trewe servant be,	According to my power (as much as I can), be thy true servant,
And holden werre alwey with chastitee.	And make war always against chastity.
That make I myn avow, so ye me helpe!	I make that my vow, providing you help me!
I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe,	I care not to boast of arms
Ne I ne axe nat tomorwe to have victorie,	Nor do I ask to have victory tomorrow,
Ne renoun in this cas, ne veyne glorie	Nor renown in this case, nor vain glory
Of pris of armes blowen up and doun;	Nor fame for deeds of arms proclaimed everywhere;
But I wolde have fully possessioun	But I would have fully possession
Of Emelye, and dye in thy servyse.	Of Emelye, and die in thy service.
Fynd thow the manere hou and in what wyse:	Find thou the manner how and in what way:
I recche nat but it may bettre be	I care not if it may better be
To have victorie of hem, or they of me,	To have victory over them, or they over me,
So that I have my lady in myne armes.	So that I have my lady in my arms.
For though so be that Mars is god of armes,	For though it be true that Mars is god of arms,
Youre vertu is so greet in hevene above	Your power is so great in heaven above
That if yow list, I shal wel have my love.	That if you please, I shall well have my love.
Thy temple wol I worshipe everemo,	I will worship thy temple evermore,
And on thyn auter, where I ride or go,	And on thy altar, whether I ride or walk (whatever I do),
I wol doon sacrifice and fires beete.	I will do sacrifice and kindle fires.
And if ye wol nat so, my lady sweete,	And if you will not (do) so, my lady sweet,
Thanne preye I thee, tomorwe with a spere	Then I pray thee, tomorrow with a spear
That Arcita me thurgh the herte bere.	That Arcite stab me through the heart.
Thanne rekke I noght, whan I have lost my lyf,	Then I care not, when I have lost my life,
Though that Arcita wynne hire to his wyf.	Though Arcite win her to be his wife.
This is th'effect and ende of my preyere:	This is the substance and goal of my prayer:
Yif me my love, thow blisful lady deere."	Give me my love, thou blessed dear lady."
Whan the orison was doon of Palamon,	When the prayer of Palamon was done,
His sacrifice he dide, and that anon,	He did his sacrifice, and that quickly,
Ful pitously, with alle circumstaunces,	Full piteously, with all due ceremony,
Al telle I noght as now his observaunces;	Although I tell not now his observances;
But atte laste the statue of Venus shook,	But at the last the statue of Venus shook,
And made a signe, wherby that he took	And made a sign, whereby he understood
That his preyere accepted was that day.	That his prayer was accepted that day.
For thogh the signe shewed a delay,	For though the sign showed a delay,
Yet wiste he wel that graunted was his boone,	Yet he knew well that his request was granted,
And with glad herte he wente hym hoom ful soone.	And with glad heart he went home very soon.
The thridde houre inequal that Palamon	The third planetary hour after Palamon
Bigan to Venus temple for to gon,	Began to go to Venus' temple,
Up roos the sonne, and up roos Emelye	Up rose the sun, and up rose Emelye
And to the temple of Dyane gan hye.	And to the temple of Diana did hasten.
Hir maydens, that she thider with hire ladde,	Her maidens, whom she led thither with her,
Ful redily with hem the fyr they hadde,	They had the fire full readily with them,
Th'encens, the clothes, and the remenant al	The incense, the cloths, and all the rest
That to the sacrifice longen shal;	That is needed for the sacrifice;
The hornes fulle of meeth, as was the gyse --	The horns full of mead, as was the custom --
Ther lakked noght to doon hir sacrifise.	There lacked nothing (needed) to do her sacrifice.
Smokynge the temple, ful of clothes faire,	The temple smoking (with incense), full of fair cloths,
This Emelye, with herte debonaire,	This Emelye, with gentle heart,
Hir body wessh with water of a welle.	Washed her body with water of a well.
But hou she dide hir ryte I dar nat telle,	But how she did her rite I dare not tell,
But it be any thing in general;	Unless it be some thing in general;
And yet it were a game to heeren al.	And yet it would be a pleasure to hear all.
To hym that meneth wel it were no charge;	To one who means well it would be no matter of concern;
But it is good a man been at his large.	But it is good for a man to be without restriction (speak freely).
Hir brighte heer was kembd, untressed al;	Her bright hair was combed, all loose;
A coroune of a grene ook cerial	A crown of an evergreen oak
Upon hir heed was set ful fair and meete.	Was set upon her head full fair and suitable.
Two fyres on the auter gan she beete,	Two fires on the altar did she kindle,
And dide hir thynges, as men may biholde	And did her duties, as men can behold
In Stace of Thebes and thise bookes olde.	In Statius' Thebaid and such old books.
Whan kyndled was the fyr, with pitous cheere	When the fire was kindled, with a pitiful expression
Unto Dyane she spak as ye may heere:	Unto Diana she spoke as you may hear:
"O chaste goddesse of the wodes grene,	"O chaste goddess of the green woods,
To whom bothe hevene and erthe and see is sene,	To whom both heaven and earth and sea is visible,
Queene of the regne of Pluto derk and lowe,	Queen of the dark and low reign of Pluto,
Goddesse of maydens, that myn herte hast knowe	Goddess of maidens, whom my heart hast known
Ful many a yeer, and woost what I desire,	Full many a year, and knowest what I desire,
As keepe me fro thy vengeaunce and thyn ire,	Keep me from thy vengeance and thy ire,
That Attheon aboughte cruelly.	Which Acteon paid for cruelly.
Chaste goddesse, wel wostow that I	Chaste goddess, well knowest thou that I
Desire to ben a mayden al my lyf,	Desire to be a maiden all my life,
Ne nevere wol I be no love ne wyf.	Nor never will I be no lover nor wife.
I am, thow woost, yet of thy compaignye,	I am, thou knowest, yet of thy company,
A mayde, and love huntynge and venerye,	A maiden, and love hunting and the chase,
And for to walken in the wodes wilde,	And to walk in the wild woods,
And noght to ben a wyf and be with childe.	And not to be a wife and be with child.
Noght wol I knowe compaignye of man.	I do not desire to know company of man.
Now help me, lady, sith ye may and kan,	Now help me, lady, since you can and know how,
For tho thre formes that thou hast in thee.	For those three forms that thou hast in thee.
And Palamon, that hath swich love to me,	And Palamon, that has such love to me,
And eek Arcite, that loveth me so soore,	And also Arcite, who loves me so painfully,
This grace I preye thee withoute moore,	This grace I pray thee and ask no more,
As sende love and pees bitwixe hem two,	Send love and peace between them two,
And fro me turne awey hir hertes so	And turn away their hearts from me so
That al hire hoote love and hir desir,	That all their hot love and their desire,
And al hir bisy torment, and hir fir	And all their intense torment, and their fire
Be queynt, or turned in another place.	Will be quenched, or turned to another place.
And if so be thou wolt nat do me grace,	And if it so be thou wilt not do me grace,
Or if my destynee be shapen so	Or if my destiny is shaped so
That I shal nedes have oon of hem two,	That I must by necessity have one of them two,
As sende me hym that moost desireth me.	Send me him who most desires me.
Bihoold, goddesse of clene chastitee,	Behold, goddess of clean chastity,
The bittre teeris that on my chekes falle.	The bitter tears that fall on my cheeks.
Syn thou art mayde and kepere of us alle,	Since thou art maiden and guardian of us all,
My maydenhede thou kepe and wel conserve,	Thou care for and well conserve my maidenhood,
And whil I lyve, a mayde I wol thee serve."	And while I live, as a maiden I will serve thee."
The fires brenne upon the auter cleere,	The fires burn brightly upon the altar,
Whil Emelye was thus in hir preyere.	While Emelye was thus in her prayer.
But sodeynly she saugh a sighte queynte,	But suddenly she saw a curious sight,
For right anon oon of the fyres queynte	For right away one of the fires quenched
And quyked agayn, and after that anon	And rekindled again, and after that straightway
That oother fyr was queynt and al agon;	That other fire was quenched and all gone;
And as it queynte it made a whistelynge,	And as it quenched it made a roaring sound,
As doon thise wete brondes in hir brennynge,	As these wet brands do in their burning,
And at the brondes ende out ran anon	And at the brand's end (the fire) ran out straightway
As it were blody dropes many oon;	As if it were many bloody drops;
For which so soore agast was Emelye	For which so sorely frightened was Emelye
That she was wel ny mad and gan to crye,	That she was well nigh mad and began to cry,
For she ne wiste what it signyfied,	For she did not know what it signified,
But oonly for the feere thus hath she cried,	But simply for fear has she cried thus,
And weep that it was pitee for to heere.	And wept that it was a pity to hear.
And therwithal Dyane gan appeere,	And right then Diana did appear,
With bowe in honde, right as an hunteresse,	With bow in hand, just like a huntress,
And seyde, "Doghter, stynt thyn hevynesse.	And said, "Daughter, cease thy sadness.
Among the goddes hye it is affermed,	Among the high gods it is affirmed,
And by eterne word writen and confermed,	And by eternal word written and confirmed,
Thou shalt ben wedded unto oon of tho	Thou shalt be wedded unto one of those
That han for thee so muchel care and wo,	Who have for thee so much care and woe,
But unto which of hem I may nat telle.	But unto which of them I may not tell.
Farwel, for I ne may no lenger dwelle.	Farwell, for I can stay no longer .
The fires which that on myn auter brenne	The fires which burn on my altar
Shulle thee declaren, er that thou go henne,	Shall declare to thee, before thou go hence,
Thyn aventure of love, as in this cas."	Thy destiny concerning love, as in this situation."
And with that word, the arwes in the caas	And with that word, the arrows in the quiver
Of the goddesse clateren faste and rynge,	Of the goddess clatter fast and ring,
And forth she wente and made a vanysshynge;	And forth she went and vanished;
For which this Emelye astoned was,	For which this Emelye was astonished,
And seyde, "What amounteth this, allas?	And said, "What does this mean, alas?
I putte me in thy proteccioun,	I put me in thy protection,
Dyane, and in thy disposicioun."	Diana, and in thy power."
And hoom she goth anon the nexte weye.	And home she goes at once the nearest way.
This is th'effect; ther is namoore to seye.	This is the substance; there is no more to say.
The nexte houre of Mars folwynge this,	The next (planetary) hour of Mars following this,
Arcite unto the temple walked is	Arcite has walked unto the temple
Of fierse Mars to doon his sacrifise,	Of fierce Mars to do his sacrifice,
With alle the rytes of his payen wyse.	With all the rites of his pagan manner (of worship).
With pitous herte and heigh devocioun,	With sorrowful heart and intense devotion,
Right thus to Mars he seyde his orisoun:	Right thus to Mars he said his prayer:
"O stronge god, that in the regnes colde	"O strong god, who in the cold reigns
Of Trace honoured art and lord yholde,	Of Thrace art honored and considered lord,
And hast in every regne and every lond	And hast in every reign and every land
Of armes al the brydel in thyn hond,	All the control of arms in thy hand,
And hem fortunest as thee lyst devyse,	And grants them fortune as it pleases thee to command.
Accepte of me my pitous sacrifise.	Accept of me my sorrowful sacrifice.
If so be that my youthe may deserve,	If it so be that my youth may deserve,
And that my myght be worthy for to serve	And that my power be worthy to serve
Thy godhede, that I may been oon of thyne,	Thy godhead, so that I may be one of thine,
Thanne preye I thee to rewe upon my pyne.	Then pray I thee to have pity upon my pain.
For thilke peyne and thilke hoote fir	For that same pain and that same hot fire
In which thow whilom brendest for desir,	In which thou once burned for desire,
Whan that thow usedest the beautee	When that thou enjoyed the beauty
Of faire, yonge, fresshe Venus free,	Of fair, young, fresh Venus the noble,
And haddest hire in armes at thy wille --	And haddest her in arms as you wished --
Although thee ones on a tyme mysfille,	Although once things went wrong for you,
Whan Vulcanus hadde caught thee in his las	When Vulcan had caught thee in his snare
And foond thee liggynge by his wyf, allas! --	And found thee lying by his wife, alas! --
For thilke sorwe that was in thyn herte,	For that same sorrow that was in thy heart,
Have routhe as wel upon my peynes smerte.	Have pity as well upon my painful sufferings.
I am yong and unkonnynge, as thow woost,	I am young and ignorant, as thou knowest,
And, as I trowe, with love offended moost	And, as I suppose, injured most by love
That evere was any lyves creature,	Than ever was any living creature,
For she that dooth me al this wo endure	For she that causes me to endure all this woe
Ne reccheth nevere wher I synke or fleete.	Nor cares never whether I sink or swim.
And wel I woot, er she me mercy heete,	And well I know, before she may promise me mercy,
I moot with strengthe wynne hire in the place,	I must win her with strength in the lists,
And wel I woot, withouten help or grace	And well I know, without help or grace
Of thee ne may my strengthe noght availle.	Of thee my strength can not avail.
Thanne help me, lord, tomorwe in my bataille,	Then help me, lord, tomorrow in my battle,
For thilke fyr that whilom brente thee,	For that same fire that once burned thee,
As wel as thilke fyr now brenneth me,	As well as that same fire now burns me,
And do that I tomorwe have victorie.	And bring it about so that I have victory tomorrow.
Myn be the travaille, and thyn be the glorie!	Mine be the labor, and thine be the glory!
Thy sovereyn temple wol I moost honouren	I will most honor thy most excellent temple
Of any place, and alwey moost labouren	Over any place, and always most labor
In thy plesaunce and in thy craftes stronge,	In thy pleasure and in thy strong crafts,
And in thy temple I wol my baner honge	And in thy temple I will hang my banner
And alle the armes of my compaignye,	And all the arms of my company,
And everemo, unto that day I dye,	And evermore, until that day I die,
Eterne fir I wol bifore thee fynde.	Eternal fire I will provide before thee (on your altar).
And eek to this avow I wol me bynde:	And also I will bind myself to this vow:
My beerd, myn heer, that hongeth long adoun,	My beard, my hair, that hangs long down,
That nevere yet ne felte offensioun	That never yet felt injury
Of rasour nor of shere, I wol thee yive,	Of razor nor of shears, I will give thee,
And ben thy trewe servant whil I lyve.	And be thy true servant while I live.
Now, lord, have routhe upon my sorwes soore;	Now, lord, have pity upon my painful sorrows;
Yif me [victorie]; I aske thee namoore."	Give me victory; I ask of thee no more."
The preyere stynt of Arcita the stronge,	The prayer of Arcite the strong stopped,
The rynges on the temple dore that honge,	The rings that hung on the temple door,
And eek the dores, clatereden ful faste,	And also the doors, clattered very fast,
Of which Arcita somwhat hym agaste.	Of which Arcite was somewhat afraid.
The fyres brenden upon the auter brighte	The fires upon the altar burned (so) brightly
That it gan al the temple for to lighte;	That it began to illuminate all the temple;
A sweete smel the ground anon up yaf,	A sweet smell the ground at once yielded up,
And Arcita anon his hand up haf,	And Arcite immediately raised up his hand,
And moore encens into the fyr he caste,	And he cast more incense into the fire,
With othere rytes mo; and atte laste	With more other rites; and at the last
The statue of Mars bigan his hauberk rynge,	The statue of Mars began to ring its coat of mail,
And with that soun he herde a murmurynge	And with that sound he heard a murmuring
Ful lowe and dym, and seyde thus, "Victorie!"	Very low and faint, that said thus, "Victory!"
For which he yaf to Mars honour and glorie.	For which he (Arcite) gave to Mars honor and glory.
And thus with joye and hope wel to fare	And thus with joy and hope to fare well
Arcite anon unto his in is fare,	Arcite at once is gone unto his lodging,
As fayn as fowel is of the brighte sonne.	As happy as a fowl is for the bright sun.
And right anon swich strif ther is bigonne,	And right away such strife there is begun,
For thilke grauntyng, in the hevene above,	Because of that same grant, in the heaven above,
Bitwixe Venus, the goddesse of love,	Between Venus, the goddess of love,
And Mars, the stierne god armypotente,	And Mars, the stern god powerful in arms,
That Juppiter was bisy it to stente,	That Jupiter was hard put to stop it,
Til that the pale Saturnus the colde,	Until the pale Saturn the hostile,
That knew so manye of aventures olde,	Who knew so many of old adventures,
Foond in his olde experience an art	Found in his old experience a plan
That he ful soone hath plesed every part.	That he full soon has pleased every side.
As sooth is seyd, elde hath greet avantage;	As is truly said, old age has a great advantage;
In elde is bothe wysdom and usage;	In old age is both wisdom and experience;
Men may the olde atrenne and noght atrede.	One can outrun the old but not outwit them.
Saturne anon, to stynten strif and drede,	Saturn anon, to stop strife and fear,
Al be it that it is agayn his kynde,	Although it is against his natural disposition,
Of al this strif he gan remedie fynde.	He found a remedy for all this strife.
"My deere doghter Venus," quod Saturne,	"My dear daughter Venus," said Saturn,
"My cours, that hath so wyde for to turne,	"My orbit, that has so wide (a course) to turn,
Hath moore power than woot any man.	Has more power than any man knows.
Myn is the drenchyng in the see so wan;	Mine is the drowning in the sea so dark;
Myn is the prison in the derke cote;	Mine is the imprisonment in the dark cell;
Myn is the stranglyng and hangyng by the throte,	Mine is the killing and hanging by the throat,
The murmure and the cherles rebellyng,	The murmur (of discontent) and the churls' rebelling,
The groynynge, and the pryvee empoysonyng;	The grumbling, and the secret poisoning;
I do vengeance and pleyn correccioun,	I exact vengeance and do full punishment,
Whil I dwelle in the signe of the leoun.	While I dwell in the (zodiacal) sign of the lion.
Myn is the ruyne of the hye halles,	Mine is the ruin of the high halls,
The fallynge of the toures and of the walles	The falling of the towers and of the walls
Upon the mynour or the carpenter.	Upon the miner or the carpenter.
I slow Sampsoun, shakynge the piler;	I slew Sampson, shaking the pillar;
And myne be the maladyes colde,	And mine are the cold maladies,
The derke tresons, and the castes olde;	The dark treasons, and the old plots;
My lookyng is the fader of pestilence.	My (astrological) aspect is the father of pestilence.
Now weep namoore; I shal doon diligence	Now weep no more; I shall do my diligence
That Palamon, that is thyn owene knyght,	So that Palamon, who is thine own knight,
Shal have his lady, as thou hast him hight.	Shall have his lady, as thou hast promised him.
Though Mars shal helpe his knyght, yet nathelees	Though Mars shall help his knight, yet nonetheless
Bitwixe yow ther moot be som tyme pees,	Between you there must be peace sometime,
Al be ye noght of o compleccioun,	Although you are not of one (the same) temperament,
That causeth al day swich divisioun.	Which daily causes such dissension.
I am thyn aiel, redy at thy wille;	I am thy grandfather, ready (to do) as you wish;
Weep now namoore; I wol thy lust fulfille."	Weep now no more; I will fulfill thy desire."
Now wol I stynten of the goddes above,	Now I will stop (speaking) of the gods above,
Of Mars, and of Venus, goddesse of love,	Of Mars, and of Venus, goddess of love,
And telle yow as pleynly as I kan	And tell you as plainly as I can
The grete effect, for which that I bygan.	The essential part, for which I began.
Greet was the feeste in Atthenes that day,	Great was the feast in Athens that day,
And eek the lusty seson of that May	And also the pleasing season of that May
Made every wight to been in swich plesaunce	Made every person to be in such delight
That al that Monday justen they and daunce,	That all that Monday they joust and dance,
And spenden it in Venus heigh servyse.	And spend that day in Venus's noble service.
But by the cause that they sholde ryse	But because they must rise
Eerly, for to seen the grete fight,	Early, to see the great fight,
Unto hir reste wenten they at nyght.	Unto their rest they went at nightfall.
And on the morwe, whan that day gan sprynge,	And in the morning, when day did spring,
Of hors and harneys noyse and claterynge	Noise and clattering of horses and armor
Ther was in hostelryes al aboute,	There was in hostelries all about,
And to the paleys rood ther many a route	And to the palace there rode many a company
Of lordes upon steedes and palfreys.	Of lords upon steeds and palfreys.
Ther maystow seen devisynge of harneys	There canst thou see preparation of armor
So unkouth and so riche, and wroght so weel	So exotic and so rich, and wrought so well
Of goldsmythrye, of browdynge, and of steel;	Of goldsmiths' works, of embroidery, and of steel;
The sheeldes brighte, testeres, and trappures,	The bright shields, horses' head-armor, and horse-armor,
Gold-hewen helmes, coats of mail, cote-armures;	Gold-colored helms, coats of mail, tunics with heraldic devices;
Lordes in parementz on hir courseres,	Lords in richly decorated robes on their coursers,
Knyghtes of retenue, and eek squieres	Knights of (their) retinues, and also squires

Giggynge of sheeldes, with layneres lacynge --	Fitting the shields with straps, fastening with laces --

The fomy steedes on the golden brydel	The steeds frothing on the golden bridles

Yemen on foote, and communes many oon	Yeomen on foot, and foot soldiers many a one

Pypes, trompes, nakers, clariounes,	Pipes, trumpets, kettle drums, bugles,

The paleys ful of peple up and doun,	The palace full of people everywhere,
Heere thre, ther ten, holdynge hir questioun,	Here three, there ten, debating,
Dyvynynge of thise Thebane knyghtes two.	Conjecturing about these two Theban knights.
Somme seyden thus, somme seyde "it shal be so";	Some said thus, some said "it shall be so";
Somme helden with hym with the blake berd,	Some held with him with the black beard,
Somme with the balled, somme with the thikke herd;	Some with the bald, some with the thickly haired;
Somme seyde he looked grymme, and he wolde fighte:	Some said he looked grim, and he would fight:
"He hath a sparth of twenty pound of wighte."	"He has a battle-ax of twenty pounds of weight."
Thus was the halle ful of divynynge,	Thus was the hall full of conjecturing,
Longe after that the sonne gan to sprynge.	Long after the sun began to rise.
The grete Theseus, that of his sleep awaked	The great Theseus, who was awakened of his sleep
With mynstralcie and noyse that was maked,	By the music and noise that was made,
Heeld yet the chambre of his paleys riche	Remained yet in the chamber of his rich palace
Til that the Thebane knyghtes, bothe yliche	Until the Theban knights, both equally
Honured, were into the paleys fet.	Honored, were fetched into the palace.
Duc Theseus was at a wyndow set,	Duke Theseus was set at a window,
Arrayed right as he were a god in trone.	Arrayed exactly as if he were a god on a throne.
The peple preesseth thiderward ful soone	The people press thither full soon
Hym for to seen, and doon heigh reverence,	In order to see him, and to do great reverence,
And eek to herkne his heste and his sentence.	And also to hear his command and his decision.
An heraud on a scaffold made an "Oo!"	A herald on a scaffold made a "Ho!"
Til al the noyse of peple was ydo,	Until all the noise of people was done,

Tho shewed he the myghty dukes wille:	Then showed he the mighty duke's will:
"The lord hath of his heigh discrecioun	"The lord has of his great sound judgment
Considered that it were destruccioun	Considered that it would be destruction
To gentil blood to fighten in the gyse	To gentle blood to fight in the manner
Of mortal bataille now in this emprise.	Of mortal battle now in this undertaking.
Wherfore, to shapen that they shal nat dye,	Wherefore, to arrange matters so that they shall not die,
He wol his firste purpos modifye.	He will modify his previous plan.
No man therfore, up peyne of los of lyf,	No man therefore, upon punishment of loss of life,
No maner shot, ne polax, ne short knyf	No sort of arrow, nor battle-axe, nor short knife
Into the lystes sende or thider brynge;	Send into the lists or bring there;
Ne short swerd, for to stoke with poynt bitynge,	Nor short sword, to stab with piercing point,
No man ne drawe, ne bere it by his syde.	May no man neither draw, nor bear it by his side.
Ne no man shal unto his felawe ryde	And no man shall ride at his opponent
But o cours with a sharpe ygrounde spere;	More than one course with a sharply honed spear;
Foyne, if hym list, on foote, hymself to were.	Let him thrust, if he wishes, on foot, to defend himself.
And he that is at meschief shal be take	And he who is at a disadvantage shall be taken

But thider he shal by force, and there abyde.	But thither he must (go) by force, and remain there.
And if so falle the chieftayn be take	And if so happen that the chieftain be taken

No lenger shal the turneiynge laste.	The tournament shall last no longer.
God spede you! Gooth forth and ley on faste!	God give you success! Go forth and lay on fast!
With long swerd and with mace fighteth youre fille.	With long sword and with mace fight your fill.
Gooth now youre wey; this is the lordes wille."	Go now on your way; this is the lord's will."
The voys of peple touchede the hevene,	The voice of people touched the heaven,
So loude cride they with murie stevene,	So loudly they cried with merry voices,
"God save swich a lord, that is so good	"God save such a lord, that is so good
He wilneth no destruccion of blood!"	He desires no destruction of blood!"
Up goon the trompes and the melodye,	Up go the trumpets and the melody,
And to the lystes rit the compaignye,	And to the lists rides the company,
By ordinance, thurghout the citee large,	In battle array, throughout all the city,
Hanged with clooth of gold, and nat with sarge.	Hung with cloth of gold, and not with serge.
Ful lik a lord this noble duc gan ryde,	Fully like a lord this noble duke did ride,
Thise two Thebans upon either syde,	These two Thebans upon either side,
And after rood the queene and Emelye,	And after rode the queen and Emelye,
And after that another compaignye	And after that another company
Of oon and oother, after hir degree.	One after another, according to their rank.
And thus they passen thurghout the citee,	And thus they pass throughout the city,
And to the lystes come they by tyme.	And they come to the lists in good time.
It nas nat of the day yet fully pryme	It was not yet fully prime (nine a.m.) of the day
Whan set was Theseus ful riche and hye,	When Theseus was set very splendidly and nobly,
Ypolita the queene, and Emelye,	Ypolita the queen, and Emelye,
And othere ladys in degrees aboute.	And other ladies about in tiers.
Unto the seetes preesseth al the route.	Unto the seats press all the crowd.
And westward, thurgh the gates under Marte,	And westward, through the gates under Mars,

With baner reed is entred right anon;	With red banner is entered right away;
And in that selve moment Palamon	And in that same moment Palamon
Is under Venus, estward in the place,	Is under Venus, eastward in the place,
With baner whyt and hardy chiere and face.	With white banner and hardy countenance and face.
In al the world, to seken up and doun,	In all the world, to seek up and down,
So evene, withouten variacioun,	So evenly, without variation,
Ther nere swiche compaignyes tweye,	There were not two such companies,
For ther was noon so wys that koude seye	For there was no one so wise that could say
That any hadde of oother avauntage	That any one had advantage over the other
Of worthynesse, ne of estaat, ne age,	In worthiness, nor in status, nor age,
So evene were they chosen, for to gesse.	So evenly were they chosen, as I estimate.
And in two renges faire they hem dresse.	And in two fair ranks they arrange themselves.
Whan that hir names rad were everichon,	When every one of their names were read,
That in hir nombre gyle were ther noon,	So that in their total number there would be no deception,
Tho were the gates shet, and cried was loude:	Then the gates were shut, and cried was aloud:
"Do now youre devoir, yonge knyghtes proude!"	"Do now your duty, proud young knights!"
The heraudes lefte hir prikyng up and doun;	The heralds left their spurring up and down;
Now ryngen trompes loude and clarioun.	Now trumpets and bugles ring loud.
Ther is namoore to seyn, but west and est	There is no more to say, but from west and east

In gooth the sharpe spore into the syde.	In goes the sharp spur into the flank.
Ther seen men who kan juste and who kan ryde;	There people see who can joust and who can ride;
Ther shyveren shaftes upon sheeldes thikke;	There splinter spears upon thick shields;
He feeleth thurgh the herte-spoon the prikke.	He feels the stabbing through the breast-bone.
Up spryngen speres twenty foot on highte;	Up spring spears twenty foot on height;
Out goon the swerdes as the silver brighte;	Out go the swords bright as silver;
The helmes they tohewen and toshrede;	The helms they hew to pieces and cut into shreds
Out brest the blood with stierne stremes rede;	Out burst the blood in strong red streams;
With myghty maces the bones they tobreste.	With mighty maces they break the bones to pieces.
He thurgh the thikkeste of the throng gan threste;	He did thrust through the thickest of the throng;
Ther stomblen steedes stronge, and doun gooth al,	There strong steeds stumble, and down goes all,
He rolleth under foot as dooth a bal;	He rolls under foot as does a ball;
He foyneth on his feet with his tronchoun,	On his feet he stabs with the broken shaft of his spear,
And he hym hurtleth with his hors adoun;	And he hurtles him down with his horse;
He thurgh the body is hurt and sithen ytake,	He is hurt through the body and then taken,

As forward was, right there he moste abyde.	As was the agreement, right there he must abide.
Another lad is on that oother syde.	Another on that other side is led away.
And some tyme dooth hem Theseus to reste,	And for a while Theseus makes them rest,
Hem to refresshe and drynken, if hem leste.	To refresh themselves and drink, if they wish.
Ful ofte a day han thise Thebanes two	Many times these two Thebans have

Unhorsed hath ech oother of hem tweye.	Each has unhorsed the other of them two.
Ther nas no tygre in the vale of Galgopheye,	There was not any tiger in the vale of Gargaphia,
Whan that hir whelp is stole whan it is lite,	When her whelp is stolen when it is little,
So crueel on the hunte as is Arcite	So cruel on the hunt as is Arcite
For jelous herte upon this Palamon.	For jealous heart upon this Palamon.
Ne in Belmarye ther nys so fel leon,	Nor in Benmarin there is not so fierce a lion,
That hunted is, or for his hunger wood,	That is hunted, or maddened by his hunger,
Ne of his praye desireth so the blood,	Nor of his prey desires so the blood,

The jelous strokes on hir helmes byte;	The fervent strokes bite on their helms;
Out renneth blood on bothe hir sydes rede.	Out runs red blood on both their sides.
Som tyme an ende ther is of every dede.	Some time there is an end of every deed.
For er the sonne unto the reste wente,	For before the sun went unto its rest,
The stronge kyng Emetreus gan hente	The strong king Emetreus did seize
This Palamon, as he faught with Arcite,	This Palamon, as he fought with Arcite,

His hardy herte myghte hym helpe naught:	His hardy heart could not help him:
He moste abyde, whan that he was caught,	He must abide, when he was caught,
By force and eek by composicioun.	By force and also by the agreed terms of battle.
Who sorweth now but woful Palamoun,	Who sorrows now but woeful Palamon,

And whan that Theseus hadde seyn this sighte,	And when Theseus had seen this sight,

Arcite of Thebes shal have Emelie,	Arcite of Thebes shall have Emelye,
That by his fortune hath hire faire ywonne."	Who by his fortune has won her fairly."
Anon ther is a noyse of peple bigonne	Immediately there is a noise of people begun

The trompours, with the loude mynstralcie,	The trumpeters, with the loud music,

But herkneth me, and stynteth noyse a lite,	But listen to me, and stop the noise for a little,

This fierse Arcite hath of his helm ydon,	This fierce Arcite has taken off his helm,

Duc Theseus, with al his compaignye,	Duke Theseus, with all his company,
Is comen hoom to Atthenes his citee,	Is come home to Athens, his city,
With alle blisse and greet solempnitee.	With all bliss and great solemnity.
Al be it that this aventure was falle,	Although this accident had happened,
He nolde noght disconforten hem alle.	He would not distress them all.
Men seyde eek that Arcite shal nat dye;	People said also that Arcite shall not dye;
He shal been heeled of his maladye.	He shall be healed of his injuries.
And of another thyng they weren as fayn,	And of another thing they were as happy,
That of hem alle was ther noon yslayn,	That of them all there was no one slain,
Al were they soore yhurt, and namely oon,	Although they (were) sorely hurt, and especially one,

For which this noble duc, as he wel kan,	For which this noble duke, as he well knows how,
Conforteth and honoureth every man,	Comforts and honors every man,
And made revel al the longe nyght	And made revel all the long night
Unto the straunge lordes, as was right.	For the foreign lords, as was right.
Ne ther was holden no disconfitynge	Nor was it considered any defeat (in battle)

The gree as wel of o syde as of oother,	The victory (is given) as well to one side as to the other,

The clothered blood, for any lechecraft,	The clotted blood, despite any medical treatment,

Al is tobrosten thilke regioun;	All is shattered in that region;
