And lat me slepe, a twenty devel wey!"	And let me sleep, in the name of twenty devils!"
"Allas," quod Absolon, "and weylawey,	"Alas," said Absolon, "and woe is me,
That trewe love was evere so yvel biset!	That true love was ever in such miserable circumstances!
Thanne kysse me, syn it may be no bet,	Then kiss me, since it can be no better,
For Jhesus love, and for the love of me."	For Jesus' love, and for the love of me."
"Wiltow thanne go thy wey therwith?" quod she.	"Wilt thou then go thy way with that?" said she.
"Ye, certes, lemman," quod this Absolon.	"Yes, certainly, sweetheart," said this Absolon.
"Thanne make thee redy," quod she, "I come anon."	"Then make thee ready," said she, "I come right now."
And unto Nicholas she seyde stille,	And unto Nicholas she said quietly,
"Now hust, and thou shalt laughen al thy fille."	"Now hush, and thou shalt laugh all thy fill."
This Absolon doun sette hym on his knees	This Absolon set himself down on his knees
And seyde, "I am a lord at alle degrees;	And said, "I am a lord in every way;
For after this I hope ther cometh moore.	For after this I hope there comes more.
Lemman, thy grace, and sweete bryd, thyn oore!"	Sweetheart, thy grace, and sweet bird, thy mercy!"
The wyndow she undoth, and that in haste.	The window she undoes, and that in haste.
"Have do," quod she, "com of, and speed the faste,	"Get done with it," said she, "come on, and hurry up,
Lest that oure neighebores thee espie."	Lest our neighbors espy thee."
This Absolon gan wype his mouth ful drie.	This Absolon wiped his mouth very dry.
Derk was the nyght as pich, or as the cole,	Dark was the night as pitch, or as the coal,
And at the wyndow out she putte hir hole,	And at the window out she put her hole,
And Absolon, hym fil no bet ne wers,	And Absolon, to him it happened no better nor worse,
But with his mouth he kiste hir naked ers	But with his mouth he kissed her naked ass
Ful savourly, er he were war of this.	With great relish, before he was aware of this.
Abak he stirte, and thoughte it was amys,	Back he jumped, and thought it was amiss,
For wel he wiste a womman hath no berd.	For well he knew a woman has no beard.
He felte a thyng al rough and long yherd,	He felt a thing all rough and long haired,
And seyde, "Fy! allas! what have I do?"	And said, "Fie! alas! what have I done?"
"Tehee!" quod she, and clapte the wyndow to,	"Tehee!" said she, and clapped the window to,
And Absolon gooth forth a sory pas.	And Absolon goes forth walking sadly.
"A berd! A berd!" quod hende Nicholas,	"A beard! A beard!" said clever Nicholas,
"By Goddes corpus, this goth faire and weel."	"By God's body, this goes fair and well."
This sely Absolon herde every deel,	This hapless Absolon heard every bit,
And on his lippe he gan for anger byte,	And on his lip he began for anger to bite,
And to hymself he seyde, "I shal thee quyte."	And to himself he said, "I shall pay thee back."
Who rubbeth now, who froteth now his lippes	Who rubs now, who now scrubs his lips
With dust, with sond, with straw, with clooth, with chippes,	With dust, with sand, with straw, with cloth, with chips,
But Absolon, that seith ful ofte, "Allas!"	But Absolon, who says very often, "Alas!"
"My soule bitake I unto Sathanas,	"My soul I entrust to Satan,
But me were levere than al this toun," quod he,	If I would not rather than (have) all this town," said he,
"Of this despit awroken for to be.	"Be avenged for this insult.
Allas," quod he, "allas, I ne hadde ybleynt!"	Alas," said he, "alas, I did not turn away!"
His hoote love was coold and al yqueynt;	His hot love was cold and all extinguished;
For fro that tyme that he hadde kist hir ers,	For from that time that he had kissed her ass,
Of paramours he sette nat a kers,	Love-making he thought not worth not a watercress,
For he was heeled of his maladie.	For he was healed of his malady.
Ful ofte paramours he gan deffie,	Very often he did renounce love-making,
And weep as dooth a child that is ybete.	And wept as does a child that is beaten.
A softe paas he wente over the strete	At a slow pace he went down the street
Until a smyth men cleped daun Gerveys,	To a smith men called dan Gerveys,
That in his forge smythed plough harneys;	Who in his forge made plowing equipment;
He sharpeth shaar and kultour bisily.	He sharpens ploughshares and plough blades busily.
This Absolon knokketh al esily,	This Absolon knocked all gently,
And seyde, "Undo, Gerveys, and that anon."	And said, "Open up, Gerveys, and that right now."
"What, who artow?" "It am I, Absolon."	"What, who art thou?" "It am I, Absolon."
"What, Absolon! for Cristes sweete tree,	"What, Absolon! for Christ's sweet cross,
Why rise ye so rathe? Ey, benedicitee!	Why rise you so early? Ay, bless me!
What eyleth yow? Som gay gerl, God it woot,	What ails yow? Some pretty girl, God knows it,
Hath broght yow thus upon the viritoot.	Hath brought you to be running around like this.
By Seinte Note, ye woot wel what I mene."	By Saint Note, you know well what I mean."
This Absolon ne roghte nat a bene	This Absolon cared not a bean
Of al his pley; no word agayn he yaf;	For all his joking; no word he gave in reply;
He hadde moore tow on his distaf	He had more business on hand
Than Gerveys knew, and seyde, "Freend so deere,	Than Gerveys knew, and said, "Friend so dear,
That hoote kultour in the chymenee heere,	That hot plough blade in the hearth here,
As lene it me; I have therwith to doone,	Lend it to me; I have something to do with it,
And I wol brynge it thee agayn ful soone."	And I will bring it back to thee very soon."
Gerveys answerde, "Certes, were it gold,	Gerveys answered, "Certainly, were it gold,
Or in a poke nobles alle untold,	Or in a sack countless silver coins,
Thou sholdest have, as I am trewe smyth.	Thou sholdest have it, as I am true smith.
Ey, Cristes foo! What wol ye do therwith?"	Ay, Christ's foe! What will you do with it?"
"Therof," quod Absolon, "be as be may.	"Concerning that," said Absolon, "be as be may.
I shal wel telle it thee to-morwe day" --	I shall well tell it to thee to-morrow" --
And caughte the kultour by the colde stele.	And caught the plough blade by the cold handle.
Ful softe out at the dore he gan to stele,	Very softly out at the door he began to steal,
And wente unto the carpenteris wal.	And went unto the carpenter's wall.
He cogheth first, and knokketh therwithal	He coughs first, and knocks then
Upon the wyndowe, right as he dide er.	Upon the window, just as he did before.
This Alison answerde, "Who is ther	This Alison answered, "Who is there
That knokketh so? I warante it a theef."	That knocks so? I swear it is a thief."
"Why, nay," quod he, "God woot, my sweete leef,	"Why, nay," said he, "God knows, my sweet beloved,
I am thyn Absolon, my deerelyng.	I am thy Absolon, my darling.
Of gold," quod he, "I have thee broght a ryng.	Of gold," said he, "I have brought thee a ring.
My mooder yaf it me, so God me save;	My mother gave it to me, as God may save me;
Ful fyn it is, and therto wel ygrave.	Very fine it is, and also nicely engraved.
This wol I yeve thee, if thou me kisse."	This will I give thee, if thou kiss me."
This Nicholas was risen for to pisse,	This Nicholas was risen to piss,
And thoughte he wolde amenden al the jape;	And thought he would make the joke even better;
He sholde kisse his ers er that he scape.	He should kiss his ass before he escapes.
And up the wyndowe dide he hastily,	And he opened up the window hastily,
And out his ers he putteth pryvely	And he puts out his ass stealthily
Over the buttok, to the haunche-bon;	Over the buttock, to the thigh;
And therwith spak this clerk, this Absolon,	And then spoke this clerk, this Absolon,
"Spek, sweete bryd, I noot nat where thou art."	"Speak, sweet bird, I know not where thou art."
This Nicholas anon leet fle a fart	This Nicholas immediately let fly a fart
As greet as it had been a thonder-dent,	As great as if it had been a thunder-bolt,
That with the strook he was almoost yblent;	So that with the stroke he was almost blinded;
And he was redy with his iren hoot,	And he was ready with his hot iron,
And Nicholas amydde the ers he smoot.	And he smote Nicholas in the middle of the ass.
Of gooth the skyn an hande-brede aboute,	Off goes the skin a hand's breadth about,
The hoote kultour brende so his toute,	The hot plough blade so burned his rump
And for the smert he wende for to dye.	And for the pain he thought he would die.
As he were wood, for wo he gan to crye,	As if he were crazy, for woe he began to cry,
"Help! Water! Water! Help, for Goddes herte!"	"Help! Water! Water! Help, for God's heart!"
This carpenter out of his slomber sterte,	This carpenter woke suddenly out of his slumber,
And herde oon crien "water!" as he were wood,	And heard someone cry "water!" as if he were crazy,
And thoughte, "Allas, now comth Nowelis flood!"	And thought, "Alas, now comes Nowell's flood!"
He sit hym up withouten wordes mo,	He sits up without more words,
And with his ax he smoot the corde atwo,	And with his ax he smote the cord in two,

Up stirte hire Alison and Nicholay,	Up started Alison and Nicholay,
And criden "Out" and "Harrow" in the strete.	And cried "Out" and "Help" in the street.
The neighebores, bothe smale and grete,	The neighbors, both low-ranking and high,
In ronnen for to gauren on this man,	Run in to gawk at this man,
That yet aswowne lay, bothe pale and wan,	Who yet lay in a swoon, both pale and wan,
For with the fal he brosten hadde his arm.	For with the fall he had broken his arm.
But stonde he moste unto his owene harm;	But he had to stand up for himself, though it went badly;
For whan he spak, he was anon bore doun	For when he spoke, he was immediately put down
With hende Nicholas and Alisoun.	By clever Nicholas and Alisoun.
They tolden every man that he was wood;	They told every one that he was crazy;
He was agast so of Nowelis flood	He was so afraid of Nowell's flood
Thurgh fantasie that of his vanytee	Because of his imagination that in his foolishness
He hadde yboght hym knedyng tubbes thre,	He had bought himself three kneading tubs,
And hadde hem hanged in the roof above;	And had hanged them in the roof above;
And that he preyed hem, for Goddes love,	And that he begged them, for God's love,
To sitten in the roof, par compaignye.	To sit in the roof, to keep him company.
The folk gan laughen at his fantasye;	The folk did laugh at his foolishness;
Into the roof they kiken and they cape,	Into the roof they stare and they gape,
And turned al his harm unto a jape.	And turned all his harm into a joke.
For what so that this carpenter answerde,	For whatever this carpenter answered,
It was for noght; no man his reson herde.	It was for naught; no one listened to his explanation,
With othes grete he was so sworn adoun	With oaths great he was so sworn down
That he was holde wood in al the toun;	That he was considered crazy in all the town;
For every clerk anonright heeld with oother.	For every clerk immediately agreed with the other.
They seyde, "The man is wood, my leeve brother";	They said, "The man is crazy, my dear brother";
And every wight gan laughen at this stryf.	And every person did laugh at this strife.
Thus swyved was this carpenteris wyf,	Thus screwed was this carpenter's wife,
For al his kepyng and his jalousye,	In spite of all his guarding and his jealousy,
And Absolon hath kist hir nether ye,	And Absolon has kissed her lower eye,
And Nicholas is scalded in the towte.	And Nicholas is scalded in the rump.
This tale is doon, and God save al the rowte!	This tale is done, and God save all this company!
Heere endeth the Millere his Tale.	Here ends the Miller's Tale.
"Wel seyd, by corpus dominus," quod oure Hoost,	"Well said, by the body of our Lord," said our Host,
"Now longe moote thou saille by the cost,	"Now long may thou sail by the coast,
Sire gentil maister, gentil maryneer!	Sir gentle master, gentle mariner!
God yeve the monk a thousand last quade yeer!	God give the monk a thousand cartloads of bad years!
A ha! Felawes, beth ware of swich a jape!	A ha! Fellows, beware of such a trick!
The monk putte in the mannes hood an ape,	The monk made a monkey of the man,
And in his wyves eek, by Seint Austyn!	And of his wife as well, by Saint Augustine!
Draweth no monkes moore unto youre in.	Invite no more monks into your dwelling.
"But now passe over, and lat us seke aboute,	"But now pass over that, and let us look around to see
Who shal now telle first of al this route	Who shall now, first of all this company, tell

As curteisly as it had been a mayde,	As courteously as if he had been a maiden,
"My lady Prioresse, by youre leve,	"My Lady Prioress, by your leave,

Now wol ye vouche sauf, my lady deere?"	Now will you grant this, my lady dear?"

Heere folweth the Prologe of the Persouns Tale.	Here follows the Prologue of the Parson's Tale.
By that the Maunciple hadde his tale al ended,	By the time that the Manciple had his tale all ended,
The sonne fro the south lyne was descended	The sun from the meridian was descended
So lowe that he nas nat, to my sighte,	So low that he was not, to my sight,
Degrees nyne and twenty as in highte.	More than nine and twenty degrees in altitude.
Foure of the clokke it was tho, as I gesse,	Four of the clock it was then, as I suppose,
For ellevene foot, or litel moore or lesse,	For eleven feet, or little more or less,
My shadwe was at thilke tyme, as there	My shadow was there at that same time,
Of swiche feet as my lengthe parted were	Of such feet as if my height were divided
In sixe feet equal of proporcioun.	Into six feet equal in size.
Therwith the moones exaltacioun --	Therewith the moon's exaltation --
I meene Libra -- alwey gan ascende	I mean Libra -- steadily ascended
As we were entryng at a thropes ende;	As we were entering at edge of a village;
For which oure Hoost, as he was wont to gye,	For which our Host, since he was accustomed to guide,
As in this caas, oure joly compaignye,	On this occasion, our jolly company,
Seyde in this wise: "Lordynges everichoon,	Said in this manner: "Gentlemen, every one,
Now lakketh us no tales mo than oon.	Now we lack no tales more than one.
Fulfilled is my sentence and my decree;	Fulfilled is my plan and my decree;
I trowe that we han herd of ech degree;	I believe that we have heard from each social class;
Almoost fulfild is al myn ordinaunce.	Almost fulfilled is all my governance.
I pray to God, so yeve hym right good chaunce,	I pray to God, give right good luck to him,
That telleth this tale to us lustily.	Who tells this tale to us pleasingly.
"Sire preest," quod he, "artow a vicary?	"Sire priest," said he, "art thou a vicar?
Or arte a person? Sey sooth, by thy fey!	Or art thou a parson? Tell the truth, by thy faith!
Be what thou be, ne breke thou nat oure pley;	Be whatever thou may be, break thou not our rules;
For every man, save thou, hath toold his tale.	For every man, save thou, has told his tale.
Unbokele and shewe us what is in thy male;	Unbuckle and show us what is in thy bag;
For trewely, me thynketh by thy cheere	For truly, it seems to me from your appearance
Thou sholdest knytte up wel a greet mateere.	Thou shouldest well conclude a long discourse.
Telle us a fable anon, for cokkes bones!"	Tell us a fictional tale right now, for cock's bones!"
This Persoun answerde, al atones,	This Parson answered, immediately,
"Thou getest fable noon ytoold for me,	"Thou gettest no fiction told by me,
For Paul, that writeth unto Thymothee,	For Paul, who writes unto Timothy,
Repreveth hem that weyven soothfastnesse	Reproves them that abandon truthfulness
And tellen fables and swich wrecchednesse.	And tell fictional tales and such wretched things.
Why sholde I sowen draf out of my fest,	Why should I sow chaff out of my fist,
Whan I may sowen whete, if that me lest?	When I can sow wheat, if I so wish?
For which I seye, if that yow list to heere	For which I say, if you want to hear
Moralitee and vertuous mateere,	Morality and virtuous subject matter,
And thanne that ye wol yeve me audience,	And providing that you will give me your attention,
I wol ful fayn, at Cristes reverence,	I will very gladly, to Christ's reverence,
Do yow plesaunce leefful, as I kan.	Provide you with permissible pleasure, insofar as I can.
But trusteth wel, I am a Southren man;	But trust well, I am a Southern man;
I kan nat geeste `rum, ram, ruf,' by lettre,	I can not recite `rum, ram, ruf,' letter by letter,
Ne, God woot, rym holde I but litel bettre;	And, God knows, rime I consider but little better;
And therfore, if yow list -- I wol nat glose --	And therefore, if you wish -- I will not deceive you --
I wol yow telle a myrie tale in prose	I will yow tell a merry tale in prose
To knytte up al this feeste and make an ende.	To conclude all this festivity and make an end.
And Jhesu, for his grace, wit me sende	And Jesus, for his grace, send me wit
To shewe yow the wey, in this viage,	To show you the way, in this journey,
Of thilke parfit glorious pilgrymage	Of that same perfect glorious pilgrimage
That highte Jerusalem celestial.	That is called Jerusalem celestial.
And if ye vouche sauf, anon I shal	And if you agree, I shall right now
Bigynne upon my tale, for which I preye	Begin my tale, for which I pray you
Telle youre avys; I kan no bettre seye.	To tell your decision; I can say nothing better.
"But nathelees, this meditacioun	"But nonetheless, this meditation
I putte it ay under correccioun	I put it ever subject to correction
Of clerkes, for I am nat textueel;	By clerks, for I am not learned in texts;
I take but the sentence, trusteth weel.	I take from them only the meaning, trust well.
Therfore I make protestacioun	Therefore I make this declaration
That I wol stonde to correccioun."	That I will be subject to correction."
Upon this word we han assented soone,	Upon this word we have quickly assented,
For, as it seemed, it was for to doone --	For, as it seemed, it was the best to do --
To enden in som vertuous sentence,	To end in some virtuous subject matter,
And for to yeve hym space and audience,	And to give him time and attention,
And bade oure Hoost he sholde to hym seye	And told our Host he should to him say
That alle we to telle his tale hym preye.	That we all pray him to tell his tale.
Oure Hoost hadde the wordes for us alle;	Our Host had the words for us all;
"Sire preest," quod he, "now faire yow bifalle!	"Sire priest," said he, "now may good fortune come to you!
Telleth," quod he, "youre meditacioun.	Tell," said he, "your meditation.
But hasteth yow; the sonne wole adoun;	But make haste; the sun is about to go down;
Beth fructuous, and that in litel space,	Be fruitful, and that in little time,
And to do wel God sende yow his grace!	And to do well God send you his grace!
Sey what yow list, and we wol gladly heere."	Say what you wish, and we will gladly hear."
And with that word he seyde in this manere.	And with that word he said in this manner.
Explicit prohemium.	The Prologue ends.
The wordes of the Hoost to the Phisicien and Pardoner.	The words of the host to the physician and pardoner.
Oure Hooste gan to swere as he were wood;	Our Host began to swear as if he was crazy;
"Harrow!" quod he, "by nayles and by blood!	"Alas!" said he, "by (Christ's) nails and by (His) blood!
This was a fals cherl and a fals justise.	This was a false churl and a false judge.
As shameful deeth as herte may devyse	As shameful a death as heart can devise
Come to thise juges and hire advocatz!	Come to these judges and their advocates!
Algate this sely mayde is slayn, allas!	At any rate, this innocent maid is slain, alas!
Allas, to deere boughte she beautee!	Alas, too dearly she paid for her beauty!
Wherfore I seye al day that men may see	Therefore I say that every day men may see
That yiftes of Fortune and of Nature	That gifts of Fortune and of Nature
Been cause of deeth to many a creature.	Are cause of death to many a creature.
Hire beautee was hire deth, I dar wel sayn.	Her beauty was her death, I dare well say.
Allas, so pitously as she was slayn!	Alas, so pitifully as she was slain!
Of bothe yiftes that I speke of now	Of both gifts that I speak of now
Men han ful ofte moore for harm than prow.	Men have very often more harm than benefit.
But trewely, myn owene maister deere,	But truly, mine own master dear,
This is a pitous tale for to heere.	This is a pitiful tale to hear.
But nathelees, passe over; is no fors.	But nonetheless, pass over; is does not matter.
I pray to God so save thy gentil cors,	I pray to God so save thy gentle body,
And eek thyne urynals and thy jurdones,	And also thy vessels for analyzing urine and thy flasks,
Thyn ypocras, and eek thy galiones,	Thine ipocras, and also thy galiones (medicines),
And every boyste ful of thy letuarie;	And every container full of thy electuaries;
God blesse hem, and oure lady Seinte Marie!	God bless them, and our lady Saint Mary!
So moot I theen, thou art a propre man,	As I may prosper, thou art a proper man,
And lyk a prelat, by Seint Ronyan!	And like a prelate, by Saint Ronyan!
Seyde I nat wel? I kan nat speke in terme;	Said I not well? I can not speak in technical terms;
But wel I woot thou doost myn herte to erme,	But well I know thou makes mine heart to grieve so,
That I almoost have caught a cardynacle.	That I almost have caught a palpitation of the heart.
By corpus bones! but I have triacle,	By corpus' bones! unless I have medicine,
Or elles a draughte of moyste and corny ale,	Or else a draught of fresh and strong ale,
Or but I heere anon a myrie tale,	Or unless I hear right now a merry tale,
Myn herte is lost for pitee of this mayde.	My heart is lost for pity of this maid.
Thou beel amy, thou Pardoner," he sayde,	Thou fair friend (rascal), thou Pardoner," he said,
"Telle us som myrthe or japes right anon."	"Tell us some mirth or comic tales right away."
"It shal be doon," quod he, "by Seint Ronyon!	"It shall be done," said he, "by Saint Ronyon!
But first," quod he, "heere at this alestake	But first," said he, "here at this ale stake (tavern sign)
I wol bothe drynke and eten of a cake."	I will both drink and eat of a cake."
But right anon thise gentils gonne to crye,	But right away these gentlefolk began to cry,
"Nay, lat hym telle us of no ribaudye!	"Nay, let him tell us of no ribaldry!
Telle us som moral thyng, that we may leere	Tell us some moral thing, that we may learn
Som wit, and thanne wol we gladly heere."	Some useful knowledge, and then will we gladly hear."
"I graunte, ywis," quod he, "but I moot thynke	"I agree, indeed," said he, "but I must think
Upon som honest thyng while that I drynke."	About some respectable thing while I drink."
Heere folweth the Prologe of the Pardoners Tale.	Here follows the Prologue of the Pardoner's Tale.
"Lordynges," quod he, "in chirches whan I preche,	"Gentlemen," he said, "in churches when I preach,
I peyne me to han an hauteyn speche,	I take pains to have a loud voice,
And rynge it out as round as gooth a belle,	And ring it out as round as goes a belle,
For I kan al by rote that I telle.	For I know all by rote that I tell.
My theme is alwey oon, and evere was --	My theme is always the same, and ever was --
Radix malorum est Cupiditas.	'Greed is the root of all evil.'
"First I pronounce whennes that I come,	"First I pronounce from whence I come,
And thanne my bulles shewe I, alle and some.	And then my papal bulls I show, each and every one.
Oure lige lordes seel on my patente,	Our liege lord's seal on my letter of authorization,
That shewe I first, my body to warente,	I show that first, to protect my body,
That no man be so boold, ne preest ne clerk,	So that no man be so bold, neither priest nor clerk,
Me to destourbe of Cristes hooly werk.	To hinder me from (doing) Christ's holy work.
And after that thanne telle I forth my tales;	And after that then I tell forth my tales;
Bulles of popes and of cardynales,	Indulgences of popes and of cardinals,
Of patriarkes and bishopes I shewe,	Of patriarchs and bishops I show,
And in Latyn I speke a wordes fewe,	And in Latin I speak a few words,
To saffron with my predicacioun,	With which to add spice to my preaching,
And for to stire hem to devocioun.	And to stir them to devotion.
Thanne shewe I forth my longe cristal stones,	Then I show forth my long crystal stones,
Ycrammed ful of cloutes and of bones --	Crammed full of rags and of bones --
Relikes been they, as wenen they echoon.	Relics they are, as suppose they each one.
Thanne have I in latoun a sholder-boon	Then I have mounted in latten (brass-like alloy) a shoulder-bone
Which that was of an hooly Jewes sheep.	Which was of a holy Jew's sheep.
`Goode men,' I seye, `taak of my wordes keep;	`Good men,' I say, `take heed of my words;
If that this boon be wasshe in any welle,	If this bone be washed in any well,
If cow, or calf, or sheep, or oxe swelle	If cow, or calf, or sheep, or ox swell
That any worm hath ete, or worm ystonge,	That any worm has eaten, or worm stung,
Taak water of that welle and wassh his tonge,	Take water of that well and wash its tongue,
And it is hool anon; and forthermoore,	And it is whole right away; and furthermore,
Of pokkes and of scabbe, and every soore	Of pocks and of scab, and every sore
Shal every sheep be hool that of this welle	Every sheep shall be whole that of this well
Drynketh a draughte. Taak kep eek what I telle:	Drinks a draft. Take heed also what I say:
If that the good-man that the beestes oweth	If the householder who owns the beasts
Wol every wyke, er that the cok hym croweth,	Will every week, before the cock crows,
Fastynge, drynken of this welle a draughte,	Fasting, drink of this well a draft,
As thilke hooly Jew oure eldres taughte,	As that same holy Jew taught our elders,
His beestes and his stoor shal multiplie.	His beasts and his possessions shall multiply.
`And, sires, also it heeleth jalousie;	`And, sirs, it also heals jealousy;
For though a man be falle in jalous rage,	For though a man be fallen in jealous rage,
Lat maken with this water his potage,	Have his potage made with this water,
And nevere shal he moore his wyf mystriste,	And he shall never more mistrust his wife,
Though he the soothe of hir defaute wiste,	Though he knew the truth of her misdeed,
Al had she taken prestes two or thre.	Although she had taken two or three priests.
`Heere is a miteyn eek, that ye may se.	`Here is a mitten also, that you may see.
He that his hand wol putte in this mitayn,	He that will put his hand in this mitten,
He shal have multipliyng of his grayn,	He shall have multiplying of his grain,
Whan he hath sowen, be it whete or otes,	When he has sown, be it wheat or oats,
So that he offre pens, or elles grotes.	Providing that he offer pennies, or else fourpences.
`Goode men and wommen, o thyng warne I yow:	`Good men and women, one thing I warn you:
If any wight be in this chirche now	If any person be in this church now
That hath doon synne horrible, that he	Who has done such horrible sin, that he
Dar nat, for shame, of it yshryven be,	Dare not, for shame, be confessed of it,
Or any womman, be she yong or old,	Or any woman, be she young or old,
That hath ymaked hir housbonde cokewold,	Who has made her husband cuckold,
Swich folk shal have no power ne no grace	Such folk shall have no power nor no grace
To offren to my relikes in this place.	To offer to my relics in this place.
And whoso fyndeth hym out of swich blame,	And whoever finds himself out of such blame,
He wol come up and offre a Goddes name,	He will come up and offer in God's name,
And I assoille him by the auctoritee	And I will absolve him by the authority
Which that by bulle ygraunted was to me.'	Which by papal bull was granted to me.'
"By this gaude have I wonne, yeer by yeer,	"By this trick have I won, year after year,
An hundred mark sith I was pardoner.	An hundred marks since I was pardoner.
I stonde lyk a clerk in my pulpet,	I stand like a clerk in my pulpit,
And whan the lewed peple is doun yset,	And when the ignorant people are set down,
I preche so as ye han herd bifoore	I preach as you have heard before
And telle an hundred false japes moore.	And tell a hundred more false tales.
Thanne peyne I me to strecche forth the nekke,	Then I take pains to stretch forth the neck,
And est and west upon the peple I bekke,	And east and west upon the people I nod,
As dooth a dowve sittynge on a berne.	As does a dove sitting on a barn.
Myne handes and my tonge goon so yerne	My hands and my tongue go so quickly
That it is joye to se my bisynesse.	That it is joy to see my business.
Of avarice and of swich cursednesse	Of avarice and of such cursedness
Is al my prechyng, for to make hem free	Is all my preaching, to make them generous
To yeven hir pens, and namely unto me.	To give their pennies, and namely unto me.
For myn entente is nat but for to wynne,	For my intention is only to make a profit,
And nothyng for correccioun of synne.	And not at all for correction of sin.
I rekke nevere, whan that they been beryed,	I care not a bit, when they are buried,
Though that hir soules goon a-blakeberyed!	Though their souls go picking blackberries!
For certes, many a predicacioun	For certainly, many a sermon
Comth ofte tyme of yvel entencioun;	Comes often times from an evil intention;
Som for plesance of folk and flaterye,	Some for pleasure of folk and flattery,
To been avaunced by ypocrisye,	To be advanced by hypocrisy,
And som for veyne glorie, and som for hate.	And some for vain glory, and some for hate.
For whan I dar noon oother weyes debate,	For when I dare debate no other ways,
Thanne wol I stynge hym with my tonge smerte	Then I will sting him with my sharp tongue
In prechyng, so that he shal nat asterte	In preaching, so that he shall not escape
To been defamed falsly, if that he	To be defamed falsely, if he
Hath trespased to my bretheren or to me.	Has trespassed to my brethren or to me.
For though I telle noght his propre name,	For though I tell not his proper name,
Men shal wel knowe that it is the same,	Men shall well know that it is the same,
By signes, and by othere circumstances.	By signs, and by other details.
Thus quyte I folk that doon us displesances;	Thus I repay folk who make trouble for us pardoners;
Thus spitte I out my venym under hewe	Thus I spit out my venom under hue
Of hoolynesse, to semen hooly and trewe.	Of holinesses, to seem holy and true.
"But shortly myn entente I wol devyse:	"But shortly my intention I will tell:
I preche of no thyng but for coveityse.	I preach of nothing but for greed.
Therfore my theme is yet, and evere was,	Therefore my theme is yet, and ever was,
Radix malorum est Cupiditas.	`Greed is the root of all evil.'
Thus kan I preche agayn that same vice	Thus I can preach against that same vice
Which that I use, and that is avarice.	Which I use, and that is avarice.
But though myself be gilty in that synne,	But though myself be guilty of that sin,
Yet kan I maken oother folk to twynne	Yet I can make other folk to turn away
From avarice and soore to repente.	From avarice and bitterly to repent.
But that is nat my principal entente;	But that is not my principal intention;
I preche nothyng but for coveitise.	I preach nothing but for greed.
Of this mateere it oghte ynogh suffise.	Concerning this matter this ought to be enough.
"Thanne telle I hem ensamples many oon	"Then I tell them illustrative tales many a one
Of olde stories longe tyme agoon.	Of old stories from long time ago.
For lewed peple loven tales olde;	For ignorant people love old tales;
Swiche thynges kan they wel reporte and holde.	Such things they can well repeat and hold in memory.
What, trowe ye, that whiles I may preche,	What, do you suppose, that while I can preach,
And wynne gold and silver for I teche,	And win gold and silver because I teach,
That I wol lyve in poverte wilfully?	That I will live in poverty voluntarily?
Nay, nay, I thoghte it nevere, trewely!	Nay, nay, I never thought it, truly!
For I wol preche and begge in sondry landes;	For I will preach and beg in various lands;
I wol nat do no labour with myne handes,	I will not do any labor with my hands,
Ne make baskettes and lyve therby,	Nor make baskets and live thereby,
By cause I wol nat beggen ydelly.	Because I will not beg idly.
I wol noon of the apostles countrefete;	I will imitate none of the apostles;
I wol have moneie, wolle, chese, and whete,	I will have money, wool, cheese, and wheat,
Al were it yeven of the povereste page,	Although it were given by the poorest servant boy,
Or of the povereste wydwe in a village,	Or by the poorest widow in a village,
Al sholde hir children sterve for famyne.	Even though her children should die of hunger.
Nay, I wol drynke licour of the vyne	Nay, I will drink liquor of the vine
And have a joly wenche in every toun.	And have a pretty wench in every town.
But herkneth, lordynges, in conclusioun:	But listen, gentlemen, in conclusion:
Youre likyng is that I shal telle a tale.	Your desire is that I shall tell a tale.
Now have I dronke a draughte of corny ale,	Now I have drunk a draft of strong ale,
By God, I hope I shal yow telle a thyng	By God, I hope I shall tell you a thing
That shal by reson been at youre likyng.	That shall, for good reason, be to your liking.
For though myself be a ful vicious man,	For though myself be a very vicious man,
A moral tale yet I yow telle kan,	Yet I can tell you a moral tale,
Which I am wont to preche for to wynne.	Which I am accustomed to preach in order to profit.
Now hoold youre pees! My tale I wol bigynne."	Now hold your peace! My tale I will begin."
Heere bigynneth the Pardoners Tale.	Here begins the Pardoner's Tale.
In Flaundres whilom was a compaignye	In Flanders once was a company
Of yonge folk that haunteden folye,	Of young folk who practiced folly,
As riot, hasard, stywes, and tavernes,	Such as debauchery, gambling, brothels, and taverns,
Where as with harpes, lutes, and gyternes,	Where with harps, lutes, and guitars,
They daunce and pleyen at dees bothe day and nyght,	They dance and play at dice both day and night,
And eten also and drynken over hir myght,	And also eat and drink beyond their capacity,
Thurgh which they doon the devel sacrifise	Through which they do the devil sacrifice
Withinne that develes temple in cursed wise	Within that devil's temple in cursed manner
By superfluytee abhomynable.	By abominable excess.
Hir othes been so grete and so dampnable	Their oaths are so great and so damnable
That it is grisly for to heere hem swere.	That it is grisly to hear them swear.
Oure blissed Lordes body they totere --	Our blessed Lord's body they tore in pieces --
Hem thoughte that Jewes rente hym noght ynough --	They thought that the Jews did not tear him enough --
And ech of hem at otheres synne lough.	And each of them laughed at the other's sin.
And right anon thanne comen tombesteres	And right away then come dancing girls
Fetys and smale, and yonge frutesteres,	Elegantly shaped and slim, and girls selling fruits,
Syngeres with harpes, baudes, wafereres,	Singers with harps, bawds, girls selling wafers,
Whiche been the verray develes officeres	Which are the very devil's officers
To kyndle and blowe the fyr of lecherye,	To kindle and blow the fire of lechery,
That is annexed unto glotonye.	That is joined unto gluttony.
The hooly writ take I to my witnesse	The Bible I take as my witness
That luxurie is in wyn and dronkenesse.	That lechery is in wine and drunkenness.
Lo, how that dronken Looth, unkyndely,	Lo, how that drunken Lot, unnaturally,
Lay by his doghtres two, unwityngly;	Lay by his two daughters, unwittingly;
So dronke he was, he nyste what he wroghte.	So drunk he was, he knew not what he did.
Herodes, whoso wel the stories soghte,	Herod, whoever should seek well the histories (would learn),
Whan he of wyn was repleet at his feeste,	When he was filled with wine at his feast,
Right at his owene table he yaf his heeste	Right at his own table he gave his command
To sleen the Baptist John, ful giltelees.	To slay John the Baptist, full guiltless.
Senec seith a good word doutelees;	Seneca says a good word, doubtless;
He seith he kan no difference fynde	He says he can find no difference
Bitwix a man that is out of his mynde	Between a man that is out of his mind
And a man which that is dronkelewe,	And a man that is drunk,
But that woodnesse, yfallen in a shrewe,	Except that madness, fallen in an evil person,
Persevereth lenger than doth dronkenesse.	Lasts longer than does drunkenness.
O glotonye, ful of cursednesse!	O gluttony, full of cursedness!
O cause first of oure confusioun!	O first cause of our ruin!
O original of oure dampnacioun,	O origin of our damnation,
Til Crist hadde boght us with his blood agayn!	Until Christ had bought us with his blood again!
Lo, how deere, shortly for to sayn,	Lo, how dearly, shortly to say,
Aboght was thilke cursed vileynye!	Was bought that same cursed villainy!
Corrupt was al this world for glotonye.	Corrupt was all this world for gluttony.
Adam oure fader, and his wyf also,	Adam our fader, and his wife also,
Fro Paradys to labour and to wo	From Paradise to labor and to woe
Were dryven for that vice, it is no drede.	Were driven for that vice, there is no doubt.
For whil that Adam fasted, as I rede,	For while Adam fasted, as I read,
He was in Paradys; and whan that he	He was in Paradise; and when he
Eet of the fruyt deffended on the tree,	Ate of the forbidden fruit on the tree,
Anon he was out cast to wo and peyne.	Immediately he was cast out to woe and pain.
O glotonye, on thee wel oghte us pleyne!	O gluttony, on thee well we ought to complain!
O, wiste a man how manye maladyes	O, if a man knew how many evils
Folwen of excesse and of glotonyes,	Follow of excess and of gluttony,
He wolde been the moore mesurable	He would be the more moderate
Of his diete, sittynge at his table.	Of his diet, sitting at his table.
Allas, the shorte throte, the tendre mouth,	Alas, the short throat, the tender mouth,
Maketh that est and west and north and south,	Makes that east and west and north and south,
In erthe, in eir, in water, men to swynke	In earth, in air, in water, men work
To gete a glotoun deyntee mete and drynke!	To get a glutton dainty food and drink!
Of this matiere, O Paul, wel kanstow trete:	Of this matter, O Paul, well can thou treat
"Mete unto wombe, and wombe eek unto mete,	"Food unto belly, and belly also unto food,
Shal God destroyen bothe," as Paulus seith.	God shall destroy both," as Paul says.
Allas, a foul thyng is it, by my feith,	Alas, a foul thing it is, by my faith,
To seye this word, and fouler is the dede,	To say this word, and fouler is the deed,
Whan man so drynketh of the white and rede	When man so drinks of the white and red
That of his throte he maketh his pryvee	That he makes his privy of his throat
Thurgh thilke cursed superfluitee.	Through that same cursed excess.
The apostel wepyng seith ful pitously,	The apostle weeping says full piteously,
"Ther walken manye of whiche yow toold have I --	"There walk many of whom I have told you --
I seye it now wepyng, with pitous voys --	I say it now weeping, with piteous voice --
They been enemys of Cristes croys,	They are enemies of Christ's cross,
Of whiche the ende is deeth; wombe is hir god!"	Of which the end is death; belly is their god!"
O wombe! O bely! O stynkyng cod,	O gut! O belly! O stinking bag,
Fulfilled of dong and of corrupcioun!	Filled with dung and with corruption!
At either ende of thee foul is the soun.	At either end of thee the sound is foul.
How greet labour and cost is thee to fynde!	How great labor and cost it is to feed thee!
Thise cookes, how they stampe, and streyne, and grynde,	These cooks, how they pound, and strain, and grind,
And turnen substaunce into accident	And turn substance into outward appearance
To fulfille al thy likerous talent!	To fulfill all thy gluttonous desire!
Out of the harde bones knokke they	Out of the hard bones they knock
The mary, for they caste noght awey	The marrow, for they throw nothing away
That may go thurgh the golet softe and swoote.	That may go through the gullet softly and sweetly.
Of spicerie of leef, and bark, and roote	Of seasonings of leaf, and bark, and root
Shal been his sauce ymaked by delit,	Shall his sauce be made for delight,
To make hym yet a newer appetit.	To make him yet a newer appetite.
But, certes, he that haunteth swiche delices	But, certainly, he who habitually seeks such delicacies
Is deed, whil that he lyveth in tho vices.	Is dead, while he lives in those vices.
A lecherous thyng is wyn, and dronkenesse	A lecherous thing is wine, and drunkenness
Is ful of stryvyng and of wrecchednesse.	Is full of striving and of wretchedness.
O dronke man, disfigured is thy face,	O drunken man, disfigured is thy face,
Sour is thy breeth, foul artow to embrace,	Sour is thy breath, foul art thou to embrace,
And thurgh thy dronke nose semeth the soun	And through thy drunken nose the sound seems
As though thou seydest ay "Sampsoun, Sampsoun!"	As though thou said always "Sampson, Sampson!"
And yet, God woot, Sampsoun drank nevere no wyn.	And yet, God knows, Sampson never drank any wine.
Thou fallest as it were a styked swyn;	Thou fallest like a stuck pig;
Thy tonge is lost, and al thyn honeste cure,	Thy tongue is lost, and all thy care for decency,
For dronkenesse is verray sepulture	For drunkenness is truly the sepulcher
Of mannes wit and his discrecioun.	Of man's wit and his discretion.
In whom that drynke hath dominacioun	In whom drink has domination
He kan no conseil kepe; it is no drede.	He can keep no secrets; there is no doubt.
Now kepe yow fro the white and fro the rede,	Now guard yourself from the white and from the red,
And namely fro the white wyn of Lepe	And namely from the white wine of Lepe
That is to selle in Fysshstrete or in Chepe.	That is for sale in Fishstreet or in Cheapside.
This wyn of Spaigne crepeth subtilly	This wine of Spain creeps subtly
In othere wynes, growynge faste by,	Into other wines, growing near by,
Of which ther ryseth swich fumositee	Of which there rise such bodily vapors
That whan a man hath dronken draughtes thre,	That when a man has drunk three drafts,
And weneth that he be at hoom in Chepe,	And supposes that he is at home in Cheapside,
He is in Spaigne, right at the toune of Lepe --	He is in Spain, right at the town of Lepe --
Nat at the Rochele, ne at Burdeux toun --	Not at La Rochelle, nor at Bordeaux town --
And thanne wol he seye "Sampsoun, Sampsoun!"	And then will he say "Sampson, Sampson!"
But herkneth, lordynges, o word, I yow preye,	But listen, gentlemen, one word, I pray you,
That alle the sovereyn actes, dar I seye,	That all the great deeds, I dare say,
Of victories in the Olde Testament,	Of victories in the Old Testament,
Thurgh verray God, that is omnipotent,	Through true God, who is omnipotent,
Were doon in abstinence and in preyere.	Were done in abstinence and in prayer.
Looketh the Bible, and ther ye may it leere.	Look in the Bible, and there you can learn it.
Looke, Attilla, the grete conquerour,	Consider how Attila, the great conqueror,
Deyde in his sleep, with shame and dishonour,	Died in his sleep, with shame and dishonor,
Bledynge ay at his nose in dronkenesse.	Bleeding ever at his nose in drunkenness.
A capitayn sholde lyve in sobrenesse.	A captain should live in sobriety.
And over al this, avyseth yow right wel	And beyond all this, consider right well
What was comaunded unto Lamuel --	What was commanded unto Lamuel --
Nat Samuel, but Lamuel, seye I;	Not Samuel, but Lamuel, I say;
Redeth the Bible, and fynde it expresly	Read the Bible, and find it explicitly
Of wyn-yevyng to hem that han justise.	About giving wine to those that have the duty of doing justice.
Namoore of this, for it may wel suffise.	No more of this, for it may well suffice.
And now that I have spoken of glotonye,	And now that I have spoken of gluttony,
Now wol I yow deffenden hasardrye.	Now I will forbid you gambling.
Hasard is verray mooder of lesynges,	Dicing is the true mother of lies,
And of deceite, and cursed forswerynges,	And of deceit, and cursed perjuries,
Blaspheme of Crist, manslaughtre, and wast also	Blasphemy of Christ, manslaughter, and waste also
Of catel and of tyme; and forthermo,	Of possessions and of time; and furthermore,
It is repreeve and contrarie of honour	It is a disgrace and contrary to honor
For to ben holde a commune hasardour.	To be considered a common dice player.
And ever the hyer he is of estaat,	And ever the higher he is of estate,
The moore is he yholden desolaat.	The more is he considered abandoned (to shame).
If that a prynce useth hasardrye,	If a prince plays at dicing,
In alle governaunce and policye	In all governance and policy
He is, as by commune opinioun,	He is, by common opinion,
Yholde the lasse in reputacioun.	Held the less in reputation.
Stilboun, that was a wys embassadour,	Stilboun, who was a wise ambassador,
Was sent to Corynthe in ful greet honour	Was sent to Corinth in very great honor
Fro Lacidomye to make hire alliaunce.	From Sparta to make their alliance.
And whan he cam, hym happede, par chaunce,	And when he came, it happened, by chance,
That alle the gretteste that were of that lond,	That all the greatest men that were of that land,
Pleyynge atte hasard he hem fond.	Playing at dice he found them.
For which, as soone as it myghte be,	For which, as soon as it could be,
He stal hym hoom agayn to his contree,	He stole home again to his country,
And seyde, "Ther wol I nat lese my name,	And said, "There I will not lose my reputation,
Ne I wol nat take on me so greet defame,	Nor will I take on me so great infamy,
Yow for to allie unto none hasardours.	To ally you unto any dice-players.
Sendeth othere wise embassadours;	Send other wise ambassadors;
For, by my trouthe, me were levere dye	For, by my troth, I would rather die
Than I yow sholde to hasardours allye.	Than I should ally you to dice-players.
For ye, that been so glorious in honours,	For you, that are so glorious in honors,
Shul nat allyen yow with hasardours	Shall not ally yourselves with dice-players
As by my wyl, ne as by my tretee."	By my will, nor by my negotiation."
This wise philosophre, thus seyde hee.	This wise philosopher, thus said he.
Looke eek that to the kyng Demetrius	Consider also that to the king Demetrius
The kyng of Parthes, as the book seith us,	The king of Parthia, as the book tells us,
Sente him a paire of dees of gold in scorn,	Sent him a pair of dice of gold in scorn,
For he hadde used hasard ther-biforn;	Because he had played at dicing before that;
For which he heeld his glorie or his renoun	For which he held his glory or his renown
At no value or reputacioun.	At no value or esteem.
Lordes may fynden oother maner pley	Lords may find other sorts of play
Honest ynough to dryve the day awey.	Respectable enough to pass the time.
Now wol I speke of othes false and grete	Now will I speak of oaths false and great
A word or two, as olde bookes trete.	A word or two, as old books treat them.
Gret sweryng is a thyng abhominable,	Great swearing is an abominable thing,
And fals sweryng is yet moore reprevable.	And false swearing is yet more worthy of reproof.
The heighe God forbad sweryng at al,	The high God forbad swearing at al,
Witnesse on Mathew; but in special	Witness on Matthew; but in special
Of sweryng seith the hooly Jeremye,	Of swearing says the holy Jeremiah,
"Thou shalt swere sooth thyne othes, and nat lye,	"Thou shall swear truly thine oaths, and not lie,
And swere in doom and eek in rightwisnesse";	And in judgement and also in righteousness";
But ydel sweryng is a cursednesse.	But idle swearing is a cursed thing.
Bihoold and se that in the firste table	Behold and see that in the first three
Of heighe Goddes heestes honurable,	Of high God's honorable commandments,
Hou that the seconde heeste of hym is this:	How the second of his commands is this:
"Take nat my name in ydel or amys."	"Take not my name in vain nor amiss."
Lo, rather he forbedeth swich sweryng	Lo, he forbids such swearing rather
Than homycide or many a cursed thyng;	Than homicide or many a cursed thing;
I seye that, as by ordre, thus it stondeth;	I say that, so far as order is concerned, thus it stands;
This knoweth, that his heestes understondeth,	He who understands his commandments knows this,
How that the seconde heeste of God is that.	How that is the second command of God.
And forther over, I wol thee telle al plat	And furthermore, I will tell thee flatly
That vengeance shal nat parten from his hous	That vengeance shall not part from his house
That of his othes is to outrageous.	Who of his oaths is too excessive.
"By Goddes precious herte," and "By his nayles,"	"By God's precious heart," and "By his nails,"
And "By the blood of Crist that is in Hayles,	And "By the blood of Christ that is in Hales Abbey,
Sevene is my chaunce, and thyn is cynk and treye!"	Seven is my number, and thine is five and three!"
"By Goddes armes, if thou falsly pleye,	"By God's arms, if thou falsely play,
This daggere shal thurghout thyn herte go!" --	This dagger shall go throughout thy heart!" --
This fruyt cometh of the bicched bones two,	This fruit comes of the two cursed dice,

Lat kutte hem of, I wol thee helpe hem carie;	Have them cut off, I will help thee carry them;
They shul be shryned in an hogges toord!"	They shall be enshrined in a hog's turd!"
This Pardoner answerde nat a word;	This Pardoner answered not a word;
So wrooth he was, no word ne wolde he seye.	So angry he was, no word would he say.
"Now," quod oure Hoost, "I wol no lenger pleye	"Now," said our Host, "I will no longer joke
With thee, ne with noon oother angry man."	With thee, nor with any other angry man."
But right anon the worthy Knyght bigan,	But immediately the worthy Knight began,
Whan that he saugh that al the peple lough,	When he saw that all the people laughed,
"Namoore of this, for it is right ynough!	"No more of this, for it is right enough!
Sire Pardoner, be glad and myrie of cheere;	Sir Pardoner, be glad and merry of cheer;
And ye, sire Hoost, that been to me so deere,	And you, sir Host, who are so dear to me,
I prey yow that ye kisse the Pardoner.	I pray you that you kiss the Pardoner.
And Pardoner, I prey thee, drawe thee neer,	And Pardoner, I pray thee, draw thyself nearer,
And, as we diden, lat us laughe and pleye."	And, as we did, let us laugh and play."
Anon they kiste, and ryden forth hir weye.	At once they kissed, and rode forth their way.
The ministre and the norice unto vices,	The minister and the nurse of vices,
Which that men clepe in Englissh Ydelnesse,	Which men call in English Idleness,
That porter of the gate is of delices,	Who is porter of the gate of pleasures
To eschue, and by hire contrarie hire oppresse --	To shun, and by her contrary to overcome her --
That is to seyn, by leveful bisynesse --	That is to say, by keeping busy in lawful good works --
Wel oghten we to doon al oure entente,	Well ought we to do all our diligence
Lest that the feend thurgh ydelnesse us hente.	Lest the fiend by means of idleness seize us.
For he that with his thousand cordes slye	For he that with his thousand sly snares
Continuelly us waiteth to biclappe,	Continually lies in wait to seize us suddenly,
Whan he may man in ydelnesse espye,	When he can espy a man in idleness,
He kan so lightly cache hym in his trappe,	He can catch him in his trap so quickly,
Til that a man be hent right by the lappe,	That until a man is seized right by the hem of his garment,
He nys nat war the feend hath hym in honde.	He is not aware that the fiend has him in hand.
Wel oghte us werche and ydelnesse withstonde.	Well ought we to work and resist idleness.
And though men dradden nevere for to dye,	And even though people never dreaded to die,
Yet seen men wel by resoun, doutelees,	Yet they can well see by reason, doubtless,
That ydelnesse is roten slogardye,	That idleness is rotten laziness,
Of which ther nevere comth no good n' encrees;	From which there never comes any good or profit;
And syn that slouthe hire holdeth in a lees	And since sloth holds her (Idleness) on a leash
Oonly to slepe, and for to ete and drynke,	(Allowing her) only to sleep, and to eat and drink,
And to devouren al that othere swynke,	And to devour all that others earn by working,
And for to putte us fro swich ydelnesse,	And in order to set us apart from such idleness,
That cause is of so greet confusioun,	Which is the cause of such great ruin,
I have heer doon my feithful bisynesse	I have here done my faithful efforts
After the legende in translacioun	In translating the legend
Right of thy glorious lif and passioun,	Correctly of thy glorious life and suffering,
Thou with thy gerland wroght with rose and lilie --	Thou with thy garland made with rose and lily --
Thee meene I, mayde and martyr, Seint Cecilie.	I mean thee, maid and martyr, Saint Cecilie.
And thow that flour of virgines art alle,	And thou who art the flower of all virgins,
Of whom that Bernard list so wel to write,	Of whom it so well pleased Bernard to write,
To thee at my bigynnyng first I calle;	To thee at my beginning first I call;
Thou confort of us wrecches, do me endite	Thou comfort of us wretches, let me narrate
Thy maydens deeth, that wan thurgh hire merite	Thy maiden's death, that won by means of her merit
The eterneel lyf and of the feend victorie,	The eternal life and victory over the fiend,
As man may after reden in hire storie.	As one may hereafter read in her story.
Thow Mayde and Mooder, doghter of thy Sone,	Thou Maid and Mother, daughter of thy Son,
Thow welle of mercy, synful soules cure,	Thou well of mercy, sinful souls' cure,
In whom that God for bountee chees to wone,	In whom God for goodness chose to dwell,
Thow humble, and heigh over every creature,	Thou humble, and high over every creature,
Thow nobledest so ferforth oure nature,	Thou so greatly enobled our nature,
That no desdeyn the Makere hadde of kynde	That the Maker of humankind had no disdain
His Sone in blood and flessh to clothe and wynde.	To clothe and wrap His Son in blood and flesh.
Withinne the cloistre blisful of thy sydis	Within the blissful cloister of thy sides
Took mannes shap the eterneel love and pees,	The eternal love and peace took man's shape,
That of the tryne compas lord and gyde is,	He who is lord and guide of the threefold universe,
Whom erthe and see and hevene out of relees	Whom earth and sea and heaven unceasing
Ay heryen; and thou, Virgine wemmelees,	Ever praise; and thou, Virgin without blemish,
Baar of thy body -- and dweltest mayden pure --	Bore in thy body -- and remained maiden pure --
The Creatour of every creature.	The Creator of every creature.
Assembled is in thee magnificence	Magnificence is in thee combined
With mercy, goodnesse, and with swich pitee	With mercy, goodness, and with such pity
That thou, that art the sonne of excellence	That thou, who art the sun of excellence
Nat oonly helpest hem that preyen thee,	Not only helpest them that pray thee,
But often tyme of thy benygnytee	But often of thy goodness
Ful frely, er that men thyn help biseche,	Very willingly, before men beseech thine help,
Thou goost biforn and art hir lyves leche.	Thou goest before and art their lives' physician.
Now help, thow meeke and blisful faire mayde,	Now, thou meek and blissful fair maid help
Me, flemed wrecche, in this desert of galle;	Me, banished exile, in this desert of bitterness;
Thynk on the womman Cananee, that sayde	Think on the Cananite woman, who said
That whelpes eten somme of the crommes alle	That dogs eat some of all the crumbs
That from hir lordes table been yfalle;	That from their lord's table are fallen;
And though that I, unworthy sone of Eve,	And though that I, unworthy son of Eve,
Be synful, yet accepte my bileve.	Be sinful, yet accept my faith.
And, for that feith is deed withouten werkis,	And, because faith is dead without works,
So for to werken yif me wit and space,	Give me wit and opportunity to work so,
That I be quit fro thennes that most derk is!	That I may be free from that place that is most dark!
O thou, that art so fair and ful of grace,	O thou, that art so fair and full of grace,
Be myn advocat in that heighe place	Be my advocate in that high place
Theras withouten ende is songe "Osanne,"	Where unceasingly is sung "Hosanna,"
Thow Cristes mooder, doghter deere of Anne!	Thou Christ's mother, daughter dear of Anne!
And of thy light my soule in prison lighte,	And of thy light enlighten in prison my soul,
That troubled is by the contagioun	That is troubled by the contamination
Of my body, and also by the wighte	Of my body, and also by the weight
Of erthely lust and fals affeccioun;	Of earthly lust and false desires;
O havene of refut, O salvacioun	O haven of refuge, O salvation
Of hem that been in sorwe and in distresse,	Of those who are in sorrow and in distress,
Now help, for to my werk I wol me dresse.	Now help, for to my work I will address myself.
Yet preye I yow that reden that I write,	Yet I pray you who read what I write,
Foryeve me that I do no diligence	Forgive me that I make no effort
This ilke storie subtilly to endite,	To narrate this same story elaborately,
For bothe have I the wordes and sentence	For I have both the words and the meaning
Of hym that at the seintes reverence	Of him who out of reverence for the saint
The storie wroot, and folwen hire legende,	Wrote the story, and (I) follow her legend,
And pray yow that ye wole my werk amende.	And pray you that you will correct (any errors in) my work.
First wolde I yow the name of Seint Cecilie	First the name of Saint Cecilie I would to you
Expowne, as men may in hir storie see.	Explain, as one can see in her story.
It is to seye in Englissh "hevenes lilie,"	It is to say in English "heaven's lily,"
For pure chaastnesse of virginitee;	For pure chastity of virginity;
Or, for she whitnesse hadde of honestee,	Or, because she had whiteness because of chastity,
And grene of conscience, and of good fame	And green because of conscience and of good reputation
The soote savour, "lilie" was hir name.	The sweet smell, "lily" was her name.
Or Cecilie is to seye "the wey to blynde,"	Or Cecilie is to mean "the way for the blind,"
For she ensample was by good techynge;	Because she set an example by good teaching;
Or elles Cecile, as I writen fynde,	Or else Cecile, as I written find,
Is joyned, by a manere conjoynynge	Is joined, by a sort of combination
Of "hevene" and "Lia"; and heere, in figurynge,	Of "heaven" and "Leah"; and here, symbolically,
The "hevene" is set for thoght of hoolynesse,	The "heaven" is set for her holiness of thought,
And "Lia" for hire lastynge bisynesse.	And "Leah" for her constant business.
Cecile may eek be seyd in this manere,	Cecile may also be explained in this manner,
"Wantynge of blyndnesse," for hir grete light	"Lack of blindness," for her great light
Of sapience and for hire thewes cleere;	Of wisdom and for her pure morals;
Or elles, loo, this maydens name bright	Or else, lo, this maidens bright name
Of "hevene" and "leos" comth, for which by right	Comes from "heaven" and "leos," for which rightly
Men myghte hire wel "the hevene of peple" calle,	Men could well call her "the heaven of people,"
Ensample of goode and wise werkes alle.	Exemplar of all good and wise works.
For "leos" "peple" in Englissh is to seye,	For "leos" in English means "people,"
And right as men may in the hevene see	And just as men may in the heaven see
The sonne and moone and sterres every weye,	The sun and moon and stars in every direction,
Right so men goostly in this mayden free	Just so in this maiden men spiritually
Seyen of feith the magnanymytee,	See the greatness of spirit of faith,
And eek the cleernesse hool of sapience,	And also the complete clarity of wisdom,
And sondry werkes, brighte of excellence.	And various works, bright because of their excellence.
And right so as thise philosophres write	And just as these scientists write
That hevene is swift and round and eek brennynge,	That heaven is swift and round and also burning,
Right so was faire Cecilie the white	Just so was fair Cecilie the white
Ful swift and bisy evere in good werkynge,	Very swift and busy ever in good works,
And round and hool in good perseverynge,	And round and whole in persevering in good (works),
And brennynge evere in charite ful brighte.	And burning ever in very bright charity.
Now have I yow declared what she highte.	Now have I declared to you what she was called.
This mayden bright Cecilie, as hir lif seith,	This bright maiden Cecilie, as her Life says,
Was comen of Romayns and of noble kynde,	Was descended from Romans and of noble birth,
And from hir cradel up fostred in the feith	And from her cradle nurtured up in the faith
Of Crist, and bar his gospel in hir mynde.	Of Christ, and bore his gospel in her mind.
She nevere cessed, as I writen fynde,	She never ceased, as I written find,
Of hir preyere and God to love and drede,	Of her prayer and God to love and dread,
Bisekynge hym to kepe hir maydenhede.	Beseeching him to preserve her virginity.
And whan this mayden sholde unto a man	And when this maiden should unto a man
Ywedded be, that was ful yong of age,	Wedded be, who was very young of age,
Which that ycleped was Valerian,	Who was called Valerian,
And day was comen of hir marriage,	And the day of her marriage was come,
She, ful devout and humble in hir corage,	She, very devout and humble in her spirit,
Under hir robe of gold, that sat ful faire,	Under her robe of gold, that became her very well,
Hadde next hire flessh yclad hire in an haire.	Had next to her flesh clad herself in a hair shirt.
And whil the organs maden melodie,	And while the organs made melody,
To God allone in herte thus sang she:	To God alone in heart thus sang she:
"O Lord, my soule and eek my body gye	"O Lord, my soul and also my body preserve
Unwemmed, lest that I confounded be."	Immaculate, lest that I be damned."
And for his love that dyde upon a tree	And for his love who died upon the cross
Every seconde and thridde day she faste,	Every second and third day she fasted,
Ay biddynge in hire orisons ful faste.	Ever praying in her prayers very earnestly.
The nyght cam, and to bedde moste she gon	The night came, and to bed must she go
With hire housbonde, as ofte is the manere,	With her husband, as often is the manner,
And pryvely to hym she seyde anon,	And privately to him she said at once,
"O sweete and wel biloved spouse deere,	"O sweet and well beloved spouse dear,
Ther is a conseil, and ye wolde it heere,	There is a secret, if you want to hear it,
Which that right fayn I wolde unto yow seye,	Which I am very eager to say to you,
So that ye swere ye shul it nat biwreye."	Providing that you swear you shall not reveal it."
Valerian gan faste unto hire swere	Valerian did earnestly unto her swear
That for no cas ne thyng that myghte be,	That for no occasion nor thing that might be,
He sholde nevere mo biwreyen here;	He should never ever betray her;
And thanne at erst to hym thus seyde she:	And then for the first time to him thus said she:
"I have an aungel which that loveth me,	"I have an angel who loves me,
That with greet love, wher so I wake or sleepe,	Who with great love, whether I wake or sleep,
Is redy ay my body for to kepe.	Is always ready to guard my body.
"And if that he may feelen, out of drede,	"And if he may sense, withoubt doubt,
That ye me touche, or love in vileynye,	That you touch me, or love me lecherously,
He right anon wol sle yow with the dede,	He straightway will slay you in the act,
And in youre yowthe thus ye shullen dye;	And in your youth thus you shall die;
And if that ye in clene love me gye,	And if you preserve me in chaste love,
He wol yow loven as me, for youre clennesse,	He will love you as (he loves) me, for your chastity,
And shewen yow his joye and his brightnesse."	And show you his joy and his brightness."
Valerian, corrected as God wolde,	Valerian, corrected as God would (have it),
Answerde agayn, "If I shal trusten thee,	Answered in reply, "If I must trust thee,
Lat me that aungel se and hym biholde;	Let me see that angel and behold him;
And if that it a verray angel bee,	And if it be a true angel,
Thanne wol I doon as thou hast prayed me;	Then will I do as thou hast prayed me;
And if thou love another man, for sothe	And if thou love another man, in truth
Right with this swerd thanne wol I sle yow bothe."	Then truly with this sword will I slay you both."
Cecile answerde anon-right in this wise:	Cecile answered immediately in this manner:
"If that yow list, the angel shul ye see,	"If you wish, you shall see the angel,
So that ye trowe on Crist and yow baptize.	Provided that you believe in Christ and have yourself baptized.
Gooth forth to Via Apia," quod shee,	Go forth to the Appian Way," said she,
"That fro this toun ne stant but miles three,	"That from this town stands no more than three miles,
And to the povre folkes that ther dwelle,	And to the poor folks that dwell there,
Sey hem right thus, as that I shal yow telle.	Say to them exactly thus, which I shall tell you.
"Telle hem that I, Cecile, yow to hem sente	"Tell them that I, Cecile, sent you to them
To shewen yow the goode Urban the olde,	To show you the good Urban the old,
For secree nedes and for good entente.	For secret needs and for a good purpose.
And whan that ye Seint Urban han biholde,	And when you have beheld Saint Urban,
Telle hym the wordes whiche I to yow tolde;	Tell him the words which I told to you;
And whan that he hath purged yow fro synne,	And when he has cleansed you of sin (by baptism),
Thanne shul ye se that angel, er ye twynne."	Then you shall see that angel, ere you depart."
Valerian is to the place ygon,	Valerian has gone to the place,
And right as hym was taught by his lernynge,	And just as he was taught by his learning (from Cecilie),
He foond this hooly olde Urban anon	He immediately found this holy old Urban
Among the seintes buryeles lotynge.	In hiding among the saints' burial places.
And he anon withouten tariynge	And he immediately without delay
Dide his message; and whan that he it tolde,	Said his message; and when he told it,
Urban for joye his handes gan up holde.	Urban for joy did hold up his hands.
The teeris from his eyen leet he falle.	He let the tears fall from his eyes.
"Almyghty Lord, O Jhesu Crist," quod he,	"Almighty Lord, O Jesus Christ," said he,
"Sower of chaast conseil, hierde of us alle,	"Sower of chaste counsel, shepherd of us all,
The fruyt of thilke seed of chastitee	The fruit of that same seed of chastity
That thou hast sowe in Cecile, taak to thee!	That thou hast sown in Cecile, take to thee!
Lo, lyk a bisy bee, withouten gile,	Lo, like a busy bee, without guile,
Thee serveth ay thyn owene thral Cecile.	Always thine own servant Cecile serves Thee.
"For thilke spouse that she took but now	"For that same spouse that she took just now
Ful lyk a fiers leoun, she sendeth heere,	Very like a fierce lion, she sends here,
As meke as evere was any lomb, to yow!"	As meek as ever was any lamb, to you!"
And with that word anon ther gan appeere	And with that word anon there did appear
An oold man, clad in white clothes cleere,	An old man, clad in clear white clothes,
That hadde a book with lettre of gold in honde,	Who had in hand a book with lettering of gold ,
And gan bifore Valerian to stonde.	And did stand before Valerian.
Valerian as deed fil doun for drede	Valerian as if dead fell down for fear
Whan he hym saugh, and he up hente hym tho,	When he saw him, and the old man picked him up then,
And on his book right thus he gan to rede:	And from his book right thus he began to read:
"O Lord, o feith, o God, withouten mo,	"One Lord, one faith, one God, without more,
O Cristendom, and Fader of alle also,	One baptism, and Father of all also,
Aboven alle and over alle everywhere."	Above all and over all everywhere."
Thise wordes al with gold ywriten were.	These words were written all with gold.
Whan this was rad, thanne seyde this olde man,	When this was read, then said this old man,
"Leevestow this thyng or no? Sey ye or nay."	"Dost thou believe this thing or not? Say yes or no."
"I leeve al this thyng," quod Valerian,	"I believe all this thing," said Valerian,
"For sother thyng than this, I dar wel say,	"For truer thing than this, I dare well say,
Under the hevene no wight thynke may."	No person under the heaven can imagine."
Tho vanysshed this olde man, he nyste where,	Then vanished this old man, he knew not where,
And Pope Urban hym cristned right there.	And Pope Urban christened him right there.
Valerian gooth hoom and fynt Cecilie	Valerian goes home and finds Cecilie
Withinne his chambre with an angel stonde.	Within his room standing with an angel.
This angel hadde of roses and of lilie	This angel had of roses and of lily

And first to Cecile, as I understonde,	And first to Cecile, as I understand,
He yaf that oon, and after gan he take	He gave that one, and after he did give
That oother to Valerian, hir make.	That other to Valerian, her mate.
"With body clene and with unwemmed thoght	"With body clean and with unblemished thought
Kepeth ay wel thise corones," quod he;	Always guard well these crowns," said he;
"Fro paradys to yow have I hem broght,	"From paradise I have brought them to you,
Ne nevere mo ne shal they roten bee,	Nor never ever shall they be rotten,
Ne lese hir soote savour, trusteth me;	Nor lose their sweet fragrance, trust me;
Ne nevere wight shal seen hem with his ye,	Nor never a person shall see them with his eye,
But he be chaast and hate vileynye.	Unless he be chaste and hates villainy.
"And thow, Valerian, for thow so soone	"And thou, Valerian, because thou so soon
Assentedest to good conseil also,	Assented to good counsel also,
Sey what thee list, and thou shalt han thy boone."	Say what pleases thee, and thou shalt have thy request."
"I have a brother," quod Valerian tho,	"I have a brother," said Valerian then,
"That in this world I love no man so.	"And in this world I love no man so much.
I pray yow that my brother may han grace	I pray you that my brother may have grace
To knowe the trouthe, as I do in this place."	To know the truth, as I do in this place."
The angel seyde, "God liketh thy requeste,	The angel said, "God likes thy request,
And bothe with the palm of martirdom	And both (of you) with the palm of martyrdom
Ye shullen come unto his blisful feste."	You shall come unto his blissful feast."
And with that word Tiburce his brother coom.	And with that word Tiburce his brother came.
And whan that he the savour undernoom,	And when he perceived the fragrance,
Which that the roses and the lilies caste,	Which the roses and the lilies cast forth
Withinne his herte he gan to wondre faste,	Within his heart he began to wonder intently,
And seyde, "I wondre, this tyme of the yeer,	And said, "I wonder, this time of the year,
Whennes that soote savour cometh so	Whence that sweet fragrance comes so (much)
Of rose and lilies that I smelle heer.	Of rose and lilies that I smell here.
For though I hadde hem in myne handes two,	For even if I had them in my two hands,
The savour myghte in me no depper go.	The fragrance could go in me no deeper.
The sweete smel that in myn herte I fynde	The sweet smell that in my heart I find
Hath chaunged me al in another kynde."	Has changed me all into another nature."
Valerian seyde: "Two corones han we,	Valerian said: "Two crowns have we,
Snow white and rose reed, that shynen cleere,	Snow white and rose red, that shine clear,
Whiche that thyne eyen han no myght to see;	Which thine eyes have no power to see;
And as thou smellest hem thurgh my preyere,	And as thou smellest them because of my prayer,
So shaltow seen hem, leeve brother deere,	So shalt thou see them, beloved brother dear,
If it so be thou wolt, withouten slouthe,	If it so be thou will, without delaying,
Bileve aright and knowen verray trouthe."	Believe correctly and know real truth."
Tiburce answerde, "Seistow this to me	Tiburce answered, "Sayest thou this to me
In soothnesse, or in dreem I herkne this?"	In actuality, or do I hear this in dream?"
"In dremes," quod Valerian, "han we be	"In dreams," said Valerian, "have we been
