But now at erst in trouthe oure dwellyng is."	But now for the first time our dwelling is in truth."
"How woostow this?" quod Tiburce, "and in what wyse?"	"How knowest thou this?" said Tiburce, "and in what manner?"
Quod Valerian, "That shal I thee devyse.	Said Valerian, "That I shall tell thee.
"The aungel of God hath me the trouthe ytaught	"The angel of God has taught me the truth
Which thou shalt seen, if that thou wolt reneye	Which thou shalt see, if thou wilt renounce
The ydoles and be clene, and elles naught."	The idols and be chaste, and otherwise nothing (will you see.)"
And of the myracle of thise corones tweye	And of the miracle of these two crowns
Seint Ambrose in his preface list to seye;	Saint Ambrose in his preface is pleased to speak;
Solempnely this noble doctour deere	Solemnly this noble dear Doctor (of the Church)
Commendeth it, and seith in this manere:	Commends it, and says in this manner:
"The palm of martirdom for to receyve,	"In order to receive the palm of martyrdom,
Seinte Cecile, fulfild of Goddes yifte,	Saint Cecile, completely filled with God's gift,
The world and eek hire chambre gan she weyve;	The world and also her bed-chamber did she give up;
Witnesse Tyburces and [Valerians] shrifte,	Witness Tyburce's and Valerian's confession,
To whiche God of his bountee wolde shifte	To which God of his goodness would provide
Corones two of floures wel smellynge,	Two crowns of flowers well smelling,
And made his angel hem the corones brynge.	And made his angel bring them the crowns.
"The mayde hath broght thise men to blisse above;	"The maid has brought these men to bliss above;
The world hath wist what it is worth, certeyn,	The world has known what it is worth, certainly,
Devocioun of chastitee to love."	To love a devotion to chastity."
Tho shewed hym Cecile al open and pleyn	Then Cecile showed him all open and plain
That alle ydoles nys but a thyng in veyn,	That all idols are but meaningless things,
For they been dombe, and therto they been deve,	For they are dumb, and moreover they are deaf,
And charged hym his ydoles for to leve.	And (she) ordered him to leave his idols.
"Whoso that troweth nat this, a beest he is,"	"Whoever believes not this, he is a beast,"
Quod tho Tiburce, "if that I shal nat lye."	Tiburce then said, "if I shall not lie."
And she gan kisse his brest, that herde this,	And she who heard this did kiss his breast,
And was ful glad he koude trouthe espye.	And was very glad he could perceive truth.
"This day I take thee for myn allye,"	"This day I take thee for my kinsman,"
Seyde this blisful faire mayde deere,	Said this blissful fair maid dear,
And after that she seyde as ye may heere:	And after that she said as you may hear:
"Lo, right so as the love of Crist," quod she,	"Lo, exactly as the love of Christ," said she,
"Made me thy brotheres wyf, right in that wise	"Made me thy brother's wife, exactly in that manner
Anon for myn allye heer take I thee,	Right now here I take thee for my kinsman,
Syn that thou wolt thyne ydoles despise.	Since thou will despise thine idols.
Go with thy brother now, and thee baptise,	Go with thy brother now, and get thyself baptized,
And make thee clene, so that thou mowe biholde	And make thyself clean, so that thou can behold
The angels face of which thy brother tolde."	The angel's face of which thy brother told."
Tiburce answerde and seyde, "Brother deere,	Tiburce answered and said, "Brother dear,
First tel me whider I shal, and to what man?"	First tell me where I must go, and to what man?"
"To whom?" quod he, "com forth with right good cheere,	"To whom?" said he, "come forth with right good cheer,
I wol thee lede unto the Pope Urban."	I will lead thee unto the Pope Urban."
"Til Urban? Brother myn Valerian,"	"To Urban? My brother Valerian,"
Quod tho Tiburce, "woltow me thider lede?	Said then Tiburce, "wilt thou lead me there?
Me thynketh that it were a wonder dede.	It seems to me that it would be a wonderful deed.
"Ne menestow nat Urban," quod he tho,	"Thou meanest not Urban," said he then,
"That is so ofte dampned to be deed,	"That is so often condemned to be dead,
And woneth in halkes alwey to and fro,	And dwells in hiding places always (going) from one to another,
And dar nat ones putte forth his heed?	And dares not once put forth his head?
Men sholde hym brennen in a fyr so reed	Men should burn him in a fire so red
If he were founde, or that men myghte hym spye,	If he were found, or if men could catch sight of him,
And we also, to bere hym compaignye;	And we too (would burn), to bear him company;
"And whil we seken thilke divinitee	"And while we seek that same divinity
That is yhid in hevene pryvely,	That is hidden secretly in heaven,
Algate ybrend in this world shul we be!"	Nevertheless we shall be burned in this world!"
To whom Cecile answerde boldely,	To whom Cecile answered boldly,
"Men myghten dreden wel and skilfully	"Men might well and reasonably fear
This lyf to lese, myn owene deere brother,	To lose this life, my own dear brother,
If this were lyvynge oonly and noon oother.	If this were the only life and (there were) none other.
"But ther is bettre lif in oother place,	"But there is a better life in another place,
That nevere shal be lost, ne drede thee noght,	That never shall be lost, doubt thee not,
Which Goddes Sone us tolde thurgh his grace.	Which God's Son told us by means of his grace.
That Fadres Sone hath alle thyng ywroght,	That Father's Son has created all things,
And al that wroght is with a skilful thoght;	And all that is created (and endowed) with the power of reason;
The Goost, that fro the Fader gan procede,	The Holy Ghost, who from the Father did proceed,
Hath sowled hem, withouten any drede.	Has given them souls, without any doubt.
"By word and by myracle heigh Goddes Sone,	"By word and by miracle high God's Son,
Whan he was in this world, declared heere	When he was in this world, declared here
That ther was oother lyf ther men may wone."	That there was another life where men may dwell."
To whom answerde Tiburce, "O suster deere,	To whom answered Tiburce, "O sister dear,
Ne seydestow right now in this manere,	Said thou not just now in this manner,
Ther nys but o God, lord in soothfastnesse?	There is but one God, lord in truthfulness?
And now of three how maystow bere witnesse?"	And now of three how canst thou bear witness?"
"That shal I telle," quod she, "er I go.	"That shall I tell," said she, "ere I go.
Right as a man hath sapiences three --	Exactly as a man has three mental faculties --
Memorie, engyn, and intellect also --	Memory, imagination, and judgement also --
So in o beynge of divinitee,	So in one being of divinity,
Thre persones may ther right wel bee."	Three persons may right well be there."
Tho gan she hym ful bisily to preche	Then very zealously she did preach to him
Of Cristes come, and of his peynes teche,	Of Christ's coming, and teach (him) of His pains,
And manye pointes of his passioun;	And many particulars of His passion;
How Goddes Sone in this world was withholde	How God's Son was compelled to remain in this world
To doon mankynde pleyn remissioun,	To provide full forgiveness for mankind,
That was ybounde in synne and cares colde;	Which was bound in sin and painful cares;
Al this thyng she unto Tiburce tolde.	All this thing she told unto Tiburce.
And after this Tiburce in good entente	And after this Tiburce with a good will
With Valerian to Pope Urban he wente,	With Valerian he went to Pope Urban,
That thanked God, and with glad herte and light	Who thanked God, and with glad and happy heart
He cristned hym and made hym in that place	He christened him and made him in that place
Parfit in his lernynge, Goddes knyght.	Perfect in his learning, God's knight.
And after this Tiburce gat swich grace	And after this Tiburce got such grace
That every day he saugh in tyme and space	That every day in real time and space he saw
The aungel of God; and every maner boone	The angel of God; and every manner of gift
That he God axed, it was sped ful soone.	That he asked of God was provided immediately.
It were ful hard by ordre for to seyn	It would be very hard in proper sequence to say
How manye wondres Jhesus for hem wroghte;	How many wonders Jesus made for them;
But atte laste, to tellen short and pleyn,	But at the last, to tell short and plain,
The sergeantz of the toun of Rome hem soghte,	The officers of the law of the town of Rome sought them,
And hem biforn Almache, the prefect, broghte,	And brought them before Almache, the prefect,
Which hem apposed, and knew al hire entente,	Who questioned them, and knew all their thought,
And to the ymage of Juppiter hem sente,	And sent them to the image of Jupiter,
And seyde, "Whoso wol nat sacrifise,	And said, "Whoever will not sacrifice,
Swape of his heed; this my sentence heer."	Strike off his head; this is my sentence here."
Anon thise martirs that I yow devyse,	Immediately these martyrs of whom I tell you,
Oon Maximus, that was an officer	One Maximus, that was an officer
Of the prefectes, and his corniculer,	Of the prefect's, and his chief assistant,
Hem hente, and whan he forth the seintes ladde,	Seized them, and when he led forth the saints,
Hymself he weep for pitee that he hadde.	He himself wept for pity that he had.
Whan Maximus had herd the seintes loore,	When Maximus had heard the saints' teaching,
He gat hym of the tormentoures leve,	He got himself permission of the executioners,
And ladde hem to his hous withoute moore,	And led them to his house without more delay,
And with hir prechyng, er that it were eve,	And with their preaching, ere that it was evening,
They gonnen fro the tormentours to reve,	They did take away from the executioners,
And fro Maxime, and fro his folk echone,	And from Maxime, and from his folk each one of them,
The false feith, to trowe in God allone.	The false faith, (and brought them) to believe in God alone.
Cecile cam, whan it was woxen nyght,	Cecile came, when it was grown night,
With preestes that hem cristned alle yfeere;	With priests who christened them all together;
And afterward, whan day was woxen light,	And afterward, when day was grown light,
Cecile hem seyde with a ful stedefast cheere,	Cecile said to them with a full steadfast countenance,
"Now, Cristes owene knyghtes leeve and deere,	"Now, Christ's own knights beloved and dear,
Cast alle awey the werkes of derknesse,	Cast away all the works of darkness,
And armeth yow in armure of brightnesse.	And arm yourselves in armor of brightness.
"Ye han for sothe ydoon a greet bataille,	"You have truly done a great battle,
Youre cours is doon, youre feith han ye conserved.	Your race is done, your faith you have maintained.
Gooth to the corone of lif that may nat faille;	Go to the crown of life that can not fail;
The rightful Juge, which that ye han served,	The rightful Judge, whom you have served,
Shal yeve it yow, as ye han it deserved."	Shall give it to you, as you have deserved it."
And whan this thyng was seyd as I devyse,	And when this thing was said as I tell,
Men ledde hem forth to doon the sacrefise.	Men led them forth to do the sacrifice.
But whan they weren to the place broght	But when they were brought to the place
To tellen shortly the conclusioun,	To tell shortly the conclusion,
They nolde encense ne sacrifise right noght,	They would not incense nor sacrifice in any way,
But on hir knees they setten hem adoun	But on their knees they set themselves down
With humble herte and sad devocioun,	With humble heart and steadfast devotion,
And losten bothe hir hevedes in the place.	And lost both their heads in the place.
Hir soules wenten to the Kyng of grace.	Their souls went to the King of grace.
This Maximus, that saugh this thyng bityde,	This Maximus, who saw this thing happen,
With pitous teeris tolde it anonright,	With piteous tears told it right away,
That he hir soules saugh to hevene glyde	That he saw their souls glide to heaven
With aungels ful of cleernesse and of light,	With angels full of clearness and of light,
And with his word converted many a wight;	And with his word converted many a person;
For which Almachius dide hym so bete	For which Almachius had him so beaten
With whippe of leed til he his lif gan lete.	With whip tipped with lead that he left his life.
Cecile hym took and buryed hym anon	Cecile took him and buried him straightway
By Tiburce and Valerian softely	By Tiburce and Valerian tenderly
Withinne hire buriyng place, under the stoon;	Within their burying place, under the tombstone;
And after this, Almachius hastily	And after this, Almachius hastily
Bad his ministres fecchen openly	Ordered his ministers to fetch publicly
Cecile, so that she myghte in his presence	Cecile, so that she might in his presence
Doon sacrifice and Juppiter encense.	Do sacrifice and burn incense to Jupiter.
But they, converted at hir wise loore,	But they, converted by her wise teaching,
Wepten ful soore, and yaven ful credence	Wept very bitterly, and gave full credence
Unto hire word, and cryden moore and moore,	Unto her word, and cried more and more,
"Crist, Goddes Sone, withouten difference,	"Christ, God's Son, without difference [between Father and Son],
Is verray God -- this is al oure sentence --	Is true God -- this is the belief of us all --
That hath so good a servant hym to serve.	That has so good a servant to serve Him.
This with o voys we trowen, thogh we sterve!"	This unanimously we believe, even if we should die!"
Almachius, that herde of this doynge,	Almachius, that heard of this business,
Bad fecchen Cecile, that he myghte hire see,	Ordered (his men to) fetch Cecile, so that he might see her
And alderfirst, lo, this was his axynge.	And first of all, lo, this was his quesation.
"What maner womman artow?" tho quod he.	"What sort of woman art thou?" then said he.
"I am a gentil womman born," quod she.	"I am a gentle woman born," said she.
"I axe thee," quod he, "though it thee greeve,	"I ask thee," said he, "though it may grieve thee,
Of thy religioun and of thy bileeve."	About thy religion and about thy belief."
"Ye han bigonne youre questioun folily,"	"You have begun your question foolishly,"
Quod she, "that wolden two answeres conclude	Said she, "you who would include two answers
In o demande; ye axed lewedly."	In one question; you asked ignorantly."
Almache answerde unto that similitude,	Almache answered unto that refutation,
"Of whennes comth thyn answeryng so rude?"	"Of whence comes thine answering so rude?"
"Of whennes?" quod she, whan that she was freyned,	"Of whence?" said she, when she was asked,
"Of conscience and of good feith unfeyned."	"Of conscience and of sincere good faith."
Almachius seyde, "Ne takestow noon heede	Almachius said, "Takest thou no heed
Of my power?" And she answerde hym this:	Of my power?" And she answered him this:
"Youre myght," quod she, "ful litel is to dreede,	"Your might," said she, "is very little to fear,
For every mortal mannes power nys	For every mortal man's power is nothing
But lyk a bladdre ful of wynd, ywys.	But only like a bladder full of wind, indeed.
For with a nedles poynt, whan it is blowe,	For with a needle's point, when it is blown up,
May al the boost of it be leyd ful lowe."	Can all the arrogance of it be laid full low."
"Ful wrongfully bigonne thow," quod he,	"Full wrongfully thou began," said he,
"And yet in wrong is thy perseveraunce.	"And yet wrongful is thy perseverance.
Wostow nat how oure myghty princes free	Dost thou not know how our mighty noble princes
Han thus comanded and maad ordinaunce	Have thus commanded and made a law
That every Cristen wight shal han penaunce	That every Christian person shall be punished
But if that he his Cristendom withseye,	Unless he renounce his Christian faith,
And goon al quit, if he wole it reneye?"	And go all free, if he will deny it?"
"Yowre princes erren, as youre nobleye dooth,"	"Your princes err, as your nobles do,"
Quod tho Cecile, "and with a wood sentence	Said then Cecile, "and with a crazy verdict
Ye make us gilty, and it is nat sooth.	You make us guilty, and it is not true.
For ye, that knowen wel oure innocence,	For you, who know well our innocence,
For as muche as we doon a reverence	Forasmuch as we do reverence
To Crist, and for we bere a Cristen name,	To Christ, and because we bear a Christian name,
Ye putte on us a cryme and eek a blame.	You accuse us of a crime and also (put on us) the blame for it.
"But we that knowen thilke name so	"But we who know that same name
For vertuous, we may it nat withseye."	To be so virtuous, we can not deny it."
Almache answerde, "Chees oon of thise two:	Almache answered, "Chose one of these two:
Do sacrifice, or Cristendom reneye,	Do sacrifice, or renounce Christendom,
That thou mowe now escapen by that weye."	So that thou can now escape by that means."
At which the hooly blisful faire mayde	At which the holy blissful fair maid
Gan for to laughe, and to the juge sayde:	Began to laugh, and to the judge said:
"O juge, confus in thy nycetee,	"O judge, confused in thy folly,
Woltow that I reneye innocence,	Wilt thou that I renounce innocence,
To make me a wikked wight?" quod shee.	To make myself a wicked person?" said she.
"Lo, he dissymuleth heere in audience;	"Lo, he hides his true feelings here in open court;
He stareth, and woodeth in his advertence!"	He stares, and goes mad in his mind!"
To whom Almachius, "Unsely wrecche,	To whom Almachius, "Miserable wretch,
Ne woostow nat how fer my myght may strecche?	Knowest thou not how far my power can stretch?
"Han noght oure myghty princes to me yiven,	"Have not our mighty princes to me given,
Ye, bothe power and auctoritee	Yea, both power and authority
To maken folk to dyen or to lyven?	To make folk to die or to live?
Why spekestow so proudly thanne to me?"	Why speakest thou so proudly then to me?"
"I speke noght but stedfastly," quod she;	"I speak only faithfully," said she;
"Nat proudly, for I seye, as for my syde,	"Not proudly, for I say, as for my side,
We haten deedly thilke vice of pryde.	We hate that same deadly sin of pride.
"And if thou drede nat a sooth to heere,	"And if thou dread not to hear a truth,
Thanne wol I shewe al openly, by right,	Then will I show all openly, according to law,
That thou hast maad a ful gret lesyng heere.	That thou hast made a very great lie here.
Thou seyst thy princes han thee yeven myght	Thou sayest thy princes have given thee power
Bothe for to sleen and for to quyken a wight;	Both to slay and to give life to a person;
Thou, that ne mayst but oonly lyf bireve,	Thou, who can only take away life,
Thou hast noon oother power ne no leve.	Thou hast no other power nor any authority.
"But thou mayst seyn thy princes han thee maked	"But thou can say thy princes have made thee
Ministre of deeth; for if thou speke of mo,	Minister of death; for if thou speak of more,
Thou lyest, for thy power is ful naked."	Thou liest, for thy power is strictly limited.
"Do wey thy booldnesse," seyde Almachius tho,	"Do away thy boldness," said Almachius then,
"And sacrifice to oure goddes er thou go!	"And sacrifice to our gods ere thou go!
I recche nat what wrong that thou me profre,	I care not what wrong that thou may express to me,
For I kan suffre it as a philosophre;	For I can suffer it as a philosopher;
"But thilke wronges may I nat endure	"But those same wrongs I can not endure
That thou spekest of oure goddes heere," quod he.	Which thou spekest of our gods here," said he.
Cecile answerde, "O nyce creature!	Cecile answered, "O foolish creature!
Thou seydest no word syn thou spak to me	Thou saidest no word since thou spoke to me
That I ne knew therwith thy nycetee	That I did not know therewith thy foolishness
And that thou were in every maner wise	And that thou were in every sort of way
A lewed officer and a veyn justise.	An ignorant officer and a foolish judge.
"Ther lakketh no thyng to thyne outter yen	"There lacks nothing to thine outer eyes
That thou n' art blynd; for thyng that we seen alle	Except that thou art blind; for thing that we all see
That it is stoon -- that men may wel espyen --	That it is stone -- that men can well see --
That ilke stoon a god thow wolt it calle.	That same stone a god thou wilt call it.
I rede thee, lat thyn hand upon it falle	I advise thee, let thine hand upon it fall
And taste it wel, and stoon thou shalt it fynde,	And taste it well, and stone thou shalt find it,
Syn that thou seest nat with thyne eyen blynde.	Since thou seest not with thy blind eyes.
"It is a shame that the peple shal	"It is a shame that the people shall
So scorne thee and laughe at thy folye,	So scorn thee and laugh at thy folly,
For communly men woot it wel overal	For without exception men know it well everywhere
That myghty God is in his hevenes hye;	That mighty God is in his high heavens;
And thise ymages, wel thou mayst espye,	And these images, thou canst well see,
To thee ne to hemself mowen noght profite,	Can do no profit to thee nor to themselves,
For in effect they been nat worth a myte."	For in fact they are not worth a penny."
Thise wordes and swiche othere seyde she,	These words and others such said she,
And he weex wroth, and bad men sholde hir lede	And he grew angry, and ordered that men should lead her
Hom til hir hous, and "In hire hous," quod he,	Home to her house, and "In her house," said he,
"Brenne hire right in a bath of flambes rede."	"Burn her right in a bath of red flames."
And as he bad, right so was doon the dede;	And as he ordered, exactly so the deed was done;
For in a bath they gonne hire faste shetten,	For they did shut her fast in a cauldron,
And nyght and day greet fyr they under betten.	And night and day they fed great fire under it.
The longe nyght, and eek a day also,	The long night, and also a day as well,
For al the fyr and eek the bathes heete	Despite the fire and also the bath's heat
She sat al coold and feelede no wo.	She sat all cool and felt no pain.
It made hire nat a drope for to sweete.	It made her not a drop to sweat.
But in that bath hir lyf she moste lete,	But in that bath her life she must leave,
For he Almachius, with ful wikke entente,	For that Almachius, with completely wicked intent,
To sleen hire in the bath his sonde sente.	Sent his messenger to slay her in the bath.
Thre strokes in the nekke he smoot hire tho,	Three strokes in the neck he smote her then,
The tormentour, but for no maner chaunce	The executioner, but in no sort of way
He myghte noght smyte al hir nekke atwo;	He could not smite all her neck in two;
And for ther was that tyme an ordinaunce	And because there was that time an ordinance
That no man sholde doon man swich penaunce	That no man should do any one such pain
The ferthe strook to smyten, softe or soore,	The fourth stroke to smite, soft or sore,
This tormentour ne dorste do namoore,	This executioner dared not do any more,
But half deed, with hir nekke ycorven there,	But half dead, with her neck carved there,
He lefte hir lye, and on his wey he went.	He left her lie, and on his way he went.
The Cristen folk, which that aboute hire were,	The Christian folk, who were about her,
With sheetes han the blood ful faire yhent.	With sheets have very carefully taken up the blood.
Thre dayes lyved she in this torment,	Three days she lived in this torment,
And nevere cessed hem the feith to teche	And never ceased to teach them the faith
That she hadde fostred; hem she gan to preche,	That she had fostered; to them she did preach,
And hem she yaf hir moebles and hir thyng,	And she gave them her personal property and her things,
And to the Pope Urban bitook hem tho,	And to the Pope Urban (she) entrusted them then,
And seyde, "I axed this of hevene kyng,	And said, "I asked this of heaven's king,
To han respit thre dayes and namo	To have respite three days and no more
To recomende to yow, er that I go,	To commend to you, ere I go,
Thise soules, lo, and that I myghte do werche	These souls, lo, and that I might have made
Heere of myn hous perpetuelly a cherche."	Here of my house perpetually a church."
Seint Urban with his deknes prively	Saint Urban with his deacons secretly
The body fette and buryed it by nyghte	Fetched the body and buried it by night
Among his othere seintes honestly.	Among his other saints decently.
Hir hous the chirche of Seint Cecilie highte;	Her house is called the church of Saint Cecilie;
Seint Urban halwed it, as he wel myghte;	Saint Urban consecrated it, as he well could;
In which, into this day, in noble wyse,	In which, unto this day, in noble manner,
Men doon to Crist and to his seint servyse.	People do service to Christ and to his saint.
The Prologe of the Somonours Tale.	The Prologue of the Summoner's Tale
This Somonour in his styropes hye stood;	This Summoner in his stirrups stood high;
Upon this Frere his herte was so wood	Upon this Friar his heart was so enraged
That lyk an aspen leef he quook for ire.	That like an aspen leaf he quaked for ire.
"Lordynges," quod he, "but o thyng I desire;	"Gentlemen," said he, "but one thing I desire;
I yow biseke that, of youre curteisye,	I you beseech that, of your courtesy,
Syn ye han herd this false Frere lye,	Since you have heard this false Friar lie,
As suffreth me I may my tale telle.	Now grant me that me I may tell my tale.
This Frere bosteth that he knoweth helle,	This Friar boasts that he knows hell,
And God it woot, that it is litel wonder;	And God knows it, that it is little wonder;
Freres and feendes been but lyte asonder.	Friars and fiends are but little different.
For, pardee, ye han ofte tyme herd telle	For, by God, you have often times heard tell
How that a frere ravysshed was to helle	How a friar was carried off to hell
In spirit ones by a visioun;	In spirit once by a vision;
And as an angel ladde hym up and doun,	And as an angel led him up and down,
To shewen hym the peynes that ther were,	To show him the pains that were there,
In al the place saugh he nat a frere;	In all the place saw he not a friar;
Of oother folk he saugh ynowe in wo.	Of other folk he saw enough in woe.
Unto this angel spak the frere tho:	Unto this angel spoke the friar then:
`Now, sire,' quod he, `han freres swich a grace	`Now, sir,' said he, `have friars such a grace
That noon of hem shal come to this place?'	That none of them shall come to this place?'
`Yis' quod this angel, `many a millioun!'	`Yes' said this angel, `many a million!'
And unto Sathanas he ladde hym doun.	And unto Satan he led him down.
`And now hath Sathanas,' seith he, `a tayl	`And now has Satan,' says he, `a tail
Brodder than of a carryk is the sayl.	Broader than of a large galleon is the sail.
Hold up thy tayl, thou Sathanas!' quod he;	Hold up thy tail, thou Satan!' said he;
`Shewe forth thyn ers, and lat the frere se	`Show forth thy ass, and let the friar see
Where is the nest of freres in this place!'	Where the nest of friars is in this place!'
And er that half a furlong wey of space,	And before half a furlong way of time (a few minutes),
Right so as bees out swarmen from an hyve,	Just as bees swarm out from a hive,
Out of the develes ers ther gonne dryve	Out of the devil's ass there began to rush
Twenty thousand freres on a route,	Twenty thousand friars in a crowd,
And thurghout helle swarmed al aboute,	And throughout hell swarmed all about,
And comen agayn as faste as they may gon,	And came back again as fast as they can go,
And in his ers they crepten everychon.	And in his ass they crept every one.
He clapte his tayl agayn and lay ful stille.	He clapped his tail again and lay very still.
This frere, whan he looked hadde his fille	This friar, when he had looked his fill
Upon the tormentz of this sory place,	Upon the torments of this sorry place,
His spirit God restored, of his grace,	His spirit God restored, by his grace,
Unto his body agayn, and he awook.	Unto his body again, and he awoke.
But natheles, for fere yet he quook,	But nonetheless, for fear yet he quaked,
So was the develes ers ay in his mynde,	So was the devil's ass always in his mind,
That is his heritage of verray kynde.	That is his true natural heritage.
God save yow alle, save this cursed Frere!	God save you all, except this cursed Friar!
My prologe wol I ende in this manere."	My prologue will I end in this manner."
Heere bigynneth the Somonour his Tale.	Here begins the Summoner's Tale.
Lordynges, ther is in Yorkshire, as I gesse,	Gentlemen, there is in Yorkshire, as I believe,
A mersshy contree called Holdernesse,	A marshy country called Holdernesse,
In which ther wente a lymytour aboute	In which there went a licensed beggar about
To preche, and eek to begge, it is no doute.	To preach, and also to beg, it is no doubt.
And so bifel that on a day this frere	And so befell that on a day this friar
Hadde preched at a chirche in his manere,	Had preached at a church in his manner,
And specially, aboven every thyng,	And specially, above every thing,
Excited he the peple in his prechyng	Excited he the people in his preaching
To trentals, and to yeve, for Goddes sake,	To masses for dead souls, and to give, for God's sake,
Wherwith men myghte hooly houses make,	The wherewithal that men might holy houses make,
Ther as divine servyce is honoured,	Where divine service is honored,
Nat ther as it is wasted and devoured,	Not where it is wasted and devoured,
Ne ther it nedeth nat for to be yive,	Nor where it needs not to be given,
As to possessioners, that mowen lyve,	As to beneficed clergymen, that may live,
Thanked be God, in wele and habundaunce.	Thanked be God, in prosperity and abundance.
"Trentals," seyde he, "deliveren fro penaunce	"Masses for souls," said he, "deliver from penance
Hir freendes soules, as wel olde as yonge --	Their friends' souls, as well old as young --
Ye, whan that they been hastily ysonge,	Yes, when they are hastily sung,
Nat for to holde a preest joly and gay --	Not to keep a priest jolly and gay --
He syngeth nat but o masse in a day.	He sings not but one masse in a day.
Delivereth out," quod he, "anon the soules!	Deliver out," said he, "immediately the souls!
Ful hard it is with flesshhook or with oules	Very hard it is with flesh hook or with awls
To been yclawed, or to brenne or bake.	To be clawed, or to burn or bake.
Now spede yow hastily, for Cristes sake!"	Now speed you hastily, for Christ's sake!"
And whan this frere had seyd al his entente,	And when this friar had said all he intended,
With qui cum patre forth his wey he wente.	With the prayer "who with the father" forth he went his way.
Whan folk in chirche had yeve him what hem leste,	When folk in church had given him what they wished,
He wente his wey; no lenger wolde he reste.	He went his way; no longer would he stay.
With scrippe and tipped staf, ytukked hye,	With satchel and metal-tipped staff, his robe tucked up high,
In every hous he gan to poure and prye,	In every house he began to peer and pry,
And beggeth mele and chese, or elles corn.	And begs meal and cheese, or else grain.
His felawe hadde a staf tipped with horn,	His fellow had a staff tipped with horn,
A peyre of tables al of yvory,	A pair of tablets all of ivory,
And a poyntel polysshed fetisly,	And a writing instrument polished carefully,
And wroot the names alwey, as he stood,	And wrote the names always, as he stood,
Of alle folk that yaf hym any good,	Of all folk that gave him any good thing,
Ascaunces that he wolde for hem preye.	As if he would for them pray.
"Yif us a busshel whete, malt, or reye,	"Give us a bushel of wheat, malt, or rye,
A Goddes kechyl, or a trype of chese,	A little cake, or a bit of cheese,
Or elles what yow lyst, we may nat cheese;	Or else what you like, we may not choose;
A Goddes halfpeny, or a masse peny,	A God's halfpenny, or a mass penny,
Or yif us of youre brawn, if ye have eny;	Or give us some of your meat, if you have any;
A dagon of youre blanket, leeve dame,	A piece of your woolen cloth, dear lady,
Oure suster deere -- lo! Heere I write youre name --	Our sister dear -- lo! Here I write your name --
Bacon or beef, or swich thyng as ye fynde."	Bacon or beef, or such thing as you find."
A sturdy harlot wente ay hem bihynde,	A sturdy rascal went always behind them,
That was hir hostes man, and bar a sak,	Who was their host's man, and bore a sack,
And what men yaf hem, leyde it on his bak.	And what men gave them, laid it on his back.
And whan that he was out at dore, anon	And when he was out at door, immediately
He planed awey the names everichon	He planed away the names every one
That he biforn had writen in his tables;	That he before had written in his tables;
He served hem with nyfles and with fables.	He served them with tricks and with falsehoods.
"Nay, ther thou lixt, thou Somonour!" quod the Frere.	"Nay, there thou lie, thou Summoner!" said the Friar.
"Pees," quod oure Hoost, "for Cristes mooder deere!	"Quiet," said our Host, "for Christ's mother dear!
Tel forth thy tale, and spare it nat at al."	Tell forth thy tale, and spare it not at al."
"So thryve I," quod this Somonour, "so I shal!"	"As I may thrive," said this Summoner, "so I shall!"
So longe he wente, hous by hous, til he	So long he went, house by house, until he
Cam til an hous ther he was wont to be	Came to a house where he was accustomed to be
Refresshed moore than in an hundred placis.	Hospitably received more than in a hundred places.
Syk lay the goode man whos that the place is;	Sick lay the good man whose the place is;
Bedrede upon a couche lowe he lay.	Bedridden upon a couch low he lay.
"Deus hic!" quod he, "O Thomas, freend, good day!"	"God be here!" said he, "Oh Thomas, friend, good day!"
Seyde this frere, curteisly and softe.	Said this friar, courteously and soft.
"Thomas," quod he, "God yelde yow! Ful ofte	"Thomas," said he, "God reward you! Very often
Have I upon this bench faren ful weel;	Have I upon this bench fared full well;
Heere have I eten many a myrie meel."	Here have I eaten many a merry meal."
And fro the bench he droof awey the cat,	And from the bench he drove away the cat,
And leyde adoun his potente and his hat,	And laid down his walking stick and his hat,
And eek his scrippe, and sette hym softe adoun.	And also his satchel, and set him softly down.
His felawe was go walked into toun	His fellow had gone walking into town
Forth with his knave, into that hostelrye	Forth with his knave, into that hostelry
Where as he shoop hym thilke nyght to lye.	Where he intended that night to lie.
"O deere maister," quod this sike man,	"Oh dear master," said this sick man,
"How han ye fare sith that March bigan?	"How have you fared since March began?
I saugh yow noght this fourtenyght or moore."	I saw you not this fortnight or more."
"God woot," quod he, "laboured I have ful soore,	"God knows," said he, "labored I have very hard,
And specially for thy savacion	And especially for thy salvation
Have I seyd many a precious orison,	Have I said many a precious prayer,
And for oure othere freendes, God hem blesse!	And for our other friends, God them bless!
I have to day been at youre chirche at messe,	I have today been at your church at mass,
And seyd a sermon after my symple wit --	And said a sermon insofar as my simple wit allowed --
Nat al after the text of hooly writ,	Not entirely according to the text of holy writ,
For it is hard to yow, as I suppose,	For it is hard for you, as I suppose,
And therfore wol I teche yow al the glose.	And therefore will I teach you all the interpretation.
Glosynge is a glorious thyng, certeyn,	Interpreting scripture is a glorious thing, certainly,
For lettre sleeth, so as we clerkes seyn --	For letter slays, so we clerks say --
There have I taught hem to be charitable,	There have I taught them to be charitable,
And spende hir good ther it is resonable;	And spend their goods where it is reasonable;
And there I saugh oure dame -- A! Where is she?"	And there I saw our lady -- Ah! Where is she?"
"Yond in the yerd I trowe that she be,"	"Yonder in the yard I believe that she be,"
Seyde this man, "and she wol come anon."	Said this man, "and she will come anon."
"Ey, maister, welcome be ye, by Seint John!"	"Ey, master, welcome are you, by Saint John!"
Seyde this wyf, "How fare ye, hertely?"	Said this wife, "How fare you, cordially (I ask)?"
The frere ariseth up ful curteisly,	The friar arises up full courteously,
And hire embraceth in his armes narwe,	And her embraces in his arms tightly,
And kiste hire sweete, and chirketh as a sparwe	And kissed her sweetly, and chirps like a sparrow
With his lyppes: "Dame," quod he, "right weel,	With his lips: "Lady," said he, "right well,
As he that is youre servant every deel,	As he who is your servant every bit,
Thanked be God, that yow yaf soule and lyf!	Thanked be God, who gave you soul and life!
Yet saugh I nat this day so fair a wyf	Yet saw I not this day so fair a wife
In al the chirche, God so save me!"	In all the church, as God may save me!"
"Ye, God amende defautes, sire," quod she.	"Yes, God correct my faults, sir," said she.
"Algates, welcome be ye, by my fey!"	"At any rate, welcome are you, by my faith!"
"Graunt mercy, dame, this have I founde alwey.	"Great thanks, lady, this have I found always.
But of youre grete goodnesse, by youre leve,	But of your great goodness, by your leave,
I wolde prey yow that ye nat yow greve,	I would pray you that you be not annoyed,
I wole with Thomas speke a litel throwe.	I will with Thomas speak a little while.
Thise curatz been ful necligent and slowe	These curates are very negligent and slow
To grope tendrely a conscience	To examine gently a conscience
In shrift; in prechyng is my diligence,	In confession; in preaching is my diligence,
And studie in Petres wordes and in Poules.	And study in Peter's words and in Paul's.
I walke and fisshe Cristen mennes soules	I walk and fish Christian men's souls
To yelden Jhesu Crist his propre rente;	To pay Jesus Christ his proper income;
To sprede his word is set al myn entente."	To spread his word is set all my intention."
"Now, by youre leve, o deere sire," quod she,	"Now, by your leave, oh dear sir," said she,
"Chideth him weel, for seinte Trinitee!	"Chide him well, for the Holy Trinity!
He is as angry as a pissemyre,	He is as angry as a pismire,
Though that he have al that he kan desire;	Though he have all that he can desire;
Though I hym wrye a-nyght and make hym warm,	Though I cover him at night and make him warm,
And over hym leye my leg outher myn arm,	And over him lay my leg or my arm,
He groneth lyk oure boor, lith in oure sty.	He groans like our boor, that lies in our sty.
Oother desport right noon of hym have I;	Other pleasure right none of him have I;
I may nat plese hym in no maner cas."	I can not please him in any sort of way."
"O Thomas, je vous dy, Thomas! Thomas!	"Oh Thomas, I tell you, Thomas! Thomas!
This maketh the feend; this moste ben amended.	This makes the fiend; this must be amended.
Ire is a thyng that hye God defended,	Ire is a thing that high God forbad,
And therof wol I speke a word or two."	And thereof will I speak a word or two."
"Now, maister," quod the wyf, "er that I go,	"Now, master," said the wife, "before I go,
What wol ye dyne? I wol go theraboute."	What will you dine? I will go work on that."
"Now, dame," quod he, "now je vous dy sanz doute,	"Now, lady," said he, "now I tell you without doubt
Have I nat of a capon but the lyvere,	Have I of a capon only the liver,
And of youre softe breed nat but a shyvere,	And of your soft breed nothing but a sliver,
And after that a rosted pigges heed --	And after that a roasted pig's head --
But that I nolde no beest for me were deed --	But that I would that no beast for me were dead --
Thanne hadde I with yow hoomly suffisaunce.	Then had I with you enough plain food.
I am a man of litel sustenaunce;	I am a man who needs little sustenance;
My spirit hath his fostryng in the Bible.	My spirit has its nourishment in the Bible.
The body is ay so redy and penyble	The body is always so ready and accustomed
To wake, that my stomak is destroyed.	To staying awake (to pray), that my stomach is destroyed.
I prey yow, dame, ye be nat anoyed,	I pray you, lady, that you be not annoyed,
Though I so freendly yow my conseil shewe.	Though I so friendly show you my private affairs.
By God! I wolde nat telle it but a fewe."	By God! I would not tell it but to a few."
"Now, sire," quod she, "but o word er I go.	"Now, sir," said she, "but one word before I go.
My child is deed withinne thise wykes two,	My child is dead within these weeks two,
Soone after that ye wente out of this toun."	Soon after you went out of this town."
"His deeth saugh I by revelacioun,"	"His death saw I by revelation,"
Seide this frere, "at hoom in oure dortour.	Said this friar, "at home in our dormitory.
I dar wel seyn that, er that half an hour	I dare well say that, before half an hour
After his deeth, I saugh hym born to blisse	After his death, I saw him carried up to bliss
In myn avision, so God me wisse!	In my vision, as God may guide me!
So dide oure sexteyn and oure fermerer,	So did our sacristan and the head of our infirmary,
That han been trewe freres fifty yeer;	That have been true friars fifty years;
They may now -- God be thanked of his loone! --	They may now -- God be thanked of his grace! --
Maken hir jubilee and walke allone.	Make their fiftieth anniversary and walk alone.
And up I roos, and al oure covent eke,	And up I rose, and all our convent as well,
With many a teere trillyng on my cheke,	With many a tear tricking on my cheek,
Withouten noyse or claterynge of belles;	Without noise or clattering of bells;
Te Deum was oure song, and nothyng elles,	Te Deum was our song, and nothing else,
Save that to Crist I seyde an orison,	Except that to Christ I said a prayer,
Thankynge hym of his revelacion.	Thanking him for his revelation.
For, sire and dame, trusteth me right weel,	For, sir and lady, trust me right well,
Oure orisons been moore effectueel,	Our prayers are more effectual,
And moore we seen of Cristes secree thynges,	And more we see of Christ's secret things,
Than burel folk, although they weren kynges.	Than secular folk, although they were kings.
We lyve in poverte and in abstinence,	We live in poverty and in abstinence,
And burell folk in richesse and despence	And secular folk in riches and expenditures
Of mete and drynke, and in hir foul delit.	Of food and drink, and in their foul delight.
We han this worldes lust al in despit.	We hold this world's lust all in scorn.
Lazar and Dives lyveden diversly,	Lazar and Dives lived diversely,
And divers gerdon hadden they therby.	And diverse rewards had they thereby.
Whoso wol preye, he moot faste and be clene,	Whoever will pray, he must fast and be pure,
And fatte his soule, and make his body lene.	And fatten his soul, and make his body lean.
We fare as seith th' apostle; clooth and foode	We fare as says the apostle; cloth and food
Suffisen us, though they be nat ful goode.	Suffice us, though they are not full good.
The clennesse and the fastynge of us freres	The purity and the fasting of us friars
Maketh that Crist accepteth oure preyeres.	Makes that Christ accepts our prayers.
"Lo, Moyses fourty dayes and fourty nyght	"Lo, Moses forty days and forty nights
Fasted, er that the heighe God of myght	Fasted, before the high God of might
Spak with hym in the mountayne of Synay.	Spoke with him in the mountain of Sinai.
With empty wombe, fastynge many a day,	With empty belly, fasting many a day,
Receyved he the lawe that was writen	Received he the law that was written
With Goddes fynger; and Elye, wel ye witen,	With God's finger; and Elijah, you know well,
In mount Oreb, er he hadde any speche	In mount Horeb, before he had any speech
With hye God, that is oure lyves leche,	With high God, who is our life's physician,
He fasted longe and was in contemplaunce.	He fasted long and was in meditation.
"Aaron, that hadde the temple in governaunce,	"Aaron, who had the temple in governance,
And eek the othere preestes everichon,	And also the other priests every one,
Into the temple whan they sholde gon	Into the temple when they should go
To preye for the peple and do servyse,	To pray for the people and do service,
They nolden drynken in no maner wyse	They would not drink in any sort of way
No drynke which that myghte hem dronke make,	Any drink which might make them drunk,
But there in abstinence preye and wake,	But there in abstinence pray and keep vigil,
Lest that they deyden. Taak heede what I seye!	Lest they died. Take heed what I say!
But they be sobre that for the peple preye,	Unless they are sober who for the people pray,
War that -- I seye namoore, for it suffiseth.	Beware that -- I say no more, for it suffices.
"Oure Lord Jhesu, as hooly writ devyseth,	"Our Lord Jesus, as holy writ devises,
Yaf us ensample of fastynge and preyeres.	Gave us an example of fasting and prayers.
Therfore we mendynantz, we sely freres,	Therefore we mendicants, we innocent friars,
Been wedded to poverte and continence,	Are wedded to poverty and chastity,
To charite, humblesse, and abstinence,	To charity, humility, and abstinence,
To persecucioun for rightwisnesse,	To persecution for righteousness,
To wepynge, misericorde, and clennesse.	To weeping, charity, and purity.
And therfore may ye se that oure preyeres --	And therefore may you see that our prayers --
I speke of us, we mendynantz, we freres --	I speak of us, we mendicants, we friars --
Been to the hye God moore acceptable	Are to the high God more acceptable
Than youres, with youre feestes at the table.	Than yours, with your feasts at the table.
Fro Paradys first, if I shal nat lye,	From Paradise first, if I shall not lie,
Was man out chaced for his glotonye;	Was man chased out for his gluttony;
And chaast was man in Paradys, certeyn.	And chaste was man in Paradise, certainly.
"But herkne now, Thomas, what I shal seyn.	"But hearken now, Thomas, what I shall say.
I ne have no text of it, as I suppose,	I have no text for it, as I suppose,
But I shal fynde it in a maner glose,	But I shall find it in some sort of gloss (interpretation),
That specially oure sweete Lord Jhesus	That especially our sweet Lord Jesus
Spak this by freres, whan he seyde thus:	Spoke this about friars, when he said thus:
`Blessed be they that povere in spirit been.'	`Blessed are they who are poor in spirit.'
And so forth al the gospel may ye seen,	And so forth all the gospel may you see,
Wher it be likker oure professioun,	Whether it is more like our profession,
Or hirs that swymmen in possessioun.	Or theirs who swim in possessions.
Fy on hire pompe and on hire glotonye!	Fie on their pomp and on their gluttony!
And for hir lewednesse I hem diffye.	And for their ignorance I scorn them.
"Me thynketh they been lyk Jovinyan,	"I think they are like Jovinian,
Fat as a whale, and walkynge as a swan,	Fat as a whale, and waddling like a swan,
Al vinolent as botel in the spence.	As full of wine as a bottle in the pantry.
Hir preyere is of ful greet reverence,	Their prayer is of full great reverence,
Whan they for soules seye the psalm of Davit:	When they for souls say the psalm of David:
Lo, `buf!' they seye, `cor meum eructavit!'	Lo, `buf!' they say (belch), `my heart has uttered' (a good word)!
Who folweth Cristes gospel and his foore,	Who follows Christ's gospel and his path,
But we that humble been, and chaast, and poore,	But we who are humble, and chaste, and poor,
Werkeris of Goddes word, nat auditours?	Workers of God's word, not mere listeners?
Therfore, right as an hauk up at a sours	Therefore, just as a hawk upon an upward flight
Up springeth into th' eir, right so prayeres	Up springs into the' air, right so prayers
Of charitable and chaste bisy freres	Of charitable and chaste busy friars
Maken hir sours to Goddes eres two.	Make their upward flight to God's two ears.
Thomas, Thomas! So moote I ryde or go,	Thomas, Thomas! As I may ride or walk,
And by that lord that clepid is Seint Yve,	And by that lord who is called Saint Yve,
Nere thou oure brother, sholdestou nat thryve.	Were thou not our brother, thou shouldest not thrive.
In our chapitre praye we day and nyght	In our assembly we pray day and night
To Crist, that he thee sende heele and myght	To Christ, that he send thee health and strength
Thy body for to weelden hastily."	Thy body to move with ease hastily."
"God woot," quod he, "no thyng therof feele I!	"God knows," said he, "no thing thereof feel I!
As help me Crist, as I in fewe yeres,	So help me Christ, I in few years,
Have spent upon diverse manere freres	Have spent upon different sorts of friars
Ful many a pound; yet fare I never the bet.	Very many a pound; yet fare I never the better.
Certeyn, my good have I almoost biset.	Certainly, I have almost spent all my goods.
Farwel, my gold, for it is al ago!"	Farewell, my gold, for it is all gone!"
The frere answerde, "O Thomas, dostow so?	The friar answered, "Oh Thomas, dost thou so?
What nedeth yow diverse freres seche?	Why do you need to seek various friars?
What nedeth hym that hath a parfit leche	Why does one who has a perfect physician need
To sechen othere leches in the toun?	To seek other physicians in the town?
Youre inconstance is youre confusioun.	Your inconstancy is your ruin.
Holde ye thanne me, or elles oure covent,	Consider you then me, or else our convent,
To praye for yow been insufficient?	To be insufficient to pray for you?
Thomas, that jape nys nat worth a myte.	Thomas, that trick is not worth a half a farthing.
Youre maladye is for we han to lyte.	Your malady is because we have too little.
A, yif that covent half a quarter otes!	Ah, give that convent half a quarter (four bushels) oats!
A, yif that covent foure and twenty grotes!	A, give that convent four and twenty groats (four pences)!
A, yif that frere a peny, and lat hym go!	A, give that friar a penny, and let him go!
Nay, nay, Thomas, it may no thyng be so!	Nay, nay, Thomas, it may in no way be so!
What is a ferthyng worth parted in twelve?	What is a farthing worth divided into twelve?
Lo, ech thyng that is oned in himselve	Lo, each thing that is united in itself
Is moore strong than whan it is toscatered.	Is more strong than when it is all scattered.
Thomas, of me thou shalt nat been yflatered;	Thomas, by me thou shalt not be flattered;
Thou woldest han oure labour al for noght.	Thou wouldest have our labor all for nothing.
The hye God, that al this world hath wroght,	The high God, who all this world has wrought,
Seith that the werkman worthy is his hyre.	Says that the workman is worthy of his hire.
Thomas, noght of youre tresor I desire	Thomas, I do not desire any of your treasure
As for myself, but that al oure covent	For myself, but because all our convent
To preye for yow is ay so diligent,	To pray for you is always so diligent,
And for to buylden Cristes owene chirche.	And to build Christ's own church.
Thomas, if ye wol lernen for to wirche,	Thomas, if you want to learn what to do,
Of buyldynge up of chirches may ye fynde	Concerning building up of churches you can find
If it be good in Thomas lyf of Inde.	If it be good in the life of Thomas of India.
Ye lye heere ful of anger and of ire,	You lie here full of anger and of ire,
With which the devel set youre herte afyre,	With which the devil set your heart afire,
And chiden heere the sely innocent,	And chide here the poor innocent,
Youre wyf, that is so meke and pacient.	Your wife, who is so meek and patient.
And therfore, Thomas, trowe me if thee leste,	And therefore, Thomas, believe me if thou wish,
Ne stryve nat with thy wyf, as for thy beste;	Strive not with thy wife, for thine own good;
And ber this word awey now, by thy feith;	And bear this word away now, by thy faith;
Touchynge swich thyng, lo, what the wise seith:	Concerning such thing, lo, what the wise man says:
`Withinne thyn hous ne be thou no leon;	`Within thy house be thou no lion;
To thy subgitz do noon oppression,	To thy subjects do no oppression,
Ne make thyne aqueyntances nat to flee.'	Nor make thy acquaintances to flee.'
And, Thomas, yet eft-soones I charge thee,	And, Thomas, yet again I command thee,
Be war from Ire that in thy bosom slepeth;	Beware of Ire that in thy bosom sleeps;
War fro the serpent that so slily crepeth	Beware of the serpent that so slyly creeps
Under the gras and styngeth subtilly.	Under the grass and stings subtly.
Be war, my sone, and herkne paciently	Beware, my son, and hearken patiently
That twenty thousand men han lost hir lyves	That twenty thousand men have lost their lives
For stryvyng with hir lemmans and hir wyves.	For striving with their sweethearts and their wives.
Now sith ye han so hooly meke a wyf,	Now since you have so holy meek a wife,
What nedeth yow, Thomas, to maken stryf?	Why do you need, Thomas, to make strife?
Ther nys, ywys, no serpent so cruel,	There is, indeed, no serpent so cruel,
Whan man tret on his tayl, ne half so fel,	When man treads on his tail, nor half so fierce,
As womman is, whan she hath caught an ire;	As woman is, when she has become angry;
Vengeance is thanne al that they desire.	Vengeance is then all that they desire.
Ire is a synne, oon of the grete of sevene,	Ire is a sin, one of the greatest of seven,
Abhomynable unto the God of hevene;	Abominable unto the God of heaven;
And to hymself it is destruccion.	And to himself it is destruction.
This every lewed viker or person	This every ignorant vicar or parson
Kan seye, how ire engendreth homycide.	Can say, how ire engenders homicide.
Ire is, in sooth, executour of pryde.	Ire is, in truth, executor of pride.
I koude of ire seye so muche sorwe,	I could of ire say so much sorrow,
My tale sholde laste til to-morwe.	My tale should last until to-morrow.
And therfore preye I God bothe day and nyght	And therefore pray I God both day and night
An irous man, God sende hym litel myght!	An angry man, God send him little power!
It is greet harm and certes greet pitee	It is great harm and certainly great pity
To sette an irous man in heigh degree.	To set an angry man in high position.
"Whilom ther was an irous potestat,	"Once there was an angry potentate,
As seith Senek, that, durynge his estaat,	As says Seneca, who, during his reign,
Upon a day out ryden knyghtes two,	Upon a day out rode two knights,
And as Fortune wolde that it were so,	And as Fortune would that it were so,
That oon of hem cam hoom, that oother noght.	That one of them came home, that other did not.
Anon the knyght bifore the juge is broght,	At once the knight is brought before the judge,
That seyde thus, `Thou hast thy felawe slayn,	Who said thus, `Thou hast thy fellow slain,
For which I deme thee to the deeth, certayn.'	For which I condemn thee to the death, certainly.'
And to another knyght comanded he,	And to another knight commanded he,
`Go lede hym to the deeth, I charge thee.'	`Go lead him to the death, I charge thee.'
And happed, as they wente by the weye	And it happened, as they went by the way
Toward the place ther he sholde deye,	Toward the place where he should die,
The knyght cam which men wenden had be deed.	The knight came who men believed had been dead.
Thanne thoughte they it were the beste reed	Then thought they it would be the best plan
To lede hem bothe to the juge agayn.	To lead them both to the judge again.
They seiden, `Lord, the knyght ne hath nat slayn	They said, `Lord, the knight has not slain
His felawe; heere he standeth hool alyve.'	His fellow; here he stands whole and alive.'
`Ye shul be deed,' quod he, `so moot I thryve!	`You shall be dead,' said he, `as I may thrive!
That is to seyn, bothe oon, and two, and thre!'	That is to say, both one, and two, and three!'
And to the firste knyght right thus spak he,	And to the first knight right thus spoke he,
`I dampned thee; thou most algate be deed.	`I condemned thee; thou must therefore be dead.
And thou also most nedes lese thyn heed,	And thou also must of necessity lose thy head,
For thou art cause why thy felawe deyth.'	For thou art the cause why thy fellow dies.'
And to the thridde knyght right thus he seith,	And to the third knight right thus he says,
`Thou hast nat doon that I comanded thee.'	`Thou hast not done what I commanded thee.'
And thus he dide doon sleen hem alle thre.	And thus he caused them all three to be slain.
"Irous Cambises was eek dronkelewe,	"Angry Cambises was also a drunkard,
And ay delited hym to been a shrewe.	And it always delighted him to be a scoundrel.
And so bifel, a lord of his meynee	And as it happened, a lord of his household
That loved vertuous moralitee	Who loved virtuous morality
Seyde on a day bitwix hem two right thus:	Said on a day betwixt them two right thus:
"`A lord is lost, if he be vicius;	"`A lord is lost, if he be vicious;
And dronkenesse is eek a foul record	And drunkenness is also a foul reputation
Of any man, and namely in a lord.	Of any man, and especially in a lord.
Ther is ful many an eye and many an ere	There is full many an eye and many an ear
Awaityng on a lord, and he noot where.	Watching a lord, and he knows not where.
For Goddes love, drynk moore attemprely!	For God's love, drink more temperately!
Wyn maketh man to lesen wrecchedly	Wine makes man to lose wretchedly
His mynde and eek his lymes everichon.'	His mind and also his limbs every one.'
"`The revers shaltou se,' quod he, `anon,	"`The reverse shalt thou see,' said he, `right now,
And preve it by thyn owene experience,	And prove it by thy own experience,
That wyn ne dooth to folk no swich offence.	That wine does to folk no such offence.
Ther is no wyn bireveth me my myght	There is no wine that deprives me of my power
Of hand ne foot, ne of myne eyen sight.'	Of hand nor foot, nor of my eyesight.'
And for despit he drank ful muchel moore,	And for spite he drank very much more,
An hondred part, than he hadde don bifoore;	By a hundred times, than he had done before;
And right anon this irous, cursed wrecche	And right away this angry, cursed wretch
Leet this knyghtes sone bifore hym fecche,	Had this knight's son fetched before him,
Comandynge hym he sholde bifore hym stonde.	Commanding him he should before him stand.
And sodeynly he took his bowe in honde,	And suddenly he took his bow in hand,
And up the streng he pulled to his ere,	And up the string he pulled to his ear,
And with an arwe he slow the child right there.	And with an arrow he slew the child right there.
`Now wheither have I a siker hand or noon?'	`Now tell me whether I have a sure hand or not?'
Quod he; `Is al my myght and mynde agon?	Said he; `Is all my power and mind gone?
Hath wyn bireved me myn eyen sight?'	Has wine bereft me of my eyesight?'
What sholde I telle th' answere of the knyght?	Why should I tell the answer of the knight?
His sone was slayn; ther is namoore to seye.	His son was slain; there is no more to say.
Beth war, therfore, with lordes how ye pleye.	Beware, therefore, how you act with lords.
Syngeth Placebo and `I shal, if I kan,'	Sing 'I shall please' and `I shall, if I can,'
But if it be unto a povre man.	Unless it be unto a poor man.
To a povre man men sholde his vices telle,	To a poor man one should tell his vices,
But nat to a lord, thogh he sholde go to helle.	But not to a lord, though he should go to hell.
"Lo irous Cirus, thilke Percien,	"Lo angry Cyrus, that Persian,
How he destroyed the ryver of Gysen,	How he destroyed the river of Gysen,
For that an hors of his was dreynt therinne,	Because a horse of his was drowned therein,
Whan that he wente Babiloigne to wynne.	When he went to conquer Babylon.
He made that the ryver was so smal	He made it that the river was so small
That wommen myghte wade it over al.	That women could wade it everywhere.
Lo, what seyde he that so wel teche kan?	Lo, what said he who so well can teach?
`Ne be no felawe to an irous man,	`Be no fellow to an angry man,
Ne with no wood man walke by the weye,	Nor with no enraged man walk by the way,
Lest thee repente;' I wol no ferther seye.	Lest thee repent;' I will no further say.
"Now, Thomas, leeve brother, lef thyn ire;	"Now, Thomas, dear brother, leave thine ire;
Thou shalt me fynde as just as is a squyre.	Thou shalt me find as true as is a carpenter's square.
Hoold nat the develes knyf ay at thyn herte --	Hold not the devil's knife always at thy heart --
Thyn angre dooth thee al to soore smerte --	Thine anger causes thee all too sorely to suffer --
But shewe to me al thy confessioun."	But show to me all thy confession."
"Nay," quod the sike man, "by Seint Symoun!	"Nay," said the sick man, "by Saint Symoun!
I have be shryven this day at my curat.	I have been shriven this day by my curate.
I have hym toold hoolly al myn estat;	I have him told completely all my condition;
Nedeth namoore to speken of it," seith he,	It needs no more to speak of it," says he,
"But if me list, of myn humylitee."	"Unless I so wish, out of my humility."
"Yif me thanne of thy gold, to make oure cloystre,"	"Give me then of thy gold, to make our cloister,"
Quod he, "for many a muscle and many an oystre,	Said he, "for many a mussel and many an oyster,
Whan othere men han ben ful wel at eyse,	When other men have been full well at ease,
Hath been oure foode, our cloystre for to reyse.	Have been our food, our cloister to erect.
And yet, God woot, unnethe the fundement	And yet, God knows, hardly the foundation
Parfourned is, ne of our pavement	Is finished, nor of our pavement
Nys nat a tyle yet withinne oure wones.	There is not a tile yet within our dwelling.
By God, we owen fourty pound for stones.	By God, we owe forty pounds for stones.
"Now help, Thomas, for hym that harwed helle!	"Now help, Thomas, for him who despoiled hell of its captives!
For elles moste we oure bookes selle.	For otherwise we must sell our books.
And if yow lakke oure predicacioun,	And if you lack our preaching,
Thanne goth the world al to destruccioun.	Then all the world goes to destruction.
For whoso wolde us fro this world bireve,	For whoever would rob us from this world,
So God me save, Thomas, by youre leve,	So save me God, Thomas, by your leave,
He wolde bireve out of this world the sonne.	He would take the sun out of this world.
For who kan teche and werchen as we konne?	For who can teach and work as we know how?
And that is nat of litel tyme," quod he,	And that is not of recent times," said he,
"But syn Elye was, or Elise,	"But since Elijah was, or Elisha,
Han freres been -- that fynde I of record --	Have friars been -- that I find in the records --
In charitee, ythanked be oure Lord!	In charity, thanked be our Lord!
Now Thomas, help, for seinte charitee!"	Now Thomas, help, for holy charity!"
And doun anon he sette hym on his knee.	And down at once he set himself on his knee.
This sike man wax wel ny wood for ire;	This sick man grew well nigh mad for ire;
He wolde that the frere had been on-fire	He wished that the friar had been afire
With his false dissymulacioun.	With his false dissimulation.
"Swich thyng as is in my possessioun,"	"Such a thing as is in my possession,"
Quod he, "that may I yeve, and noon oother.	Said he, "that can I give, and none other.
Ye sey me thus, how that I am youre brother?"	You say me thus, that I am your brother?"
"Ye, certes," quod the frere, "trusteth weel.	"Yes, certainly," said the friar, "trust well.
I took oure dame oure lettre with oure seel."	I gave our lady our letter with our seal."
"Now wel," quod he, "and somwhat shal I yive	"Well now," said he, "and something shall I give

And in thyn hand thou shalt it have anon,	And in thy hand thou shalt it have right now,

This shaltou swere on thy professioun,	This shalt thou swear on thy religious vows,
Withouten fraude or cavillacioun."	Without fraud or quibbling."
"I swere it," quod this frere, "by my feith!"	"I swear it," said this friar, "by my faith!"
And therwithal his hand in his he leith,	And therewith his hand in his he lays,
"Lo, heer my feith; in me shal be no lak."	"Lo, have here my faith; I shall not fail (to keep my word)."
"Now thanne, put in thyn hand doun by my bak,"	"Now then, put in thy hand down by my back,"

Bynethe my buttok there shaltow fynde	Beneath my buttock where shalt thou find
A thyng that I have hyd in pryvetee."	A thing that I have hidden in private."
"A!" thoghte this frere, "That shal go with me!"	"Ah!" thought this friar, "That shall go with me!"
And doun his hand he launcheth to the clifte	And down his hand he thrusts to the cleft

And whan this sike man felte this frere	And when this sick man felt this friar

Amydde his hand he leet the frere a fart;	Amid his hand he let the friar a fart;
Ther nys no capul, drawynge in a cart,	There is no horse, pulling a cart,
That myghte have lete a fart of swich a soun.	That could have let a fart of such a sound.
The frere up stirte as dooth a wood leoun --	The friar up started as does a mad lion --
"A, false cherl," quod he, "for Goddes bones!	"Ah, false churl," said he, "for God's bones!
This hastow for despit doon for the nones.	This hast thou done on purpose for spite.
Thou shalt abye this fart, if that I may!"	Thou shalt pay for this fart, if I can (do so)!"
His meynee, whiche that herden this affray,	His servants, who heard this affray,
Cam lepynge in and chaced out the frere;	Came leaping in and chased out the friar;
And forth he gooth, with a ful angry cheere,	And forth he goes, with a very angry look,
And fette his felawe, ther as lay his stoor.	And fetched his fellow, where lay his store.
He looked as it were a wilde boor;	He looked like a wild boar;
He grynte with his teeth, so was he wrooth.	He gnashed his teeth, he was so angry.
A sturdy paas doun to the court he gooth,	At a rapid pace down to the court he goes,
Wher as ther woned a man of greet honour,	Where there dwelt a man of greet honor,
To whom that he was alwey confessour.	To whom he was always confessor.
This worthy man was lord of that village.	This worthy man was lord of that village.
This frere cam as he were in a rage,	This friar came as if he were in a rage,
Where as this lord sat etyng at his bord;	Where the lord sat eating at his table;
Unnethes myghte the frere speke a word,	Hardly could the friar speak a word,
Til atte laste he seyde, "God yow see!"	Until at the last he said, "God you see!"
This lord gan looke, and seide, "Benedicitee!	This lord did look, and said, "Bless me!
What, frere John, what maner world is this?	What, friar John, what sort of carrying on is this?
I se wel that som thyng ther is amys;	I see well that there is something amiss;
Ye looken as the wode were ful of thevys.	You look as if the wood were full of thieves.
Sit doun anon, and tel me what youre grief is,	Sit down right now, and tell me what your grief is,
And it shal been amended, if I may."	And it shall be amended, if I can."
"I have," quod he, "had a despit this day,	"I have," said he, "had an insult this day,
God yelde yow, adoun in youre village,	God reward you, down in your village,
That in this world is noon so povre a page	That in this world is none so poor a servant boy
That he nolde have abhomynacioun	That he would not be nauseated
Of that I have receyved in youre toun.	By what I have received in your town.
And yet ne greveth me nothyng so soore,	And yet there grieves me nothing so sore,
As that this olde cherl with lokkes hoore	As that this old churl with white locks
Blasphemed hath oure hooly covent eke."	Blasphemed has our holy convent as well."

Thogh I have had in scole that honour.	Though I have had in school that honor.
God liketh nat that `Raby' men us calle,	God likes not that `Rabbi' men us call,

"No fors," quod he, "but tel me al youre grief."	"No matter," said he, "but tell me all your grief."

And so, per consequens, to ech degree	And so, consequently, to each degree

"Sire," quod the lord, "ye woot what is to doone.	"Sir," said the lord, "you know what is to be done.
Distempre yow noght; ye be my confessour;	Do not be angry; you are my confessor;
Ye been the salt of the erthe and the savour.	You are the salt of the earth and the delight.
For Goddes love, youre pacience ye holde!	For God's love, keep your patience!
Tel me youre grief." And he anon hym tolde,	Tell me your grief." And he straightway told him,

The lady of the hous ay stille sat	The lady of the house always still sat
Til she had herd what the frere sayde.	Until she had heard what the friar said.
"Ey, Goddes mooder," quod she, "Blisful mayde!	"Ey, God's mother," said she, "Blissful maid!

I seye a cherl hath doon a cherles dede.	I say a churl has done a churl's deed.
What shold I seye? God lat hym nevere thee!	What should I say? God let him never prosper!
His sike heed is ful of vanytee;	His sick head is full of foolishness;
I holde hym in a manere frenesye."	I consider him in a sort of delirium."
"Madame," quod he, "by God, I shal nat lye,	"My lady," said he, "by God, I shall not lie,

I shal disclaundre hym over al ther I speke,	I shall defame him wherever I speak,
This false blasphemour that charged me	This false blasphemer who charged me
To parte that wol nat departed be	To divide that which will not be divided

"How hadde this cherl ymaginacioun	"How had this churl imagination
To shewe swich a probleme to the frere?	To show such a problem to the friar?
Nevere erst er now herde I of swich mateere.	Never previously before now heard I of such a matter.
I trowe the devel putte it in his mynde.	I believe the devil put it in his mind.
In ars-metrike shal ther no man fynde,	In the art of measuring (arithmetic) shall there no man find,

Who sholde make a demonstracion	Who should make a logical proof
That every man sholde have yliche his part	That every man should have equally his part
As of the soun or savour of a fart?	As of the sound or odor of a fart?
O nyce, proude cherl, I shrewe his face!	Oh ingenious, proud churl, I curse his face!
Lo, sires," quod the lord, "with harde grace!	Lo, sirs," said the lord, "with bad luck (to him)!

It is an inpossible; it may nat be.	It is an impossibility; it can not be.
Ey, nyce cherl, God lete him nevere thee!	Ey, clever churl, God let him never prosper!
The rumblynge of a fart, and every soun,	The rumbling of a fart, and every sound,
