Heere endeth the Somonours Tale.	Here ends the Summoner's Tale.
Ther was, as telleth Titus Livius,	There was, as Titus Livius tells,
A knyght that called was Virginius,	A knight who was called Virginius,
Fulfild of honour and of worthynesse,	Filled with honor and with worthiness,
And strong of freendes, and of greet richesse.	And having powerful friends, and great wealth.
This knyght a doghter hadde by his wyf;	This knight had a daughter by his wife;
No children hadde he mo in al his lyf.	No more children had he in all his life.
Fair was this mayde in excellent beautee	Fair was this maid in excellent beauty
Aboven every wight that man may see;	Above every person that one may see;
For Nature hath with sovereyn diligence	For Nature has with her greatest diligence
Yformed hire in so greet excellence,	Formed her in such great excellence,
As though she wolde seyn, "Lo! I, Nature,	As though she would say, "Lo! I, Nature,
Thus kan I forme and peynte a creature,	Thus can I form and paint a creature,
Whan that me list; who kan me countrefete?	When I wish; who can counterfeit my work?
Pigmalion noght, though he ay forge and bete,	Not Pygmalion, though he always forge and beat,
Or grave, or peynte; for I dar wel seyn	Or carve, or paint; for I dare well say
Apelles, Zanzis, sholde werche in veyn	Apelles or Zeuxis, should work in vain
Outher to grave, or peynte, or forge, or bete,	Either to carve, or paint, or forge, or beat,
If they presumed me to countrefete.	If they presumed to imitate me.
For He that is the formere principal	For He who is the principal creator
Hath maked me his vicaire general,	Has appointed me his Chief Deputy,
To forme and peynten erthely creaturis	To form and paint earthly creatures
Right as me list, and ech thyng in my cure is	Right as I wish, and in my control is each thing
Under the moone, that may wane and waxe,	Under the moon, which may grow less or grow larger,
And for my werk right no thyng wol I axe;	And nothing at all will I ask for my work;
My lord and I been ful of oon accord.	My lord and I are fully in agreement.
I made hire to the worshipe of my lord;	I made her to the worship of my lord;
So do I alle myne othere creatures,	So do I all my other creatures,
What colour that they han or what figures."	Whatever complexion they have or whatever shapes."
Thus semeth me that Nature wolde seye.	It seems to me that Nature would say thus.
This mayde of age twelve yeer was and tweye,	This maid was twelve years of age and two,
In which that Nature hadde swich delit.	In whom Nature had such delight.
For right as she kan peynte a lilie whit,	For just as she can paint a lily white,
And reed a rose, right with swich peynture	And a rose red, just so with such pigments
She peynted hath this noble creature,	Has she painted this noble creature,
Er she were born, upon hir lymes fre,	Before she was born, upon her noble limbs,
Where as by right swiche colours sholde be;	Where such colors should rightly be;
And Phebus dyed hath hire tresses grete	And Phebus has dyed her great tresses
Lyk to the stremes of his burned heete.	Resembling the rays of his burnished sunbeams.
And if that excellent was hire beautee,	And if her beauty was excellent,
A thousand foold moore vertuous was she.	A thousand times more virtuous was she.
In hire ne lakked no condicioun	In her there lacked no characteristic
That is to preyse, as by discrecioun.	That is to be praised by (one with) sound moral judgement.
As wel in goost as body chast was she,	As well in spirit as in body chaste was she,
For which she floured in virginitee	For which she flourished in virginity
With alle humylitee and abstinence,	With all humility and abstinence,
With alle attemperaunce and pacience,	With all temperance and patience,
With mesure eek of beryng and array.	With moderation also in demeanor and dress.
Discreet she was in answeryng alway;	She was always discreet in conversation;
Though she were wis as Pallas, dar I seyn,	Though she was wise as Pallas, I dare say,
Hir facound eek ful wommanly and pleyn,	Her manner of speaking was also very womanly and plain,
No countrefeted termes hadde she	No pretentious terms had she
To seme wys, but after hir degree	To seem wise, but in accordance with her rank in life
She spak, and alle hire wordes, moore and lesse,	She spoke, and all her words, long speeches and brief,
Sownynge in vertu and in gentillesse.	In accord with virtue and nobility.
Shamefast she was in maydens shamefastnesse,	Modest she was in maidenly modesty,
Constant in herte, and evere in bisynesse	Constant in heart, and ever diligent
To dryve hire out of ydel slogardye.	To keep herself away from idle sluggishness.
Bacus hadde of hir mouth right no maistrie;	Bacchus had no mastery of her mouth at all;
For wyn and youthe dooth Venus encresse,	For wine and youth does increase (the power of) Venus,
As men in fyr wol casten oille or greesse.	As if men would cast oil or grease into a fire.
And of hir owene vertu, unconstreyned,	And of her own moral strength, of her own free choice,
She hath ful ofte tyme syk hire feyned,	She has very often pretended to be ill,
For that she wolde fleen the compaignye	Because she wanted to flee the company
Where likly was to treten of folye,	Where there was likely to be talk of folly,
As is at feestes, revels, and at daunces,	As is at feasts, revels, and at dances,
That been occasions of daliaunces.	That provide opportunities for flirtations.
Swich thynges maken children for to be	Such things make children to be
To soone rype and boold, as men may se,	Too soon ripe and bold, as anyone can see,
Which is ful perilous and hath been yoore.	Which is very perilous and has been since long ago,
For al to soone may she lerne loore	For all too soon may she learn the lore
Of booldnesse, whan she woxen is a wyf.	Of boldness, when she is grown to be a wife.
And ye maistresses, in youre olde lyf,	And you mistresses, in your old age,
That lordes doghtres han in governaunce,	Who have lords' daughters in governance,
Ne taketh of my wordes no displesaunce.	Do not take of my words any displeasure.
Thenketh that ye been set in governynges	Think that you are set in charge
Of lordes doghtres oonly for two thynges:	Of lords' daughters only for two things:
Outher for ye han kept youre honestee,	Either because you have kept your chastity,
Or elles ye han falle in freletee,	Or else you have fallen into frailty,
And knowen wel ynough the olde daunce,	And know very well the tricks of the trade,
And han forsaken fully swich meschaunce	And have fully renounced such misconduct
For everemo; therfore, for Cristes sake,	For evermore; therefore, for Christ's sake,
To teche hem vertu looke that ye ne slake.	Look that you do not desisit from teaching them virtue.
A theef of venysoun, that hath forlaft	A thief of venison, who has abandoned
His likerousnesse and al his olde craft,	His greedy appetite and all his old craft,
Kan kepe a forest best of any man.	Can guard a forest better than any other man.
Now kepeth wel, for if ye wole, ye kan.	Now guard well, for if you want (to do it), you can.
Looke wel that ye unto no vice assente,	Take good care that you assent unto no vice,
Lest ye be dampned for youre wikke entente;	Lest you be damned for your wicked intent;
For whoso dooth, a traitour is, certeyn.	For whoever does so, is a traitor, certainly.
And taketh kep of that that I shal seyn:	And pay attention to what I shall say:
Of alle tresons sovereyn pestilence	Of all betrayals the supreme wickedness
Is whan a wight bitrayseth innocence.	Is when a person betrays innocence.
Ye fadres and ye moodres eek also,	You fathers and you mothers also as well,
Though ye han children, be it oon or mo,	If you have children, be it one or more,
Youre is the charge of al hir surveiaunce,	Yours is the responsibility for all their supervision,
Whil that they been under youre governaunce.	While they are under your governance.
Beth war, if by ensample of youre lyvynge,	Beware, lest by example of your (manner of) living,
Or by youre necligence in chastisynge,	Or by your negligence in chastising,
That they ne perisse; for I dar wel seye	That they should perish; for I dare well say
If that they doon, ye shul it deere abeye.	If they do, you shall dearly pay for it.
Under a shepherde softe and necligent	Under a soft and negligent shepherd
The wolf hath many a sheep and lamb torent.	The wolf has many a sheep and lamb torn to pieces.
Suffiseth oon ensample now as heere,	Let one ensample sufficefor the present,
For I moot turne agayn to my matere.	For I must turn again to my subject.
This mayde, of which I wol this tale expresse,	This maiden, of whom I will narrate this tale,
So kepte hirself hir neded no maistresse,	So guarded herself she needed no governess
For in hir lyvyng maydens myghten rede,	For in her manner of life maidens might read,
As in a book, every good word or dede	As in a book, every good word or deed
That longeth to a mayden vertuous,	That is proper to a virtuous maiden,
She was so prudent and so bountevous.	She was so prudent and so filled with good.
For which the fame out sprong on every syde,	For which sprang out all around the fame,
Bothe of hir beautee and hir bountee wyde,	Both of her beauty and her goodness widespread,
That thurgh that land they preised hire echone	So that throughout that land they praised her everyone
That loved vertu, save Envye allone,	Who loved virtue, save Envy alone,
That sory is of oother mennes wele	Who is sorry of other men's prosperity
And glad is of his sorwe and his unheele.	And is glad of his sorrow and his misery.
(The Doctour maketh this descripcioun.)	(The Doctor [St. Augustine] makes this description.)
This mayde upon a day wente in the toun	This maid upon a day went in the town
Toward a temple, with hire mooder deere,	Toward a temple, with her mother dear,
As is of yonge maydens the manere.	As is the manner of young maidens.
Now was ther thanne a justice in that toun,	Now was there then a justice in that town,
That governour was of that regioun.	Who was governor of that region.
And so bifel this juge his eyen caste	And it so happened that this judge cast his eyes
Upon this mayde, avysynge hym ful faste,	Upon this maid, considering her very intently,
As she cam forby ther as this juge stood.	As she passed by where this judge stood.
Anon his herte chaunged and his mood,	Immediately his heart changed and his mood,
So was he caught with beautee of this mayde,	So was he caught by the beauty of this maid,
And to hymself ful pryvely he sayde,	And to himself very secretly he said,
"This mayde shal be myn, for any man!"	"This maid shall be mine, despite what any man (may do)!"
Anon the feend into his herte ran,	Immediately. the fiend ran into his heart,
And taughte hym sodeynly that he by slyghte	And taught him suddenly that he by trickery
The mayden to his purpos wynne myghte.	Could win the maiden to his purpose.
For certes, by no force ne by no meede,	For certainly, not by any force nor by any bribery,
Hym thoughte, he was nat able for to speede;	He thought, would he be able to succeed;
For she was strong of freendes, and eek she	For she had powerful friends, and also she
Confermed was in swich soverayn bountee	Was confirmed in such supreme goodness
That wel he wiste he myghte hire nevere wynne	That he knew well he could never win her
As for to make hire with hir body synne.	And make her sin with her body.
For which, by greet deliberacioun,	For which, after great deliberation,
He sente after a cherl, was in the toun,	He sent for a churl, who was in the town,
Which that he knew for subtil and for boold.	Whom he knew for trickery and for boldness.
This juge unto this cherl his tale hath toold	This judge unto this churl his tale has told
In secree wise, and made hym to ensure	Secretly, and made him swear
He sholde telle it to no creature,	He should tell it to no creature,
And if he dide, he sholde lese his heed.	And if he did, he should lose his head.
Whan that assented was this cursed reed,	When this cursed plot was agreed upon
Glad was this juge, and maked him greet cheere,	Glad was this judge, and made much of him (the churl),
And yaf hym yiftes preciouse and deere.	And gave him precious and expensive gifts.
Whan shapen was al hire conspiracie	When all their conspiracy was planned
Fro point to point, how that his lecherie	In great detail, how his lechery
Parfourned sholde been ful subtilly,	Should be accomplished very subtly,
As ye shul heere it after openly,	As you shall later hear it clearly,
Hoom gooth the cherl, that highte Claudius.	Home goes the churl, who is called Claudius.
This false juge, that highte Apius,	This false judge, who is called Apius,
(So was his name, for this is no fable,	(Such was his name, for this is no fable,
But knowen for historial thyng notable;	But known for a noteworthy historical fact;
The sentence of it sooth is, out of doute),	The substance of it is true, beyond doubt),
This false juge gooth now faste aboute	This false judge goes now fast about
To hasten his delit al that he may.	Hastening his delight all that he can.
And so bifel soone after, on a day,	And so it happened soon after, on a certain day,
This false juge, as telleth us the storie,	This false judge, as the story tells us,
As he was wont, sat in his consistorie,	As he was accustomed, sat in his court,
And yaf his doomes upon sondry cas.	And gave his judgements upon various cases.
This false cherl cam forth a ful greet pas,	This false churl came forth at a very rapid pace,
And seyde, "Lord, if that it be youre wille,	And said, "Lord, if it be your will,
As dooth me right upon this pitous bille,	Do me justice concerning this piteous formal complaint,
In which I pleyne upon Virginius;	In which I complain about Virginius;
And if that he wol seyn it is nat thus,	And if he will say it is not thus,
I wol it preeve, and fynde good witnesse,	I will prove it, and find good evidence,
That sooth is that my bille wol expresse."	That what my formal complaint will express is truth."
The juge answerde, "Of this, in his absence,	The judge answered, "Of this, in his absence,
I may nat yeve diffynytyf sentence.	I can not give definitive judgment.
Lat do hym calle, and I wol gladly heere;	Let him be called, and I will gladly hear (the case);
Thou shalt have al right, and no wrong heere."	Thou shalt have all justice, and no wrong here."
Virginius cam to wite the juges wille,	Virginius came to learn the judge's will,
And right anon was rad this cursed bille;	And right away this cursed complaint was read;
The sentence of it was as ye shul heere:	The substance of it was as you shall hear:
"To yow, my lord, sire Apius so deere,	"To you, my lord, Sir Apius so dear,
Sheweth youre povre servant Claudius	Your poor servant Claudius shows
How that a knyght, called Virginius,	How a knight, called Virginius,
Agayns the lawe, agayn al equitee,	Against the law, against all equity,
Holdeth, expres agayn the wyl of me,	Expressly against my will, holds
My servant, which that is my thral by right,	My servant, who is my slave by right,
Which fro myn hous was stole upon a nyght,	Who was stolen from my house upon one night,
Whil that she was ful yong; this wol I preeve	While she was very young; this will I prove
By witnesse, lord, so that it nat yow greeve.	By evidence, lord, providing that you be not displeased.
She nys his doghter nat, what so he seye.	She is not his daughter, whatever he may say.
Wherfore to yow, my lord the juge, I preye,	Therefore to you, my lord judge, I pray,
Yeld me my thral, if that it be youre wille."	Yield me my slave, if it be your will."
Lo, this was al the sentence of his bille.	Lo, this was all the substance of his complaint.
Virginius gan upon the cherl biholde,	Virginius began to look upon the churl,
But hastily, er he his tale tolde,	Hastily, before he finished telling his tale,
And wolde have preeved it as sholde a knyght,	And would have proven it as a knight should (by battle),
And eek by witnessyng of many a wight,	And also by the evidence of many a person,
That al was fals that seyde his adversarie,	That all that his adversary said was false,
This cursed juge wolde no thyng tarie,	This cursed judge would not at all delay,
Ne heere a word moore of Virginius,	Nor hear one word more from Virginius,
But yaf his juggement, and seyde thus:	But gave his judgment, and said thus:
"I deeme anon this cherl his servant have;	"I decide that this churl should have his slave right now;
Thou shalt no lenger in thyn hous hir save.	Thou shalt no longer keep her in thine house.
Go bryng hire forth, and put hire in oure warde.	Go bring her forth, and put her in our guardianship.
The cherl shal have his thral, this I awarde."	The churl shall have his slave, this I decree."
And whan this worthy knyght Virginius	And when this worthy knight Virginius
Thurgh sentence of this justice Apius	Because of the verdict of this justice Apius
Moste by force his deere doghter yiven	By force had to give his dear daughter
Unto the juge, in lecherie to lyven,	Unto the judge, to live in lechery,
He gooth hym hoom, and sette him in his halle,	He goes home, and sat himself in his hall,
And leet anon his deere doghter calle,	And immediately had his dear daughter called,
And with a face deed as asshen colde	And with a face as dead as cold ashes
Upon hir humble face he gan biholde,	Upon her humble face he did behold,
With fadres pitee stikynge thurgh his herte,	With a father's pity stabbing through his heart,
Al wolde he from his purpos nat converte.	Although he would not deviate from his purpose.
"Doghter," quod he, "Virginia, by thy name,	"Daughter," said he, "Virginia, by thy name,
Ther been two weyes, outher deeth or shame,	There are two ways, either death or shame,
That thou most suffre; allas, that I was bore!	That thou most suffer; alas, that I was born!
For nevere thou deservedest wherfore	For never thou deservedest for whatever reason
To dyen with a swerd or with a knyf.	To die by a sword or by a knife.
O deere doghter, endere of my lyf,	O dear daughter, ender of my life,
Which I have fostred up with swich plesaunce	Whom I have nurured with such pleasure
That thou were nevere out of my remembraunce!	That thou were never out of my thoughts!
O doghter, which that art my laste wo,	O daughter, who art my greatest woe,
And in my lyf my laste joye also,	And in my life my greatest joy also,
O gemme of chastitee, in pacience	O gem of chastity, in patience
Take thou thy deeth, for this is my sentence.	Take thou thy death, for this is my decision.
For love, and nat for hate, thou most be deed;	For love, and not for hate, thou must be dead;
My pitous hand moot smyten of thyn heed.	My piteous hand must smite off thy head.
Allas, that evere Apius the say!	Alas, that ever Apius saw thee!
Thus hath he falsly jugged the to-day" --	For that reason he has falsely judged thee to-day" --
And tolde hire al the cas, as ye bifore	And told her the whole business, as you before
Han herd; nat nedeth for to telle it moore.	Have heard; there is no need to tell it again.
"O mercy, deere fader!" quod this mayde,	"O mercy, dear father!" said this maid,
And with that word she bothe hir armes layde	And with that word she both her arms laid
Aboute his nekke, as she was wont to do.	About his neck, as she was accustomed to do.
The teeris bruste out of hir eyen two,	The tears burst out of her two eyes,
And seyde, "Goode fader, shal I dye?	And said, "Good father, must I dye?
Is ther no grace, is ther no remedye?"	Is there no grace, is there no remedy?"
"No, certes, deere doghter myn," quod he.	"No, certainly, dear daughter mine," said he.
"Thanne yif me leyser, fader myn," quod she,	"Then give me time, father mine," said she,
"My deeth for to compleyne a litel space;	"To lament my death for a little while;
For, pardee, Jepte yaf his doghter grace	For, truly, Jeptha gave his daughter grace
For to compleyne, er he hir slow, allas!	To lament, before he slew her, alas!
And, God it woot, no thyng was hir trespas,	And, God knows it, her trespass was nothing,
But for she ran hir fader first to see,	Except that she ran first to see her father,
To welcome hym with greet solempnitee."	To welcome him with great solemnity."
And with that word she fil aswowne anon,	And with that word immediately she fell in a swoon,
And after, whan hir swownyng is agon,	And afterwards, when her swooning is gone,
She riseth up, and to hir fader sayde,	She rises up, and to her father said,
"Blissed be God that I shal dye a mayde!	"Blessed be God that I shall die a maid!
Yif me my deeth, er that I have a shame;	Give me my death, before I have dishonor;
Dooth with youre child youre wyl, a Goddes name!"	Do with your child your will, in God's name!"
And with that word she preyed hym ful ofte	And with that word she prayed him repeatedly
That with his swerd he wolde smyte softe;	That with his sword he would smite gently;
And with that word aswowne doun she fil.	And with that word down she fell in a swoon.
Hir fader, with ful sorweful herte and wil,	Her father, with very sorrowful heart and will,
Hir heed of smoot, and by the top it hente,	Struck off her head, and by the hair siezed it,
And to the juge he gan it to presente,	And he did present it to the judge,
As he sat yet in doom in consistorie.	As he sat yet rendering judgements in court.
And whan the juge it saugh, as seith the storie,	And when the judge saw it, as says the story,
He bad to take hym and anhange hym faste;	He ordered [his men] to take him and hang him at once;
But right anon a thousand peple in thraste,	But right away a thousand people burst in,
To save the knyght, for routhe and for pitee,	To save the knight, for compassion and for pity,
For knowen was the false iniquitee.	For the false wickedness was known.
The peple anon had suspect in this thyng,	The people immediately suspected in this matter,
By manere of the cherles chalangyng,	Because of the manner of the churl's claim,
That it was by the assent of Apius;	That it was by the conspiring of Apius;
They wisten wel that he was lecherus.	They knew well that he was lecherous.
For which unto this Apius they gon	For which unto this Apius they go
And caste hym in a prisoun right anon,	And cast him in a prison straightway,
Ther as he slow hymself; and Claudius,	Where he slew himself; and Claudius,
That servant was unto this Apius,	Who was servant unto this Apius,
Was demed for to hange upon a tree,	Was condemned to hang upon a tree,
But that Virginius, of his pitee,	Except that Virginius, of his pity,
So preyde for hym that he was exiled;	So prayed for him (Claudius) that he was exiled;
And elles, certes, he had been bigyled.	And also, certainly, he had been tricked (by Apius).
The remenant were anhanged, moore and lesse,	The remnant were hanged, high ranking and low,
That were consentant of this cursednesse.	Who were accessories to this crime.
Heere may men seen how synne hath his merite.	Here may men see how sin has its reward.
Beth war, for no man woot whom God wol smyte	Beware, for no man knows whom God will smite
In no degree, ne in which manere wyse;	In any rank, nor in what sort of way;
The worm of conscience may agryse	The worm of conscience may tremble for fear
Of wikked lyf, though it so pryvee be	Because of a wicked life, though it so secret be
That no man woot therof but God and he.	That no man knows about it but God and he.
For be he lewed man, or ellis lered,	For be he ignorant man, or else learned,
He noot how soone that he shal been afered.	He knows not how soon he shall be terrified.
Therfore I rede yow this conseil take:	Therefore I advise you to take this counsel:
Forsaketh synne, er synne yow forsake.	Abandon sin, before sin abandons you.
Heere is ended the Phisiciens Tale	Here ends the Physician's Tale.
Heere bigynneth the Shipmannes Tale.	Here begins the Shipman's Tale.
A marchant whilom dwelled at Seint-Denys,	A merchant once dwelled at Seint-Denis,
That riche was, for which men helde hym wys.	Who was rich, for which men considered him wise.
A wyf he hadde of excellent beautee;	He had a wife of excellent beauty;
And compaignable and revelous was she,	And she was sociable and fond of revelry,
Which is a thyng that causeth more dispence	Which is a thing that causes more expense
Than worth is al the chiere and reverence	Than is worth all the good cheer and reverence
That men hem doon at festes and at daunces.	That men do to them at festivities and at dances.
Swiche salutaciouns and contenaunces	Such salutations and courtesies
Passen as dooth a shadwe upon the wal;	Pass away as does a shadow upon the wall;
But wo is hym that payen moot for al!	But woe to him that must pay for all!
The sely housbonde, algate he moot paye,	The poor (hapless) husband, always he must pay,
He moot us clothe, and he moot us arraye,	He must clothe us, and he must adorn us
Al for his owene worshipe richely,	Richly, all for the sake of his own reputation,
In which array we daunce jolily.	In which finery we dance merrily.
And if that he noght may, par aventure,	And if it happens he can not pay,
Or ellis list no swich dispence endure,	Or else desires to endure no such expense,
But thynketh it is wasted and ylost,	But thinks it is wasted and lost,
Thanne moot another payen for oure cost,	Then another must pay for our costs,
Or lene us gold, and that is perilous.	Or lend us gold, and that is perilous.
This noble marchaunt heeld a worthy hous,	This noble merchant held a worthy house,
For which he hadde alday so greet repair	For which he always had so many guests
For his largesse, and for his wyf was fair,	Because of his generosity, and because his wife was fair,
That wonder is; but herkneth to my tale.	That it is a wonder; but listen to my tale.
Amonges alle his gestes, grete and smale,	Among all his guests, high ranking and low,
Ther was a monk, a fair man and a boold --	There was a monk, a handsome man and a bold one --
I trowe a thritty wynter he was oold --	I believe he was about thirty years old --
That evere in oon was drawynge to that place.	Who continually was drawing to that place.
This yonge monk, that was so fair of face,	This young monk, who had so handsome a face,
Aqueynted was so with the goode man,	Was so acquainted with the good man,
Sith that hir firste knoweliche bigan,	Since their first acquaintance began,
That in his hous as famulier was he	That in his house as intimate was he
As it is possible any freend to be.	As it is possible for any friend to be.

A KNYGHT ther was, and that a worthy man,	A KNIGHT there was, and that (one was) a worthy man,

Ful worthy was he in his lordes werre,	He was very worthy in his lord's war,
