Of Brugges were his hosen broun,	Of Bruges were his brown stockings,
His robe was of syklatoun,	His robe was of silk woven with gold,
That coste many a jane.	That cost many a half-penny.
He koude hunte at wilde deer,	He knew how to hunt for wild animals,
And ride an haukyng for river	And ride a-hawking for water-fowl
With grey goshauk on honde;	With grey gos-hawk on hand;
Therto he was a good archeer;	Moreover he was a good archer;
Of wrastlyng was ther noon his peer,	In wrestling there was no one his peer,
Ther any ram shal stonde.	Where any ram shall stand (as a prize).
Ful many a mayde, bright in bour,	Very many a maid, bright in bed-chamber,
They moorne for hym paramour,	They mourn for him passionately,
Whan hem were bet to slepe;	When it would be better for them to sleep;
But he was chaast and no lechour,	But he was chaste and no lecher,
And sweete as is the brembul flour	And sweet as is the dog rose
That bereth the rede hepe.	That bears the red hip.
And so bifel upon a day,	And it so happened upon a day,
For sothe, as I yow telle may,	In truth, as I can tell you,
Sire Thopas wolde out ride.	Sir Thopas wanted to ride out.
He worth upon his steede gray,	He mounted upon his gray steed,
And in his hand a launcegay,	And in his hand a light lance,
A long swerd by his side.	A long sword by his side.
He priketh thurgh a fair forest,	He spurs through a fair forest,
Therinne is many a wilde best,	In which is many a wild best,
Ye, bothe bukke and hare;	Yea, both buck and hare;
And as he priketh north and est,	And as he spurs north and east,
I telle it yow, hym hadde almest	I tell it you, to him had almost
Bitid a sory care.	Happened a grievous misfortune.
Ther spryngen herbes grete and smale,	There spring herbs large and small,
The lycorys and the cetewale,	The licorice and the zedoary,
And many a clowe-gylofre;	And many a clove-gillyflower;
And notemuge to putte in ale,	And nutmeg to put in ale,
Wheither it be moyste or stale,	Whether it be new or old,
Or for to leye in cofre.	Or to lay in a clothes press.
The briddes synge, it is no nay,	The birds sing, it can not be denied,
The sparhauk and the papejay,	The sparrow hawk and the parrot,
That joye it was to heere;	That it was joy to hear;
The thrustelcok made eek hir lay,	The male thrush made also her lay,
The wodedowve upon the spray	The wood-pigeon upon the branch
She sang ful loude and cleere.	She sang very loud and clear.
Sire Thopas fil in love-longynge,	Sir Thopas fell in a yearning for love,
Al whan he herde the thrustel synge,	As soon as he heard the thrush sing,
And pryked as he were wood.	And spurred as if he were crazy.
His faire steede in his prikynge	His fair steed in his spurring
So swatte that men myghte him wrynge;	So sweated that one could wring him;
His sydes were al blood.	His sides were all blood.
Sire Thopas eek so wery was	Sir Thopas also so weary was
For prikyng on the softe gras,	For spurring on the soft grass,
So fiers was his corage,	So fierce was his heart,
That doun he leyde him in that plas	That down he laid him in that place
To make his steede som solas,	To give his steed some rest,
And yaf hym good forage.	And gave him good dry fodder.
"O Seinte Marie, benedicite!	"O Saint Mary, bless me!
What eyleth this love at me	What does this love have against me
To bynde me so soore?	To bind me so painfully?
Me dremed al this nyght, pardee,	I dreamed all this night, by God,
An elf-queene shal my lemman be	An elf-queen shall be my sweetheart
And slepe under my goore.	And sleep under my cloak.
"An elf-queene wol I love, ywis,	"An elf-queen will I love, indeed,
For in this world no womman is	For in this world no woman is
Worthy to be my make	Worthy to be my mate
In towne;	In town;
Alle othere wommen I forsake,	All other women I forsake,
And to an elf-queene I me take	And to an elf-queen I betake nyself,
By dale and eek by downe!"	By dale and also by hill!"
Into his sadel he clamb anon,	Into his saddle he climbed at once,
And priketh over stile and stoon	And spurs over stile and stone
An elf-queene for t' espye,	An elf-queen for to see,
Til he so longe hath riden and goon	Until he so long had ridden and walked
That he foond, in a pryve woon,	That he found, in a secret place,
The contree of Fairye	The country of Fairy
So wilde;	So wild;
For in that contree was ther noon	For in that country there was no one
That to him durste ride or goon,	Who dared ride or go on foot at him,
Neither wyf ne childe;	Neither woman nor child;
Til that ther cam a greet geaunt,	Until there came a big giant,
His name was sire Olifaunt,	His name was sir Olifaunt,
A perilous man of dede.	A perilous man of deeds.
He seyde, "Child, by Termagaunt,	He said, "Child, by Termagaunt,
But if thou prike out of myn haunt,	Unless thou spur out of my territory,
Anon I sle thy steede	At once I will slay thy steed
With mace.	With mace.
Heere is the queene of Fayerye,	Here is the queen of Fairyland,
With harpe and pipe and symphonye,	With harp and pipe and hurdy-gurdy,
Dwellynge in this place."	Dwelling in this place."
The child seyde, "Also moote I thee,	The child said, "As I may prosper,
Tomorwe wol I meete with thee,	Tomorrow will I meet with thee,
Whan I have myn armoure;	When I have my armor;
And yet I hope, par ma fay,	And yet I trust, by my faith,
That thou shalt with this launcegay	That thou shalt by means of this light lance
Abyen it ful sowre.	Very bitterly pay for it.
Thy mawe	Thy maw
Shal I percen, if I may,	Shall I pierce, if I can,
Er it be fully pryme of day,	Ere it be fully prime of day ( a.m.),
For heere thow shalt be slawe."	For here thou shalt be slain."
Sire Thopas drow abak ful faste;	Sir Thopas drew back very fast;
This geant at hym stones caste	This giant threw stones at him
Out of a fel staf-slynge.	Out of a terrible staff-sling.
But faire escapeth child Thopas,	But child Thopas safely escapes,
And al it was thurgh Goddes gras,	And it was all due to God's grace,
And thurgh his fair berynge.	And due to his fair bearing.
Yet listeth, lordes, to my tale	Yet listen, gentlemen, to my tale
Murier than the nightyngale,	Merrier than the nightingale,
For now I wol yow rowne	For now I will you tell
How sir Thopas, with sydes smale,	How sir Thopas, with slender waist,
Prikyng over hill and dale,	Spurring over hill and dale,
Is comen agayn to towne.	Is come again to town.
His myrie men comanded he	His merry men commanded he
To make hym bothe game and glee,	To make him both amusement and delight,
For nedes moste he fighte	For by necessity he must fight
With a geaunt with hevedes three,	With a giant with three heads,
For paramour and jolitee	For love and pleasure
Of oon that shoon ful brighte.	Of one who shone very bright.
"Do come," he seyde, "my mynstrales,	"Do come," he said, "my musicians,
And geestours for to tellen tales,	And story tellers to tell tales,
Anon in myn armynge,	Right now in my arming,
Of romances that been roiales,	Of romances that are royal,
Of popes and of cardinales,	Of popes and of cardinals,
And eek of love-likynge."	And also of the joys of love."
They fette hym first the sweete wyn,	They fetched him first the sweet wine,
And mede eek in a mazelyn,	And mead also in a maple drinking bowl,
And roial spicerye	And royal delicacies
Of gyngebreed that was ful fyn,	Of gingerbread that was very fine,
And lycorys, and eek comyn,	And licorice, and also cumin,
With sugre that is trye.	With sugar that is excellent.
He dide next his white leere	He put on next to his white flesh
Of cloth of lake fyn and cleere,	Of linen cloth fine and clear,
A breech and eek a sherte;	A pair of trousers and also a shirt;
And next his sherte an aketoun,	And next to his shirt a quilted jacket,
And over that an haubergeoun	And over that a chain-mail shirt
For percynge of his herte;	To prevent piercing of his heart;
And over that a fyn hawberk,	And over that a fine plate armor,
Was al ywroght of Jewes werk,	Which was all wrought with jewelers' work,
Ful strong it was of plate;	Very strong it was of iron plate;
And over that his cote-armour	And over that his surcoat
As whit as is a lilye flour,	As white as is a lily flour,
In which he wol debate.	In which he will dispute.
His sheeld was al of gold so reed,	His shield was all of gold so red,
And therinne was a bores heed,	And on that was a boar's head,
A charbocle bisyde;	Beside a carbuncle (red gem);
And there he swoor on ale and breed	And there he swore on ale and bread
How that the geaunt shal be deed,	How the giant shall be dead,
Bityde what bityde!	Whatever may happen!
His jambeux were of quyrboilly,	His leg guards were of hardened leather,
His swerdes shethe of yvory,	His sword's sheath of ivory,
His helm of latoun bright;	His helm of bright brass;
His sadel was of rewel boon,	His saddle was of ivory,
His brydel as the sonne shoon,	His bridle shone like the sun,
Or as the moone light.	Or like the moon light.
His spere was of fyn ciprees,	His spear was of fine cypress,
That bodeth werre, and nothyng pees,	That foretells war, and nothing of peace,
The heed ful sharpe ygrounde;	The head ground very sharp;
His steede was al dappull gray,	His steed was all dapple gray,
It gooth an ambil in the way	It goes at a slow walk on the way
Ful softely and rounde	Very softly and easily
In londe.	In land.
Loo, lordes myne, heere is a fit!	Lo, my lords, here is a fit!
If ye wol any moore of it,	If you want to hear any more of it,
To telle it wol I fonde.	To tell it will I try
Now holde youre mouth, par charitee,	Now hold your mouth, for kindness, please,
Bothe knyght and lady free,	Both knight and noble lady,
And herkneth to my spelle;	And hearken to my tale;
Of bataille and of chivalry,	Of battle and of chivalry,
And of ladyes love-drury	And of ladies' passionate love
Anon I wol yow telle.	Right now I will you tell.
Men speken of romances of prys,	Men speak of excellent romances,
Of Horn child and of Ypotys,	Of Horn child and of Ypotys,
Of Beves and sir Gy,	Of Bevis of Hampton and sir Guy of Watwick,
Of sir Lybeux and Pleyndamour --	Of sir Lybeux Desconus and Pleyndamour --
But sir Thopas, he bereth the flour	But sir Thopas, he bears the flower
Of roial chivalry!	Of royal chivalry!
His goode steede al he bistrood,	His good steed he mounted
And forth upon his wey he glood	And forth upon his way he glided
As sparcle out of the bronde;	Like a spark out of the burning log;
Upon his creest he bar a tour,	Upon his top of his helmet he bore a tower,
And therinne stiked a lilie flour --	And in that stuck a lily flower --
God shilde his cors fro shonde!	God protect his body from shame!
And for he was a knyght auntrous,	And because he was a knight errent,
He nolde slepen in noon hous,	He would not sleep in any house,
But liggen in his hoode;	But lie in his hood;
His brighte helm was his wonger,	His bright helm was his pillow,
And by hym baiteth his dextrer	And by him his war-horse grazes
Of herbes fyne and goode.	On herbs fine and good.
Hymself drank water of the well,	He himself drank water of the well,
As dide the knyght sire Percyvell	As did the knight sir Perceval
So worly under wede,	So worthy in his armor,
Til on a day --	Until on a day --
"Namoore of this, for Goddes dignitee,"	"No more of this, for God's dignity,"
Quod oure Hooste, "for thou makest me	Said our Host, "for thou makest me
So wery of thy verray lewednesse	So weary of thy true ignorance
That, also wisly God my soule blesse,	That, as surely as God may bless my soul,
Myne eres aken of thy drasty speche.	My ears ache from thy crappy speech.
Now swich a rym the devel I biteche!	Now such a rime I commit to the devil!
This may wel be rym dogerel," quod he.	This may well be doggerel verse," said he.
"Why so?" quod I, "why wiltow lette me	"Why so?" said I, "why wilt thou prevent me
Moore of my tale than another man,	From telling more of my tale than another man,
Syn that it is the beste rym I kan?"	Since it is the best rime I know?"
"By God," quod he, "for pleynly, at a word,	"By God," said he, "for plainly, at one word,
Thy drasty rymyng is nat worth a toord!	Thy crappy riming is not worth a turd!
Thou doost noght elles but despendest tyme.	Thou dost nothing else but waste time.
Sire, at o word, thou shalt no lenger ryme.	Sir, at one word, thou shalt no longer rime.
Lat se wher thou kanst tellen aught in geeste,	Let's see whether thou can tell anything in alliterative verse,
Or telle in prose somwhat, at the leeste,	Or tell something in prose, at the least,
In which ther be som murthe or som doctryne."	In which there may be some mirth or some doctrine."
"Gladly," quod I, "by Goddes sweete pyne!	"Gladly," said I, "by God's sweet pain!
I wol yow telle a litel thyng in prose	I will you tell a little thing in prose
That oghte liken yow, as I suppose,	That ought to please you, as I suppose,
Or elles, certes, ye been to daungerous.	Or else, certainly, you are too hard to please.
It is a moral tale vertuous,	It is a virtuous moral tale,
Al be it told somtyme in sondry wyse	Although it is told sometimes in various ways
Of sondry folk, as I shal yow devyse.	By various folk, as I shall tell you.
"As thus: ye woot that every Evaungelist	"As thus: you know that every Evangelist
That telleth us the peyne of Jhesu Crist	Who tells us of the pain of Jesus Christ
Ne seith nat alle thyng as his felawe dooth;	Does not say everything as his fellow does;
But nathelees hir sentence is al sooth,	But nonetheless their essential meaning is all true,
And alle acorden as in hire sentence,	And all agree in their meaning,
Al be ther in hir tellyng difference.	Although there may be a difference in their telling.
For somme of hem seyn moore, and somme seyn lesse,	For some of them say more, and some say less,
Whan they his pitous passioun expresse --	When they His piteous passion express --
I meene of Mark, Mathew, Luc, and John --	I mean of Mark, Matthew, Luke, and John --
But doutelees hir sentence is al oon.	But doubtless their essential meaning is all the same.
Therfore, lordynges alle, I yow biseche,	Therefore, gentlemen, I beseech you,
If that yow thynke I varie as in my speche,	If you think I vary as in my speech,
As thus, though that I telle somwhat moore	As thus, though I tell something more
Of proverbes than ye han herd bifoore	Of proverbs than you have heard before
Comprehended in this litel tretys heere,	Comprehended in this little treatise here,
To enforce with th' effect of my mateere;	With which to strengthen the effect of my matter;
And though I nat the same wordes seye	And though I do not say the same words
As ye han herd, yet to yow alle I preye	As you have heard, yet to you all I pray
Blameth me nat; for, as in my sentence,	Blame not me; for, in my essential meaning,
Shul ye nowher fynden difference	You shall nowhere find difference
Fro the sentence of this tretys lyte	From the meaning of that little treatise
After the which this murye tale I write.	In imitation of which this merry tale I write.
And therfore herkneth what that I shal seye,	And therefore hearken what I shall say,
And lat me tellen al my tale, I preye."	And let me tell all my tale, I pray."
The Prologe of the Marchantes Tale.	The Prologue of the Merchant's Tale.
"Wepyng and waylyng, care and oother sorwe	"Weeping and wailing, grief and other sorrow
I knowe ynogh, on even and a-morwe,"	I know enough, on evenings and mornings,"
Quod the Marchant, "and so doon other mo	Said the Merchant, "and so do many others
That wedded been. I trowe that it be so,	Who are wedded. I believe that it is so,
For wel I woot it fareth so with me.	For well I know it fares so with me.
I have a wyf, the worste that may be;	I have a wife, the worst that can be;
For thogh the feend to hire ycoupled were,	For though the fiend were married to her,
She wolde hym overmacche, I dar wel swere.	She would outmatch him, I dare well swear.
What sholde I yow reherce in special	Why should I tell you in detail
Hir hye malice? She is a shrewe at al.	Her high malice? She is a shrew in every way.
Ther is a long and large difference	There is a long and large difference
Bitwix Grisildis grete pacience	Between Griselda's great patience
And of my wyf the passyng crueltee.	And the extreme cruelty of my wife
Were I unbounden, also moot I thee,	Were I released (from marriage), so may I may prosper,
I wolde nevere eft comen in the snare.	I would never again come in the snare.
We wedded men lyven in sorwe and care.	We wedded men live in sorrow and care.
Assaye whoso wole, and he shal fynde	Try it whoso will, and he shall find
That I seye sooth, by Seint Thomas of Ynde,	That I say truth, by Saint Thomas of India,
As for the moore part -- I sey nat alle.	As for the greater part (majority) -- I say not all.
God shilde that it sholde so bifalle!	God prevent that it should so happen!
"A, goode sire Hoost, I have ywedded bee	"A, good sir Host, I have been wedded
Thise monthes two, and moore nat, pardee;	These two months, and no more, by God;
And yet, I trowe, he that al his lyve	And yet, I believe, he who all his life
Wyflees hath been, though that men wolde him ryve	Wifeless has been, though one would him stab
Unto the herte, ne koude in no manere	Unto the heart, could not in any way
Tellen so muchel sorwe as I now heere	Tell so much sorrow as I now here
Koude tellen of my wyves cursednesse!"	Could tell of my wife's cursedness!"
"Now," quod oure Hoost, "Marchaunt, so God yow blesse,	"Now," said our Host, "Merchant, as God may you bless,
Syn ye so muchel knowen of that art	Since you know so much of that art
Ful hertely I pray yow telle us part."	Full heartily I pray you tell us part."
"Gladly," quod he, "but of myn owene soore,	"Gladly," said he, "but of my own sorrow,
For soory herte, I telle may namoore."	For sorry heart, I can tell no more."
Heere bigynneth the Marchantes Tale.	Here begins the Merchant's Tale.
Whilom ther was dwellynge in Lumbardye	Once there was dwelling in Lombardy
A worthy knyght, that born was of Pavye,	A worthy knight, who was born in Pavia,
In which he lyved in greet prosperitee;	In which he lived in great prosperity;
And sixty yeer a wyflees man was hee,	And sixty years a wifeless man was he,
And folwed ay his bodily delyt	And followed always his bodily desire
On wommen, ther as was his appetyt,	On women, where was his appetite,
As doon thise fooles that been seculeer.	As do these fools that are secular.
And whan that he was passed sixty yeer,	And when he was passed sixty years,
Were it for hoolynesse or for dotage	Were it for holiness or for dotage
I kan nat seye, but swich a greet corage	I can not say, but such a great desire
Hadde this knyght to been a wedded man	Had this knight to be a wedded man
That day and nyght he dooth al that he kan	That day and night he does all he can
T' espien where he myghte wedded be,	To discover where he might wedded be,
Preyinge oure Lord to graunten him that he	Praying our Lord to grant him that he
Mighte ones knowe of thilke blisful lyf	Might once know of that blissful life
That is bitwixe an housbonde and his wyf,	That is between a husband and his wife,
And for to lyve under that hooly boond	And to live under that holy bond
With which that first God man and womman bond.	With which God first bound man and woman.
"Noon oother lyf," seyde he, "is worth a bene,	"No other life," said he, "is worth a bean,
For wedlok is so esy and so clene,	For wedlock is so easy and so pure,
That in this world it is a paradys."	That in this world it is a paradise."
Thus seyde this olde knyght, that was so wys.	Thus said this old knight, who was so wise.
And certeinly, as sooth as God is kyng,	And certainly, as truly as God is king,
To take a wyf it is a glorious thyng,	To take a wife it is a glorious thing,
And namely whan a man is oold and hoor;	And especially when a man is old and white-haired;
Thanne is a wyf the fruyt of his tresor.	Then is a wife the best part of his treasure.
Thanne sholde he take a yong wyf and a feir,	Then should he take a young wife and a fair,
On which he myghte engendren hym an heir,	On which he might engender himself an heir,
And lede his lyf in joye and in solas,	And lead his life in joy and in pleasure,
Where as thise bacheleris synge "allas,"	Whereas these bachelors sing "alas,"
Whan that they fynden any adversitee	When they find any adversity
In love, which nys but childyssh vanytee.	In love, which is nothing but childish vanity.
And trewely it sit wel to be so,	And truly it is fitting to be thus,
That bacheleris have often peyne and wo;	That bachelors have often pain and woe;
On brotel ground they buylde, and brotelnesse	On brittle ground they build, and insecurity
They fynde whan they wene sikernesse.	They find when they expect security.
They lyve but as a bryd or as a beest,	They live but as a bird or as a beast,
In libertee and under noon arreest,	In liberty and under no restraint,
Ther as a wedded man in his estaat	Whereas a wedded man in his estate
Lyveth a lyf blisful and ordinaat	Lives a blissful and orderly life
Under this yok of mariage ybounde.	Bound under this yoke of marriage.
Wel may his herte in joy and blisse habounde,	Well may his heart in joy and bliss abound,
For who kan be so buxom as a wyf?	For who can be so obedient as a wife?
Who is so trewe, and eek so ententyf	Who is so true, and also so eager
To kepe hym, syk and hool, as is his make?	To care for him, sick and well, as is his mate?
For wele or wo she wole hym nat forsake;	For happiness or woe she will not forsake him;
She nys nat wery hym to love and serve,	She is not weary of loving and serving him,
Though that he lye bedrede til he sterve.	Though he lie bedridden until he dies.
And yet somme clerkes seyn it nys nat so,	And yet some clerks say it is not so,
Of whiche he Theofraste is oon of tho.	Of which that Theofrastus is one of those.
What force though Theofraste liste lye?	What does it matter though Theofrastus wants to lie?
"Ne take no wyf," quod he, "for housbondrye,	"Take no wife," said he, "for managing the household,
As for to spare in houshold thy dispence.	As to economize in thy household expenditures.
A trewe servant dooth moore diligence	A true servant does more diligence
Thy good to kepe than thyn owene wyf,	To guard thy goods than thine own wife,
For she wol clayme half part al hir lyf.	For she will claim half part all her life.
And if thou be syk, so God me save,	And if thou be sick, as God may save me,
Thy verray freendes, or a trewe knave,	Thy real friends, or a true servant,
Wol kepe thee bet than she that waiteth ay	Will take care of thee better than she that waits always
After thy good and hath doon many a day.	To inherit thy goods and has done so many a day.
And if thou take a wyf unto thyn hoold	And if thou take a wife unto thy household
Ful lightly maystow been a cokewold."	Full easily canst thou be a cuckold."
This sentence, and an hundred thynges worse,	This opinion, and a hundred things worse,
Writeth this man, ther God his bones corse!	Writes this man, may God his bones curse!
But take no kep of al swich vanytee;	But take no heed of all such foolishness;
Deffie Theofraste, and herke me.	Defy Theofrastus, and listen to me.
A wyf is Goddes yifte verraily;	A wife is God's gift truly;
Alle othere manere yiftes hardily,	All other sorts of gifts certainly,
As londes, rentes, pasture, or commune,	Such as lands, rents, pasture, or right to use common land,
Or moebles -- alle been yiftes of Fortune	Or personal possessions -- all are gifts of Fortune
That passen as a shadwe upon a wal.	That pass like a shadow upon a wall.
But drede nat, if pleynly speke I shal:	But doubt not, if I shall speak plainly:
A wyf wol laste, and in thyn hous endure,	A wife will last, and in thy house endure,
Wel lenger than thee list, paraventure.	Well longer than thou will wish, indeed.
Mariage is a ful greet sacrement.	Marriage is a full great sacrament.
He which that hath no wyf, I holde hym shent;	He who has no wife, I consider him ruined;
He lyveth helplees and al desolat --	He lives helpless and all desolate --
I speke of folk in seculer estaat.	I speak of folk in secular life.
And herke why -- I sey nat this for noght --	And hearken why -- I say not this for nothing --
That womman is for mannes helpe ywroght.	That woman is created for man's help.
The hye God, whan he hadde Adam maked,	The high God, when he had made Adam,
And saugh him al allone, bely-naked,	And saw him all alone, stark naked,
God of his grete goodnesse seyde than,	God of his great goodness said then,
"Lat us now make an helpe unto this man	"Let us now make a helper for this man
Lyk to hymself"; and thanne he made him Eve.	Like to himself"; and then he made him Eve.
Heere may ye se, and heerby may ye preve,	Here can you see, and hereby can you prove,
That wyf is mannes helpe and his confort,	That wife is man's help and his comfort,
His paradys terrestre, and his disport.	His earthly paradise, and his source of consolation.
So buxom and so vertuous is she,	So obedient and so virtuous is she,
They moste nedes lyve in unitee.	They must necessarily live in unity.
O flessh they been, and o fleesh, as I gesse,	One flesh they are, and one flesh, as I guess,
Hath but oon herte, in wele and in distresse.	Has but one heart, in prosperity and in distress.
A wyf! a, Seinte Marie, benedicite!	A wife! A, Saint Mary, bless me!
How myghte a man han any adversitee	How could a man have any adversity
That hath a wyf? Certes, I kan nat seye.	That has a wife? Certainly, I can not say.
The blisse which that is bitwixe hem tweye	The bliss that is betwixt them two
Ther may no tonge telle, or herte thynke.	There can no tongue tell, nor heart think.
If he be povre, she helpeth hym to swynke;	If he be poor, she helps him to work;
She kepeth his good, and wasteth never a deel;	She keeps his goods, and wastes not a bit;
Al that hire housbonde lust, hire liketh weel;	All that her husband desires, well pleases her;
She seith nat ones "nay," whan he seith "ye."	She says not once "nay," when he says "yea."
"Do this," seith he; "Al redy, sire," seith she.	"Do this," says he; "All ready, sir," says she.
O blisful ordre of wedlok precious,	O blissful order of wedlock precious,
Thou art so murye, and eek so vertuous,	Thou art so merry, and also so virtuous,
And so commended and appreved eek	And so commended and approved also
That every man that halt hym worth a leek	That every man that considers himself worth a leek
Upon his bare knees oughte al his lyf	Upon his bare knees ought all his life
Thanken his God that hym hath sent a wyf,	To thank his God that has sent him a wife,
Or elles preye to God hym for to sende	Or else pray to God to send him
A wyf to laste unto his lyves ende.	A wife to last unto his life's end.
For thanne his lyf is set in sikernesse;	For then his life is set in security;
He may nat be deceyved, as I gesse,	He may not be deceived, as I guess,
So that he werke after his wyves reed.	Providing that he work according to his wife's advice.
Thanne may he boldely beren up his heed,	Then may he boldly bear up his head,
They been so trewe and therwithal so wyse;	They are so true and therewithal so wise;
For which, if thou wolt werken as the wyse,	For which, if thou will act like a wise man,
Do alwey so as wommen wol thee rede.	Do always as women will advise thee.
Lo, how that Jacob, as thise clerkes rede,	Lo, how Jacob, as these clerks tell,
By good conseil of his mooder Rebekke,	By good counsel of his mother Rebecca,
Boond the kydes skyn aboute his nekke,	Bound the kid's skin about his neck,
For which his fadres benyson he wan.	For which his father's blessing he won.
Lo Judith, as the storie eek telle kan,	Lo Judith, as the story also can tell,
By wys conseil she Goddes peple kepte,	By wise counsel she God's people kept,
And slow hym Olofernus, whil he slepte.	And slew that Holofernes, while he slept.
Lo Abigayl, by good conseil how she	Lo Abigail, by good counsel how she
Saved hir housbonde Nabal whan that he	Saved her husband Nabal when he
Sholde han be slayn; and looke, Ester also	Should have been slain; and look, Esther also
By good conseil delyvered out of wo	By good counsel delivered out of woe
The peple of God, and made hym Mardochee	The people of God, and made that same Mordecai
Of Assuere enhaunced for to be.	To be exalted by Ahasuerus.
Ther nys no thyng in gree superlatyf,	There is no thing superior (in degree of virtue),
As seith Senek, above an humble wyf.	As says Seneca, above a humble wife.
Suffre thy wyves tonge, as Catoun bit;	Submit to thy wife's tongue, as Cato bids;
She shal comande, and thou shalt suffren it,	She shall command, and thou shalt submit to it,
And yet she wole obeye of curteisye.	And yet she will (seem to) obey by way of courtesy.
A wyf is kepere of thyn housbondrye;	A wife is keeper of thy household;
Wel may the sike man biwaille and wepe,	Well may the sick man bewail and weep,
Ther as ther nys no wyf the hous to kepe.	Where there is no wife to keep the house.
I warne thee, if wisely thou wolt wirche,	I warn thee, if wisely thou wilt act,
Love wel thy wyf, as Crist loved his chirche.	Love well thy wife, as Christ loved his church.
If thou lovest thyself, thou lovest thy wyf;	If thou lovest thyself, thou lovest thy wife;
No man hateth his flessh, but in his lyf	No man hates his flesh, but in his life
He fostreth it, and therfore bidde I thee	He nurtures it, and therefore I bid thee
Cherisse thy wyf, or thou shalt nevere thee.	Cherish thy wife, or thou shalt never prosper.
Housbonde and wyf, what so men jape or pleye,	Husband and wife, however much men may jest or play,
Of worldly folk holden the siker weye;	Of worldly folk hold the secure way;
They been so knyt ther may noon harm bityde,	They are so knit together no harm can there befall,
And namely upon the wyves syde.	And especially upon the wife's side.
For which this Januarie, of whom I tolde,	For which this January, of whom I told,
Considered hath, inwith his dayes olde,	Considered has, in his old age,
The lusty lyf, the vertuous quyete,	The pleasing life, the virtuous quiet,
That is in mariage hony-sweete,	That is in honey-sweet marriage,
And for his freendes on a day he sente,	And for his friends on a day he sent,
To tellen hem th' effect of his entente.	To tell them the substance of his intention.
With face sad his tale he hath hem toold.	With serious face his tale he has them told.
He seyde, "Freendes, I am hoor and oold,	He said, "Friends, I am white-haired and old,
And almoost, God woot, on my pittes brynke;	And almost, God knows, on my grave's brink;
Upon my soule somwhat moste I thynke.	Upon my soul somewhat must I think.
I have my body folily despended;	I have my body foolishly wasted;
Blessed be God that it shal been amended!	Blessed be God that it shall be amended!
For I wol be, certeyn, a wedded man,	For I will be, certainly, a wedded man,
And that anoon in al the haste I kan.	And that at once in all the haste I can (do it).
Unto som mayde fair and tendre of age,	Unto some maid fair and tender of age,
I prey yow, shapeth for my mariage	I pray yow, prepare for my marriage
Al sodeynly, for I wol nat abyde;	Right away, for I will not delay;
And I wol fonde t' espien, on my syde,	And I will attempt to discover, on my side,
To whom I may be wedded hastily.	To whom I may be wedded hastily.
But forasmuche as ye been mo than I,	But forasmuch as you are more than I,
Ye shullen rather swich a thyng espyen	You shall rather such a thing discover
Than I, and where me best were to allyen.	Than I, and where it would be best to ally myself (marry).
"But o thyng warne I yow, my freendes deere,	"But one thing warn I you, my friends dear,
I wol noon oold wyf han in no manere.	I will no old wife have in any way.
She shal nat passe twenty yeer, certayn;	She shall not pass twenty years, certainly;
Oold fissh and yong flessh wolde I have fayn.	Old fish and young flesh would I gladly have.
Bet is," quod he, "a pyk than a pykerel,	Better is," said he, "a pike than a pickerel (young pike),
And bet than old boef is the tendre veel.	And better than old beef is the tender veal.
I wol no womman thritty yeer of age;	I want no woman thirty years of age;
It is but bene-straw and greet forage.	It is but dry bean-stalks and coarse fodder.
And eek thise olde wydwes, God it woot,	And also these old widows, God it knows,
They konne so muchel craft on Wades boot,	They know so much trickery on Wade's boat,
So muchel broken harm, whan that hem leste,	Do so much harm, when they please,
That with hem sholde I nevere lyve in reste.	That with them should I never live in rest.
For sondry scoles maken sotile clerkis;	For various schools make clever clerks;
Womman of manye scoles half a clerk is.	A woman of many schools is half a clerk.
But certeynly, a yong thyng may men gye,	But certainly, one can guide a young thing,
Right as men may warm wex with handes plye.	Just as one can mold warm wax with hands.
Wherfore I sey yow pleynly, in a clause,	Therefore I tell you plainly, in brief,
I wol noon oold wyf han right for this cause.	I will no old wife have at all for this reason.
For if so were I hadde swich myschaunce	For if it so were that I had such bad luck
That I in hire ne koude han no plesaunce,	That I in her could have no pleasure,
Thanne sholde I lede my lyf in avoutrye	Then I should lead my life in adultery
And go streight to the devel whan I dye.	And go straight to the devil when I die.
Ne children sholde I none upon hire geten;	Nor any children should I upon her beget;
Yet were me levere houndes had me eten	Yet I would rather hounds had eaten me
Than that myn heritage sholde falle	Than that my heritage should fall
In straunge hand, and this I telle yow alle.	In a stranger's hand, and this I tell you all.
I dote nat; I woot the cause why	I am not in my dotage; I know the cause why
Men sholde wedde, and forthermoore woot I	One should wed, and furthermore know I
Ther speketh many a man of mariage	There speaks many a man of marriage
That woot namoore of it than woot my page	Who knows no more of it than my servant boy knows
For whiche causes man sholde take a wyf.	For which causes man should take a wife.
If he ne may nat lyven chaast his lyf,	If he can not live his life chastely,
Take hym a wyf with greet devocioun,	Let him take him a wife with great devotion,
By cause of leveful procreacioun	For the sake of lawful procreation
Of children to th' onour of God above,	Of children to the honor of God above,
And nat oonly for paramour or love;	And not only for sexual passion or love;
And for they sholde leccherye eschue,	And so that they should abstain from lechery,
And yelde hir dette whan that it is due;	And yield their marital debt when it is due;
Or for that ech of hem sholde helpen oother	Or so that each of them should help the other
In meschief, as a suster shal the brother,	In distress, as a sister shall the brother,
And lyve in chastitee ful holily.	And live in celibacy full piously.
But sires, by youre leve, that am nat I.	But sirs, by your leave, that am not I.
For -- God be thanked! -- I dar make avaunt	For -- God be thanked! -- I dare make boast
I feele my lymes stark and suffisaunt	I feel my limbs strong and sufficient
To do al that a man bilongeth to;	To do all that is proper to a man;
I woot myselven best what I may do.	I know myself best what I can do.
Though I be hoor, I fare as dooth a tree	Though I be white-haired, I fare as does a tree
That blosmeth er that fruyt ywoxen bee;	That blossoms before the fruit is grown;
And blosmy tree nys neither drye ne deed.	And a blossom-filled tree is neither dry nor dead.
I feele me nowhere hoor but on myn heed;	I feel me nowhere white-haired but on my head;
Myn herte and alle my lymes been as grene	My heart and all my limbs are as green
As laurer thurgh the yeer is for to sene.	As laurel through the year is to be seen.
And syn that ye han herd al myn entente,	And since you have heard all my intention,
I prey yow to my wyl ye wole assente."	I pray you to my will you will assent."
Diverse men diversely hym tolde	Diverse men diversely him told
Of mariage manye ensamples olde.	Of marriage many old examples.
Somme blamed it, somme preysed it, certeyn,	Somme blamed it, some praised it, certainly,
But atte laste, shortly for to seyn,	But at the last, shortly to say,
As al day falleth altercacioun	As every day altercation occurs
Bitwixen freendes in disputisoun,	Between friends in disputation,
Ther fil a stryf bitwixe his bretheren two,	There befell a strife betwixt his two brothers,
Of whiche that oon was cleped Placebo;	Of whom that one was called Placebo;
Justinus soothly called was that oother.	Justinus truly was called that other.
Placebo seyde, "O Januarie, brother,	Placebo said, "O January, brother,
Ful litel nede hadde ye, my lord so deere,	Full little need had you, my lord so dear,
Conseil to axe of any that is heere,	To ask counsel of any that is here,
But that ye been so ful of sapience	Except that you are so full of wisdom
That yow ne liketh, for youre heighe prudence,	That it does not please you, for your high prudence,
To weyven fro the word of Salomon.	To deviate from the word of Solomon.
This word seyde he unto us everychon:	This word said he unto us every one:
`Wirk alle thyng by conseil,' thus seyde he,	`Do everything according to good advice,' thus said he,
`And thanne shaltow nat repente thee.'	`And then shalt thou not repent.'
But though that Salomon spak swich a word,	But though Solomon spoke such a word,
Myn owene deere brother and my lord,	My own dear brother and my lord,
So wysly God my soule brynge at reste,	As surely as God my soul may bring to rest,
I holde youre owene conseil is the beste.	I hold your own counsel is the best.
For, brother myn, of me taak this motyf:	For, brother mine, of me take this advice:
I have now been a court-man al my lyf,	I have now been a courtier all my life,
And God it woot, though I unworthy be,	And God it knows, though I am unworthy,
I have stonden in ful greet degree	I have stood in very high degree
Abouten lordes of ful heigh estaat;	Among lords of very high rank;
Yet hadde I nevere with noon of hem debaat.	Yet had I never with any of them disagreement.
I nevere hem contraried, trewely;	I never contradicted them, truly;
I woot wel that my lord kan moore than I.	I know well that my lord knows more than I.
What that he seith, I holde it ferme and stable;	What he says, I consider it unshakably true;
I seye the same, or elles thyng semblable.	I say the same, or else something similar.
A ful greet fool is any conseillour	A full great fool is any counselor
That serveth any lord of heigh honour,	That serves any lord of high honor,
That dar presume, or elles thenken it,	That dares presume, or else think it,
That his conseil sholde passe his lordes wit.	That his counsel should surpass his lord's judgment.
Nay, lordes been no fooles, by my fay!	Nay, lords are no fools, by my faith!
Ye han youreselven shewed heer to-day	You have yourselves showed here to-day
So heigh sentence, so holily and weel,	Such high good judgment, so piously and well,
That I consente and conferme everydeel	That I consent and confirm every bit
Youre wordes alle and youre opinioun.	All your words and your opinion.
By God, ther nys no man in al this toun,	By God, there is no man in all this town,
Ne in Ytaille, that koude bet han sayd!	Nor in Italy, that could have spoken better!
Crist halt hym of this conseil ful wel apayd.	Christ considers himself by this counsel very well pleased.
And trewely, it is an heigh corage	And truly, it is a bold act
Of any man that stapen is in age	By any man that is advanced in age
To take a yong wyf; by my fader kyn,	To take a young wife; by my father's kin,
Youre herte hangeth on a joly pyn!	Your heart hangs on a jolly pin (is very merry)!
Dooth now in this matiere right as yow leste,	Do now in this matter exactly as you please,
For finally I holde it for the beste."	For finally I consider it for the best."
Justinus, that ay stille sat and herde,	Justinus, that always still sat and listened,
Right in this wise he to Placebo answerde:	Right in this manner he to Placebo answered:
"Now, brother myn, be pacient, I preye,	"Now, brother mine, be patient, I pray,
Syn ye han seyd, and herkneth what I seye.	Since you have spoken, and hear what I say.
Senek, amonges othere wordes wyse,	Seneca, amongst other words wise,
Seith that a man oghte hym right wel avyse	Says that a man ought very carefully consider
To whom he yeveth his lond or his catel.	To whom he gives his land or his moveable possessions.
And syn I oghte avyse me right wel	And since I ought to consider very carefully
To whom I yeve my good awey fro me,	To whom I give my goods away from me,
Wel muchel moore I oghte avysed be	Well much more I ought to consider
To whom I yeve my body for alwey.	To whom I give my body for always.
I warne yow wel, it is no childes pley	I warn you well, it is no child's play
To take a wyf withouten avysement.	To take a wife without deliberation.
Men moste enquere -- this is myn assent --	One must inquire -- this is my opinion --
Wher she be wys, or sobre, or dronkelewe,	Whether she be wise, or sober, or given to drink,
Or proud, or elles ootherweys a shrewe,	Or proud, or else otherwise a shrew,
A chidestere, or wastour of thy good,	A scold, or waster of thy goods,
Or riche, or poore, or elles mannyssh wood.	Or rich, or poor, or else man-crazy.
Al be it so that no man fynden shal	Although it is so that no man shall find
Noon in this world that trotteth hool in al,	Any in this world that is perfect in everything,
Ne man, ne beest, swich as men koude devyse;	No man, nor beast, such as men could imagine;
But nathelees it oghte ynough suffise	But nevertheless it ought enough suffice
With any wyf, if so were that she hadde	With any wife, (to learn) if it so were that she had
Mo goode thewes than hire vices badde;	More good personal qualities than her bad vices;
And al this axeth leyser for t' enquere.	And all this requires leisure to find out.
For, God it woot, I have wept many a teere	For, God it knows, I have wept many a tear
Ful pryvely, syn I have had a wyf.	Full privately, since I have had a wife.
Preyse whoso wole a wedded mannes lyf,	Praise whosoever will a wedded man's life,
Certein I fynde in it but cost and care	Certainly I find in it nothing but cost and care
And observances, of alle blisses bare.	And duties, of all blisses bare.
And yet, God woot, my neighebores aboute,	And yet, God knows, my neighbors about,
And namely of wommen many a route,	And especially many a crowd of women,
Seyn that I have the mooste stedefast wyf,	Say that I have the most steadfast wife,
And eek the mekeste oon that bereth lyf;	And also the meekest one that bears life;
But I woot best where wryngeth me my sho.	But I know best where my shoe pinches me.
Ye mowe, for me, right as yow liketh do;	You may, for me, do just as you like;
Avyseth yow -- ye been a man of age --	Consider -- you are a man of advanced age --
How that ye entren into mariage,	How that you enter into marriage,
And namely with a yong wyf and a fair.	And especially with a young wife and a fair.
By hym that made water, erthe, and air,	By him that made water, earth, and air,
The yongeste man that is in al this route	The youngest man that is in all this company
Is bisy ynough to bryngen it aboute	Is busy enough to bring it about
To han his wyf allone. Trusteth me,	To have his wife alone. Trust me,
Ye shul nat plesen hire fully yeres thre --	You shall not please her fully years three --
This is to seyn, to doon hire ful plesaunce.	This is to say, to do her full pleasure.
A wyf axeth ful many an observaunce.	A wife requires constant attention.
I prey yow that ye be nat yvele apayd."	I pray you that you be not displeased."
"Wel," quod this Januarie, "and hastow ysayd?	"Well," said this January, "and hast thou spoken?
Straw for thy Senek, and for thy proverbes!	Straw for thy Seneca, and for thy proverbs!
I counte nat a panyer ful of herbes	I would not give a bread basket full of herbs
Of scole-termes. Wyser men than thow,	For academic talk. Wiser men than thou,
As thou hast herd, assenteden right now	As thou hast heard, assented right now
To my purpos. Placebo, what sey ye?"	To my purpose. Placebo, what say you?"
"I seye it is a cursed man," quod he,	"I say it is a cursed man," said he,
"That letteth matrimoigne, sikerly."	"That hinders matrimony, certainly."
And with that word they rysen sodeynly,	And with that word they rise immediately,
And been assented fully that he sholde	And are agreed fully that he should
Be wedded whanne hym liste and where he wolde.	Be wedded when he pleased and where he would.
Heigh fantasye and curious bisynesse	Exaggerated imagination and constant thought
Fro day to day gan in the soule impresse	From day to day became fixed in the soul
Of Januarie aboute his mariage.	Of January concerning his marriage.
Many fair shap and many a fair visage	Many a fair shape and many a fair visage
Ther passeth thurgh his herte nyght by nyght,	There passes through his heart night after night,
As whoso tooke a mirour, polisshed bryght,	As if one took a mirror, polished bright,
And sette it in a commune market-place,	And set it in a common market-place,
Thanne sholde he se ful many a figure pace	Then should he see full many a figure pace
By his mirour; and in the same wyse	By his mirror; and in the same manner
Gan Januarie inwith his thoght devyse	Did January within his thought imagine
Of maydens whiche that dwelten hym bisyde.	About maidens which dwelt nearby him.
He wiste nat wher that he myghte abyde.	He knew not on which he might settle.
For if that oon have beaute in hir face,	For if that one have beauty in her face,
Another stant so in the peples grace	Another stands so in the people's good opinion
For hire sadnesse and hire benyngnytee	For her seriousness and her goodness
That of the peple grettest voys hath she;	That of the people greatest praise has she;
And somme were riche and hadden badde name.	And some were rich and had a bad reputation.
But nathelees, bitwixe ernest and game,	But nevertheless, between earnestness and joking (in every way),
He atte laste apoynted hym on oon,	He at the last decided upon one,
And leet alle othere from his herte goon,	And let all others from his heart go,
And chees hire of his owene auctoritee;	And chose her by his own authority;
For love is blynd alday, and may nat see.	For love is blind always, and can not see.
And whan that he was in his bed ybroght,	And when he was in his bed brought,
He purtreyed in his herte and in his thoght	He portrayed in his heart and in his thought
Hir fresshe beautee and hir age tendre,	Her fresh beauty and her tender age,
Hir myddel smal, hire armes longe and sklendre,	Her small waist, her arms long and slender,
Hir wise governaunce, hir gentillesse,	Her wise self-control, her nobility,
Hir wommanly berynge, and hire sadnesse.	Her womanly bearing, and her seriousness.
And whan that he on hire was condescended,	And when he on her had decided,
Hym thoughte his choys myghte nat ben amended.	He thought his choice could not be bettered.
For whan that he hymself concluded hadde,	For when he himself had decided,
Hym thoughte ech oother mannes wit so badde	He thought each other man's wit so bad
That inpossible it were to repplye	That it would be impossible to reply
Agayn his choys; this was his fantasye.	Against his choice; this was his fantasy.
His freendes sente he to, at his instaunce,	His friends sent he to, at his request,
And preyed hem to doon hym that plesaunce,	And prayed them to do him that pleasure,
That hastily they wolden to hym come;	That hastily they would come to him;
He wolde abregge hir labour, alle and some.	He would abridge their labor, one and all.
Nedeth namoore for hym to go ne ryde;	He needs no more to travel about;
He was apoynted ther he wolde abyde.	He had decided on whom he would settle.
Placebo cam, and eek his freendes soone,	Placebo came, and also his friends quickly,
And alderfirst he bad hem alle a boone,	And first of all he asked them all a favor,
That noon of hem none argumentes make	That none of them make any arguments
Agayn the purpos which that he hath take,	Against the purpose which he has taken,
Which purpos was plesant to God, seyde he,	Which purpose was pleasing to God, said he,
And verray ground of his prosperitee.	And true ground of his prosperity.
He seyde ther was a mayden in the toun,	He said there was a maiden in the town,
Which that of beautee hadde greet renoun,	Who for beauty had great renown,
Al were it so she were of smal degree;	Even though she was of low rank;
Suffiseth hym hir yowthe and hir beautee.	Her youth and her beauty are enough for him .
Which mayde, he seyde, he wolde han to his wyf,	Which maid, he said, he would have as his wife,
To lede in ese and hoolynesse his lyf;	To lead in ease and holiness his life;
And thanked God that he myghte han hire al,	And thanked God that he might have her entirely,
That no wight his blisse parten shal.	So that no one shall share his bliss.
And preyed hem to laboure in this nede,	And prayed them to labor in this need,
And shapen that he faille nat to spede;	And arrange that he fail not to succeed;
For thanne, he seyde, his spirit was at ese.	For then, he said, his spirit was at ease.
"Thanne is," quod he, "no thyng may me displese,	"Then there is," said he, "nothing that can displease me,
Save o thyng priketh in my conscience,	Save one thing sticks in my conscience,
The which I wol reherce in youre presence.	Which I will tell in your presence.
"I have," quod he, "herd seyd, ful yoore ago,	"I have," said he, "heard said, full long ago,
Ther may no man han parfite blisses two --	There can no man have perfect blisses two --
This is to seye, in erthe and eek in hevene.	This is to say, in earth and also in heaven.
For though he kepe hym fro the synnes sevene,	For though he keep him from the seven sins,
And eek from every branche of thilke tree,	And also from every branch of that same tree (of sin),
Yet is ther so parfit felicitee	Yet is there such perfect felicity
And so greet ese and lust in mariage	And such great ease and pleasure in marriage
That evere I am agast now in myn age	That ever I am frightened now in my old age
That I shal lede now so myrie a lyf,	That I shall lead now so merry a life,
So delicat, withouten wo and stryf,	So pleasing, without woe and strife,
That I shal have myn hevene in erthe heere.	That I shall have my heaven here in earth.
For sith that verray hevene is boght so deere	For since that true heaven is bought so dear
With tribulacion and greet penaunce,	With tribulation and great penance,
How sholde I thanne, that lyve in swich plesaunce	How should I then, who live in such pleasure
As alle wedded men doon with hire wyvys,	As all wedded men do with her wives,
Come to the blisse ther Crist eterne on lyve ys?	Come to the bliss where Christ eternally lives?
This is my drede, and ye, my bretheren tweye,	This is my dread, and you, my brethren two,
Assoilleth me this question, I preye."	Resolve this problem, I pray."
Justinus, which that hated his folye,	Justinus, who hated his folly,
Answerde anon right in his japerye;	Answered straight away in his mockery;
And for he wolde his longe tale abregge,	And because he would his long tale abridge,
He wolde noon auctoritee allegge,	He would cite no authority,
But seyde, "Sire, so ther be noon obstacle	But said, "Sir, providing there be no obstacle
Oother than this, God of his hygh myracle	Other than this, God by his high miracle
And of his mercy may so for yow wirche	And of his mercy may so for you work
That, er ye have youre right of hooly chirche,	That, before you have your rite of holy church (last sacrament),
Ye may repente of wedded mannes lyf,	You may repent of the wedded man's life,
In which ye seyn ther is no wo ne stryf.	In which you say there is no woe nor strife.
And elles, God forbede but he sente	And else, God forbid that he should not send
A wedded man hym grace to repente	A wedded man grace to repent himself
Wel ofte rather than a sengle man!	Well more often than a single man!
And therfore, sire -- the beste reed I kan --	And therefore, sir -- the best advice I know --
Dispeire yow noght, but have in youre memorie,	Despair you not, but have in your memory,
Paraunter she may be youre purgatorie!	Perhaps she may be your purgatory!
She may be Goddes meene and Goddes whippe;	She may be God's instrument and God's whip;
Thanne shal youre soule up to hevene skippe	Then shall your soul up to heaven skip
Swifter than dooth an arwe out of a bowe.	Swifter than does an arrow out of a bow.
I hope to God, herafter shul ye knowe	I hope to God, hereafter shall you know
That ther nys no so greet felicitee	That there is not so great felicity
In mariage, ne nevere mo shal bee,	In marriage, nor never more shall be,
That yow shal lette of youre savacion,	That shall keep you from your salvation,
So that ye use, as skile is and reson,	Providing that you use, as is proper and reasonable,
The lustes of youre wyf attemprely,	The pleasures of your wife moderately,
And that ye plese hire nat to amorously,	And that you please her not too amorously,
And that ye kepe yow eek from oother synne.	And that you keep yourself also from other sin.
My tale is doon, for my wit is thynne.	My tale is done, for my wit is thin.
Beth nat agast herof, my brother deere,	Be not afraid of this, my brother dear,
But lat us waden out of this mateere.	But let us wade out of this matter.
The Wyf of Bathe, if ye han understonde,	The Wife of Bath, if you have understood her,
Of mariage, which we have on honde,	Of marriage, which we have in hand,
Declared hath ful wel in litel space.	Declared has full well in little space.
Fareth now wel. God have yow in his grace."	Now farewell. God have you in his grace."
And with this word this Justyn and his brother	And with this word this Justin and his brother
Han take hir leve, and ech of hem of oother.	Have taken their leave, and each of them of other.
For whan they saughe that it moste nedes be,	For when they saw that it must necessarily be,
They wroghten so, by sly and wys tretee,	They worked so, by sly and wise negotiation,
That she, this mayden which that Mayus highte,	That she, this maiden who May was called,
As hastily as evere that she myghte	As hastily as ever that she might
Shal wedded be unto this Januarie.	Shall wedded be unto this January.
I trowe it were to longe yow to tarie,	I believe it would be too long to delay you,
If I yow tolde of every scrit and bond	If I told you of every legal document and bond
By which that she was feffed in his lond,	By which she was endowed with his land,
Or for to herknen of hir riche array.	Or to hear of her rich array.
But finally ycomen is the day	But finally the day is come
That to the chirche bothe be they went	That to the church both are they went

Forth comth the preest, with stole aboute his nekke,	Forth comes the priest, with stole about his neck,
And bad hire be lyk Sarra and Rebekke	And commanded her to be like Sarah and Rebecca
In wysdom and in trouthe of mariage;	In wisdom and in faithfulness of marriage;
And seyde his orisons, as is usage,	And said his prayers, as is the usage,
And croucheth hem, and bad God sholde hem blesse,	And makes the sign of the cross over them, and prayed God should them bless,
And made al siker ynogh with hoolynesse.	And made all secure enough with holiness.
Thus been they wedded with solempnitee,	Thus are they wedded with solemnity,
And at the feeste sitteth he and she	And at the feast sits he and she
With othere worthy folk upon the deys.	With other worthy folk upon the dais.
Al ful of joye and blisse is the paleys,	All full of joy and bliss is the palace,
And ful of instrumentz and of vitaille,	And full of instruments and of foods,
The mooste deyntevous of al Ytaille.	The most delicious of all Italy.
Biforn hem stoode instrumentz of swich soun	Before them stood instruments of such sound
That Orpheus, ne of Thebes Amphioun,	That Orpheus, nor Amphioun of Thebes,
Ne maden nevere swich a melodye.	Made never such a melody.
At every cours thanne cam loud mynstralcye	At every course then came loud minstrelsy
That nevere tromped Joab for to heere,	That never trumpeted Joab to be heard,
Nor he Theodomas, yet half so cleere	Nor that Theodomas, yet half so clear
At Thebes whan the citee was in doute.	At Thebes when the city was in danger.
Bacus the wyn hem shynketh al aboute,	Bacchus pours them the wine all around,
And Venus laugheth upon every wight,	And Venus laughs upon every person,
For Januarie was bicome hir knyght	For January had become her knight
And wolde bothe assayen his corage	And would test his spirit both
In libertee, and eek in mariage;	In liberty, and also in marriage;
And with hire fyrbrond in hire hand aboute	And with her torch in her hand about
Daunceth biforn the bryde and al the route.	Dances before the bride and all the company.
And certeinly, I dar right wel seyn this,	And certainly, I dare right well say this,
Ymeneus, that god of weddyng is,	Hymen, that god of wedding is,
Saugh nevere his lyf so myrie a wedded man.	Saw never in his life so merry a wedded man.
Hoold thou thy pees, thou poete Marcian,	Hold thou thy peace, thou poet Martianus Capella,
That writest us that ilke weddyng murie	Who writes for us that same wedding merry
Of hire Philologie and hym Mercurie,	Of her, Philology, and him, Mercury,
And of the songes that the Muses songe!	And of the songs that the Muses sang!
To smal is bothe thy penne, and eek thy tonge,	Too small is both thy pen, and also thy tongue,
For to descryven of this mariage.	To describe this marriage.
Whan tendre youthe hath wedded stoupyng age,	When tender youth has wedded stooping age,
Ther is swich myrthe that it may nat be writen.	There is such mirth that it can not be written.
Assayeth it youreself; thanne may ye witen	Try it yourself; then can you know
If that I lye or noon in this matiere.	If I lie or not in this matter.
Mayus, that sit with so benyngne a chiere,	May, that sits with so benign a manner,
Hire to biholde it semed fayerye.	Her to behold it seemed an enchantment.
Queene Ester looked nevere with swich an ye	Queen Esther looked never with such an eye
On Assuer, so meke a look hath she.	On Ahasuerus, so meek a look has she.
I may yow nat devyse al hir beautee.	I can not describe to you all her beauty.
But thus muche of hire beautee telle I may,	But thus much of her beauty tell I can,
That she was lyk the brighte morwe of May,	That she was like the bright morning of May,
Fulfild of alle beautee and plesaunce.	Filled with all beauty and delight.
This Januarie is ravysshed in a traunce	This January is ravished in a trance
At every tyme he looked on hir face;	At every time he looked on her face;
But in his herte he gan hire to manace	But in his heart he began to menace her
That he that nyght in armes wolde hire streyne	That he that night in arms would her strain
Harder than evere Parys dide Eleyne.	Harder than ever Paris did Helen of Troy.
But nathelees yet hadde he greet pitee	But nevertheless yet had he great pity
That thilke nyght offenden hire moste he,	That that same night he must offend her,
And thoughte, "Allas! O tendre creature,	And thought, "Alas! O tender creature,
Now wolde God ye myghte wel endure	Now would God you might well endure

I am agast ye shul it nat susteene.	I am afraid you shall not be able to endure it.
But God forbede that I dide al my myght!	But God forbid that I did all my might!
Now wolde God that it were woxen nyght,	Now would God that it were become night,
And that the nyght wolde lasten everemo.	And that the night would last evermore.
I wolde that al this peple were ago."	I would that all this people were gone."
And finally he dooth al his labour,	And finally he takes all possible pains,

The tyme cam that resoun was to ryse;	The time came that it was reasonable to rise;
And after that men daunce and drynken faste,	And after that men dance and drink deeply,
And spices al aboute the hous they caste,	And spiced cakes all about the house they passed,
And ful of joye and blisse is every man --	And full of joy and bliss is every man --
Al but a squyer, highte Damyan,	All but a squire, called Damian,
Which carf biforn the knyght ful many a day.	Who carved before the knight full many a day.
He was so ravysshed on his lady May	He was so ravished on his lady May
That for the verray peyne he was ny wood.	That for the very pain he was nearly crazy.
Almoost he swelte and swowned ther he stood,	Almost he fainted and swooned where he stood,

Namoore of hym at this tyme speke I,	No more of him at this time speak I,
But there I lete hym wepe ynogh and pleyne	But there I let him weep enough and complain
Til fresshe May wol rewen on his peyne.	Until fresh May will rue on his pain.
O perilous fyr, that in the bedstraw bredeth!	O perilous fire, that in the bedstraw breeds!
O famulier foo, that his servyce bedeth!	O enemy in one's household, that offers his service!
O servant traytour, false hoomly hewe,	O servant traitor, false domestic servant,
Lyk to the naddre in bosom sly untrewe,	Like to the sly untrue adder in one's bosom,
God shilde us alle from youre aqueyntaunce!	God protect us all from your acquaintance!
O Januarie, dronken in plesaunce	O January, drunk with pleasure
In mariage, se how thy Damyan,	In marriage, see how thy Damian,
Thyn owene squier and thy borne man,	Thine own squire and thy servant from birth,
Entendeth for to do thee vileynye.	Intends to do thee villainy.
God graunte thee thyn hoomly fo t' espye!	God grant thee thy foe in thy household to espy!
For in this world nys worse pestilence	For in this world is no worse pestilence
Than hoomly foo al day in thy presence.	Than a foe in thy household always in thy presence.
Parfourned hath the sonne his ark diurne;	The sun has completed his daily journey;
No lenger may the body of hym sojurne	No longer can its body sojourn
On th' orisonte, as in that latitude.	On the horizon, in that latitude.
Night with his mantel, that is derk and rude,	Night with its mantle, that is dark and rude,

For which departed is this lusty route	For which departed is this cheerful crowd

Hoom to hir houses lustily they ryde,	Home to their houses cheerfully they ride,
Where as they doon hir thynges as hem leste,	Where they attend to their affairs as they pleased
And whan they sye hir tyme, goon to reste.	And when they see their time, go to rest.
Soone after that, this hastif Januarie	Soon after that, this hasty January

He drynketh ypocras, clarree, and vernage	He drinks mulled wine, claret, and strong white wine

And many a letuarie hath he ful fyn,	And many a very fine aphrodisiac has he,
Swiche as the cursed monk, daun Constantyn,	Such as the cursed monk, Dan Constantine,
Hath writen in his book De Coitu;	Has written in his book "Concerning Intercourse";
To eten hem alle he nas no thyng eschu.	To eat them all he was not at all averse.
And to his privee freendes thus seyde he:	And to his private friends thus said he:
"For Goddes love, as soone as it may be,	"For God's love, as soon as it can be done,
Lat voyden al this hous in curteys wyse."	Have all this house emptied in courteous manner."
And they han doon right as he wol devyse.	And they have done right as he will command.
Men drynken and the travers drawe anon.	Men drink and draw the curtain (dividing the room) straightway.

His fresshe May, his paradys, his make.	His fresh May, his paradise, his mate.

Er tyme come that I wil doun descende.	Before the time comes that I will down descend.
But nathelees, considereth this," quod he,	But nevertheless, consider this," said he,

That may bothe werke wel and hastily;	That can work both well and hastily;
This wol be doon at leyser parfitly.	This will be done at leisure perfectly.
It is no fors how longe that we pleye;	It does not matter how long we play;
In trewe wedlok coupled be we tweye,	In true wedlock we two are coupled,
And blessed be the yok that we been inne,	And blessed be the yoke that we are in,

The slakke skyn aboute his nekke shaketh	The slack skin about his neck shakes

But God woot what that May thoughte in hir herte,	But God knows what May thought in her heart,

And afterward, whan that he saugh his tyme,	And afterwards, when he saw his time,

Heeld hire chambre unto the fourthe day,	Held her chamber until the fourth day,
As usage is of wyves for the beste.	As is the best usage of wives.
For every labour somtyme moot han reste,	For every labor sometime must have rest,
Or elles longe may he nat endure;	Or else long can he not endure;
This is to seyn, no lyves creature,	This is to say, no living creature,
Be it of fyssh, or bryd, or beest, or man.	Be it of fish, or bird, or beast, or man.

Andswere to my demaunde, as in this cas.	Answer to my question, in this case.
How shaltow to thy lady, fresshe May,	How shalt thou to thy lady, fresh May,

This sike Damyan in Venus fyr	This sick Damian in Venus' fire

He taketh hire, and kisseth hire ful ofte,	He takes her, and kisses her full often,
And leyde hym doun to slepe, and that anon.	And laid him down to sleep, and that straightway.
She feyned hire as that she moste gon	She pretended that she must go
Ther as ye woot that every wight moot neede;	Where you know that every person must go by necessity;
And whan she of this bille hath taken heede,	And when she of this letter has taken heed,
She rente it al to cloutes atte laste,	She tore it all to pieces at the last,
And in the pryvee softely it caste.	And in the privy softly threw it.
Who studieth now but faire fresshe May?	Who is perplexed now but fair fresh May?
Adoun by olde Januarie she lay,	Down by old January she lay,
That sleep til that the coughe hath hym awaked.	Who slept until the cough has him awaked.
Anon he preyde hire strepen hire al naked;	Straightway he prayed her to strip herself all naked;
He wolde of hire, he seyde, han som plesaunce;	He would of her, he said, have some pleasure;
He seyde hir clothes dide hym encombraunce,	He said her clothes got in his way,
And she obeyeth, be hire lief or looth.	And she obeys, whether she wants to or not.
But lest that precious folk be with me wrooth,	But lest that prudish folk be with me wroth,
How that he wroghte, I dar nat to yow telle,	How he worked, I dare not tell to you,
Or wheither hire thoughte it paradys or helle.	Or whether she thought it paradise or hell.
But heere I lete hem werken in hir wyse	But here I let them work in their way
Til evensong rong and that they moste aryse.	Until bell for evening prayers rang and they had to arise.
Were it by destynee or by aventure,	Were it by destiny or by chance,
Were it by influence or by nature,	Were it by astronomical influence or by nature,
Or constellacion, that in swich estaat	Or configuration of the stars, that in such a state
The hevene stood that tyme fortunaat	The heaven stood that time that it fortunate
Was for to putte a bille of Venus werkes --	Was to present a petition concerning Venus' works --
For alle thyng hath tyme, as seyn thise clerkes --	For every thing has time, as say these clerks --
To any womman for to gete hire love,	To any woman to get her love,
I kan nat seye; but grete God above,	I can not say; but great God above,
That knoweth that noon act is causelees,	That knows that no act is without cause,
He deme of al, for I wole holde my pees.	May he judge of all, for I will hold my peace.
But sooth is this, how that this fresshe May	But truth is this, how this fresh May
Hath take swich impression that day	Has taken such impression that day
Of pitee of this sike Damyan	Of pity for this sick Damian
That from hire herte she ne dryve kan	That from her heart she can not drive
The remembrance for to doon hym ese.	The thought to comfort him.
"Certeyn," thoghte she, "whom that this thyng displese	"Certainly," thought she, "whomever this thing may displease

To love hym best of any creature,	To love him best of any creature,
Though he namoore hadde than his sherte."	Though he had no more than his shirt."
Lo, pitee renneth soone in gentil herte!	Lo, pity runs soon in gentle heart!
Heere may ye se how excellent franchise	Here can you see what excellent generosity
In wommen is, whan they hem narwe avyse.	In women is, when they carefully deliberate a matter.
Som tyrant is, as ther be many oon	Some tyrant is, as there be many a one
That hath an herte as hard as any stoon,	Who has a heart as hard as any stone,
Which wolde han lat hym sterven in the place	Who would have let him die in the place
Wel rather than han graunted hym hire grace,	Well rather than have granted him her grace,
And hem rejoysen in hire crueel pryde,	And rejoice in her cruel pride,
And rekke nat to been an homycide.	And care not to be a homicide.
This gentil May, fulfilled of pitee,	This gentle May, filled full of pity,
Right of hire hand a lettre made she,	In her own hand a letter made she,
In which she graunteth hym hire verray grace.	In which she grants him her true grace.
Ther lakketh noght oonly but day and place	There lacks nothing but only day and place
Wher that she myghte unto his lust suffise,	Where she might satisfy his desires,
For it shal be right as he wole devyse.	For it shall be right as he will devise.
And whan she saugh hir tyme, upon a day	And when she saw her time, upon one day
To visite this Damyan gooth May,	To visit this Damian goes May,
And sotilly this lettre doun she threste	And craftily this letter down she thrust
Under his pilwe; rede it if hym leste.	Under his pillow; let him read it if he wishes.
She taketh hym by the hand and harde hym twiste	She takes him by the hand and hard him squeezes
So secrely that no wight of it wiste,	So secretly that no one knew of it,
And bad hym been al hool, and forth she wente	And bade him be all healthy, and forth she went
To Januarie, whan that he for hire sente.	To January, when he for her sent.
Up riseth Damyan the nexte morwe;	Up rises Damian the next morning;
Al passed was his siknesse and his sorwe.	All passed was his sickness and his sorrow.
He kembeth hym, he preyneth hym and pyketh,	He combs himself, he preens and neatens himself,
He dooth al that his lady lust and lyketh,	He does all that his lady desires and pleases,
And eek to Januarie he gooth as lowe	And also to January he goes as humbly
As evere dide a dogge for the bowe.	As ever did a dog trained to hunt with an archer.
He is so plesant unto every man	He is so pleasant unto every man
(For craft is al, whoso that do it kan)	(For craft is all, whoever can do it)
That every wight is fayn to speke hym good,	That every one is eager to speak good of him,
And fully in his lady grace he stood.	And fully in his lady's favor he stood.
Thus lete I Damyan aboute his nede,	Thus leave I Damian going about his business,
And in my tale forth I wol procede.	And in my tale forth I will proceed.
Somme clerkes holden that felicitee	Some clerks maintain that felicity
Stant in delit, and therfore certeyn he,	Consists of delight, and therefore certainly he,
This noble Januarie, with al his myght,	This noble January, with all his might,
In honest wyse, as longeth to a knyght,	In a respectable manner, as is suitable to a knight,
Shoop hym to lyve ful deliciously.	Arranged for himself to live full voluptuously.
His housynge, his array, as honestly	His lodging, his clothing, as suitably
To his degree was maked as a kynges.	To his degree was made as is a king's.
Amonges othere of his honeste thynges,	Amongst others of his suitable things,
He made a gardyn, walled al with stoon;	He made a garden, walled all with stone;
So fair a gardyn woot I nowher noon.	So fair a garden know I anywhere none.
For, out of doute, I verraily suppose	For, beyond doubt, I truly suppose
That he that wroot the Romance of the Rose	That he who wrote the Romance of the Rose
Ne koude of it the beautee wel devyse;	Could not the beauty of it well describe;
Ne Priapus ne myghte nat suffise,	Nor Priapus could not be adequate,
Though he be god of gardyns, for to telle	Though he be god of gardens, to tell
The beautee of the gardyn and the welle	The beauty of the garden and the well
That stood under a laurer alwey grene.	That stood under a laurel always green.
Ful ofte tyme he Pluto and his queene,	Very often he, Pluto, and his queen,
Proserpina, and al hire fayerye,	Proserpine, and all their fairies,
Disporten hem and maken melodye	Amused themselves and made melody
Aboute that welle, and daunced, as men tolde.	About that well, and danced, as men told.
This noble knyght, this Januarie the olde,	This noble knight, this January the old,
Swich deyntee hath in it to walke and pleye,	Such pleasure has in it to walk and play,
That he wol no wight suffren bere the keye	That he will no one allow to bear the key
Save he hymself; for of the smale wyket	Save he himself; for of the small gate
He baar alwey of silver a clyket,	He bore always of silver a latchkey,
With which, whan that hym leste, he it unshette.	With which, when he desired, he unlocked it.
And whan he wolde paye his wyf hir dette	And when he would pay his wife her marital debt

And May his wyf, and no wight but they two;	And May his wife, and no one but those two;
And thynges whiche that were nat doon abedde,	And things which that were not done abed,
He in the gardyn parfourned hem and spedde.	He in the garden performed and accomplished them.
And in this wyse, many a murye day,	And in this way, many a merry day,
Lyved this Januarie and fresshe May.	Lived this January and fresh May.
But worldly joye may nat alwey dure	But worldly joy can not always endure
To Januarie, ne to no creature.	To January, nor to any creature.
O sodeyn hap! O thou Fortune unstable!	O sudden chance! O thou Fortune unstable!
Lyk to the scorpion so deceyvable,	Similar to the scorpion so deceitful,
That flaterest with thyn heed whan thou wolt stynge;	That flatter with thy head when thou wilt sting;
Thy tayl is deeth, thurgh thyn envenymynge.	Thy tail is death, through thy poisoning.
O brotil joye! O sweete venym queynte!	O brittle joy! O sweet venom deceitful!
O monstre, that so subtilly kanst peynte	O monster, that so subtly can disguise
Thy yiftes under hewe of stidefastnesse,	Thy gifts under appearance of steadfastness,
That thou deceyvest bothe moore and lesse!	That thou deceivest both high and low (everyone)!
Why hastow Januarie thus deceyved,	Why hast thou January thus deceived,
That haddest hym for thy fulle freend receyved?	Thou who had received him for thy closest friend ?
And now thou hast biraft hym bothe his yen,	And now thou hast deprived him of both his eyes,
For sorwe of which desireth he to dyen.	For sorrow of which he desires to die.
Allas, this noble Januarie free,	Alas, this noble generous January,
Amydde his lust and his prosperitee,	Amid his pleasure and his prosperity,
Is woxen blynd, and that al sodeynly.	Is grown blind, and that all suddenly.
He wepeth and he wayleth pitously;	He weeps and he wails pitifully;
And therwithal the fyr of jalousie,	And with all this the fire of jealousy,
Lest that his wyf sholde falle in som folye,	Lest that his wife should fall in some folly,
So brente his herte that he wolde fayn	So burned his heart that he sincerely wished
That som man bothe hire and hym had slayn.	That some man both her and him had slain.
For neither after his deeth nor in his lyf	For neither after his death nor in his life
Ne wolde he that she were love ne wyf,	Would he that she were neither lover nor wife,
But evere lyve as wydwe in clothes blake,	But ever live as widow in clothes black,
Soul as the turtle that lost hath hire make.	Solitary as the turtledove that lost has her mate.
But atte laste, after a month or tweye,	But at the last, after a month or two,
His sorwe gan aswage, sooth to seye;	His sorrow abated, truth to say;
For whan he wiste it may noon oother be,	For when he knew it can not be otherwise,
He paciently took his adversitee,	He patiently accepted his adversity,
Save, out of doute, he may nat forgoon	Except that, no doubt, he can not refrain

Which jalousye it was so outrageous	Which jealousy was so excessive

Ne in noon oother place, neverthemo,	Nor in any other place, no longer,
He nolde suffre hire for to ryde or go,	He would suffer her to ride or walk,
But if that he had hond on hire alway;	Unless he had a hand always on her;
For which ful ofte wepeth fresshe May,	For which full often weeps fresh May,
That loveth Damyan so benyngnely	Who loves Damian so graciously

Or elles she moot han hym as hir leste.	Or else she must have him as she wishes.
She wayteth whan hir herte wolde breste.	She expects that her heart would burst.
Upon that oother syde Damyan	Upon that other side Damian
Bicomen is the sorwefulleste man	Is become the most sorrowful man
That evere was, for neither nyght ne day	That ever was, for neither night nor day
Ne myghte he speke a word to fresshe May,	Could he speak one word to fresh May,
As to his purpos, of no swich mateere,	Regarding his purpose, of any such matter,
But if that Januarie moste it heere,	Without January's hearing it,
That hadde an hand upon hire everemo.	Who had a hand upon her always.
But nathelees, by writyng to and fro	But nevertheless, by writing to and fro
And privee signes wiste he what she mente,	And secret signs he knew what she meant,
And she knew eek the fyn of his entente.	And she knew also the aim of his plan.
O Januarie, what myghte it thee availle,	O January, what might it thee avail,
Thogh thou myghtest se as fer as shippes saille?	Though thou could see as far as ships sail?
For as good is blynd deceyved be	For it is as good to be deceived when blind
As to be deceyved whan a man may se.	As to be deceived when a man can see.
Lo, Argus, which that hadde an hondred yen,	Lo, Argus, who had a hundred eyes,
For al that evere he koude poure or pryen,	For all that ever he could peer or pry,
Yet was he blent, and, God woot, so been mo	Yet was he deceived, and, God knows, so are others
That wenen wisly that it be nat so.	That confidently suppose indeed that it is not so.
Passe over is an ese, I sey namoore.	To overlook (trouble) is an advantage, I say no more.
This fresshe May, that I spak of so yoore,	This fresh May, whom I spoke of formerly,
In warm wex hath emprented the clyket	In warm wax has made an impression of the latchkey

By which into his gardyn ofte he wente;	By which into his garden often he went;
And Damyan, that knew al hire entente,	And Damian, who knew all her plan,
