Ther nys namoore to seye, but hastily	There is no more to say, but hastily
Som wonder by this clyket shal bityde,	Some wonder by this latchkey shall betide,
Which ye shul heeren, if ye wole abyde.	Which you shall hear, if you will abide.
O noble Ovyde, ful sooth seystou, God woot,	O noble Ovid, full truth sayest thou, God knows,
What sleighte is it, thogh it be long and hoot,	What trick is it, though (finding) it be long and painful,
That Love nyl fynde it out in som manere?	That Love will not find it out in some manner?
By Piramus and Tesbee may men leere;	By Pyramus and Thisbe can one learn;
Thogh they were kept ful longe streite overal,	Though they were kept full long strictly in every way,
They been accorded, rownynge thurgh a wal,	They are agreed, whispering through a wall,
Ther no wight koude han founde out swich a sleighte.	Where no one could have found such a trick.
But now to purpos: er that dayes eighte	But now to purpose: before eight days
Were passed [of] the month of [Juyn], bifil	Were passed [of] the month of [June], it happened
That Januarie hath caught so greet a wil,	That January has caught so great a desire,
Thurgh eggyng of his wyf, hym for to pleye	Through incitement of his wife, to enjoy himself
In his gardyn, and no wight but they tweye,	In his garden, and no one (there) but those two,
That in a morwe unto his May seith he:	That in a morning unto his May says he:
"Rys up, my wyf, my love, my lady free!	"Rise up, my wife, my love, my noble lady!
The turtles voys is herd, my dowve sweete;	The turtle dove's voice is heard, my dove sweet;
The wynter is goon with alle his reynes weete.	The winter is gone with all his rains wet.
Com forth now, with thyne eyen columbyn!	Come forth now, with thy dove-like eyes!
How fairer been thy brestes than is wyn!	How fairer are thy breasts than is wine!
The gardyn is enclosed al aboute;	The garden is enclosed all about;
Com forth, my white spouse! Out of doute	Come forth, my white spouse! Beyond doubt

No spot of thee ne knew I al my lyf.	No blemish on thee knew I all my life.
Com forth, and lat us taken oure disport;	Come forth, and let us take our pleasure;
I chees thee for my wyf and my confort."	I chose thee for my wife and my comfort."
Swiche olde lewed wordes used he.	Such old ignorant words used he.
On Damyan a signe made she,	To Damian a sign made she,
That he sholde go biforn with his cliket.	That he should go before with his latchkey.
This Damyan thanne hath opened the wyket,	This Damian then has opened the gate,
And in he stirte, and that in swich manere	And in he hurried, and that in such a way
That no wight myghte it se neither yheere,	That no one could either see or hear it,
And stille he sit under a bussh anon.	And quickly he sits still under a bush.
This Januarie, as blynd as is a stoon,	This January, as blind as is a stone,
With Mayus in his hand, and no wight mo,	With May in his hand, and no one else,
Into his fresshe gardyn is ago,	Into his fresh garden has gone,
And clapte to the wyket sodeynly.	And closed the gate quickly.
"Now wyf," quod he, "heere nys but thou and I,	"Now wife," said he, "here is no one but thou and I,
That art the creature that I best love.	That art the creature that I best love.
For by that Lord that sit in hevene above,	For by that Lord that sits in heaven above,
Levere ich hadde to dyen on a knyf	I had rather die on a knife
Than thee offende, trewe deere wyf!	Than thee offend, true dear wife!
For Goddes sake, thenk how I thee chees,	For God's sake, think how I thee chose,
Noght for no coveitise, doutelees,	Not for any greed, doubtless,
But oonly for the love I had to thee.	But only for the love I had to thee.
And though that I be oold and may nat see,	And although I be old and can not see,

Thre thynges, certes, shal ye wynne therby:	Three things, certainly, shall you win thereby:
First, love of Crist, and to youreself honour,	First, love of Christ, and to yourself honor,

This shal be doon to-morwe er sonne reste,	This shall be done to-morrow before sun goes to rest,

Ye been so depe enprented in my thoght	You are so deeply imprinted in my thought

Forbere to been out of youre compaignye	Bear to be out of your company
For verray love; this is withouten doute.	For true love; this is without doubt.
Now kys me, wyf, and lat us rome aboute."	Now kiss me, wife, and let us roam about."
This fresshe May, whan she thise wordes herde,	This fresh May, when she these words heard,
Benyngnely to Januarie answerde,	Graciously to January answered,
But first and forward she bigan to wepe.	But first of all she began to weep.
"I have," quod she, "a soule for to kepe	"I have," said she, "a soul to keep

And of my wyfhod thilke tendre flour,	And of my wifehood that same tender flower,
Which that I have assured in youre hond,	Which I have entrusted in your hand,
Whan that the preest to yow my body bond;	When the priest to you my body bound;
Wherfore I wole answere in this manere,	Wherefore I will answer in this manner,

I prey to God that nevere dawe the day	I pray to God that never dawn the day

If evere I do unto my kyn that shame,	If ever I do unto my kin that shame,
Or elles I empeyre so my name,	Or else I damage so my name,
That I be fals; and if I do that lak,	That I be false; and if I commit that offense,

But speke to us of untrust and repreeve."	Except to speak to us of distrust and reproof."

Phebus hath of gold his stremes doun ysent	Phoebus has his streams of gold down sent

He was that tyme in Geminis, as I gesse,	He was that time in Gemini, as I guess,
But litel fro his declynacion	But little from his declination
Of Cancer, Jovis exaltacion.	Of Cancer, Jove's exaltation.
And so bifel, that brighte morwe-tyde	And it so befell, that bright morning-tide

And many a lady in his compaignye,	And many a lady in his company,

Th' experience so preveth every day	The experience so proves every day

O Salomon, wys, and richest of richesse,	O Solomon, wise, and richest of wealth,

Ful worthy been thy wordes to memorie	Full worthy are thy words to (keep in) memory

Bothe in repreve of hire and othere mo."	In reproof of both her and many others."
"Ye shal?" quod Proserpyne, "wol ye so?	"You shall?" said Proserpine, "will you so?
Now by my moodres sires soule I swere	Now by my mother's father's soul I swear
That I shal yeven hire suffisant answere,	That I shall give her sufficient answer,
And alle wommen after, for hir sake,	And all women afterwards, for her sake,
That, though they be in any gilt ytake,	That, though they be in any guilt taken,
With face boold they shulle hemself excuse,	With bold face they shall themselves excuse,
And bere hem doun that wolden hem accuse.	And bear them down who would them accuse.
For lak of answere noon of hem shal dyen.	For lack of answer none of them shall die.
Al hadde man seyn a thyng with bothe his yen,	Although a man had seen a thing with both his eyes,
Yit shul we wommen visage it hardily,	Yet shall we women face it out boldly,
And wepe, and swere, and chyde subtilly,	And weep, and swear, and chide deceitfully,
So that ye men shul been as lewed as gees.	So that you men shall be as ignorant as geese.
"What rekketh me of youre auctoritees?	"What do I care for your authorities?
I woot wel that this Jew, this Salomon,	I know well that this Jew, this Solomon,
Foond of us wommen fooles many oon.	Found of us women many a fool.
But though that he ne foond no good womman,	But though he found no good woman,
Yet hath ther founde many another man	Yet many another man has there found
Wommen ful trewe, ful goode, and vertuous.	Women full true, full good, and virtuous.
Witnesse on hem that dwelle in Cristes hous;	Witness on them that dwell in Christ's house (heaven);
With martirdom they preved hire constance.	With martyrdom they proved their constancy.
The Romayn geestes eek make remembrance	The Roman histories also remind us
Of many a verray, trewe wyf also.	Of many a genuine, true wife also.
But, sire, ne be nat wrooth, al be it so,	But, sir, be not angry, even though it be so,
Though that he seyde he foond no good womman,	Though he said he found no good woman,
I prey yow take the sentence of the man;	I pray you take the meaning of the man;
He mente thus, that in sovereyn bontee	He meant thus, that in perfect goodness
Nis noon but God, but neither he ne she.	There is no one but God, neither man nor woman.
"Ey! for verray God that nys but oon,	"Ah! by him who is the only true God,
What make ye so muche of Salomon?	Why make you so much of Solomon?
What though he made a temple, Goddes hous?	Why though he made a temple, God's house?
What though he were riche and glorious?	Why though he was rich and glorious?
So made he eek a temple of false goddis.	So made he also a temple of false gods.
How myghte he do a thyng that moore forbode is?	How might he do a thing that more forbidden is?
Pardee, as faire as ye his name emplastre,	By God, however approvingly you gloss over his name,
He was a lecchour and an ydolastre,	He was a lecher and an idolater,
And in his elde he verray God forsook;	And in his old age he true God forsook;
And if God ne hadde, as seith the book,	And if God had not, as says the book,
Yspared him for his fadres sake, he sholde	Spared him for his father's sake, he should
Have lost his regne rather than he wolde.	Have lost his reign sooner than he would have wanted.
I sette right noght, of al the vileynye	I reckon all the villainy
That ye of wommen write, a boterflye!	That you of women write not worth a butterfly!
I am a womman, nedes moot I speke,	I am a woman, I must necessarily speak,
Or elles swelle til myn herte breke.	Or else swell until my heart breaks.
For sithen he seyde that we been jangleresses,	For since he said that we are chatterers,
As evere hool I moote brouke my tresses,	As ever whole I may enjoy my hair (remain alive),
I shal nat spare, for no curteisye,	I shall not cease, for any courtesy,
To speke hym harm that wolde us vileynye."	To speak harm of him that would do us dishonor."
"Dame," quod this Pluto, "be no lenger wrooth;	"My Lady," said this Pluto, "be no longer angry;
I yeve it up! But sith I swoor myn ooth	I give it up! But since I swore my oath
That I wolde graunten hym his sighte ageyn,	That I would grant him his sight again,
My word shal stonde, I warne yow certeyn.	My word shall stand, I warn you certainly.
I am a kyng; it sit me noght to lye."	I am a king; it is not proper for me to lie."
"And I," quod she, "a queene of Fayerye!	"And I," said she, "a queen of Fairy!
Hir answere shal she have, I undertake.	Her answer shall she have, I declare.
Lat us namoore wordes heerof make;	Let us have no more words concerning this;
For sothe, I wol no lenger yow contrarie."	For truly, I will no longer contradict you."
Now lat us turne agayn to Januarie,	Now let us turn again to January,
That in the gardyn with his faire May	That in the garden with his fair May
Syngeth ful murier than the papejay,	Sings full merrier than the parrot,
"Yow love I best, and shal, and oother noon."	"You love I best, and shall, and none other."
So longe aboute the aleyes is he goon,	So long about the garden paths is he gone,
Til he was come agaynes thilke pyrie	Until he was come in front of that same pear tree
Where as this Damyan sitteth ful myrie	Where this Damian sits full merry
An heigh among the fresshe leves grene.	On high among the fresh leaves green.
This fresshe May, that is so bright and sheene,	This fresh May, who is so bright and sheen,
Gan for to syke, and seyde, "Allas, my syde!	Began to sigh, and said, "Alas, my side!
Now sire," quod she, "for aught that may bityde,	Now sire," said she, "for whatever may happen,
I moste han of the peres that I see,	I must have some of the pears that I see,
Or I moot dye, so soore longeth me	Or I must die, so sore I long
To eten of the smale peres grene.	To eat some of the small green pears.
Help, for hir love that is of hevene queene!	Help, for her love that is of heaven queen!
I telle yow wel, a womman in my plit	I tell you well, a woman in my condition
May han to fruyt so greet an appetit	May have for fruit so great an appetite
That she may dyen but she of it have."	That she may die but she have some of it."
"Allas," quod he, "that I ne had heer a knave	"Alas," said he, "that I do not have here a servant boy
That koude clymbe! Allas, allas," quod he,	That could climb! Alas, alas," said he,
"For I am blynd!" "Ye, sire, no fors," quod she;	"For I am blind!" "Yea, sir, no matter," said she;
"But wolde ye vouche sauf, for Goddes sake,	"But would you grant, for God's sake,
The pyrie inwith youre armes for to take,	The pear tree within your arms to take,
For wel I woot that ye mystruste me,	For well I know that you mistrust me,
Thanne sholde I clymbe wel ynogh," quod she,	Then should I climb well enough," said she,
"So I my foot myghte sette upon youre bak."	"If I my foot might set upon your back."
"Certes," quod he, "theron shal be no lak,	"Certainly," said he, "there shall be no lack,
Mighte I yow helpen with myn herte blood."	(Even if) I might you help with my heart's blood."
He stoupeth doun, and on his bak she stood,	He stoops down, and on his back she stood,
And caughte hire by a twiste, and up she gooth --	And caught her by a branch, and up she goes --
Ladyes, I prey yow that ye be nat wrooth;	Ladies, I pray you that you be not angry;
I kan nat glose, I am a rude man --	I can not use circumlocutions, I am an unlearned man --
And sodeynly anon this Damyan	And suddenly at once this Damian
Gan pullen up the smok, and in he throng.	Pulled up the smock, and in he thrust.
And whan that Pluto saugh this grete wrong,	And when Pluto saw this great wrong,
To Januarie he gaf agayn his sighte,	To January he gave again his sight,
And made hym se as wel as evere he myghte.	And made him see as well as he ever could.
And whan that he hadde caught his sighte agayn,	And when he had recovered his sight again,
Ne was ther nevere man of thyng so fayn,	There was never man of anything so happy,
But on his wyf his thoght was everemo.	But on his wife his thought was evermore.
Up to the tree he caste his eyen two,	Up to the tree he cast his eyes two,
And saugh that Damyan his wyf had dressed	And saw that Damian had treated his wife
In swich manere it may nat been expressed,	In such a manner it can not be expressed,
But if I wolde speke uncurteisly;	Unless I would speak crudely;
And up he yaf a roryng and a cry,	And up he gave a roaring and a cry,
As dooth the mooder whan the child shal dye:	As does the mother when the child shall die:
"Out! Help! Allas! Harrow!" he gan to crye,	"Out! Help! Alas! Help!" he began to cry,
"O stronge lady stoore, what dostow?"	"O brazen crude lady, what dost thou?"
And she answerde, "Sire, what eyleth yow?	And she answered, "Sir, what ails you?
Have pacience and resoun in youre mynde.	Have patience and reason in your mind.
I have yow holpe on bothe youre eyen blynde.	I have helped you with both your eyes blind.
Up peril of my soule, I shal nat lyen,	Upon peril of my soul, I shall not lie,
As me was taught, to heele with youre eyen,	As I was taught, to heal with your eyes,
Was no thyng bet, to make yow to see,	Was no thing better, to make you to see,
Than strugle with a man upon a tree.	Than to struggle with a man upon a tree.
God woot, I dide it in ful good entente."	God knows, I did it in full good intent."
"Strugle?" quod he, "Ye, algate in it wente!	"Struggle?" said he, "Yea, indeed in it went!
God yeve yow bothe on shames deth to dyen!	God give you both a shameful death to die!
He swyved thee; I saugh it with myne yen,	He screwed thee; I saw it with my eyes,
And elles be I hanged by the hals!"	And else may I be hanged by the neck!"
"Thanne is," quod she, "my medicyne fals;	"Then is," said she, "my medicine false;
For certeinly, if that ye myghte se,	For certainly, if you could see,
Ye wolde nat seyn thise wordes unto me.	You would not say these words unto me.
Ye han som glymsyng, and no parfit sighte."	You have some glimpse, and no perfect sight."
"I se," quod he, "as wel as evere I myghte,	"I see," said he, "as well as ever I could,
Thonked be God! With bothe myne eyen two,	Thanked be God! With both my eyes two,
And by my trouthe, me thoughte he dide thee so."	And by my troth, it seemed to me he did thee so."
"Ye maze, maze, goode sire," quod she;	"You are dazed, dazed, good sir," said she;
"This thank have I for I have maad yow see.	"This thanks have I because I have made you see.
Allas," quod she, "that evere I was so kynde!"	Alas," said she, "that ever I was so kind!"
"Now, dame," quod he, "lat al passe out of mynde.	"Now, lady," said he, "let all pass out of mind.
Com doun, my lief, and if I have myssayd,	Come down, my dear, and if I have misspoken,
God helpe me so, as I am yvele apayd.	So God help me, I am very sorry.
But, by my fader soule, I wende han seyn	But, by my father's soul, I thought to have seen
How that this Damyan hadde by thee leyn,	How this Damian had by thee laid,
And that thy smok hadde leyn upon his brest."	And thy smock had lain upon his breast."
"Ye, sire," quod she, "ye may wene as yow lest.	"Yea, sir," said she, "you may think as you please.
But, sire, a man that waketh out of his sleep,	But, sir, a man that wakes out of his sleep,
He may nat sodeynly wel taken keep	He can not suddenly well take heed
Upon a thyng, ne seen it parfitly,	Of a thing, nor see it perfectly,
Til that he be adawed verraily.	Until he be fully awakened.
Right so a man that longe hath blynd ybe,	Right so a man that long has blind been,
Ne may nat sodeynly so wel yse,	Can not suddenly so well see,
First whan his sighte is newe come ageyn,	First when his sight is newly come again,
As he that hath a day or two yseyn.	As he that has a day or two been able to see.
Til that youre sighte ysatled be a while	Until your sight be settled a while
Ther may ful many a sighte yow bigile.	There may full many a sight deceive you.
Beth war, I prey yow, for by hevene kyng,	Beware, I pray you, for by heaven's king,
Ful many a man weneth to seen a thyng,	Full many a man supposes to see a thing,
And it is al another than it semeth.	And it is entirely different than it seems.
He that mysconceyveth, he mysdemeth."	He that misunderstands, he misjudges."
And with that word she leep doun fro the tree.	And with that word she leaped down from the tree.
This Januarie, who is glad but he?	This January, who is glad but he?
He kisseth hire and clippeth hire ful ofte,	He kisses her and embraces her full often,
And on hire wombe he stroketh hire ful softe,	And on her womb he strokes her full softly,
And to his palays hoom he hath hire lad.	And to his palace he has her led home.
Now, goode men, I pray yow to be glad.	Now, good men, I pray you to be glad.
Thus endeth heere my tale of Januarie;	Thus ends here my tale of January;
God blesse us, and his mooder Seinte Marie!	God bless us, and his mother Saint Mary!
"Ey! Goddes mercy!" seyde oure Hooste tho,	"Ah! God's mercy!" said our Host then,
"Now swich a wyf I pray God kepe me fro!	"Now such a wife I pray God keep me from!
Lo, whiche sleightes and subtilitees	Lo, what tricks and craftiness
In wommen been! For ay as bisy as bees	Are in women! For always as busy as bees
Been they, us sely men for to deceyve,	Are they, us innocent men to deceive,
And from the soothe evere wol they weyve;	And from the truth ever will they deviate;
By this Marchauntes tale it preveth weel.	By this Merchant's tale it is well proven.
But doutelees, as trewe as any steel	But doubtless, as true as any steel
I have a wyf, though that she povre be,	I have a wife, though that she poor be,
But of hir tonge, a labbyng shrewe is she,	But of her tongue, a blabbing shrew is she,
And yet she hath an heep of vices mo;	And yet she has a heap of other vices;
Therof no fors! Lat alle swiche thynges go.	Thereof no matter! Let all such things go by.
But wyte ye what? In conseil be it seyd,	But know you what? In secret be it said,
Me reweth soore I am unto hire teyd.	I sorely rue that I am unto her tied.
For and I sholde rekenen every vice	For if I should reckon every vice
Which that she hath, ywis I were to nyce.	Which she has, indeed I would be too foolish.
And cause why? It sholde reported be	And the cause why? It should reported be
And toold to hire of somme of this meynee --	And told to her by some of this company --
Of whom, it nedeth nat for to declare,	By whom, it needs not to declare,
Syn wommen konnen outen swich chaffare;	Since women know how to display such wares;
And eek my wit suffiseth nat therto	And also my wit suffices not concerning this
To tellen al; wherfore my tale is do."	To tell all; therefore my tale is done."
